meaning: The tweet exaggerates the possibility that Republicans could reverse vaccine mandates and advocates for the reversal of vaccine mandates.

The tweet is linking to a video claiming that people, specifically aboriginal people, are being pinned down and vaccinated against their will in Australia by the military. Trying to create alarm about vaccine mandates.

The tweet is promoting the fact that anti-vaxxers will get sick from not getting vaccinated. The tweet is in support of this, and specifies that there will be more vaccines for the thinking population.

The tweet is linking to a inaccurate study that claims vaccinated people are 27 times more likely to get COVID and have a higher chance of complications and claims that those with natural immunity have a stronger defense.
The tweet is replying to a tweet of a study about Sweet Syndrome, a vaccine complication. The tweet is implying that vaccine injury is common and many vaccinated people regret getting the vaccine.

The tweet is highlighting the importance of a London, England protest against COVID restrictions and vaccine mandates. It is calling out the press for misrepresenting the population of people as anti-vaccine. It tries to clarify the difference between 'anti-vax' and 'anti-mandate' and anti kids getting the vaccine, pointing to potential harm against children if they were to be vaccinated.

This tweeter seems to criticize conservative media by saying that their tweet is not a conspiracy. The tweet shares an article from The Guardian, highlighting that almost all of the COVID-19 patients  currently in the ICU are unvaccinated.
This tweet is saying that governments and big pharma are working together and that by creating vaccine mandates they are both benefitting, which is not true.

This tweet is replying to Chris Rock's tweet urging people to get vaccinated. The tweeter seems to be calling out some kind of stereotype or generalization that all anti-vax individuals are republican. The tweeter is wondering why Chris Rock would feel the need to encourage his Twitter followers to get vaccinated if all his fans are liberals, which feels untrue, and only republicans are anti-vax which they seem to be saying sarcastically but is also untrue.

The tweeter is asking for a Congressional investigation into all of the, 'bad actors', which seems to be referring to politicians, responsible for politicizing the pandemic. The tweeter wants these politicians who discredited the CDC, spread disinformation and went against mask mandates to be held accountable for their part in COVID deaths in America.

The tweeter is saying that because all children have access to the vaccine they shouldn't have to wear masks in schools, particularly cafeterias. They are urging their Twitter followers to contact the board of health to make sure this happens.

This tweeter is expressing their anger towards republican politicians and conservative media, as well as himself for not being able to convince his wife to get vaccinated. The tweeter urges the following of public health guidelines such as getting vaccinated, wearing a mask, washing hands, and staying home.
This tweet is difficult to decipher but the tweeter seems to be saying the vaccines are "emergency use" and therefore insinuating they were authorized without proper testing which is inaccurate.

This tweet is responding to a TMZ tweet saying that  Chis Brown referred to Kyrie Irving as a hero for not getting vaccinated. The tweeter is calling out Chris Brown's hypocrisy and pointing to rumours that Chris Brown had previously done crack, unconfirmed, saying how illogical it is for Brown to be okay with crack but not okay with the vaccine.

The tweeter is replying to a post showing statistics from South Australia on COVID-19 hospitalizations and deaths. The tweet says that this data is inaccurate, as most cases are double vaccinated, and one person who died from COVID-19 was double vaccinated. The tweeter is saying that unvaccinated people should therefore not feel nervous about getting COVID-19.

The tweet suggests that vaccines are ineffective, as the ICU capacity in Larimer County, Colorado is at 100%, and 75% of the population in that county are vaccinated. The tweeter suggests that since most of the population is vaccinated, and COVID-19 hospitalizations are still quite high, vaccines do not work.

This tweet is in response to a thread, where the tweeter is arguing with people who are opposed to vaccine mandates, and skeptical of vaccines themselves, and public health policy. The tweeter replies that the vaccine is important to improve the economy and people's way of life, and supports public health officials pushing the vaccine.
The tweet is criticizing a linked article that says the Kansas Governor will sign a bill that will allow businesses to have broad vaccine exemptions for workers.

The tweeter explains that she has been careful during the pandemic, by wearing a mask, getting triple vaccinated and isolating when needed. She indicated that she did take some risks, by sometimes eating indoors. She is glad that she got the vaccine, as she contracted COVID-19, and being triple vaccinated lessened her symptoms.
The tweet is asking that anti-vaxx people stop speaking on behalf of vaccinated people and allow vaccinated people to speak for themselves.
The tweet is from a public health official is sharing a resource on how to decipher misinformation about COVID-19 and vaccines.

The tweet is criticizing the limited availability of monoclonal antibodies, as an alternative to vaccines, due to the actions of Biden and Fauci. At the same time, he is criticizing the abundance of vaccines. The tweeter has leukaemia and COVID-19, and is hoping to receive monoclonal antibodies as treatment.

The tweeter is saying that even after getting all three of his vaccines Colin Powell still died of COVID implying that either the vaccines are ineffective, unnecessary, not enough, or a combination of factors.

The tweet is informing readers that since enacting a vaccine mandate, zero vaccinated United Airlines employees were hospitalized. Prior to the mandate, one United employee was dying of COVID-19 each week.
The tweet is claiming that many people are being injured by the vaccine and are dying because of it. The tweeter is calling out the media for underreporting this exaggerated harm caused by vaccines.

This tweet is advocating for the effectiveness of vaccines stating that in Seattle there is a high vaccination rate leading to decreased COVD cases, hospitalizations, and deaths. It highlights another tweet urging people to get vaccinated and wear masks.
This tweet seems to imply that vaccines are not effective, as dozens of vaccinated athletes recently tested positive for COVID-19.
This tweet seems to imply that vaccines are not effective, as dozens of vaccinated athletes recently tested positive for COVID-19.
This tweet is saying that the tweeter is against vaccines, citing a study they have linked which shows the rates of vaccine side effects.

The context of this tweet is unclear but the tweeter is replying to Twitter user @WaitingForPerot, who uses their platform in part to call out anti-vax misinformation, saying he can only be pro vaccine for so long.

This tweet is linking to an article saying that a 13-year-old boy died a few days after receiving their COVID vaccination. All the tweeter said was 'poor boy' and it's unclear if this is just commenting on the sad situation of a boy dying or if they are using this article to perpetuate anti-vax rhetoric but there is not enough information to speculate.

This tweet is part of a thread promoting masks. This tweet is saying that masks are effective and vaccines are useless and the tweeter states this has been 'officially confirmed' which is untrue and their source is unclear.

This tweeter is saying the vaccines have failed and will continue to fail on an even larger scale, it is unclear exactly what that means. The tweet is saying that vaccines are unsafe for children and that enforcing yearly vaccination of children is a violation of freedom and that getting vaccinated every 6 months is not the solution to COVID.

This tweet is telling people how to fight against Omicron and is instructing people to get vaccinated and to get a booster. The tweeter is also telling their followers the vaccine needs 14 days to become fully effective and to still get vaccinated even if you have previously had COVID.

This tweet is pointing to a Forbes article where the headline was allegedly changed from saying that the vaccine changes your DNA to say that it doesn't. The tweeter is posting the original headline that a 'based anon' screenshotted meaning a 'woke' anonymous poster who can see through the so-called lies the government and mainstream media are perpetrating.

This tweet is quoting the Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs outlining the support that is required for individuals in Ethiopia who are currently in the Tigray War. The tweet says they need to vaccinate over 887 000 children for polio and 790 000 for measles as well as they need the gas to get these vaccines to them.
This tweet links a Deacon Herald article saying that in India the gap between the 2nd vaccine dose and the 3rd booster or precautionary shot would be 9-12 months.

This tweeter is identifying the confusion among anti-vaxxers that vaccination means the same as a cure when vaccines are an important measure to slow the spread and improve the severity of illness but are not a cure.

It seems this tweeter is trying to say that the group of people who are not getting vaccinated are a heterogeneous group and not all are 'anti-vax'. This tweet is directed at British member of parliament, Sajid Javid. The tweeter is advocating for 'pretesting' to try to limit negative reactions to the COVID vaccine as well as respecting individuals who are exempt from getting the vaccine. The tweeter goes on to say the same thing is happening in Austria but it is unclear what exactly they are referring to.
The tweet is agreeing with a linked opinion piece that criticizes vaccine mandates for collecting excess data on individuals. The tweet also says that the left should be opposed to vaccine mandates.
The tweeter is replying to a deleted tweet, stating that he has received three doses of the Moderna vaccine.
The tweet is criticizing basketball player Kyrie Irvings stance to not get vaccinated because he does not believe in vaccine mandates. The tweet hopes a politician can help change his mind.
The tweet is criticizing an Australian politician for pushing for vaccine mandates. The tweet also inaccurately claims that vaccine mandates cause less people to receive non-COVID vaccines.

The tweeter is replying to a tweet advocating for schools to remain open for the mental health of children and is connecting that to the restrictions on what unvaccinated individuals cannot do. They are saying that there is a double standard of people advocating for in-person learning for children for their well-being while simultaneously not allowing unvaccinated children to attend restaurants and movie theatres. The tweeter is saying these restrictions are causing damage to children and advocating restrictions for the unvaccinated be lifted.

In response to a thread about food shortages in Ontario, the tweeter seems to promote a conspiracy theory titled the Great Reset. The tweet suggests that these food shortages highlight a government conspiracy to 'reset' the planet, through the COVID-19 pandemic and other means.
criticism_other: Food shortages due to trucker protests, government

meaning: The tweet is quoting the CDC's definitions of natural immunity and vaccine induced immunity, implying that natural immunity is better than immunity through vaccines.
The tweeter is questioning the safety of vaccines, as he is skeptical that people who are getting the vaccine, are now contracting COVID-19 as well.

This tweet is referring to the idea that pharmaceutical manufacturers are not responsible for any vaccine-related deaths and includes a video claiming that 40% of the people who are dying from COVID are completely vaccinated. The tweeter is pointing to the idea that if officials truly believed vaccines were safe and effective then they would take accountability when things go wrong.

This tweet is criticizing the decision for schools in India to open in-person before people under 18 are able to be vaccinated. The tweet is concerned for children's health and suggests the decision to re-open schools be reviewed.
This tweet is replying to the Financial Times in a critical manner. The tweeter is accurately saying that 28% of South Africa is fully vaccinated.

This tweet is highlighting data that older, unvaccinated people are more at risk to die from COVID than other demographics and is encouraging people to get vaccinated and get their booster as they are effective.

The tweeter is highlighting Joe Rogan's decision not to perform in Vancouver, due to vaccine mandates, and is encouraging other performers to do the same. In the video attached, Joe Rogan explains that he does not wish to get vaccinated, due to his antibodies.

This tweeter is saying that all the doctors speaking out against vaccines are banned from speaking out because of Pfizer. It is part of a larger thread of this tweeter against another with this tweeter defending their stance against vaccines.

This tweet claims that higher vaccination rates are leading to higher rates of COVID cases and the tweeter is urging people to listen to "science" instead of "Big Pharma". This tweet is going against vaccine mandates citing a now-debunked article published in the European Journal of Epidemiology which said that vaccine rates were unrelated to COVID cases. The tweet goes on to inaccurately say that higher vaccination rates are associated with higher COVID-19 rates.
This tweet is celebrating the announcement saying that Biden's vaccine mandate would be reinstated and speculates what the Supreme Court will do to try to thwart the vaccine mandates.

This tweeter criticizes those who are vaccinated, by calling them Fauci worshippers. It also justifies the use of myocarditis after vaccination by presenting a chart on incidents of negative reactions to the vaccine, that appears to be falsified.

This tweet criticizes those who receive the vaccine, stating that they are obnoxious and have a holier-than-thou attitude. The tweeter also criticizes how this attitude creates societal division, as he says that vaccinated individuals blame unvaccinated individuals for spreading COVID-19.

This tweet is part of a thread which comments on the global disparity in vaccine accessibility, stating that the gap in vaccination between countries is growing. It praises the effectiveness of vaccines against Omicron in countries like Germany and the U.S.

This tweet criticizes the white liberal response to Black athletes who are unwilling to get vaccinated, or who have taken a public stance against vaccination. It says that this is an example of white liberals silencing Black people.

This tweet criticizes Boris Johnson's statement that getting vaccinated may help prevent winter holiday lockdowns. It suggests that alternative solutions to COVID-19, like early treatment, are effective while vaccination is not.

This tweeter responds to a tweet criticizing vaccine mandates in the military. The tweeter, who says he is a veteran, states that unvaccinated soldiers would likely perish from COVID-19 and would cost taxpayers money. He notes that all individuals in the military are vaccinated for other diseases, and that this practice was never previously questioned.

This tweet is part of a thread discussing vaccine mandates in Ontario legislature. The quote tweet attached is unavailable, but this tweet seems to argue that unvaccinated and vaccinated individuals should be able to interact, and that certain vaccine mandates should be dropped.

The tweet is replying to a series of tweets about the ineffectiveness of vaccines. The tweet is inaccurately saying that the risk of death for people under 40 always has been very low, vaccinated or not.

The tweeter is saying they live in a state which is inundated with anti-vax rhetoric constantly but when their wife tried to get a vaccine they were all unavailable pointing to the idea that all the people loudly speaking out against vaccines were in fact still getting them.

The tweeter is pointing to the parallels of waiting in line and showing identification to vote to getting a COVID vaccine and showing your proof of vaccination. They are advocating that if people will do these things for COVID reasons than they should also vote.

The tweeter is a doctor responding to the idea that asking for vaccination status would be an invasion of privacy but makes the connection to asking about domestic abuse and STI status which are not seen as an invasion of privacy and can directly improve treatment outcomes. They are advocating for more conversations about vaccines and change.
The tweet is announcing a panel of experts who will be discussing how the effectiveness of the COVID vaccine could be used to investigate better vaccines as well as pneumonia research.

The tweet is supporting a legal motion that granted an exemption to vaccine mandates to members of the military for religious reasons. They are making the point that the people defending freedom in a military sense need their freedom to choose whether or not to get vaccinated protected.
The tweet is commenting on the announcement that Lithuania will be donating over 200 000 vaccines to Taiwan. The tweeter is thanking Lithuanian health officials and the prime minister.

This tweet is encouraging individuals who are hesitant to get the vaccine to read an article from the Guardian about an incredibly healthy man who decided not to get the vaccine and ended up dying of COVID.
The tweet is criticising individuals who support the vaccine referring to them as 'vax nuts' and referring to the implementation of vaccine mandates and COVID restrictions as 'authoritarian'.

This tweet is replying to one announcing that vaccines can be made locally all around the world and the tweeter is thanking the individuals who are making this possible as well as wishing for the speedy delivery of vaccines to those who need them.

The tweeter is criticizing anti-vaxxers and calling into question their intelligence and saying that they are putting others in danger. The tweeter is calling them out for being afraid of the vaccine.

This tweet is a reply to one from someone who said their daughter had contracted COVID as they lived in a largely unvaccinated county. This tweeter is expressing how she hopes their daughter got the vaccine and how frustrating it is when people are refusing to get vaccinated.

This tweet is presenting a graph showing the effectiveness of vaccines and how the vaccines were particularly effective at preventing hospitalizations among elderly individuals. It is urging people, particularly the elderly, using this data to get a booster shot.

The tweeter is saying that liberals, specifically President Biden, will try to blame so-called vaccine failures on Trump since he endorsed the vaccine. The tweet links to an article trying to poke holes in vaccine research pointing to 'survivorship bias' and 'natural immunity' as the things that are actually responsible for the vaccine trials and not actual effectiveness.

This tweet is advocating for teachers not being allowed to ask the vaccination status of their students. They are saying this will lead to pressure from both other students and 'leftist' teachers to get vaccinated. They seem to suggest that teachers would encourage students to get vaccinated and then not tell the parents of the student who got vaccinated. They are claiming this currently happens with abortions, meaning schools will help students procure abortions without telling parents which the tweeter deems evil.

The tweet is saying that both mainstream and progressive media have been presenting support for the COVID vaccine and claims mainstream media are not giving enough attention to any negative aspects of the vaccine and point to the death of Lisa Shaw. Shaw died from vaccine complications and the tweeter is saying they are not giving enough attention to their death.

This tweet is calling out Australian individuals who are advocating for COVID restrictions to be lifted stating that vaccines need to be available in every country and that it must be a global response.
This tweet is linked to an AP article announcing that Germany is surpassing 100 000 deaths yet vaccine hesitancy remains.

This tweet is replying to a Fox news article documenting the first omicron case in Sacramento. The tweeter is calling Fox 'liars' because according to them it is impossible to test for specific variants. The tweeter then goes on to accuse Fox News of promoting 'poison', what they refer to vaccines as, on behalf of Pfizer saying that vaccines are causing deaths, specifically in children.

This tweet is responding to one looking for stats on the number of people who have died from the COVID vaccine and the tweeter said there were 3 'confirmed' deaths. It is unclear what the quotation marks are insinuating.

This tweet is calling out the democratic governor of Illinois for not going against vaccine mandates claiming he has money on the line which is why he is supporting vaccines and tests. The tweeter says the governor is corrupt and a disgrace.
This tweet is commenting on Biden's announcement to enforce vaccination among federal employees and the tweeter is saying they are in favour.
This tweet from CBS is announcing that the military will begin to discharge individuals who refuse to get vaccinated.

This tweeter is saying that despite their company not requiring their employees to get vaccinated the clients they work for are which will inevitably lead to people losing their jobs. The tweet includes the #unvaxxed.

This tweeter is pointing to the length of time it is taking American boxing promoter Oscar de la Hoya to recover from COVID as evidence that they don't work seeing as he was in peak physical condition and double vaccinated. The tweeter is instead promoting the alternative medicine Regeneron falsely stating that it was the reason that unvaccinated Joe Rogan was able to recover from COVID within 72 hours.

This tweet is calling out the corruption they have falsely identified in among politicians and pharmaceutical companies. The cycle they have created is that pharmaceutical companies donate to politicians who then appoint people from said pharmaceutical companies to the regulatory bodies that approve vaccines. The tweeter then claims that the pharmaceutical companies and politicians mandate vaccines and profit off them then restarting the cycle.

This tweeter is saying that the unvaccinated are not being forced into anything and do in fact have a choice they just need to live with the consequences of their choice and the restrictions that come with that choice.

This tweet is trying to disprove vaccine effectiveness by pointing to countries with low vaccine rates and inaccurately low COVID rates and countries with high vaccination rates which continue to have COVID cases as proof that the vaccine doesn't work which is also untrue. The tweeter is suggesting 'early treatment' as the solution but it is unclear exactly what that means.

This tweet is pointing out inconsistencies in what Tucker Carlson has said about his stance on vaccines. The tweet links to an article where the Fox news anchor claims he is not anti-vax and has never been spoken out against vaccines and the tweeter is calling out that lie.
The tweeter is bragging about having made it into a pub without any proof of vaccination or certification.
The tweet is saying that people who still believe that vaccines and masks don't are 'immune to facts'.
The tweeter is saying their employers' beliefs in the effectiveness of vaccines and the ability of vaccine mandates to help people is entirely false.
The tweet is describing an agreement between South Korea and Singapore to allow travellers to move freely between them without any quarantine requirements.
The tweet describes an antibody response in individuals with kidney cancer from the COVID-19 vaccines.

This tweet is in response to another saying we should be paying more attention to the well-being of caseworkers who were "sacked" for not getting the vaccine. The tweeter is correcting that tweet saying they actually resigned due to a refusal to get vaccinated and a lack of regard for the long term care residents.
This tweet is advertising pop-up vaccination clinics across Maniapoto.
This tweet is a tally of all positive COVID cases, COVID deaths, as well as the number of people who have received both the first and second vaccine doses in the UK.

The tweet is responding to one about Novak Djokovic that said it was his choice not to get vaccinated and that the hospitals are filling up with vaccinated individuals and everyone receiving the vaccine is getting sick. This tweeter is responding by making the point that things could be much worse without the vaccine and this is a 'short-sided' comment.
This tweet is of someone saying they trust the vaccine because there are more virus-related deaths than vaccine-related deaths
This tweet is a news outlet linking an article critical of a politicians restrictive public health measures because there have been more COVID-19 deaths than before they came into office.
This tweet is saying that vaccines are not safe because some vaccine compounds cause bladder cancer in rats, which is misinformation.
This tweet is posing a theoretical situation in which insurance companies would charge increased premiums to the unvaccinated.

This tweet is misleading by saying that fourth-dose booster shots are ineffective against the omicron variant. The article that is linked states that fourth-dose booster shots are partially effective which it true.
This tweet is satire of anti-vaxxers and the far right criticizing a politician for buying vaccines from other countries.
This tweet suggests that spike protein vaccines kill you, which is misinformation. It also suggests standing up for ones rights.

This tweet is of a video of Donald Trump saying he supports vaccines but also that people have a choice whether or not to get vaccinated. A journalist points out that more people have died of COVID-19 under Donald Trump than they have Joe Biden, which is misleading.
This tweet is criticizing a politician for removing disabled people from being prioritized to receive vaccines, saying that this was done because the politician did not order enough vaccine supply.
support_other: disabled people being prioritized to receive vaccines

meaning: This tweet is saying someone is in support of vaccines, but is against vaccine mandates.

This tweet could mean a variety of different things. If the tweeter is a fan of Mitt Romney then it is a pro-vaccine tweet referring to how much better Romney would've handled vaccine mandates than President Biden. If the tweeter is against Romney then they are saying this as a negative against Biden. This tweeter is a very complex individual with lots of conflicting imagery and messages so hard to tell but it seems to be pro-vaccine.
This tweet is saying that both unvaccinated and vaccinated individuals can get COVID and they both are equally affected and get as sick, which is misleading and inaccurate.
This tweeter is saying that one of their immunocompromised clients is refusing to get vaccinated because they heard somewhere the untrue statement that if you get vaccinated you will die in 3 years.

This tweet is speaking out against Rhode Island's decision to stop a doctor from practicing for refusing to get vaccinated. The tweeter is citing the doctor's previous infection to COVID, and therefore natural immunity, as evidence that they should be allowed to practice without being vaccinated.

This tweet links to an article announcing vaccine requirements will be banned in certain states. Though the tweeter does not explicitly say they are in favour of this and only post the date and a selection of emojis with the article, their previous tweets point to them being anti-vax, and therefore in favour of this.

The tweeter seems to be making some kind of connection that undocumented individuals don't need to get vaccinated and therefore they have decided to 'identify as an illegal alien' to avoid getting vaccinated.

This tweet is part of a thread on whether or not vaccines cause mutations. The previous tweet stated that because of the higher viral load on the unvaccinated they are more susceptible to virus mutation but this tweeter is disagreeing stating that the vaccinated are in fact the 'experiment' and therefore more susceptible to mutations.

This tweeter claims they personally know 4 people who have died from the vaccines, children who can no longer do sports because of the vaccine and someone who got a stroke from the vaccine. They also say they are vaccinated and still got COVID pointing to that as evidence that not only do they believe the vaccines are unsafe they believe they are ineffective.

The tweet is announcing white-nationalist political commentator Nick Fuentes would not be attending the anti-vaccine protest he organized because he was sick. The tweeter is pointing to the irony of that situation.

This tweet is part of a larger thread arguing with someone who is antivax. This tweet is explaining that the mortality rate would be considerably higher without the vaccine and that the vaccine is doing what it was designed to do.

This tweet is referring to Novak Djokovic being granted 'medical exemption' to getting the COVID vaccine and still being told by the Australian PM that he is not welcome in Australia. The tweeter is saying this is an injustice because he was issued a medical exemption and is in fact a 'diplomatic stoush'.

This tweet is replying to another tweet, asking how someone can believe that vaccination status won't matter with future variants. It is implying that vaccination will help with protection against future variants.
This tweet is saying that vaccines cause viruses to mutate faster and thus we should not be vaccinating so rapidly, which is misleading.
This tweet is criticizing the government for withholding money for politicians when they could have used the money to vaccinate the whole country.
This tweet is asking when a leftist politician that has been vaccinated will get sick, assuming that vaccines have harmful side-effects which is incorrect.

This is a partial tweet commenting on how COVID outbreaks in New Zealand are not the fault of the unvaccinated. It is unclear exactly the point they are trying to make in erroneously claiming that individuals with one shot are considered unvaccinated but they are saying that the NZ government is implementing scare tactics to try to convince individuals to get vaccinated.

This tweet is replying to a thread promoting natural immunity and condemning vaccine mandates. The tweeter is saying that getting the vaccine is more likely to be effective and help protect you from COVID than it is to be harmful and kill you.

This tweet is part of a thread condemning Biden for not providing free N95 masks and free testing. This tweet specifically is promoting vaccines, mask mandates, paid lockdowns, and free and accessible testing.
This tweet is saying that even though they are not required to, Broadway theatres will continue to require vaccines and masks in their theatres.

This tweet is quoting the governor of West Virginia, Jim Justine who was pointing out the hypocrisy of anti-vaxxers who claim the vaccine is tracking you while also carrying around a cell phone which is aware of your location and buying habits and is absolutely tracking you at all times.

The tweet lacks context as many of the previous tweets have been deleted but it seems as though they are calling out individuals who would hand over power back to Donald Trump if he was reelected. He is making a connection that the hypocrisy of believing Trump did a terrible job and also agreeing to hand the reigns back over if he was reelected to believing in science but removing mask mandates and vaccine requirements.
This tweet is an individual announcing they got their first vaccine. It is unclear if JGH has some meaning or is a typo. Could possibly be making reference to the Jewish General Hospital.

This tweet is linking to an article about statements made by the Minister of Roads and Highways, Kwasi Amoako-Atto. The article talks about how Africa should not be relying on other countries to gain access to vaccines when they have a wealth of scientists available to them.

This tweet is replying to one made by Senator Cory Booker after contracting COVID on how grateful they are to have gotten their vaccinations and booster because his symptoms would be considerably worse if he hadn't. The tweeter is asking for how he knows that and to state his sources that his COVID would in fact be worse with the vaccine.
This tweet seems to promote natural immunity against COVID-19, and encourages people not to vaccinate themselves or their children. The tweeter also mentions that people now avoid them in public.

The tweet criticizes the Republican party and GOP, encouraging people to vote against them. The tweet responds to a thread, which says that the GOP will limit or eliminate access to abortion, birth control and marriage equality.

This tweet is in response to a notice sent out to parents that their children would have the option to be vaccinated for both COVID and HPV. This tweeter is looking for more information on the "interaction between Pfizer and HPV vaccine". It can be assumed they are referring to some kind of conspiracy but unclear.

This tweet mocks a common anti-vaccine argument that vaccine side effects can be lethal. Using a clown emoji to express sarcasm, the tweeter jokingly says that thousands have died from vaccine side effects.

This tweet praises the success of a vaccination program, where first doses were administered the entire eligible population in Uttarakhand, India. It discusses Indian PM Narendra Modi's praise of this program as well, on his radio show Mann Ki Baat. This tweet seems misleading, as it is unlikely that the entire population of Uttarakhand is now vaccinated.
This tweet questions the effectiveness of vaccines, and says that the tweeter noticed both vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals contract COVID-19.

This tweet criticizes vaccine mandates for children. It argues that the chances of having an inverse reaction to the vaccine are higher than the chances of dying from COVID-19. And, the tweet states that individuals are more likely to die of the flu, heart disease, drowning, firearms and motor vehicles than from COVID-19.

This tweeter is expressing their skepticism towards vaccines citing vaccine ineffectiveness and the Event 201 conspiracy. They say that the vaccine was supposed to wipe out COVID completely and seeing as they haven't done that means that vaccine mandates are "excessive" and "exploitative". Event 201 was a simulated exercise put on by John Hopkins and Bill and Melinda Gates in 2019 to practice what to do in the event of a SARS outbreak but in no way predicted the COVID-19 epidemic nor are the two connected in anyway.

This tweet criticizes republican representative Ken Weyler for his report on COVID-19 vaccine conspiracy theories, including a theory that vaccines contain tentacled creatures. This tweet also criticizes Weyler's negative comments and conspiracy theories about the Catholic church. The tweeter says that Weyler needs mental health care.

This tweet is congratulating Biden on making the decision to require vaccines saying that other presidents wouldn't have made this call and alluding to Trump without naming him. The tweeter is saying these vaccine mandates will keep people safe and lead to a quicker end to the pandemic.

This tweet responds to a conversation discussing the efficacy of vaccines, given that one can still contract COVID-19 when vaccinated. The tweeter argues that those who receive the vaccine are foolish, as they received the vaccine with the knowledge that they may still contract COVID-19.

This tweeter shared an article, which highlighted that an anti-vaccine activist recently died from COVID-19, after doubting the legitimacy of the COVID-19 epidemic. The article includes two pictures, visible in the tweet, one of the activist in a healthy state, the other where he is sick and relying on a ventilator.

This tweet responds to a news article, which states that migrants who tested positive for COVID-19 entered the United States. This tweet criticizes the decision to admit these migrants, using this argument to oppose mandatory vaccination in the workplace.
The tweeter is curious about the long-term impact of the vaccine on children between the ages of 5 to 11.

The tweet replies to a Reuters article about strict COVID-19 measures at the Beijing Olympics. The tweeter seems skeptical about vaccination, telling readers to wait and see about the impacts of the vaccine.
The tweet states that protests against vaccine mandates will continue in France. The tweeter is seems to generally oppose vaccine mandates.
The tweet seems to joke about those who claim to have unusual side effects from the vaccine, sarcastically stating that the vaccine caused infidelity from the tweeter's cousin.

This tweet replies to a thread where an individual opposed vaccination, as vaccination may not protect one from catching COVID-19. This tweeter clarifies that while immunity from catching COVID-19 reduces after a period of time, the vaccine does protect individuals from serious illness and death.

This tweet is in response to a thread debating the statistical efficacy of vaccines. This tweeter argues that vaccines are indeed effective, which can be observed when examining infection rates, as well as statistics concerning those admitted to the hospital and ICU for COVID-19 infection.

This tweet seems to joke about the development of vaccines. The tweet includes a photo of a children's toy science kit. The tweeter sarcastically states that they will develop a vaccine using this toy, and will not require a booster.

This tweet expresses support for India's COVID-19 Vaccine Drive, a campaign to develop a COVID-19 vaccine and immunize Indian citizens. It states that this is the world's largest vaccine drive, and also the most successful.

This tweet encourages individuals to safeguard against COVID-19 infection during the winter holidays by wearing a mask, getting vaccinated and getting tested for the virus. The tweet particularly encourages individuals to get vaccinated, saying that it is not too late to do so.

This tweet opposes vaccines, and says that no one should get the COVID-19 vaccine. The tweeter justifies this by saying that their cousin is a researcher, who said that COVID-19 restrictions should have been lifted from the time the virus began.

This tweet criticizes those who oppose vaccination, and disinformation which encourages individuals not to get vaccinated. This tweet is in response to a news article, where a young girl passed away from COVID-19, and her mother was not vaccinated. The tweet also criticizes anti-vaccine logic.

This tweet seems to support the Melbourne protests against COVID-19 vaccine mandates. It highlights that individuals should be able to choose which vaccine they recieve, and criticizes the belief that those who wish to choose the type of vaccine they recieve are inherently opposed to all vaccines.

This tweet states that there is no FDA-approved COVID-19 vaccine in the United States, and therefore COVID-19 vaccines are unsafe. The tweeter seems to state that Pfizer is leveraging children to receive FDA authorization for the vaccine.
This tweet seems to criticize a delay to implement mandatory vaccination among workers until after the winter holidays.

The tweet replies to a thread, where an individual expresses fear and frustration with an inability to receive a booster shot due to time and resource restrictions. The tweeter suggests that the individual contact public health authorities, as home visits to administer vaccines are offered in some cities.
This tweet seems to criticize a popular anti-vaccine advocate, Chris Sky, for retweeting a post that spreads vaccine misinformation.

This tweet criticizes the slow global response for providing vaccines to vulnerable populations. The tweeter argues that providing these vaccines to vulnerable populations early in the pandemic would have stopped the spread of harmful COVID-19 variants.

This tweet criticizes the closure of a vaccination site in South Africa. Earlier, the City of Cape Town provided shuttle buses to increase vaccine accessibility. Now, this tweeter says that these buses will be going nowhere.

This tweet urges pregnant individuals to become immunized, as COVID-19 infections while pregnant can lead to hospitalizations and complications. The post encourages pregnant individuals to get vaccinated to protect themselves and their baby.
This tweet suggests that pharmaceutical companies bribe the government to promote vaccines.

This tweet argues that, given the tweeter's three COVID-19 doses, he is unlikely to require a ventilator for serious illness due to the virus. He argues that we should stop lockdowns and hiding away, and address other illnesses like cancer and heart disease.

The tweet shares a video of anti-vaccine protests, where the protestors express that their interest in defunding the media. They are presumably seeking coverage which aligns with their viewpoints opposing vaccine mandates. The tweeter seems to oppose mandatory vaccination in general.
This tweet claims that people are not dying in large numbers due to COVID-19, seemingly justifying the tweeter's choice to not get vaccinated.

This tweet explains that there is significant research to support the development COVID-19 vaccines, as coronavirus vaccine technology was researched and developed during the SARS epidemic. It seems to oppose a common argument that COVID-19 vaccines were developed too quickly, and are therefore unreliable.
The tweet states that mandatory vaccination, among other factors, may have led to the rebellion in Kazakhstan.

The tweeter shares a news story from a right-wing media outlet, which states that a foreign object was found in a Moderna vaccine sample. The tweet seems to imply that vaccines are dangerous, and that parasites or organisms could be found in vaccines.

The tweet is arguing the COVID vaccine is negatively impacting menstruators' cycles and that a journal article, attached to the tweet, did not do enough research in their determination that the vaccine only causes minor alterations to the menstrual cycle and accounted that to 'stress' which the tweeter did not find acceptable.
This tweet is thanking and praising a politician for supplying vaccines to vulnerable populations.
This tweet is a meme asking if someone would like to engage in sexual activity with the tweeter before or after they are vaccinated.
This tweet is repeating the headline of a linked article about a study that says the COVID-19 is interfering with peoples menstruation.
This tweet is criticizing public heath authorities for changing the definition of vaccines, which is misinformation.
This tweet is criticizing vaccine manufacturers for not supplying the Global South with vaccines free of charge after profiting off of supplying the Global North with vaccines.

This tweet is showing a study that says BIPOC people are more likely be affected by COVID-19, but have higher morality rates. This tweet is part of a thread trying to make a racist argument to another tweeter.
This tweet is linking to a video that talks about spike proteins and their relationship to long covid or vaccine related illness.
This tweet is explaining that the tweeter is experiencing side effects from the vaccine that are worse than when the tweeter had COVID-19
This tweet is criticizing politicians for creating vaccine mandates but not supplying people with free rapid testing.
This tweet is quoting a politician who has stepped down from his position that said people should have the choice to be vaccinated or not. An article is linked.

This tweet is saying that covid-19 has no effect on kids, which is incorrect. The tweet also says the risk of vaccine caused cardiomyopathy is greater than the protection the vaccine offers, which is incorrect.
This tweet is the headline of a linked article that talks about how a conservative media journalist was banned from twitter after incorrectly saying that vaccines contain satanic trackers.
This tweet is praising vaccines and scientists, but criticizing the accessibility of vaccines.

This tweet calls for an end to childhood vaccination, saying that countries like Norway have already ended the mandates. It calls for the PM of India, Donald Trump, the PM of the UK, and the PM of Pakistan to end childhood vaccination mandates.

This tweet discusses the hypocrisy of anti-vaccine arguments in the name of rights and freedoms. It states that those who oppose vaccine mandates because of restrictions on freedoms do not oppose the removal of rights and freedoms for activists, protestors, immigrants, and those without documentation.
This tweet celebrates Beaumont Hospital's successful vaccine rollout, and its vaccine accessibility.

This tweet responds to a post from an anti-vaccine protest, where a mother claims she is not vaccinating her children to protect their future. This tweeter argues that vaccinations are safe for children, as children receive routine vaccines like diptheria, polio and tetanus.
This tweet questions the effectiveness of indoor capacity restrictions, when vaccine mandates are in place.

This tweet criticizes South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster, due to his stance on vaccine mandates. This tweeter says that McMaster panders to anti-vaxxers, and that his opposition to vaccine mandates is the reason that federal vaccine mandates are needed.
This informative tweet states that some parents in Long Island, NJ oppose vaccine mandates for young children.
This tweet is criticizing health authorities and news media for platforming an anti-vax doctor that claims the diet he created can help reduce risk from COVID-19. His claims are misinformation.

This tweet is implying that anti-vax beliefs that Bill Gates is trying to depopulate the globe through vaccination are ridiculous. The tweet features a video of a journalist interviewing an antivaxxer about Bill Gates agenda.
This tweet is saying that two good things have happened. One is that children ages 5-11 are now able to be vaccinated. Two is that Donald Trump has been banned from Twitter.

This tweet is criticizing anti-vaxers for focusing on one vaccinated person who died from covid-19 while there are many more unvaccinated people who have died from covid-19. The tweet says for every one vaccinated covid-19 death there are 1000 unvaccinated covid-19 deaths, which is incorrect.
This tweet is saying that a politician has done all they can to slow the spread of covid-19 with vaccines, mandates and testing. The tweet is implying that anti-vaxxers minds cannot be changed.
This tweet is criticizing claims that the omicron wave is milder and not of concern, which is misinformation. This tweet talks about case counts in the Netherlands.
This tweet is saying that the tweeter is doing a rapid test before attending a social gathering and hoping that their vaccine booster helps protect them from covid-19.
This tweet is saying that someone immunocompromised who had recovered from cancer twice was killed not by cancer, but by covid-19. This tweet wonders if an anti-vaxxer gave them the virus.
This tweet is saying a company is no longer going ahead with a vaccine mandate for employees after the government announced they will stop requiring workplaces to have them.

The tweeter is looking for more information on the effectiveness of the vaccine and citing the alleged differing results on how effective the vaccine is at liming hospitalizations. The tweeter accounts these so-called inconsistent results to the government citing they have an 'agenda'.

This tweet is citing the increased deaths in 2021 compared to 2020 as proof that the vaccines are not effective and promote bringing monetary support into communities and 'laws against the virus' but it's unclear exactly what that means.

This tweet is saying that the mandate for employers to enforce vaccination on their employees when they have more than 100 employees. The tweet is saying this is an abuse of power and is spreading a petition to go against Biden's vaccine mandate.
This tweet is referring to alleged animal abuse in the search for an HIV vaccine and is urging Dr. Fauci to stop using monkeys in the search for a vaccine.

The tweet is talking about how public opinion on COVID regulations and vaccine mandates have changed in France and insinuating that the same thing could occur in England as France's vaccine resistance was even worse than in England.
This tweeter is trying to get their child, with needle-phobia, vaccinated and is reaching out to their Twitter followers for advice on how to do that.

This is a tweet from the Premier of Yukon, seemingly encouraging his constituents to get vaccinated. He quotes an immunology expert, and says that vaccination will still prevent individuals diagnosed with COVID-19 from needing hospitalization. The tweet links an article from the financial post, which discusses COVID-19 vaccines' effectiveness against the Omicron variant.

This tweet intends to promote a podcast, where the host and two scientists discuss the effectiveness of a third COVID-19 vaccine dose. This tweet argues that a third dose of the vaccine provides additional protection against the virus, and that a three-dose vaccine schedule may become standardized.
This tweet shares an article from The Hill, which states that actor Matthew McConaughey refuses to vaccinate his children, and opposes vaccine mandates for minors.

This tweeter states that COVID-19 vaccines are unsafe, as more individuals have died from the COVID-19 vaccine than any other vaccine in the past 30 years. The tweet links to an inaccurate chart illustrating death rates for each vaccine type.

This tweet questions vaccine effectiveness, asking why officials did not know that vaccinated individuals could still spread COVID-19. This in response to a tweet from Republican Thomas Massie, who argues that vaccine mandates should not be in place, as vaccines and the booster shot are not effective at reducing the spread of COVID-19.

This tweeter seems to oppose vaccine mandates. This tweet mocks the common argument from public health officials that vaccines are safe and effective at preventing death from COVID-19, and ultimately implies that COVID-19 vaccines are unsafe. The link in this tweet is no longer available or active.

This tweet seems to inform business owners as to their rights and responsibilities with respect to vaccine mandates. It informs business owners that they may post a form from the DC government about vaccine entry requirements in their establishment.
This tweeter says that they would admit if they were wrong about COVID-19 vaccines and mask wearing. It argues that those against vaccines and Brexit would likely not admit if they were wrong.

This tweet replies to a story by Global News BC, criticizes vaccine mandates, and argues that both vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals may contract COVID-19. It says that the vaccine is ineffective at stopping the spread of COVID-19.
This tweet argues that quarantine mandates regardless of vaccine status or test results is harming the economy. It blames Scottish MP Humza Yousaf for this policy.

This tweet criticizes the governments of Scotland and Wales for mandating vaccines. It encourages the UK government not to mandate vaccines, as it claims they are ineffective at stopping the spread of COVID-19.
This tweet is linked to an article talking about what could happen if children continue to get COVID without a vaccine and how the long COVID symptoms could impact children.

This tweet, once you look into the reactions to the article linked, is supporting a Tesco ad being taken down because it included a Santa with a vaccine passport. The tweeter's message is that many people have complained and the pro-vaccine message shouldn't be forced upon people.

This tweet is in response to a thread, where two individuals argue about the effectiveness of the COVID-19 vaccine. This tweet argues that natural immunity is more effective at preventing serious illness than vaccination, and expresses concern that the vaccine is not fully approved. The tweet equates contracting COVID-19 to a common cold.

This tweeter states that they refuse to work for an employer or dine in a restaurant that requires mandatory COVID-19 vaccination, implying that the tweeter is not vaccinated and does not intend to receive the vaccine.

This tweet seems to question the safety of vaccines overall. It states that public health officials and the government are using the drug Ivermectin to treat vaccinated individuals, in order to promote the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines. The tweeter also states that unvaccinated individuals must rely on ventilators.
This tweet argues that Americans living overseas do not have adequate access to vaccines. The tweet is in response to another tweet, calling for a global response for vaccine accessibility.
criticism_other: Unavailability of vaccines to American expatriates and Americans living overseas

meaning: This tweet states that while vaccines do not prevent individuals from contracting COVID-19, they do improve the immune system, and can prevent serious illness or death.
This tweet argues that COVID-19 vaccines are ineffective, as hospitalizations for unvaccinated individuals in Colorado is decreasing, while hospitalizations for vaccinated individuals is increasing.

This tweeter states that both the COVID-19 virus and vaccines were manufactured to reduce the population. It mocks those who received the vaccine or plan to receive the vaccine, by calling them sheep.

This tweet expresses frustration with the current vaccine mandates, drawing on an example of a Colorado patient who was refused an organ transplant because they were not vaccinated. The tweeter criticizes Democrats, saying that this is a way to undermine the humanity of those who disagree with Liberal policies, and to gain control and power.
This tweeter seems to be encouraging their government to follow Canada's lead by implementing a health tax on unvaccinated individuals, and by providing a tax credit to those who are vaccinated.

This tweet criticizes a limited access to the HPV vaccine for women who were denied the vaccine during their childhood. It states that women are now charged over 600 euros for this vaccine, and uses the example of Vicky Phelan to argue that the HPV vaccine should be more accessible.

This tweet criticizes unvaccinated individuals who are hospitalized due to COVID-19. It argues that these individuals plead for help when they are sick, and if they recover, they often return to anti-vaccine narratives.
This tweeter seems to oppose all childhood vaccinations, including measles, mumps and polio. The tweet is in response to another tweet, which announces the suspension of Biden's vaccine mandate.
This tweet informs individuals about a vaccine information campaign, geared towards individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

This tweeter informs about his latest study on COVID-19 vaccine effectiveness. He explains that two doses of the vaccine provide short-term protection against mild COVID-19. Two doses of the vaccine also provide longer-term protection from hospitalization and death, due to severe COVID-19.

This tweet argues that health officials of varying ranks have different access to information. It argues that senior nurses are aware that masks are ineffective, and that natural immunity is more effective than the vaccine.

This tweet seems to criticize a conspiracy theorist from Idaho, who equated vaccine mandates to sexual assault. It highlights MSNBC reporter Rachel Maddow's response, stating that she opposed the conspiracy theorists' views and phrasing.
This informative tweet states that Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro told the UN that he rejects vaccine passports and vaccine-related mandates.
This tweet mainly argues that Kyle Rittenhouse is innocent, and criticizes Liberal/Democratic viewpoints about Donald Trump, vaccines, police funding, and protests.
This tweet argues that vaccines are unnecessary as COVID-19 has a 99% survival rate. It also criticizes a tweet that seems to promote vaccines, however, the tweet above is unavailable.
This tweet states that English football manager, Steve Cotterill encourages players to get vaccinated, as he is currently hospitalized with COVID-19.
This tweet states that the president of a school board in California uttered insults at a mother who opposed mask and vaccine mandates.
This tweet congratulates an individual - presumably a friend or family member - for getting vaccinated.
This tweet claims that information on Pfizer was leaked via email, stating that Pfizer uses fetal cells in its vaccines.

This tweeter responds to a tweet about vaccines for children under 12, and argues that vaccines not effective, and that children are not severely impacted by the virus. It calls vaccine mandates crimes against children.

This tweet shares an article from BBC News about high death rates from COVID-19 amongst healthcare workers. It states that only 1 in 7 vaccine doses promised by pharmaceutical companies and governments reached poorer countries.

This tweeter is sharing a news article about a shortage of staff and equipment to address large numbers of COVID-19 patients in Alberta hospitals. It explains that Alberta doctors are calling on the province to implement mandatory vaccinations and a lockdown to address the crisis.

This tweet states that the Omicron variant may evade antibody responses from infection or vaccination, making individuals more vulnerable to COVID-19. It introduces a thread on the consequence of this immune response.
This tweet seems to respond to a tweet from an anti-vaxxer, and states that this anti-vaxxer is wrong. Many tweets in the thread are unavailable.

This tweet argues that public health officials should research natural immunity, to increase public trust. It states that officials are attempting to profit off the vaccine, and that Fauci is wrong for stating there is not enough data on natural immunity.

This tweet states that the White House offered to call pop star Nicki Minaj to answer her questions about the vaccine. This offer follows a tweet by Minaj, questioning the effectiveness and safety of vaccines.

This tweet is trying to disprove common COVID vaccine misconceptions including that it makes it impossible to get COVID and the tweeter correctly identifies that it gives your body a better chance at fighting the virus. The tweeter is expressing their frustration at anti-vaxxers who at this point in the pandemic still don't understand how they work.

The tweeter is pointing out a flaw in the logic of anti-vaxxers speaking out against Colin Powell's death and pointing to it as evidence that the vaccine doesn't work. The tweeter points to Powell's age and previous health conditions as a much more likely explanation than exclusively the vaccine.
The tweeter here is announcing getting their booster.

This tweet says self-proclaimed doctor, Biswaroop Roy Chowdhury announced that natural immunity was better than the vaccine, which is inaccurate, and Biswaroop Roy Chowdhury has no qualifications to make these claims. The tweet includes hashtags like #NoVaccineMandates and #StopForceVaccination.
The user has made or found a quote that suggests the vaccine is not safe and was made with sinister or genocidal intentions.
Tweeter is critical of people who follow vaccine mandates uncritically in response to a video questioning the safety of vaccines.
This tweet argues against the idea that being critical of public health intervention or mandates is different than being anti-vaccine. The tweet is against arguing the semantics surrounding vaccines.

The user is expressing frustration that they are forced to take reduced hours and miss work because they have refused the vaccine. Language about being a taxpayer, veteran, and hard worker suggests that mandates are against American values.
criticism_other: employers who prevent unvaccinated employees from working or restrict their hours

meaning: This is a retweet of a Detroit News story about how vaccine mandates have lowered the supply of truck drivers, increasing fruit prices. The tweet takes the article out of context to make it look like it has anti-vaccine spin, despite the article's explanation of the existing supply chain issues.

This tweet regards herd immunity and it is situated within a pro-choice, anti-mandate thread. The tweeter made various previous statements about rejecting vaccine or public health mandates and also wrote that people who get the vaccine should be protected regardless of whether people around them are vaccinated. The post promotes misinformation because it relies on alternative facts regarding herd immunity.
The tweeters expresses frustration towards people who will not get the flu vaccine because COVID-19 is deemed more threatening.
criticism_other: Those who will not get the flu vaccine

meaning: The tweeter explains that allowing a host allowing someone to speak on their show about why one should not comply with vaccines in the media is a call to action, not free speech. This seems to be in reference to Joe Rogan's podcast and its related scandal.

This tweet refers to a politician's decision to keep vaccine passports in place. The tweeter views vaccine passports as a divide between people who do and don't want to be vaccinated during the COVID-19 pandemic. This is misinformation because it discredits public health policy by labelling it as a form of warfare.
This tweeter is arguing with an anti-vaxxer by way of refuting their arguments. This tweeter is stating that there are valuable immuno-responses within young children who are vaccinated.

This tweet promotes vaccine hesitation and fear by spreading misinformation that the media is not reporting "complications" and "deaths" caused by vaccines. The post is not grounded in fact and does not provide any examples of such claims.
The tweeter states people around them who are anti-vax are dying of COVID-19 in reply to a tweet about a politician trying to convince people that hospitals are mainly filled with anti-vaxxers.

This tweet seems to criticize mandatory vaccination in the NBA, and advocates for freedom of choice. The tweeter seems to understand the importance of herd immunity, and says that NHS frontline workers should be vaccinated if there is enough supply, but argues that 1% of individuals die from the vaccine. The tweeter says that vaccine mandates in private organizations should therefore not be allowed.

This tweet is saying that the reason disinformation is so effective is that it stems from some element of truth and preexisting insecurities. They connect this to justifiable fears racialized individuals have about the vaccine considering their historical mistreatment in the medical industry.

This tweet is talking about the death of this individual's 33-year-old cousin due to COVID. The tweeter is saying their cousin was not vaccinated because her husband, a pastor, told her it was a 'mark of the Beast', presumably referring to the devil. The tweeter is urging people to get vaccinated.
This tweeter states that a particular politician lost their support because the politician refuses to oppose vaccine mandates. The tweeter says this politician has gotten too comfortable in his role.

This tweeter responds to a tweet by Attorney General Ken Paxton, who states that one must defend individual liberties and oppose COVID-19 safety measures. This tweeter responds by saying that not taking precautionary measures endangers lives, and that Paxton should wear a mask, get the vaccine, and stay home.

This tweet condemns vaccine mandates under Joe Biden, calling them unconstitutional. It also says that not implementing a vaccine mandate for immigrants and refugees crossing the US-Mexico border is nonsensical, given the vaccine mandates for the general population.

This tweet advocates for vaccine availability in children between 5 and 11 years old. It states that children are getting sick and dying from COVID-19, while public health officials cannot come to an agreement on policy measures.

This tweet seems to condemn a variety of COVID-19 safety measures, saying that vaccine passports restrict movement, that vaccines are experimental gene therapy, and that lockdown can be equated to public incarceration.
The tweeter advocates for freedom of choice and empathy or compassion for those who choose not to get vaccinated.
Tweeter is sharing their own experience of following vaccine mandates, getting all the shots, and effectiveness vaccine in keeping COVID-19 at bay.
This tweet is suggesting that vaccines don't work. It was in response to a tweet saying that sometimes tests don't work.

This tweeter is a parent expressing their relief towards vaccines being available to children aged 5-11. They are saying how difficult its been trying to protect their son prior to vaccine availability and how emotional this news is.

This tweeter opposes a tweet by a political candidate, who argues that his opponent Ron DeSantis is a vaccine skeptic. The tweeter highlights an excerpt, presumably from DeSantis' platform, showing support for the vaccine.

This tweet shares an article from an arthritis support network, which states that most immunocompromised individuals received the flu shot this year, and are planning to receive or have already received their third COVID-19 vaccine dose.

This tweet shares an article from the Financial Times about Ethiopian Airlines' effort to ship COVID-19 vaccines to locations in Africa and Latin America. The tweet commends Ethiopian Airlines' efforts, and says that this initiative proves the airlines' positive reputation.
This tweet seems to advocate for vaccines for the under-12 population in New Zealand, as children under 12 years old comprise 15 per cent of the population, and they are not immune to COVID-19

This tweeter responds to a tweet by Thomas Massie, where he equates COVID-19 to the common cold and states that the vaccine cannot protect against the Omicron variant. This tweeter says that by spreading this information, Massie is increasing the death rate, as COVID-19 vaccines and boosters prevent serious illness and death.

This tweet shares an article about a reverend's support of Maine's vaccine mandate. The article appeals to those who may oppose the vaccine on religious grounds, and highlights the reverend's positive sentiment towards the COVID-19 vaccine.
The tweet does not advocate for or against vaccination, it is replying to a question about whether a particular travel mandate has gone into affect in South Africa.
The tweeter is sharing his own experience getting vaccinated, saying he had temporary side effects that were "bad," but in the long term, getting the vaccine is good.
criticism_other: people who do not get the vaccine because they are afraid of the short term side affects

meaning: The tweet is making a sarcastic comment about vaccine efficacy and misrepresenting the idea of herd immunity. It seems to imply that the idea of herd immunity is a lie to convince people to get vaccinated as part of a scheme.
This tweet seems to neutrally announce that the company General Electric will suspend vaccine-or-test requirements for its employees, following a ruling by the Supreme Court of the U.S.

This tweet seems to support a movement in South Africa to push out major companies like the Gates Foundations. It says that opposing vaccine mandates may kickstart this movement to exile major politicians and business owners one by one.

This tweet replies to a tweet by Christopher Snowdon about the low death rate among vaccinated individuals, citing this as misinformation. The tweeter says that most COVID-19 deaths are now among vaccinated individuals, and that vaccines do work, but not perfectly.

This tweet argues that hospitalizations from presumed vaccine side effects like myocarditis are equally or more severe than hospitalizations from COVID-19. It also claims that myocarditis is caused by the spike protein in the vaccine.
This tweet follows the easing of some vaccine mandates, and seems to make fun of those who purchased a forged vaccine certificate, as this will no longer be required.
This tweet uses seemingly fabricated graphs to argue that overall mortality has increased since the implementation of COVID-19 vaccines.

This tweet argues against vaccines and advocates for the self-reporting and unverified app VAERS. It states that vaccines have unreliable ingredients and impacts. This tweet replies to a thread, and states that another individual is making medical decisions for others by arguing in favor of the vaccine.

This tweet criticizes the decision to ease COVID-19 restrictions and reporting tools. It states that COVID-19 is at its highest levels of the pandemic, and says that Governor Mike DeWine is doing nothing to address this.

This tweet is claiming that COVID was 'created in a lab' and the people who created it need to be held accountable. The tweeter is saying that people have died from COVID, COVID restrictions and from side effects of the vaccine and that the people who 'created' COVID need to be held accountable.
This tweet is linked to a The Hill Times article quoting Howard Stern speaking out against anti-vaxxers saying that their 'freedom' isn't worth more than his life.

This tweeter is thanking the police who were fired for not getting vaccinated because they think the police's refusal to get vaccinated is proof they weren't equipped to be police officers. The tweeter then says that the fact the police wouldn't get vaccinated means they were probably also 'racist' and 'abusers'.

This tweeter states that their employer recently implemented mandatory vaccination in the workplace, but did not provide instructions on how to upload one's vaccine certificate. The tweeter criticizes this policy, calling it 'dumb'.
This tweeter states that vaccinated individuals are fearful of unvaccinated individuals. It states that vaccines contain gene transfers, and that vaccinated individuals should depend on neohumanism.

This tweeter responds to a video of a man getting vaccinated, to prove that the vaccine is safer than any alternative COVID-19 remedies. This tweeter responds, saying that the man is crazy, and so is anyone else who decides to receive the vaccine.

This tweeter responds to a video of Chinese president Xi Jinping promoting the vaccine as a safe tool to prevent COVID-19. During the video, Jinping says that vaccines are a powerful weapon against the virus. This tweeter responds by highlighting this statement, and implies that vaccines are unsafe.

This tweeter responds to a tweet criticizing the Biden administration for increased unemployment rates, inflation, crime rates, and supply shortages. This tweeter adds that another downfall of the Biden administration is the implementation of vaccine mandates for workplaces.
This tweeter states that COVID-19 infection rates are in line with predicted numbers, and that increasing the vaccination rate will help prevent further lockdowns.

This tweet shares a video by Russel Brand, which discusses Bill Gates' role in promoting vaccine. The intent of this video is unclear, and seems to simultaneously support vaccines in general, while arguing against the COVID-19 vaccine.

This tweeter is suggesting that all SouthWest Airlines employee who is protesting the vaccine mandate should be banned from any future travel suggesting that if they intend on endangering passengers they don't deserve to be able to fly.
This tweet is announcing the CDC's vote that they preferred mRNA vaccines to the Johnston and Johnston vaccines for individuals over 18.

This tweeter is saying they don't want to get vaccinated but feel they have no choice. They say they're worried about their body too much and it is unclear if they mean worried about getting COVID or what the vaccine will do to their body or both.
This tweet links to a rant from Fox News anchor Dan Bongino about how vaccine mandates are ineffective and all the people who are speaking out against them including NBA players.

This tweet is part of a thread arguing that Faucci and Biden claimed the vaccine would be 100% effective and stop any COVID transmission. The tweeter is making the claim that because that isn't true the vaccines don't work.

This tweet links to a video saying that vaccines cause heart tissue scarring, haven't been tested, and are considerably more harmful than getting COVID. The tweet is directed at @RWMaloneMD who the tweeter claims invented vaccines.

This tweet is commenting on Steve Burton's firing from the show General Hospital because he was not vaccinated. This tweeter is saying the vaccine mandate is coming from Disney, which owns ABC, the network General Hospital is on, not the show itself.

This tweeter takes issue to how the definition of 'fully vaccinated' is changing from two shots to three. They are saying its from a 'totalitarian government' forcing a vaccine that they claim isn't working suggesting another vaccine will be required in 6 months.
This tweet says a Louisiana judge  has made it so that Head Start teachers are not required to be vaccinated going against President Joe Bidens' vaccine mandate.

This tweet is in response to one asking why Trump is 'pushing' vaccines and this tweeter is coming to Trumps defence saying that getting vaccinated is not the same as pushing vaccines and the tweeter claims Biden is the one pushing vaccines, not Trump.
This tweeter is saying the vaccine does not stop the spread of COVID.

This tweet is referring to Australia acknowledging that two doses of Sputnik vaccine among other international vaccines would be recognized for international travel into Australia. This tweeter is asking why Australian citizens don't have access to these vaccines also.
This tweet from author Brigitte Gabriel saying that she shouldn't have to tell anyone her vaccination status.
The tweet is saying that being picky about which vaccine to get is 'madness' and that individuals should just get whichever vaccine is available to them.

This tweet is in response to one from a vaccine researcher. This tweeter is saying they 'need new data' and the tweet links to a document by David John Sorensen and Dr. Vladimir Zelenko  saying the COVID vaccine is whats causing the death and the harm and not COVID.
This tweet is fact-checking a claim that 27 US Air Forces pilots resigned over vaccine mandates. This tweet links to an article disproving the claim. The tweeter says this rumour is a "Q hoax".

This tweeter, Dominique Samuels a right-leaning political commentator, is tweeting about Wales' vote which passed the need for vaccine passports. She claims that because the vote only passed by one vote and a Tory MP could not get onto Zoom to vote that the vote is not legitimate.

This is a retweet of an anti-vaccine article which argues that global elites have conspired to use COVID-19 to implant tracking chips in people. This tweet and article leverage the history of science and health officials violating the human rights of Black communities to promote distrust of the vaccine.
This is a reply tweet applauding Connecticut's high vaccination rate. The tweet supports science as it trusts the data and the safety associated with high vaccination rates.

The tweeter is responding to another tweet that has been deleted, questioning whether vaccines are still effective amidst the Omicron variant. The tweet includes a video of Pfizer's CEO explaining that two doses of the vaccine provides limited protection.
The tweet seems to have simply shared an article from Time magazine about the missteps of a vaccine manufacturer.
This tweeter is describing their side effects from the vaccine saying they were a little woozy for an hour.

This tweet is saying that comparing COVID vaccines to polio vaccines doesn't work because the polio vaccine eliminated the spread of polio and the tweeter is claiming no COVID vaccine is currently doing that.

This tweet is in response to one saying that Joe Rogan managed to beat COVID in 2 days without getting vaccinated. The tweeter is saying thats misleading because of all the treatments Rogan received including monoclonal antibodies treatment which promotes an immune response similar to that of the vaccine.
The tweeter is saying now that vaccines are available people get to make the choice to help people and save lives citing that COVID causes long term damage.

This tweet is in response to a tweet from an individual saying their mother with cancer recently got COVID also. The tweeter links to a video saying the 'truth' with a doctor listing all the negative impact of the vaccine including something called 'spike protein'.
Pastor Phil Rizzo is tweeting that anyone who believes in unvaccinated people not being allowed certain privileges, which he refers to as 'vaccine segregation' is 'evil'.

Conservative media platform, The Blaze, tweets a link to their article about Republican Representative Cawthorn's bill to block businesses from requiring COVID vaccines or testing. Cawthorn and The Blaze refer to vaccine mandates as 'subsidized medical apartheid.'

This tweet links to a youtube video in Hindi. This tweeter is saying that according to the supreme court and the constitution there is no one including, 'SP, DSP, DC, DM, CM, PM', who can force anyone to get vaccinated.
This tweet, from news organization 7News in Brisbane Australia, says that thousands gathered across Australia to protest vaccine mandates and COVID restrictions.
This tweet is announcing Singapore Prime Minister Lee's support for a 'swift and equitable' distribution of vaccines throughout Singapore.
This tweet supports Tesco's decision to mandate vaccination in their stores. The tweeter says that they are excited to visit the store knowing everyone is vaccinated.

This tweeter responds to a tweet arguing in support of the COVID-19 vaccine, and responds by saying that only older individuals or those who are immunocompromised have to worry about getting seriously ill from COVID-19. It argues that everyone other than older individuals and those who are immunocompromised do not need to get vaccinated.

This tweet is from the Physicians for Informed Consent, and states that parents are unable to sue manufacturers for vaccine injury to their children. It argues in favor of parental choice when it comes to the COVID-19 vaccine, and seemingly advocates against vaccine mandates.

This tweeter states that those who oppose vaccines are privileged, and use vaccine mandates to claim personal oppression. This tweet is part of a thread highlighting the danger of anti-vaccine movements, stating that there are death threats currently placed against politicians who support vaccine mandates.
