This tweet is saying that the tweeter got vaccinated with the moderna vaccine.

This tweet highlights a supposed deal between Justin Trudeau and Pfizer to continue supplying vaccines until 2024. This tweeter argues that this deal indicates that Trudeau will continue to declare that Canada is in a public health crisis in order to use these vaccines.
This tweet argues that for some individuals, the risks of the COVID-19 vaccine outweigh the benefits, and therefore argues against vaccine mandates for all.

This tweeter responds to someone saying that public health officials should charge higher hospital fees for those who are obese, as opposed to charging higher fees for those who are unvaccinated. This tweeter argues that this logic is flawed, as vaccines are a choice and obesity is much less of a choice.

This tweet is comparing Australia to Nazi Germany because of Australia's vaccine mandate. It is referring to Novak Djokovic needing to vaccinated saying that it doesn't have anything to do with health and is just "dirty politics".
This tweet is an update of COVID stats in the UK including case, death, and vaccine numbers.
This tweet is saying that among children hospitalized for COVID only 0.4 % of them eligible to be vaccinated were. The tweeter goes on to say that vaccines for children are safe and effective.
This tweet is claiming that vaccines are created from fetus cells and compares vaccine mandates to the holocaust.
This tweet is saying that Republican Senator Doug Ericksen, who has been fighting to oppose vaccine mandates, how has contracted COVID in El Salvador and is unable to return back to the states.

This tweet is in response to one from the CDC saying that vaccines work. This tweeter is saying the CDC is lying and that vaccines have caused over 16 000 deaths which is untrue. The tweeter also claims that the CDC is run by Bill Gates and that when the "mass awakening" occurs, Bill Gates and the CDC will be charged with crimes against humanity.

This tweet is in response to one saying that a Christmas event was supposed to happen in France but few will able to attend because all the "triple jabbed" were ill and the event would not allow people who had only received one dose. This tweeter is saying that is happening "everywhere" insinuating that people who have gotten three doses of the vaccine are getting sick while the un-vaccinated are not, though the tweet makes very little sense.

This tweet is saying that a minister in Jamaica is urging individuals to get vaccinated because they have 190 000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine that are about to expire and people should take this opportunity to get vaccinated.

This tweet is saying that data from the "Medicare Tracking System", which is a database that does not exist, show that over 48 000 people died the two weeks following receiving their COVID vaccines. This is an entirely unsubstantiated claim and it is unclear where the tweeter got these numbers from.

This tweet is part of a thread advocating for more COVID-19 safety measures in Ontario schools and daycares. It states that politicians must take action to protect children by making vaccines available to those under 12 years old.

This tweet argues that the CDC discouraged some individuals from getting the vaccines by stating that vaccines stop the spread of COVID-19. The tweeter argues here that this poor and untrue messaging early on in the the pandemic ultimately discouraged people from getting the vaccine and trusting public health sources.

This tweet includes a photo of a 52 year old cardiologist who allegedly died from his vaccine booster shot. The tweet claims that the vaccines are "experimental mRNA gene therapy" and that "vaccines are the real pandemic".
This tweet is announcing that 12-15 year olds are able to get vaccinated in England and hours that the vaccination clinic is open.
This tweet is saying that "Vaccine Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (VAIDS)" will become more common effectively claiming that the COVID vaccines will be causing AIDS.

This tweet links to a video from Fox News of Laura Ingraham and another anchor who is trying to explain an episode of the Netflix show, "You". Ingraham thinks he's referring to her and is not understanding that there is a show called "You" despite his best efforts. The tweeter then says, "These are the people lecturing us about vaccines. Un-freaking-believable 😂😅😂", insinuating that this interaction is showing a lack of intelligence and they should not be trusted to speak about vaccines.

This tweet is linking a Washington Post with the headline, "Big Bird got his Pfizer shot, and conservatives are calling it vaccine ‘propaganda’". The tweeter says that every story mainstream media or "every news cycle inside DC" puts out is just about what conservatives are angry about.

This tweet is saying that children don't necessarily need to be vaccinated if they are already immune and that 'anti-body tests' should be done on children. The tweeter is saying that the focus should be off of vaccines and onto 'immunity'.

This tweet is in response to one showing conflicting information on whether or not Omicron was as severe at Delta by two American scientists Dr. Forman and Dr. Topol. The tweeter then says that neither doctor can be trusted because they allegedly tried to stop the vaccines from being available prior to the 2020 election as a political move against Trump.

This tweet is in response to a tweeter saying that his dad got COVID despite being vaccinated. This tweeter was asking if his dad got two or three doses and said that the Johnson and Johnson vaccine is useless against Omicron.

This tweet is saying that vaccine mandates and firing paramedics for refusing to get vaccinated is uncivilized and unconstitutional. The tweeter says that it will be detrimental to the economy as well as public safety.
This tweet is saying that the vaccines were meant to help slow the spread but the government acted as if it eliminated COVID completely.
This tweeter is referring to anti-vaxxers paying for fake vaccine passports instead of just getting vaccinated is the "definition of stupid".

This tweeter is saying they know to understand how the Nazis could "rise to power" after seeing the rollout of the vaccine mandates comparing the "imprisonment" of the unvaccinated to Jewish people during Nazi Germany.
This tweeter is saying that vaccines were distributed too late and the federal provision of quarantine was both "incompetent and harmful".
This tweet is saying that COVID is a "mental health crisis" because people are completely vaccinated, triple vaccinated, but still scared of doing things for fear of contracting COVID.
This tweet is upset that a child was given pizza for getting the vaccine at school and was told not to tell anyone.

Tweeter is criticizing the hypocrisy of conservative politicians, who show solidarity with the freedom of choice of anti-vaccine and anti-mandate groups but not women's choice regarding abortion rights.

The tweet was posted in response to someone who is upset that an area in New Zealand has not been deemed "green" even though cases are low. The tweeter is suggesting that these "zones" are a way to force people to get vaccinated.
This twitter post suggests that the German government lightly bribed people to get vaccinated, sarcastically stating that low value gifts were give to promote vaccination.

The tweeter relays a quote they heard in public, from a seemingly paranoid anti-vaxxer. This tweeter revealed shock -- given what they heard took place in a deeply democrat-voting state -- which indicated that they were in disbelief that people in the area could have such anti-vaxx beliefs.

The tweet shares information on out-of-pocket spending for COVID-19 hospitalizations, based on information from the University of Michigan. The changes being discussed apply to patients who cannot be vaccinated.

This Twitter post was made in response to a person who publicly claimed that monoclonal antibody treatments (MAT) are a great solution to combating COVID-19, while simultaneously rejecting vaccine mandates and "big pharma." It is not clear if this post is truly anti-"big pharma," yet it certainly brings attention to the fact that MAT is also produced by "big pharma."
support_other: Awareness about who produces certain medical treatments.

meaning: A person who is clearly skeptical of vaccines uses percentages regarding herd immunity to push vaccine skepticism. Public health officials have never publicized that a vaccination rate of 90% or higher is required for herd immunity -- the number has typically been in the mid-80's -- so this post is misleading and promotes mistrust towards public health.
This tweet links to a tool that was created to determine an individual's risk for contracting and being hospitalized for COVID.
This tweet is saying that the new requirements for being "fully vaccinated" now include getting a third dose. This tweeter is expressing frusteration that this will "never end".
This tweet is saying there is new data from Isreal saying that vaccines "augment" the chance of getting COVID speculating the vaccine might increase the risk of infection.
This tweeter is pointing out the hypocrisy of anti-vaxxers taking issue with vaccine passports but wanting trans people to "prove' their gender before using a washroom.
This tweet is saying that there's another vaccine that creates T cells which they are claiming works better than the current vaccines available.
This tweet is sharing a link to a video that explains Joe Bidens policy on vaccine mandates in workplaces
This tweet is saying that vaccines are not effective and only help big pharma, which is incorrect. The tweet is formatted as a checklist.
This tweet is implying that South Africa is reporting new COVID variants to justify their mandate and lockdown measures.
This tweet is saying that mandates are not discriminatory because vaccines are free.
This tweet is a reminder for attendees of a concert that they must show proof of vaccination or a negative COVID test to enter the venue.
This tweet is saying that states of emergency should be stopped because vaccines are available, COVID is treatable and deaths are low, which is misinformation.
This tweet is tweeting at an airline to ask for clarification on it's vaccine policy that says negative PCR test and vaccine are necessary for boarding.
This tweet is saying that it does not matter is a person is vaccinated or has gotten their booster shot, which is incorrect.
This tweet is saying that public health officials have a unanimous consensus in vaccinating kids aged 5-11, despite the general public having varying opinions on vaccines.
This tweet is replying to an anti-vax tweet comparing the rate of booster shot administration to a miracle.
This tweet is linking to a story about a vaccinated sports team having a COVID outbreak, sarcastically implying that vaccines do not work.
This tweet is saying that an anti-vaxxer on a conservative media network is too intense with his anti-vax messaging and that the media network should be ashamed to have had him as a guest.
This tweet is saying that vaccines are an experiment, which is incorrect.
This tweet is saying a reporter implied that anti-vaxxers do not deserve healthcare if they become ill.
This tweet is saying that anti-vaxxers asking for medical records of people who have died of COVID more invasive than proof of vaccinations that anti-vaxxers are criticizing.
This tweet is saying that we don't know the ingredients of most of the things we put in our bodies so anti-vaxxers should not use that argument against the vaccine.
This tweet is a list of COVID case counts and vaccination statistics.
This tweet is saying that facial recognition software could make vaccine mandates more enforceable in the future
This tweet is sharing a new story that says vaccination numbers grew as the start of a mandate for healthcare workers approached.
This tweet is criticizing a reporter for not saying that someone who died of COVID had a pre-existing condition.
This tweet is saying that children need extra help to arrange their vaccines and to get their proof of vaccination.
This tweet is criticizing the vaccine for having waning immunity and is implying that Ivermectin may be more effective.
This tweet is a quote from a government official saying that they will do whatever is needed to limit the spread of COVID.
This tweet is reporting that anti-vaxxers protested in a shopping center against mandatory proof of vaccination.
This tweet is saying that the COVID vaccine reduces immunity to other illnesses, which is incorrect.
This tweet is saying that the tweeter is worried about the high levels of adverse affects from the vaccine, which is incorrect.
The tweeter discusses how vaccines no longer work amid the Delta variant and that vaccine mandates are harmful and illegal.
This tweet is using bible verses to say that big pharma should not be profiting from the pandemic because peoples lives are at stake.
This tweet is saying nurses who do not want to be vaccinated should leave healthcare and asks how they became misinformed.
This tweet is asking for clarification on an airlines COVID-19 policy.
This tweet is saying that unvaccinated children are healthier than vaccinated children, which is incorrect, but doctors will not study this.
This tweet is saying that as time has gone on public health and government have been okay with higher and higher numbers of COVID deaths.
This tweet is sharing an article that says police officers who do not get vaccinated could be fired.
This tweet is saying that vaccinated people will be able to enter the United States by air.
This tweet is saying that big pharma is comparable to the mafia and what is in the vaccine is unclear, which is incorrect.
This tweet is saying that the tweeter who is unvaccinated has not gotten COVID and that he thinks the pandemic is a joke.
This tweet is asking if there is a correlation between vaccination rates and COVID case counts.
This tweet is sharing an article that explains the United States' COVID travel policies.
This tweet is criticizing a pop star for spreading misinformation about the vaccine and not admitting she was wrong.
This tweet is saying that government has more interest in foreign affairs than their own citizens that are not vaccinated.
This tweet is saying the tweeter has an app to check peoples vaccine certificates to use when they suspect their certificate may be fake.
This person is defending the effectiveness of vaccine in preventing suffering of people from COVID-19.
The tweeter is criticizing a politician who trusts that a federal vaccine database in the U.S. will be kept confidential and not abused by the government.
support_other: Conspiracy theories, Protection of private information

meaning: This post clearly supports anti-vaccine sentiments. It depicts anti-vaxx protests at the California senate. Due to the emoticons that are used to describe the video, the tweeter doesn't support vaccination. The video displays what it describes as a group of mothers and children banging on the walls, refusing to consent to what they call vaccine mandates. It appears that this posted video may actually be a clip from a protest that took place in September 2019, before the pandemic happened. I was not able to verify this footage in other news sources, but this footage was likely taken out of context (from that non-pandemic related protest in 2019) and spun into a COVID-19 "anti-mandate" video.

This controversial MD, Bhattacharya, is a Brownstone Institute scholar, which is a think tank that opposes various COVID-19 measures. He opposed lockdowns at the very beginning of the pandemic and he was also critical of mask mandates. He was involved with various court cases regarding mandates and testified in support of banning mask mandates. He was eventually deemed as "untrustworthy" by a Tennessee judge. He used his MD status to push his credibility publicly, but he has faced criticism by peers.
The tweeter is upset that federal funding for uninsured and international residents in the U.S. is running out because many may be unable to afford to get vaccinated.

Tweeter discusses how mortality rates for unvaccinated vs. vaccinated populations differ drastically to encourage vaccinations. Tweets are backed up by research articles, but some of the information does not seem to reflect those articles well.
This is an informational tweet. It is a re-post of a news article regarding vaccination rates and the approaches different countries of the world are taking.
This tweeter promotes his personal opinion that children don't need vaccinations if they are healthy. This is medical disinformation and this tweeter is highly likely to be an anti-vaxxer in general.
The tweeter is promoting misinformation by saying masks, test kits, ventilators and vaccines are either ineffective, harmful or deadly.

Tweeter, who is a journalist, is sharing general information about vaccinations in Dallas. He shares a graph detailing vaccination rates, but the information is not attributed to another source, which may indicate it is part of his work as a journalist.
Kyrie Irving is still not able to play professional basketball despite New York City lifting vaccine mandates because the Net's private sector mandate is different. And Irving is unvaccinated.

The tweeter is discussing how the COVID-19 vaccine is useless and ineffective to promote misinformation. The tweet also includes a photo about the changing definitions of vaccine goals to promote distrust.
The tweet is linking to an article from Nature about how vaccines may not protect people from long COVID. The tweeter's profile seems to promoting science and vaccinations.
The tweet is highlighting a letter the Tamil Nadu Unit of Bharathiya Janata Party received from the Prime Minister of India expressing his appreciation for them handing out 100 vaccinations.

The tweet is discussing a strict outdoor-vaccination mandate in LA, taking affect after the World Series ends. The tweeter seems to criticizing the timing of this mandate because it suits the needs of those watching the World Series.
The tweeter expresses distrust towards vaccines, calling COVID-19 a pandemic of the vaccinated.
The tweeter is explaining why it is important for people to get vaccinated, but they seem frustrated that they need to explain it at all.

This post claims that protein-based vaccines are safer than the original COVID-19 vaccines that have been released during the pandemic. This tweet is not necessarily anti-vaxx, rather it is pro-protein-based vaccines. The tweeter is spreading disinformation by saying regular vaccines can be "cytotoxic."

This tweeter is making an economic statement regarding the BREXIT dividend, in relation to vaccination rates, and vaccine exports or donations made by the U.K. and the EU respectively. It's not completely clear what is politically implied, this could be a critique on the lack of a BREXIT dividend coming into fruition, yet the post appears informational.
support_other: COVAX / Vaccine donations or exports abroad

meaning: This tweeter's comment is a sarcastic response to news about anti-vaxxers drinking iodine as an alternative remedy for COVID-19. The tweet is pro-vaccination and anti-alternative remedy.

This tweeter challenged an anti-vaxxer who made a claim that a particular COVID-19 vaccine causes myocarditis (a heart problem). He addressed the false spread of information that was not relevant to the specific vaccine under discussion. This tweet is, therefore, pro-vaccine.
The tweeter says that politicians and pharmaceutical companies are working together to financially benefit from making vaccines to promote misinformation.
The tweeter says the vaccine is ineffective, and that there is probably something else government and pharmaceutical companies want to inject in people.
Tweet shares a link to a Reuters article discussing how Boris Johnson plans to lift some COVID-19 mandates, including vaccines passports.
The tweeter implies mandatory vaccinations in Germany have the same intentions as the Holocaust. The tweet includes an old image of Nazi supporters.

The tweet is part of an anti-vaccine reply chain. It is a response to a pro-vaccine user defending the effectiveness of vaccines. Although the tweet is mostly true, it is misleading because vaccine immunity is still being studied and natural immunity lasts just month or two longer.

It's a reply to a tweet about someone who allegedly had an adverse reaction. It seems like honest condolences, and an instance where the vaccine did fail somebody. It says that they are supposed to help but sometimes fail.

It's a direct tweet of an article about states with low vaccination rates. The tweet makes a misleading generalisation that anti-vaxxers from those states hate science, whereas many of them just don't understand the science.
The tweet implies vaccine mandates are about something other than public health, implying a conspiracy.

It's from a Fox reporter linking to her own story about how athletes and performers were able to work unvaccinated. The story has some misleading elements but the tweet, knowing its context, is a fair critique of a double standard.
It's a tweet informing people about Saskatchewan's policy for vaccinating people 12 and older. It's urging people to get their kids vaccinated.

The link provided with this post is somewhat nonsensical. I was not able to decipher it, but it appears to be an anti-vaxx related letter, for employees that may be subjected to vaccine mandates to remain employed. The text is very confusing.
The tweet explains that the restrictions exemption program was meant to increase the vaccinated public, which to the tweeter is coercion.
The tweet expresses disgust for unvaccinated truck drivers and anyone who supported the freedom convoy.
The tweeter is asking whether there are other viruses that require multiple doses of a vaccine besides COVID-19.
The tweeter is criticizing anti-vaxxers who compare the COVID-19 vaccine to the Holocaust.
British politician tweets about not getting vaccinated because he is against COVID-19 passports and believes all big pharmaceutical companies have predatory practices.
A doctor tweets about vaccine supply issues. She speaks about her own medical practice having to wait about a month for vaccines.
criticism_other: General practices causing vaccine supply delays

meaning: The tweeter, who calls himself a journalist, promotes misinformation by saying the COVID-19 vaccine is meant to better the economy.
criticism_other: Economists, Those in positions of power

meaning: Using greek letters avoids stigmatising places where variants emerge, a global vaccine response is the only way to stop the emergence of new variants of COVID-19.
support_other: Greek letter labels for COVID variants

meaning: A legal team searching for people who had adverse reactions to the vaccine and felt the government did not properly report their reaction. It is almost misleading but it is attempting to find information to let the court decide the truth rather than claiming the system doesn't work.

This tweet defends the messaging around COVID-19 vaccines. The tweeter implies that libertarians would still be anti-vaxx, even if pro-vaccine messaging had been geared towards their political beliefs.
This tweet encourages mask mandates, stating that the transmission rate is still too high to consider dropping indoor masking.
The tweet links to something that is unavailable but it argues that American conservative leadership is split when it comes to Trump, and that social media is filled with anti-vaccine misinformation.

This tweeter is full vaccinated and therefore pro-vaccine. However, he believes in living life as normal now that he's vaccinated and equates being careful in public with being a scared democrat. The post criticizes liberals, stating that they live in a state of fear.
support_other: Living life like normal once vaccinated

meaning: The tweet uses this headline as proof that vaccines and lockdowns were a mistake, but the article explains that NZ R values were comparable to other surges earlier that year, and that R values are not the best measure for outbreak severity.

This tweeter claims that the vaccine trails had a mishap that lead to false results, or "fraud" and "shenanigans." His profile contains other anti-vaxx posts as well. He provided a link to his own blog, which would not be peer reviewed.

The tweet itself is informational, however the posted video is blatantly anti-vaccine. It depicts a man who attempts to get food in Israel. That man orders at a McDonald's machine and is asked if he is vaccinated. When he selects the "no" option, he is denied the option to order. The man then equates that mandate with Nazi Germany.

It is part of a long thread about a problem with conflicting testing kits and people getting vaccinated while potentially having COVID, ultimately this tweet is arguing for booster vaccines for people of all ages.

This tweeter promotes distrust towards the COVID-19 vaccine, saying that it's not normal that a vaccine must be taken ever three months. There various other vaccines that require multiple doses to be effective, so this tweeter is spreading disinformation by saying that this has not happened in history before.
This post appears to be informational about vaccine mandates being passed. It does not appear to pass judgment, nor does it take a clear stance on this matter.
This tweeter claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is ineffective and that it can even kill people.

Although the post is rather sensational, this news outlet is somewhat reputable. The article is not taking a stance, rather reporting news about a pro-vaxxer criticizing a public figure who is anti-vaxx.
This is a post of a quote taken from the Washington Post with no outside commentary.

This twitter post rejects the idea of vaccine passports and shows disdain towards officials who have instated the idea of it. The post is personal opinion and doesn't necessarily contain disinformation, rather anger towards vaccine passports, as well as anti-vaxx beliefs.

This post states that DBS (background) checks on asylum seekers are complicated in the current pandemic, and that vaccine mandates around social care and health staff should be reviewed. The tweet doesn't take a clear pro or ant-vaxx stance.
support_other: Reviewing vaccine mandates for health and social care staff, regarding asylumm seekers jobs

meaning: This post suggests that vaccines are not safe and that they have side-effects.
This post suggests that some vaccines are safe, while others are not. It claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is too new to be tested properly, and that it is experimental.
criticism_other: Safety of the COVID-19 vaccine specifically

meaning: This tweet claims that there is something negative revealed about vaccines by way of the COVID-19 pandemic. The post intends to build mistrust towards vaccines.

This tweet claims that vaccinations and testing are useless because tourists on a cruise ship still contracted COVID-19, despite starting the cruise with negative tests and vaccine passports. This post discounts the fact that the severity of those passengers' illnesses were likely much lower than if they had not been vaccinated.
This tweet appears to be incomprehensible; However, the tweeter seems to say "I have no idea why people want to get the vaccine." Therefore, his post is promoting fear of the COVID-19 vaccine.
criticism_other: People who choose to get the vaccine

meaning: This is an information post, stating where Cayuga County vaccine clinics will be located. The link doesn't work anymore, so I was not able to verify it's content.
This tweet argues that South Africa was in a bad spot concerning Omicron compared to countries with higher vaccination rates.

This post is informational, it's not clear if the tweeter is promoting any values, rather just laughing at  these women for getting caught. The shared article appears to come from a tabloid website and it may not be fact checked. This tweet itself is not pro or anti-vaxx, however the tweeter's profile clearly states that she is a MAGA fan (a hardcore republican), so one may assume she is anti-vaxx.

This post promotes vaccination by stating that it's positive that various regions of Australia have an extremely high vaccination rate in comparison to countries of the world. The chart that the tweeter refers to is sourced from the Australian Department of Health.

This tweet is critical of the U.K. government's decisions regarding BREXIT fall out. It states that vaccination rates are lower than they should be, even though the government is claiming U.K.'s vaccine roll-out was "world-beating."
criticism_other: Lack of mandates at schools, BREXIT decisions

meaning: This post is promoting conspiracy theories about Bill Gates and Fauci. Bill Gates was a subject of discussion among many anti-vaxxers who thought he (along with Fauci) developed COVID-19. There are other baseless beliefs about the two public figures as well.
This is a very vague post that supports lowering vaccine restrictions. It is not clear and does not give any details on what mandates were removed in which states, therefore the post is misleading.

This tweeter believes that Trump rushed the vaccine through and wonders why members of the left are following the lead. They also celebrate their employer for not enforcing the vaccine as a requirement to stay employed. The post is misleading because Trump did not push the vaccine through, it was a world-wide decision. The post also stokes fear towards vaccines, claiming the COVID-19 vaxx was rushed.
This post makes fun of an unreputable doctor who was pushing Ivermectin as a remedy for COVID-19. The post is pro-vaccine, anti-alternative remedy.

This is a humorous opinion comment on the topic of freedom of choice. The tweeter claims that pro-vaxx people have more of a sense of freedom than anti-vaxxers, because the anti-vaxxers have more problems with vaccinated people than the vaccinated people have with anti-vaxxers.
This post claims that children do not need to be vaccinated, which is obviously a false claim because COVID-19 presents risks to all people.
This is a critical comment about people who believe in NFTs (crypto currency) but don't believe in vaccinations. Crypto currency is supported by the anti-vaxx, conspiracy theory movement.
Tweeter suggests that vaccine passports aren't allowed unless the PM of Australia allows them.
Many people who contracted Omicron were fully vaxxed, so public health said it was important to wear masks. The tweeter states that the vaccine was a complete failure because of this.
Tweeter re-tweets Guardian article about how vaccine hesitancy may be related to traumatic events in childhood and calls it unsurprising research results.

This tweet reports on an online battle between Candace Owens and Meghan McCain. McCain took a pro-vaccine approach and tried to debunk Owen's conspiracy theories about the vaccine. The post itself does not take a stance.
This woman is relaying information that her 8-year-old family member was vaccinated and that she didn't like the prick because it was uncomfortable.
This is a reply to a deleted tweet, but on its own it seems like a genuine question about how the vaccine works and affects the virus' spread.

This post seems like a legitimate news article, however Newsmax is a conservative opinion website. So the post is a bit misleading because it clearly takes an anti-vaxx stance (regarding vaccination of children), while appearing to be a reputable outlet.
This post is blatantly anti-vaxx. It encourages vaccine fear and labels the COVID-19 vaccination as experimental.
This is a news article that relays information about a vaccine mandate at entertainment venues in Taiwan. The post itself does not take a stance on this information.
This tweeter claims that HIV is contained inside vaccines. She is spreading false information to generate fear about immunization.

The post implies that vaccination is ineffective because people still contract the virus when vaccinated, while also criticizing vaccine mandates. This is misleading, because anti-vaxxers often argue that the vaccine doesn't stop a person from contracting a disease. They fail to acknowledge that the vaccine makes the disease less severe.
This is an informational post about a trucker convoy entering a specific area of the U.S. It's void of opinion.
This is a sympathetic post regarding a pro-vaccine person's approach to dealing with anger towards anti-vaxxers. They take an approach of "pity" to allow themselves to feel at peace with the world.

This tweet criticizes vaccine mandates and claims some kind of conspiracy theory about the Omicron variant and a control group for death. The post is obviously skeptical of vaccines, and of the politicians and officials who instated public health measures.

This doctor, who has been called into question for his controversial rejection of COVID-19 lockdowns and mask wearing, tweets that the government coerced people into getting vaccinated, which is not true. He also claims that government mandates reduce trust in public health measures, which is a controversial claim.
Tweeter refers to Jennette Young being criticized for saying she didn't want a certain age range taking AstraZeneca and Breakfast News host Lisa Millar using that to question vax safety.
In response to a tweet about a 20-year-old who died of COVID-19, tweeter suggests that vaccines don't work and most people with COVID-19 are vaccinated.
Tweeter is unable to go to a concert because of vaccine mandates and says they think it's wrong.

This tweet shares a video of an anti-vaxx woman who calls herself a GP, yet in the video she says she mainly gives BOTOX to clients. The tweet celebrates this woman and promotes freedom of choice by calling vaccine mandates into question. The post is misleading because the "GP" in the video is not working in the field of immunology.

This tweet makes a sweeping generalization about the type of people, and their politics, that would agree with vaccine mandates. They imply that liberal types, or environmentalists, would also support vaccine mandates. Therefore, this post politicizes vaccine mandates and is misleading.
This post celebrates a man who was previously anti-vaxx, who got vaccinated along with his son after getting discharged from something.

This post is pro-vaccine, however it is making claims about government that may not be accurate. The post appears to be a jab at Australia's Scott Morrison and the way that government handled vaccine roll-out. The tweeter implies Australia should order more vaccines, yet Canada was criticized for ordering the most per capita in the world, thus creating shortages in the global south.

This post contains false information because it says masking cuts off oxygen. The tweeter also claims that they do not need the vaccine because they are "fit and health," which has nothing to do with how the virus effects an individual body.

This woman posted information about her household's vaccination status, saying that the only person in the house that contracted Omicron was the one who did not have a booster. The post is, therefore, clearly pro-vaxx.

This post is in response to an anti-vaxx type post. Anti-vaxxers claim that the vaccine is not effective because a fully vaccinated person will still get COVID-19. Yet this tweeter shows frustration because they feel it should be common knowledge that vaccines reduce the risk of serious illness, rather than making a person completely unable to contract the virus.

It's a tweet of an article about Russia's Sputnik vaccine. The tweet says that the Russian people don't trust the vaccine and so it probably doesn't work or isn't safe. It does not argue against all vaccines just Russia's.
There is no information in the tweet, it's is just the user saying they are against government mandates and will not get the vaccine.
It's a direct tweet of an article about how right-wing, religious conservatives are split about vaccine safety.

This is an anti-vaxx post. It claims that natural immunity is effective, meaning that by contracting the virus we can stop the spread. But that is ludicrous because many people would have extreme reactions to contracting the virus while unvaccinated.

This tweet says that Africa's vaccination rate is only 15%, which is a number that was reported by the WHO. The tweet links this low rate to anti-vaxxers spreading disinformation, which may or may not be partially true.
It argues that vaccine mandates are more about controlling the working class than about public health. The context is missing but the far-right, freedom loving implications are there.
This tweet criticises the way that the NFL, this coach in particular, can do things that risk COVID exposure but still fire players who are unvaccinated.
Tweeter clarifies how a politician said omicron was not a reason to halt an election but also used the rise in infections to encourage people to get the booster.

This post claims that vaccines are ineffective and that they can kill people, which is misinformation. It also is worried about the consistency about the required boosters needed for achieving virus resistance.

This tweet is in reply to a pro-vaccine tweet that called out a public figure who was spreading disinformation. This tweet disagrees with that tweet. Although the point about the national 30% is not clear, it is clear they are criticizing something to do with vaccine effectiveness. It appears that he's claiming pro-vaccine people are spreading misinformation, which is misinformation.

This tweet is not entirely clear, but it is a sarcastic reply to a pro-vaccine comment. This tweet seems to be saying that vaccines are not related to asymptomatic carriers, to support an argument that vaccines are not required to protect unvaccinated people.
It's mocking how people ignore the numbers that show the efficacy of the vaccine, which in this case seem accurate.

The tweeter posted an article that is likely fake, from an unverified news source. It claims a doctor accidentally injected a baby with an adult vaccine dose, as a way to build distrust for the medical system.
This post is clearly a criticism of anti-vaxxers because the article it links to is a very sarcastic take on why anti-vaxxers can't and shouldn't compare themselves to Holocaust victims.
criticism_other: People who compare vaccine mandates to the Holocaust

meaning: This post is about a family's decision to get their kids vaccinated and it clearly states why they believe in vaccination. The post frames vaccination as an exciting experience.

This post is grounded in disinformation because it says Fauci is working with China and that a strong immune system is enough to combat COVID-19 without the vaccine. The post also insults fact-checkers and accuses them of being members of the "left."
This post reports data that was released by the U.K. government from the The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation about vaccine effectiveness in children.

The links within and to this post is not working. It is not possible to understand what this tweeter means about the Big Push, nor is it possible to understand what African country this post refers to. Therefore, it is not possible to know if the information is true or false. But the post is definitely pro-vaccine.
This tweeter criticizes Fauci for taking a pro-vaccine stance. The tweeter implies that the Merck antiviral drug, which would treat COVID-19, is a sufficient replacement to vaccination.

The post criticizes people who have taken all of the recommended vaccines. It claims that vaccination is ineffective because people still get COVID-19 anyway. This is false information because the vaccine is intended to reduce illness caused by the virus, not remove it completely.

This tweeter is claiming that his brother suffered severe side effects from the vaccination but has not given any details or proof of this statement. No mention of the brother's medical history was provided, what vaccine they took or what other complications were involved, so this is disinformation and harbours fear.

This tweeter promotes vaccine hesitation by posting a testimonial video from pro mountain biker, Kyle Warner, who claims to have lost his career after taking the vaccine. Kyle claims the vaccine gave him arthritis, among other things, however these reports were not verified in reputable media sources.
The is a poster to the public, posted by a theatre in Norfolk. It contains information about when people could attend their pop-up vaccination clinic.

This tweeter criticizes the Trucker Convoy for being bad patriots. By posting this video, they imply that the convoy supporters are not real men because they are afraid of a "boo boo" from the vaccine. The post also raises the point that mandates would not be needed if people just acted as good patriots and got the shot.

This post promotes anxiety around vaccines, equating a scary in-flight moment with the uncertainty they felt will getting vaccinated. This tweeter was clearly unsure about getting vaccinated and communicates fear to the public.

This tweet posts a chart, without mentioning the source, and claims that the vaccine is not effective because death rates are still rising, despite vaccination. This post could generate fear about vaccine effectiveness.

Although this post appears to be neutral, and a simple repost of a NYPost article about vaccine mandates being halted, it comes from a person who has an anti-vaxx, Christian perspective. The post is used to support that person's identity.
The tweeter promotes misinformation by explaining that the COVID-19 vaccine affects people's nervous systems so they can be controlled by aliens.
The tweeter is implying Monique Morley, a celebrity from the Bachelor, was hospitalized due to the Pfizer vaccine.
The tweeter claims teachers who were sitting socially distanced in Australia were arrested for disagreeing with vaccine mandates.
The tweeter is criticizing those who compare vaccines and the Holocaust.
The tweeter shares an article about how Anthony Fauci shared vaccine misinformation on a podcast. The article is from Breitbart News, a far-right news organization that is not rated as credible.
The tweeter shares an article from The Guardian about health department warnings for vaccine mandates for National Health Service workers in England.
The tweeter compares anti-vaxxers who are upset about their freedom to nationalist mentalities in North Korea.
Editor-in-chief for a community-focused media outlet in Kyiv shares that metros are nearly empty and taxi prices are increasing due required vaccinations in all metros.
The tweeter thinks Joe Biden made vaccines mandatory for political reasons. They also shared an article from Business Insider, which explained Biden had said he wouldn't implement mandates.
Tweeter is criticizing anti-vax Republicans and Fox News's hypocritical stance on vaccines.
The tweet just summarizes the news of the day with regards to vaccines, testing  and COVID-19.
Tweeter is asking everyone to get vaccinated so that she can get back to a normal life without restrictions.
The tweeter explains it is wrong to let Bradley Beal play in the NBA when he's not vaccinated, when Kyrie Irving is being forced to sit out.

This comment is situated within a thread about a new antiviral, Paxlovid, that was released to treat COVID-19. The tweeter is replying to another tweeter who was concerned that anti-vaxxers will use all of this drug's stock as a replacement for vaccination. This tweet states they believe anti-vaxxers will also not take this antiviral and placed vaccine in quotes, so they appear to be critical of vaccination.

This tweet, released by the Peterborough City Council, promotes vaccination and states that travel will be far less complicated and expensive for travellers who are vaccinated. This is a government message to the public.
The tweeter is asking why the definition of vaccine changed for COVID-19 shots.
The tweet shares information from a website called NewsDeal that discusses support for vaccines for children. The article is no longer available and the website is not credible.
The tweeter, who has been fully vaccinated, shares their opinion that getting vaccinated should not be a requirement, but rather a choice.
Tweeter expressed his anger at Ontario's Premier because vaccines were unavailable at a pharmacy, where he booked an appointment for a booster shot.
Tweeter is insinuating that vaccine rollout in BC had something to do with deaths from COVID-19, by providing unverified information about COVID deaths between October 2020 and September 2021.
The tweeter shares her story about having concerning symptoms after her first Pfizer vaccine. Her doctor said it's probably anxiety. She refused to get the second vaccine.
Tweeter is replying to another tweeter who wrote vaccine is unnecessary for people with natural immunity.
Tweeter shared an article from the website of LifeSite news which published a piece of fake news about ER patients showing mysterious symptoms after getting two shots.
Tweeter is criticizing people for being afraid of vaccines but not something that damages the kidney.
Twetter notes tobacco's harmful impact and calls on Health Canada not to support Medicago's COVID vaccine because the company has ties with a tobacco manufacturer.
The tweet shares an article from the Daily Sceptic, an untrustworthy website, which claims the UK Health Security Agency deleted evidence of the vaccine's high infection rates.
The tweeter promotes the idea that big pharmaceutical companies and the government started a fake pandemic to promote mass vaccinations.
Tweeter debunked an antivaxxer's claim about the harmfulness of 5G and that vaccinated people are not safe.

This post claims people should not trust vaccine effectiveness because "big pharma" and WHO control the narrative. And the post promotes other ways, although it is not clear which ways, on how to boost immunity.
Tweeter is criticizing Australian politicians by hinting that they kept public health interventions in place to preserve their political legacy.
Tweeter retells scientists' comments about 'herd immunity' in 2020 and relates it with a recent understanding of COVID-19 to insinuate that scientists did not know better.
The tweeter shows dislike for a big group of students in Florida who gathered with no COVID-19 safety protocols and had unnecessary mask-exemption medical notes.
The tweeter promotes misinformation by saying the COVID-19 vaccine causes demyelinating disorders, such as mad cow disease.
The tweeter expresses a desire for changes and leniency within Canadian labour codes for unvaccinated workers.
The tweeter is explaining a thread where an anti-vaxxer contracted COVID-19, got very sick and upon her second visit to the hospital received monoclonal antibodies.
The tweeter promotes misinformation by sharing an untrustworthy article from the Daily Sceptic and claiming the COVID-19 vaccine will harm children.
A far-right journalist criticizes The New York Times for not covering the border crisis effectively. The crisis she includes people who crossed into the U.S. without COVID-19 tests and vaccines.

This is a re-post of a news article hosted on a conservative political news website. The tweeter does not provide any commentary on their beliefs, rather states the information contained in the story.
This is a news article stating facts that the FDA could authorize the vaccine for kids, as of Oct.2021. No opinion or commentary of any kind is included in the post and the facts appear to be true.

This tweet is clearly anti-vaxx and accuses public health officials of damaging the public my mandating vaccines. The post is misleading because it does not consider the severity of the emergency that the pandemic brought.

This post appears to be pro-vaccine, unless it is mocking what pro-vaccine people say. The tweeter pleads to the public to get vaccinated, so that their life is not put at risk. The language is a bit dramatic so I flagged this post as misleading. The person claims that they could die if others don't get vaxxed, even though they are vaxxed, and no insight into this risk is provided. Essentially, this post could stoke vaccine hesitation, because the tweeter proposes that vaccines don't lower the risk of death.
Not enough context is provided in this tweet to understand what it refers to, however it appears to be pro-vaccine because the tweeter publicly declares he is vaxxed.

The tweeter is critical of the athlete in the posted video. The tweeter states that this man quit two teams and also faked a vaccine passport. The tweeter calls him a "shit head" and clearly disapproves of this anti-vaxx behaviour.
It is a traveller's app saying that New Year's celebration can be attended at Times Square with proof of vaccine. But the site is no longer available.
The tweet promotes misinformation through an article that questions vaccine mandates and whether COVID-19 is real. It also implicitly compares vaccines and the Holocaust.

Tweeter is saying that non-COVID deaths were also passed on as 
 being a result of long COVID. It's a reply to a tweet with unverified graphs showing more people died of non-COVID illnesses in the USA.
The tweeter promotes misinformation by claiming pandemic restrictions will never be lifted and no one will be free. He implies the government and health officials are lying to the public.
The tweeter promotes misinformation by saying masks, testing and vaccines are all ineffective. They also encourage others to not comply with mandates and restrictions.
The tweeter shares an article from The Guardian about how AstraZeneca has sold 2.2 billion COVID-19 vaccines in its first nine months.
The tweeter shares their opinion that children should not be vaccinated, based on an untrustworthy article from The DC Patriot about a vote from the FDA to approve vaccinations for children.

This anti-vaxx tweet says that cops are too concerned with power to do what the tweeter considers the right thing: Quitting the force due to vaccine mandates. The tweeter seemingly implies that police are corrupt because they chickened out of their threats to leave the force due to vaccine mandates and went back to work.
This tweet celebrates two scientists involved with developing CORBEVAX. The post is clearly pro-vaccine and it contains an NPR article link, which is a reputable news source.
This person is questioning people who claim they know people who died from the COVID-19 vaccine. The tweeter is requesting proof of those claims.
This student is stating facts about when they will get the vaccine. No clear commentary is provided.
This is an informational post and does not pass commentary. It appears to be fact about Ukraine and how deaths rise due to faked vaccine passports.

This tweet is critical of far-right messaging. It claims that the far-right skips over facts (such as "we don't want to take the safe and effective vaccine) and replaces them with sensational claims, such as saying the government is tyrannical.
The post is claiming that a nurse says vaccines are dangerous ("weapons") but provides no proof of that claim. This post builds distrust in vaccines.
This tweet is commending a person who works to get her coworkers vaccinated. It's also promoting pop-up clinics.

This is an outraged and concerned reply to a video of young girls who fell unconscious after being vaccinated which is common. The user, in their bio, says the vaccine killed their daughter. It seems the girls in the video were completely fine and the tweet is reactionary.
This tweet expresses concern for the Omicron variant and hope that more people in the US will get vaccinated.
It's a sexist tweet expressing extreme discontent with the mask and vaccine mandates. They make a point that mental health is affected by mandates.
This tweet is just an insult and baseless critique of politicians who enforce vaccine mandates.

This is an anti-vaxx tweet because it is placed in reply to a photo depicting a man shaking a blanket. The text below that image says there is a risk of heart attack if a person shakes the duvet to hard.
This post is trying to debunk misinformation about deaths that happened. The tweeter lists names and says they didn't die from the vaccine.
This is a repost of a reputable article with no comment, opinion or bias revealed.

BLF, a pan-African political movement with extreme ideologies, is confirming the organization's opposition to vaccine mandates. The misinformation is in the thread it quotes, which accuses the current SA regime of forcing teachers to get vaccinated and implied something Satanic about it.
Tweeter is calling PM Trudeau an "anti-semite", totalitarian, Nazi supporter by quoting a piece of fake news about doctors calling for an end to mass vaccination.
Tweeter is sharing what the vaccine cannot do in terms of full immunity against COVID-19 and preventing the spread of the disease.
This is an informational post and does not pass commentary. It appears to be fact about Ukraine and how deaths rise due to faked vaccine passports.

This post appears to be anti-vaxx because it undermines the role vaccines play in reducing illness when the virus is contracted. It claims that the "jab" is not enough and mentions something unclear about hospital care as a solution.
This tweet states that Fox News viewers are throwing death threats at a pro-vaccine news anchor, Neil Cavuto. The tweet is clearly pro-vaccine and sympathetic towards Cavuto's position.
This is a promotion for a pro-vaccine campaign to vaccinate youth between the ages of 12-14.

This is an anti-vaxx tweet. It claims vaccines kill and that public health officials lied about the effectiveness. They use some percentages about the vaccine that appear to be false and they discredit the fact that vaccines lower illness by saying vaccines don't prevent immunity.
This is an information post yet has a pro-vaccine stance because it's happy to announce that an Omicron vaccine would be ready in March.
This is an information post regarding the number of vaccines administered in C’garh. No commentary is posted here.
This is an informational post, telling the public how to get their vaccination records. No commentary posted here.

This tweet promotes alternative or natural remedies to COVID-19 and accuses pharmaceutical companies of being money, not health, orientated. The tweeter posted a video about monoclonal antibody treatment and made a request for such approaches to come to the U.K., while simultaneously attacking the U.K. government and health officials.

This is a tabloid-esque article posted on a site that is not reputable. The article claims that many experts believe the pandemic is nearly over and that Omicron is a replacement to vaccines. It does not site any expert's names in its claims. And it claims that people are not getting sick from Omicron, which simply isn't true.
This tweet stokes vaccine fear. The woman claims she is more afraid of the vaccine than the COVID-19 virus.

This woman is an anti-vaxxer who claims CNN left important information out of an article about vaccine effectiveness by not reporting that a man who contracted COVID-19 was vaccinated. This post raises skepticism towards vaccine effectiveness and does not acknowledge that the purpose of vaccines is to reduce infection, rather than prevent it completely.

This tweet supports the quick installation of vaccine passports and says that the health system could collapse if they are not put into place quickly. The tweet is critical of conservative government and it writes that people are dying due to a delay in instating vaccine passports.

This tweeter criticizes Biden for not releasing information to the public about the vaccine. He posts a Breitbart article, which is not a fact-checked news source, about how Biden stalled on releasing information about vaccine mandates at the work place. The tweet is clearly anti-vaxx.

Tweeter in his original tweet insinuated that Australian cricketer Shane Warne died because of the COVID vaccine. Then he selectively uses a guidance paper from U.K. govt. on a rare heart condition to support his point.
Tweeter debunks the myth that the U.S. never enforced any vaccine mandate by sharing a piece of news from 1981 about school boards banning unvaccinated high school students.
The tweet is just giving updates about the availability of vaccines in the York region and details about locations and bookings.

Tweeter is calling an article on Bari Weiss' site Common Sense "disingenuous" because it did not mention non-adherence to vaccine mandate as one of the reasons the writer joined a conservative college from a liberal one.
The tweet quotes a global health researcher's opinion column on the Globe and Mail about needs-based vaccine production and distribution.
Tweeter is saying that it is not unusual for vaccinated people to get COVID-19 again but it ends well, given people follow the protocols and do not spread the disease.
Tweeter conducts a Q&A thread using CDC and ACAcamps as sources. Tweet answers the likeness of spreading COVID-19 after vaccination by saying you are less likely to get and spread it.
Tweeter reposts Fox News article and suggests Biden and Fauci give uneven COVID-19 science and want America to live in fear while other states want to move forward.

This is a link to a story about Maine's healthcare worker vaccine mandate. The news story is anti-vaccine and highlights the negative impact of the mandate, but the tweet itself is accurate and indifferent about the mandate.
This tweet is largely about the political situation in Alabama, but it argues that vaccine hesitancy is a problem in the state and is motivated by Trump supporters and conservative politics.

It argues there is a difference between being anti-vaccine and being anti-mandate. It also says the vaccine has not been properly tested or developed, promoting the idea that the COVID vaccine is fake.

A retweet of a far right news article, the tweet itself uses conspiracy theory language to imply that there is an effort to conceal information about the vaccine. It also supports anti-vaccine policy.

This tweet is hard to decipher due to strange language being used. It appears to support the video that it posted, and it appears to support nurses who are vaccinating the population under impossible conditions. The video is also hard to understand, but it appears to depict a woman who is angry at anti-vaxx, anti-vaccine mandate protesters.

This is a comment on anti-vaxxers. The tweeter points out that other vaccines, such as the polio vaccine, required boosters as well. This post is pro-vaccine because it promotes education about vaccines.
Tweeter replied to a question about getting COVID saying how many times he and his children became infected before getting vaccinated.
Tweeter used an old photo of Trump riding a truck from 2017 to show that U.S. truckers are gearing up for an anti-vaccine protest in February 2022.
Tweeter used screenshots of news heading of several athletes' deaths from cardiac arrest, falsely claiming that the deaths were caused by the COVID vaccine and calling it "conspiracy facts".
Tweeter is criticizing that vaccine mandates did not encourage enough people to get vaccinated, by quoting an unverified percentage of people who got shots following the mandates.
Tweeter points to the irony that two Supreme Court lawyers arguing against Biden's vaccine mandate tested positive. The news was published on Jan 7, 2022.
Tweeter is using biblical expressions like a prayer to say that vaccines can save people from the Omicron variant.
Tweeter is calling President Biden a coward for not being present in Washington DC during an anti-vaccine protest. Biden's schedule for that particular day could not be verified.
Tweeter criticizes people for needing to be bribed to get the vaccine despite it being accessible.
Update on vaccine requirements from travellers when arriving in Marinduque.
Tweeter addresses the high amount of deaths in group homes and how vaccine rollout in Australia failed to prioritize them.

This tweet argues that pharmaceutical companies made a fake vaccine in order to profit from the pandemic. It uses false information about break through cases to support the idea that there is a conspiracy between companies and governments.

This tweet argues that vaccine mandates are dividing the country, implying the belief that putting public health over freedom is more harmful than beneficial. It implies we have lost a huge list of freedoms, exaggerating the effect of mandates.
A retweet from the Boston Medical Centre of a Boston Globe article reporting on vaccine development for children.

The tweet links to a pro-vaccine article. It explains that linking abortion to vaccines is unscientific. It implies that often religious anti-vaxxers are also anti-abortion, but for different reasons than they say.
This tweet is in response to a woman who posts an anti-vaxx rally poster. This tweet is pro-vaccine because it rejects the need for a vaccine mandate protest march.
This post encourages freedom of choice around vaccines, and it is situated within a thread that discusses vaccine passports.

This post accuses vaccines of maiming children, which is disinformation. And it complains about the lack of consistent messaging about the need for boosters, as well as the lack of freedoms due to vaccine mandates -- even though the third vaccine was never required for a vaccine passport in many countries.
support_other: Conspiracy theories about vaccines maiming kids

meaning: This man seems to be supporting vaccine passports by saying that he's had one to track all of his lifelong vaccines since he was born. The tweet is pro-vaccine.
This post supports vaccines by saying that the risks associated with taking one are "rare," in comparison to the risks associated with contracting COVID-19.

This post passes on information to the public to not clog up telephone lines by calling their GPs for information. The post encourages the public to wait for the government's announcements regarding vaccination plans.
criticism_other: The ways the public seeks information

meaning: This tweet contains information that does not have a source link. It claims that a number of severe adverse effects happened to people who took the vaccine. The post intends to create fear and disinformation around vaccination. The site also claims that over 18,000 deaths occurred due to the Pfizer vaccine. The BBC reported that there is no link to some deaths that have been reported after a person was vaccinated, stating that the deaths were linked to other issues.

It is an NBC headline repeated several times, the article is about how health care workers are quitting because of vaccine mandates. It implies that the mandates are affecting essential workers and industries like healthcare.

This post seems to be factual, although it was hard to verify the news about drug regulators being able to analyze data through a third party. This Tweet appears to be neutral and accurate, although the Epoch Times is not the most reliable news source in terms of fact checking and it pushes a right-wing bias.

This tweet argues that vaccines are ineffective, it is a reply about quoting a higher number for vaccine effectiveness than is accurate by 30%. The tweet is misleading about the lack of data, but they are correct that the previous tweet was wrong.

This post is not necessarily anti-vaxx, but it is questioning how long the second vaccine is effective for, once it is administered into the body. The tweeter says they have health issues, giving weight to their concerns.
It's a tweet from President Biden about free vaccines, masks, and tests. It also links to the US government's COVID information page.
It is an anti-vaccine Rebel News tweet linking to a petition to support Kyrie Irving's choice not to take the vaccine.

A reply to a tweet that has been deleted, but Rick is saying that his wife and her coworkers would quit rather than get the vaccine but the US Supreme Court ruled against vaccine mandates in the workplace.

This post is from an anti-vaxxer who complains about being called a Trump supporter and anti-vaxxer by their social networks. The post is not written in a coherent way, however it does seem to accuse their friends on the other, "left" side as having no brains.

This doctor was suspended. His post claims that children are not at risk of contracting COVID-19 (which is not true) and he says children may instead suffer from pericarditis if vaccinated. The U.S. CDC estimated that two cases of myocarditis or pericarditis per 100,000 second doses of mRNA vaccine were a possibility. This suspended doctor accuses Mr. Andrews of spreading misinformation, while he himself is.
support_other: Disinformatino about the risks COVID present to children

meaning: This tweet argues against vaccine mandates, and against liberals who support vaccination. It also says that many working class people are against mandates which is misleading because anti-vaxxers come from anywhere.
It's a tweet about some vaccine data, which showed that there is no newly discovered risk to getting vaccinated.
This person is calling out a Freedom Convoy type event in London, UK. She's arguing against a group of anti-vaxxers who believe the UK government is a rigged democracy.
It's a reply to an article about Prince Charles getting COVID, blaming it on vaccine inefficacy. It's using a single case to argue that the vaccine as a whole doesn't work.
This tweet is saying that COVID vaccines could be administered in schools like other vaccines children get.

This tweet is a response to another tweet that stated vaccination helps get rid of the virus. This tweet builds fear towards the vaccine, stating that the vaxx itself makes variants. Various reputable news sources state that vaccines do not create variants.

This tweet criticizes a "liberal" MSNBC show host for saying that vaccines will stop the virus in their tracks. The post is disinformation because it builds up distrust towards vaccine effectiveness. Vaccines have never claimed to stop the possibility of infection, rather they claim to reduce illness when an infection is contracted.

It's a reply to the argument that COVID vaccine mandates would be the same as hep B vaccine mandates. It says COVID is different because the vaccines don't provide sterilising immunity, it is misleading because neither does the hep B vaccine.
The user says that they haven't had COVID and are triple vaccinated with plans to get the next booster shot.

This is a link to an article about Cuba's vaccine production and vaccination rates, the user is praising Cuba's vaccine production and vaccination rate. Arguing that the global response should follow the same strategy.
This tweet, notably from Florida, argues against the government's promotion of the vaccine, as well as mandates.
It's a tweet about a vaccination clinic at Detroit's airport, urging people to go an get vaccinated.

This person is arguing that because a single person who is vaccinated died of COVID that vaccines do not prevent death. It misrepresents the vaccine effectiveness claims made by the CDC or vaccine producers.
The tweet calls into question why the number of Covid-19 infections has increased despite the fact that a high percentage of people are now vaccinated.
The tweet claims that secret recordings obtained by a federal government whistleblower show that the government is covering up adverse effects of the Covid-19 vaccine.
This person argues that even if 100% of people in the United Kingdom were vaccinated, the omicron variant would still not have been ignored.

This tweet is written by someone who openly identifies as a Project Veritas Google Whistleblower. The tweet includes a video that claims a healthy individual became very sick after getting vaccinated. The video may have been edited to contain false information.
This tweet claims that UK Health Security Agency data shows that Covid-19 infection rates are highest among the fully vaccinated, and growing fastest the more vaccinated someone is.

This tweet shares a chart that shows the percentage of vaccinated care home staff, between a certain period, after a state vaccination mandate was implemented. The tweeter says that vaccination mandates make homes safer for elderly people, based on the data in the graph.

This tweet is tricky. It claims to be pro-vaccine, however the rest of the statement undermines that. The tweeter is clearly anti-vaxx, likely posing as pro-vaxx, to undermine trust in government and pharmaceutical companies.
This post refers to making schools a safer place during COVID-19. The tweeter is suggesting some areas to consider, to mitigate those risks.

The Governor of Oklahoma declares that he is vaccinated but that he doesn't believe it's the government's job to dictate what people do in terms of getting vaxxed. He ultimately promotes pro-choice and liberty in this video. He used the word "force" in relation to the president's vaccine mandates in this post, which seems misleading, therefore this post is tagged as misinformation. Governments were not forcing people to get vaxxed.

This tweet isn't obviously pro- or anti-vaxx, however it is clearly asking for consistent mandates between businesses. The tweeter asks why fitness and restaurant patrons must follow mandates, while small business employees and patrons don't have to.

This post is a criticism of Pope Francis, who supported vaccination, yet who also opposed abortion. The tweeter is making a comment about freedom of choice regarding one's body, and likely comes from an anti-vaxx perspective because she discredits Francis's decision with her statement.

This post perpetuates vaccine hesitation. It claims that contracting the virus provides better protection than that vaccine. It also claims that COVID-19 doesn't hurt the young or healthy, which is disinformation. It also states that vaccines don't prevent infection, which is true, but doesn't mention that vaccines lower the risk of death.
support_other: Immunity through exposure to the virus

meaning: This tweet is sharing that a restaurant in Harlem, New York was vaccinating people in the community to combat vaccine hesitancy.

This tweet, which appears to be from a bot, is sharing a news piece from a questionable source about the negative impacts of a loss of funding for Covid treatments and vaccines on those who are uninsured.
support_other: Equal access to treatment and vaccination

meaning: This tweet is relatively true in terms of fact. This is a freedom of choice statement, from a person who does not want to be vaxxed. Although the risk of transmission between humans and animals, and vice versa is present, the risk is quite low.

It's not clear who this post is referring to, or what the details are. But it appears the tweeter is a woman who called the vaccine into question was silenced. Therefore, this is an anti-vaxx statement.

This tweet is a comment on the price of the pandemic. The tweeter is very concerned about the cost of vaccination. The tweet could be anti-vaxx, but it's not certain, so I labelled it as unsure about the vaccine. The number of 1M is hard to verify yet the remainder of this opinion post is accurate.

This tweet says the vaccine is garbage because it acts as a screen door that would still let things inside your body. This is misinformation because no vaccine guaranteed 100% prevention in contracting the virus. It offers reduced illness instead.

This tweet accuses an Australian politician of turning a blind eye to high COVID-19 death rates in Eastern Australia (Perth). The tweet also states that vaccination rates are low there, correlating that to the deaths.

This post is asking Sajid Javid, a British politician and Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, to remove COVID-19 vaccine mandates. The tweeter also asks why lawyers can't take the mandates down and posts a link for a crowd funding campaign to remove those mandates.
This is a pro-vaccine post. It encourages people to get a second vaccine, by promoting that Traditional Council Leader Chief MP Mahlangu got vaccinated. This post promotes vaccination to the public.

This post is anti-vaxx because it questions why mandates have not been removed in certain parts of the country. The post is misleading because it says mandates had been removed everywhere except Ottawa, but that was not true as of February 2022.
This is a rude opinion post that criticizes people who declare their vaccination status on online profiles.

This post is a sarcastic comment. It refers to a news article about a U.S. hospital that doesn't have enough vaccinated nurses to work there. The post implies that the vaccine mandates put a stop to that particular facility, and therefore the tweeter does not support the mandates.

This post does not promote or criticize anything. However the statement is a bit misleading. According to Our World in Data, over 83% of Hong Kong has already been vaccinated, which is a decent percentage.
This tweet reply challenges an earlier tweet that claims vaccines are bad for you. It asks the original tweeter to name which sources they are drawing on to conclude that vaccines are bad for health.

It's not clear who this post is referring to, or what the details are. But it appears the tweeter is a woman who called the vaccine into question was silenced. Therefore, this is an anti-vaxx statement.

This is a pro-vaccination tweet. The tweeter's claim that Omicron wiped out Delta because people were vaccinated is misleading though. Omicron did not wipe out Delta, according to various recent news reports.
This is a news post. The news link posted here is from a reputable outlet. The tweet states that democrat Gov. Newsom is supported in California counties that have high vaccination rates.

This is a concerned citizen who has noticed the paranoid of the conspiracy theory group QANON. QANON has been linked to violent crimes and delusional beliefs. This post warns of the possibility that QANON could do harm to health care workers, because QANON members don't believe in science.

This post accuses the government of China (the tweeter uses CCP for Chinese Communist Party) for making the COVID-19 virus, to kill people. It also warns of a vaccine disaster, therefore this is an anti-vaxx post.

This tweeter is saying that the vaccine was an experiment because the FDA won't release documents regarding the trails for 75 years. The tweeter did not mention that it will take that long to redact personal information found in the documents, thus slowing the release time down. However it is a valid concern that it should take that long. That doesn't discount that this person is generating conspiracy theories about vaccine hesitation though.

This is an anti-vaxxer's post. It calls the government tyrannical and it implies the government is in bed with media. They tweeter posts a video to support their statements, stating that Aussies are in alignment with his beliefs, as if to give those beliefs weight.

This is an opinion post by an anti-vaxxer. There is no misinformation because the post states their wishes about lockdowns, even if those wishes are unsafe given the global pandemic. The person wants all restrictions removed regarding COVID-19 mandates, and requests that life is like before the pandemic again.

This anti-vaxxer promotes fear around the vaccine by posting a link from a discredited Alberta-based doctor, Dr. Daniel Nagase, who claimed that Ivermectin was a cure for COVID-19 and that the vaccine is dangerous.
The tweet implies that the vaccine has not been properly studied and that it's unsafe for children. It's a response to a politician urging people to vaccinate their children.
This post is trying to debunk misinformation about deaths that happened. The tweeter lists names and says they didn't die from the vaccine.

This is a somewhat nonsensical comment. It is an observation stating that the tweeter believes someone appears to be vaxxed. No video or photo is provided, so it's hard to understand the connotation of this tweet.

This seems to be a relay of information that this tweeter heard. This is not an official news outlet, it appears to be an independent person. No comment is passed on the vaccine drive that this tweeter mentioned.
Tweeter shares his own experience of long-COVID and quotes a piece of news about a study done at the University of Oxford about the harmful effects of long-COVID.
Tweeter quotes a chart to defend his argument that fatality was high in 2021 among unvaccinated people in the US.

This tweet by the Liberty Justice Center says that forcing workers to choose between getting vaccinated and losing their jobs is unlawful and unethical. It includes a link to a questionable Daily Wire news piece about former NIH director Francis Collins.
The tweet is claiming that the Trump administration intentionally politicized vaccines for more votes, which is why there are less protests around other vaccination campaigns.
support_other: a bipartisan, apolitical approach to vaccines and public health

meaning: This tweet is anti-vaxx because it spreads misinformation about the effectiveness of vaccines, especially in their relation to reaching herd immunity.
It's a straightforward report about the FDA's announcement that the vaccine is safe and effective in children.
Tweeter says he was jabbed by forced in India, but it is not clear if he meant COVID19 vaccine. It cannot be verified independently if he was vaccinated by force.

This tweet is providing context on Dr.Golden, who wants schools open. The intention of the tweet is to raise awareness about what that Dr.Golden does (sees patients virtually) even though she asks for schools to open up. The intention is to show readers that Dr.Golden does not practise what she preaches.
This anti-vaxxer is criticizing Illinois superintendents, saying that they are pushing vaccines. He questions why they are doing that, stating it's a distraction from the roles they were hired to do.
This post is pushing alternative remedies, because it is in reply to a tweet about hydroxychloroquine and bleach being used to treat COVID-19. This is an anti-vaxx post.

This post itself is hard to decipher and the link did not work. However, I googled Robert Young and his website contains a similar article with a similar headline. That article is geared towards allowing readers to make informed decisions on whether or not to take the vaccine. Therefore this article promotes vaccine hesitation.

This post seems rather neutral, however the tweeter's page is full of anti-democratic posts and she seems to be posting this as a way to undermine vaccine mandates. She is twisting racism to suit her cause.

This post supports world-wide vaccination. The tweeter is a journalist for the Daily Mail, whose article is posted under the statement. The information seems accurate and the post is pro-vaccine because he wrote that mutations happened due to a lack of vaccination.

Tweeter is worried that the COVID-19 restrictions are being lifted too soon, citing a recent report about a child dying from the disease.  She claims, without any basis, that there are more deaths now compared to the time before the vaccine became available.
