Tweeter is replying to a thread about vaccine mandates in workplaces and sees mandates as coercion. He implies that the COVID vaccines were not well researched.
Tweeter quotes a report about the low rate of vaccination in rural America saying a higher incidence of the disease would put more pressure on the rural areas' limited medical care.
Tweeter shares a graph showing COVID hospitalization in Harris County and hopes that a higher rate of vaccination will prevent a surge in COVID hospitalization in the future.
Tweeter is glad that the Indian government provided free COVID vaccines.

This post essentially argues that the Republican Party should not have done anything when the COVID-19 virus arose. The tweeter seems to imply that the government should have let people die off. I flagged this post as misleading because the intention here is dark and absurd, even though it's an opinion post.

This post is filled with disinformation because the tweeter claims more children will die from the vaccine than those who are saved. The tweeter says that "experts" said this, but gives no proof to that statement.
This tweet is not anti-vaccine, however it shows concern for getting multiple vaccines at once. It's not clear what the tweeter means about vaccines damaging her past.
criticism_other: Taking too many vaccines at once

meaning: This post is not promoting or criticizing anything. It is making a comment about the ability of vaccine passports to allow freedom of activity for vaccinated people.
This is a pro-vaccine post. The tweeter presents a chart revealing the vaccination rate of a region of Pakistan and encourages people to go get their vaccine.

This tweeter is claiming that "natural immunity" is the answer to the virus, rather than testing and vaccination. Therefore this is an anti-vaxx post. It is misleading because it implies that "natural immunity" is safe for the public, even though it could kill.
support_other: "Natural Immunity" through exposure to the virus

meaning: This post is not necessarily pro-vaccine. It is pro COVID-19 restrictions, such as social distancing. It seems to undermine the effectiveness of vaccines by not mentioning that vaccines lower the risk of serious illness. The tweet reminds readers that they need to live as if there is a virus, to avoid the virus, regardless of a person's vaxx status.
This is a pro-vaccine post. The tweeter wants NZ to boost workers with the COVID-19 vaccine to prevent deaths.

This tweeter claims that they have evidence about some kind of contract that would expose vaccines as being bad. No details are given, but this is clearly an anti-vaxx post that is promoting vaccine hesitation.
It criticises news stories that make studies about 'chimeras' in virology seem risky or unsafe. It defends researchers whose work is being criticised in the media.
A direct tweet of an article about football coaches being let go because they refused to get vaccinated. The tweet is factual, but the article makes the event seem like some kind of tragedy.
The tweet argues that vaccine and mask mandates are unconstitutional, despite the fact that many are in effect and some are still under litigation.
Tweeter is falsely claiming that there have been more than 3000 deaths from vaccines. Also hints at vote miscalculation, and that President Biden and VP Harris will bring catastrophe like 9/11.

Tweeter is criticizing the JAMA medical journal.  He claims there isn't enough evidence to prove that COVID-19 does not impact pregnancy or fertility, a statement which the study, published in JAMA, used as an example of misinformation.

This tweeter is questioning vaccines because she made an earlier tweet that questions why Dr.Malone was banned from Twitter. Malone spread disinformation about the COVID-19 vaccine, which he claimed to invent, although many other scientists were involved with that development.

The article that this tweeter posted relates to a naughty video that was used to disrupt the trucker convoy. The video depicts gay cowboys and has sexual content. It was played on Trucker Convoy forums to disrupt their chat channels. Therefore this tweet is related to the Trucker Convoy, and likely rejects it, rather than having vaccine related content.

This post is criticizing the fact that an ESPN reporter was asked to leave her job due to being unvaccinated. The tweet is misleading because it claims that she is young and healthy and could not be harmed by the virus.

This is an anti-vaxxer who is claiming that vaccines are ineffective because they don't prevent the spread of COVID-19. Anti-vaxxers use that line to undermine trust in the effectiveness of vaccines. Vaccines never claimed they'd stop the contraction of the virus, they claim to reduce illness.

This post regards Obama care. The tweeter claims it created other financial issues for the American public. The tweeter is vaccinated and is not making a comment on COVID-19, rather on the state of healthcare in America. She claims clients would pay less for insurance if healthcare provided across state lines.
support_other: Healthcare across state lines to lower patient costs

meaning: This is a pro-vaccine post. It's a comment on anti-vaxxers who refuse the vaccine then use other drugs from "big pharma" to get better if they go to the hospital.
The link that this tweeter posted would not open. However, the post is clearly anti-vaxx and claims that vaccines lead to massive infection rates, which is not true.
This tweet gives information on vaccination possibilities and states that one vaccination opportunity was cancelled due to a winter storm.

This post promotes natural immunity to COVID-19 through exposure to the virus. The post links to an article that I was not able to verify as true information, posted on a tabloid-esque website. I was able to find this statement from the CDC, which contradicts this tweet: "If you have had COVID-19 before, please still get vaccinated,” said CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky.“ This study shows you are twice as likely to get infected again if you are unvaccinated. Getting the vaccine is the best way to protect yourself and others around you, especially as the more contagious Delta variant spreads around the country.”
This tweet argues that anti-vaxxers will spin information, in this case an inaccurate death count, to confirm a conspiracy theory.
A tweet from a person asking if AZ vaccine is approved for travel to the US. It seems the person is vaccinated and is genuinely asking.

This tweet is part of a reply chain discussing how the virus changes but the vaccine is still the same. Implying that pharmaceutical companies should develop new vaccines for new variants, which some companies are working on.
It is a direct link to an article about how government intervention through trucker mandates and economic relief, blamed on Trudeau, is ruining our economy.
This organization works with people with disabilities. The tweet quotes a report from Oregon Health authority on a parent who soothed the vaccine anxiety of her child, who has disabilities.
A quote tweet linking to an article about COVID cases amongst the unvaccinated, urging people to get themselves and their kids vaccinated.
It's a part of an argument about freedom of choice, saying that being unvaccinated is a choice with negative effects, medically and socially, like smoking.
Tweeter is taking the news about the resignation of two FDA officials out of context and claiming that vaccine mandates are anti-science.
The tweet uses inaccurate science to argue vaccine inefficacy as well as blame the vaccine for new strains of the virus.
Tweeter tweeted an announcement by Dr. Faucci about when children are likely to receive their shots. The news could not be verified because the link no longer exists.
This tweet argues that vaccine mandates in Australia are facist. It supports Kelly Slater's decision to be unvaccinated, and promotes freedom of choice.
The tweet is bragging about how the user is outspoken and loud in their opposition to vaccine mandates and other health interventions. It seems accurate though, I bet she was annoying about it.
The tweet argues that the pandemic is over and vaccine doses should be suspended until they can be further studied. It implies that the vaccine is more dangerous than the virus itself.
Tweeter is saying that the side effects from the COVID vaccine shots are no different from other vaccines.
Tweeter is saying that the UK did not do well in getting more people vaccinated compared to other OECD countries.
Tweeter shared a report about New Jersey republicans defying the vaccine mandate of showing proof of vaccination before entering the state's general assembly chamber.
It's a COVID-19 vaccination campaign for pregnant women by the National Health Service Toronto.
Tweeter claims that anti-vaxxers are getting fired but does not provide any verified link to support the tweet.

This is a direct link to an article that uses a scary piece of data, a 47 per cent increase in deaths, to baselessly conclude that it must be caused by the vaccine and the cause of death is being covered up.
A tweet promoting a program from Duke University working to collect global data on COVID-19 to inform a better global response to the virus.
Tweeter is insinuating that the COVID vaccines do not work by saying that Harvard which implemented the vaccine mandate had a COVID outbreak.
A direct link of an article expressing concern about the vaccine and mandates. The article is filled with speculation but the tweet itself is just asking the question.

Tweeter quotes a study on vaccine hesitancy in the US, which shows vaccine hesitancy is high among PhDs, to reply to a tweet about pilots unwilling to get vaccinated. He is implying that highly educated people do not trust vaccines.
Tweeter is supporting tennis player Novak Djokovic's to not getting vaccinated, by falsely claiming that vaccine killed 50million Africans.
Tweeter is promoting the conspiracy theory that children are in danger of learning non-binary pronouns and vaccine-induced English at school.
The tweet uses an unsourced number to make it seem like vaccine deaths are a notable portion of COVID-19 related deaths.
Tweeter is explaining why proof of vaccination for international travel still makes sense at this stage of the pandemic.
It is a direct tweet to an article about how the vaccine is not as effective against Omicron as it was for previous variants.
Tweeter is claiming that COVID vaccines won't stop the virus and public health officials' insistence on vaccination is just mental gymnastic.
Tweeter quotes an Amnesty International report on unequal access to vaccines across the globe, blaming wealthy countries and big pharma.
Tweeter is implying that the vaccine mandate is dangerous because it led to a shortage of firefighters in New York City, by quoting a report by The Epoch Times, which he republished on his website.
Tweeter is sharing her experience of encountering an anti-vaxxer who lectured about vaccine safety even though he is not a virologist.
Tweeter is saying that an indoor events centre should have remained a vaccination centre. It should not have been opened for events in Jan 2022.
Tweeter is falsely claiming that Omicron is just like the common cold and vaccinated people are more likely to get infected. He is equating booster shot advocates with Nazis.
Tweeter is replying to a conversation about a person who is apparently sharing false information about the safety of vaccines.
This is part of a thread that notes the precautionary steps taxi drivers should take while taking people to their vaccine appointments.
Tweeter is promoting a conspiracy theory that Bill Gates and big pharma are responsible for the pandemic and that they took away people's natural immunity by getting them vaccinated.
Tweeter is saying that anti-vaxxers are correlating vaccines with Omicron case numbers. They should rather look at how vaccines resulted in lower hospitalization during the Omicron wave.
This is a statement about sports leagues being vaccinated. It is pro-vaccine in nature but does not take a biased tone.
Tweeter is falsely claiming that vaccines have adverse health impacts and cannot prevent hospitalizations and deaths from COVID. He claims to be a hospital inspector but provides no proof.

This is an anti-vaxx post. It claims that natural immunity (through contracting the virus) is more effective than the "failed" vaccine. The post uses some graph to support this claim and is misleading.

This post promotes vaccine fear and conspiracy theories about the New World Order (a belief that totalitarianism is on its way). It claims that vaccination is a form of government control over the people and it attempts to create fear about vaccination.
This man says that he would have been much sicker from COVID if he did not have three vaccines. This is a pro-vaccine post.
Tweeter is saying once COVID restrictions are lifted in Victoria, BC they will not be imposed again in case anti-vaxxers fall sick from the virus.
Tweeter is implying most people he knows are anti-vaxxers and he prefers lockdown over getting vaccinated because it is his freedom of choice.
Tweeter is saying that the COVID vaccine is not a real vaccine and falsely claims the survival rate from the virus to be 99.5%. Therefore, people should not get the COVID vaccines.
Tweeter is implying that lockdowns and vaccine passports took people's freedom away. He is laughing at the Alliance Party in Northern Ireland for stating freedom as one of their core values.
Tweeter is saying that people cannot show their vaccine passports where and when necessary because of technological failures.

This post was made by a conspiracy theorist, based on what their Twitter wall hosts. This tweet is not entirely clear, but it seems to imply that they are anti-vaxx and blaming the WEF and "globalists" for controlling the vaccine narrative, while also saying that people on their side control a narrative about Ukraine. Anti-vaxxers have circulated pro-Russian sentiments since the beginning of the recent conflict.
criticism_other: The World Economic Forum and Globalists

meaning: This is an anti-vaxx post that implies public health officials and, or, government are exercising mind control by administering the vaccine. She is undermining trust in the vaccine by questioning its safety.
This is a pro-vaccine post. It is a reply to someone who questions vaccines in relation to Omicron. The post encourages getting a booster shot.
The tweet is from CNN's page about US automaker Ford making vaccines mandatory for its employees.
Tweeter is implying that testing and getting vaccinated would make people fall sick.

This person is an anti-vaxxer who calls vaccines into question by asking why vaccinated people are worried about people who don't want to be vaccinated. This is a form of misinformation because it rejects science, whose claims state that a certain vaccination rate must be met to reach herd immunity.
Tweeter is congratulating Indian PM Modi for vaccinating Indians using their own vaccines. But he does not say what percentage of the population got vaccinated.
This is an anti-vaxxer who is calling for a freedom of choice bill.
This tweet is pro-vaccine because it suggests that the U.K. could do better with vaccine roll-out.
In reply to tweets about all vaccines' effectiveness, tweeter says because many took a polio vaccine it is pretty much eradicated. They suggest this could be done with COVID-19 too.
Tweeter refers to the Chicago police union head allowing officers to not get vaccinated despite city mandates.
This tweet is in favour of vaccine mandates and comments on how they have helped remove radicals from the military and law enforcement.
This tweeter writes that they are excited for their son to become eligible for the vaccine so he can be vaccinated and return to pre-pandemic activities.
This tweet says that their orthopaedic appointment has been delayed by six months because their hospital is full of vaccine-injured patients.

This woman is angry because documents pertaining to people with vaccination exemptions -- who work within the Oregon government -- were given to two news outlets. The tweeter says this was a violation of her/their rights, which indicates her anti-vaxx status.
criticism_other: Releasing of personal data, such as vaccine status

meaning: This tweeter claims that Ivermectin is a safe remedy for COVID-19. Most people who believe in Ivermectin as a COVID treatment are anti-vaxxers in need of a miracle cure. Ivermectin has been discredited by scientists as a form of treatment for COVID-19.

This tweet focuses on the messaging around Omicron and the importance of vaccination. She suggests that the focus of the messaging should be that vaccination will lower the chance of death. She also suggests that messaging shouldn't focus on vaccination reducing contraction, because Omicron is highly contagious.
support_other: Messaging about the risk of death with Omicron if unvaccinated

meaning: It's not clear if this post is promoting anything, the tweet is deactivated. This tweet seems to be a statement about which groups are the lowest vaccination rates. One of the people tagged in the tweet, Paul Anthony, has a suspended account. And the woman tagged, Gillian McKeith, is a promoter of natural remedies and COVID-19 snake oil.
Tweeter tags Victoria police asking them if they will protect people from losing their jobs because they don't want to be vaccinated.
This is clearly a pro-vaccine tweet. It offers information on where to get vaccines in Durham. The link in this post is broken and the original tweet is no longer available.

This tweet is no longer live so it's impossible to read the connotation. The tweeter is telling another tweeter about an article released by the Wall Street Journal titled "To Prevent the Next Pandemic, Scientists Seek One Vaccine for Many Coronaviruses."
This is a repost of a video and it is from someone who identifies as a journalist. The post does not seem to be passing comment, rather it's information about a news event.
Tweeter is promoting a conspiracy theory about Antifa being part of the FBI, the government. Also, antifa is monitoring riots with drones and obstructing anti-vaccination protests.

This is an anti-vaxxer who complains about the BBC's coverage of vaccine passports. This person claims that vaccination passports are a violation of bodily autonomy. The tweeter also equates vaccine passports with a "Chinese style social credit system."
Tweeter is criticizing Scotland's government based on a Telegraph commentary that the country imposed the harshest vaccine rules in all of Europe.
This is a pro-vaccine post, that reveals upset at people who no longer mask. The post intends to share that people can still contract the virus, even if they are vaccinated.

This post appears to be critiquing a woman's choice to vaccinate her young child. The post is asking another twitter user for comment. The post calls the people in this photo "media cheerleaders," therefore the post appears to be a criticism of "mainstream" media.
This is a twitter post that criticizes vaccine mandates. It's personal opinion that questions the vaccine passport system. The tweeter clearly states "it's time to move on."

Tweeter is implying that proof of vaccination goes against America's Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act which protects sensitive patient information from being disclosed without patient's knowledge or consent.

This tweet defends vaccines by asking an anti-vaxxer who commented in a forum what they understand about immunity. The post seems to imply that no vaccine offers 100% immunity, but that what it gives contributes to immunity.
Tweeter is saying vaccines and other safety won't prevent infection but will keep hospitalization low and reduce the spread of the virus.
Tweeter is saying that since vaccination is not mandatory in Australia restricting people to go anywhere they want is illegal. He says millions have been blacklisted without providing any proof.
Tweeter is happy that 50% parents of a certain school refused vaccination for their kids. Since it is a personal story the number could not be verified.
Tweeter is implying that vaccination caused people to fall sick, by taking numbers out of context. Tweeter also does not indicate where the numbers and percentages came from.
Tweeter is falsely claiming that the vaccine is experimental and compares the restrictions anti-vaxxers face to those of the Jews in Nazi Germany.

This post is critical of anti-vaxx protest mobs situated outside schools and vaccination centres. The tweeter states that they are a product of disinformation. The tweeter posted some screenshots of people promoting disinformation.
criticism_other: Disinformation and angry anti-vaxx protest mobs

meaning: Tweeter is saying that the chance of people getting sick from Pfizer vaccine is much lower than getting infected with COVID. However, he does not mention the source of this information.
Tweeter is implying that there is something dangerous about wiping the skin with alcohol swabs before administering the vaccine.
Georgia's governor is upset by Biden administration's vaccine mandates saying it encroaches freedom of choice.

Tweeter is laughing at a person, shown in a video complaining about a restaurant at Trump Tower not allowing him to enter without proof of vaccination. Video content could not be verified independently.

Tweeter is saying that people who do not believe in vaccines also do not belong to the medical profession. She says so in reply to a tweet about the unfairness of firing unvaccinated nurses and doctors.
Tweeter is implying that doctors are being censored from talking about vaccines, which he claims makes more people suspicious of the vaccine. He does not say which doctors have been censored.
Tweeter questions the effectiveness of vaccines, by basing it on vaccinated family members' refusal to be around unvaccinated people.

This woman is concerned about the effectiveness of vaccines for pregnant mothers. She says she couldn't find evidence to support the headline of the article she posted, which says vaccination protects mothers and babies. But the article has information to guide her in her quest to answer her question, therefore I flagged her tweet as misleading.
Tweeter replies to now deleted tweet. Tweeter refers to a book, The Real Anthony Fauci, which talks about how the medical system is corrupt. Its to support why she will not vaccinate her children.

This is an academic paper that Yale and CSH Laboratory were involved with. It regards "waning of immunity in vaccinated individuals." It has not yet been peer reviewed. The tweet itself is a repost of the paper's title and does not pass comment.

This appears to be a pro-vaccine post because it makes fun of an anti-vaxxer's quote about how vaccines were made to control minds. This tweet refers to that quote as "a dozie" and "the most stupid one!" The link is not active to click, to see how this tweet is situated in the thread though.
This appears to be a reputable news report about how a TV star got pericarditis as a result of getting vaccinated.
This post encourages "Armys" to get their vaccine, stating that it will be required to enter SoFi Stadium.

This tweeter rejects claims that were likely made by a trucker convoy supporter. The tweet they replied to has been deleted. But it's clear that this tweet supports public health measures and government, while it calls the deleted poster a troll.

This tweeter claims their vaccinations didn't prevent them from getting sick from the virus. This is misinformation because vaccines never promised to prevent contraction of the virus. They help mitigate the level of risk associated with getting COVID-19.

Tweeter insinuates that Pfizer and Bill Gates want the pandemic to continue to keep the demand for vaccines up. Tweeter quotes Pfizer's CEO and Gates but does not provide dates or context of the comment.
Tweeter is sharing her experience of getting infected with COVID after two years, but is thankful she got vaccinated.
Tweeter is falsely stating that Pfizer claimed their vaccine to be 100 per cent effective and that more vaccinated people died during the trial.

Tweeter took an unverified statement by Dr. Fauci from 2020 out of context and claimed that he lied about vaccination and other pandemic issues. Tweeter uses Iraq's WMD to draw a parallel with the pandemic.
Tweeter points out that serious COVID infection can land people in hospitals and affects their nerves and muscles. So people should get vaccinated and follow public health protocols.
The news is about AstraZeneca changing its not-for-profit stance regarding the COVID vaccine to a for-profit one.

This post claims that vaccines have a number of dangerous side effects, including autism, which was a claim made by a discredit scientist. The post also claims vaccines cause death or cancer, which is a very big and broad, unsupported claim to make. This post also criticizes "big pharma" or public health officials, complaining that those companies are all about the money, no matter what the cost.
This is a pro-vaccine post. It celebrates the serious measures Ecuador took to get their population vaccinated.

This tweet was made by a journalist. He questions China's motives in helping Africa to obtain vaccines. He writes that there were ulterior motives with providing Italy support when their cases where high in 2020, such as waging information warfare.
This post is misleading because it shows disbelief at a person getting COVID-19 despite being vaxxed. Vaccines don't prevent contraction of a virus, they lower the risk of illness.

This is an anti-vaxx post. It tries to undermine the effectiveness of vaccines by stating the Whoppi Goldberg contracted COVID-19 despite being vaccinated. Of course vaccines don't prevent contraction of a virus, they only lower the risk of serious illness.
This tweet is anti-vaxx and claims that Castanet News is responsible for generating hate towards anti-vaxxers. This post is a criticism of mainstream media.
This is a repost of a news article that states that 169 marines were booted out of the army for refusing to get vaccinated. No personal comment is provided within this tweet.

This is a news article posted by the Epoch Times, which is a far-right publication, about how governors in the U.S. rejected vaccine mandates. This story was also published in the New York Times, and likely other reputable news outlets.
This anti-vaxxer is spreading conspiracy theories about the World Economic Forum and vaccine passports, saying that it is all a form of tyranny.

This post questions vaccines and their intent by posting an innaccurate article that says the FDA banned NAC, a supplement that could boost immunity. The FDA did not ban it though, it is still for sale, so the post is disinformation. The website that the article claiming this is on, is not reputable journalism.

This tweet is not based in fact. It claims that vaccines made the Delta virus, which is not true. It also claims there is no such thing as herd immunity, which is not true. It also states that there is no "workable vax" for COVID-19, which is disinformation.
This anti-vaxxer is promoting the idea that the pandemic never existed and that vaccines cripple people.
criticism_other: The notion that the pandemic existed

meaning: This anti-vaxxer is promoting "natural immunity" and rejecting vaccines. Natural immunity is a dangerous concept that involves contracting the virus without immunization. She is quoting Trump to support and promote her beliefs on Twitter.
This is a news article, released by CNN. It is information about research completed by Johnson and Johnson about vaccine effectiveness.

This tweet promotes fear of vaccines by saying they debilitate people. The tweet posts a link about a new variant that requires a revised version of the vaccine, which that article says could take 100 days to make.
This anti-vaxxer is making a claim that vaccines are not effective. That is simply not true.

This person is pedalling "natural immunity" by saying that vaccines are ineffective because the virus still transmits if a person is vaccinated. The claim is misinformed. Natural immunity would not prevent further infections as well, and it is dangerous.

This is a repost of a Washington Post article that reports vaccine effectiveness against Omicron. It does not pass comment, but it comes from a pro-vaccine stance because an anti-vaxxer would have passed comment.
This retweet shares an article by the Washington Post about Americans abroad who have trouble getting the vaccine, while those physically in the United States do not.
This tweet by news 12 links to an article about Governor Kathy Hochul’s monitoring of COVID-19 cases in school-aged children, and the possibility that a student vaccine mandate could be implemented.
This tweet is critical of members of the "right wing" who celebrated Walmart -- despite that company's destruction on small businesses, etc. -- until they mandated vaccines for workers.
criticism_other: Walmart's ethics and monopolies, Right Wing contradictions

meaning: This is an informational post about a public information event about pediatric vaccines. The tweeter posted the event's poster.
This is an anti-vaxxer who is promoting conspiracy theories about the vaccine being an experiment that the "elite" refuse to take.
This tweet is pro-vaccine and states a matter of opinion about religion. They state that any religious group that is anti-vaxx is not credible.
criticism_other: Religious groups who say they're anti-vaxx

meaning: This anti-vaxxer says the vaccine is a Frankenstein thing and that masks never worked. The tweeter believes that scientists are corrupt and being paid by the government to spread misinformation.

This person is promoting supplements to combat adverse side effects from the vaccine. The post is anti-vaxx because it undermines trust in vaccine safety by saying there is a need for vitamins to combat the risks.
The link here is broken. So it's not clear what stance this tweet takes on vaccines. It could be making fun of an anti-vaxxer, or a pro-vaccine person. Impossible to tell without an active link.

This is an anti-vaxxer making a sarcastic comment about vaccines. The comment implies that vaccines don't actually work. It is clear that the person is anti-vaxx because their profile is filled with questionable articles and political comments.

This tweet from the Philippine Information Agency announces that more than 1.5 million doses of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine arrived in the country on December 23. The included hashtags such as #RESBAKUNA and #BIDABakunation are in favour of vaccination.
This tweet by a Swedish journalist reports on the vaccination rate of people living in Scandinavia. No sources are cited.
This post denounces Ted Cruz for supporting Canada's Trucker Convoy. It states that he should instead acknowledge those who died of COVID-19 in Texas.
This tweeter concludes that successful government spending and vaccination improved the GDP of India.
This tweeter claims that children are dying from the vaccine, but not from COVID-19.

This tweeter is equating higher vaccination rates in West Germany with lower COVID-19 infections. And the tweet also equates the higher population of anti-vaxxers in East Germany with a higher population of alt-right members.
This post is pro-vaccine and asserts that vaccines save lives. It criticizes people who bashed actor Martin Kemp for standing up for vaccination.
Tweeter quotes a tweet about a petition placed in New Zealand's parliament requesting the prevention of COVID-19 vaccine passport system.
This is a post story post by the Toronto star, which promotes getting the flu shot in addition to the COVID-19 vaccine.

This is an informational post from a New York Times reporter who reported on vaccine related comments from a politician or public health official (short form is used for the name so it's hard to understand).
This tweet is making fun of some republicans who shouted at Lindsey Graham for promoting vaccines. He equates those anti-vaxx republicans to "stupid" four year olds.

This is an anti-vaxxer criticizing what CDC director Rochelle Walensky said at a conference on March 3, 2022 about vaccine effectiveness amongst variants. The video does not appear to be altered, however some clips were altered of Walenksy in the past, to deceive the public about her words. The anti-vaxxer claims that the conference she spoke at is about waning vaccine effectiveness and that the CDC lied by not putting that information in their preview - thus claiming the CDC is hiding something about vaccines.

This anti-vaxxer is criticizing vaccine passports and says that the government discriminates by making the public use them. The tweet also criticizes vaccine effectiveness by saying Omicron is still landing people in hospitals despite their vaccination status.
This tweet lists the COVID-19 mandates required to enter an ASCO symposium. It passes no comment, yet it clearly supports public health measures.
This person is pro-vaccine, yet they are worried about the wait period required to book to book a booster shot. They worry too many people will book at once, and they prefer to get it early.
support_other: Boosters provide with less waiting times since previous vaccine

meaning: This is an informational post about how proof of vaccination will no longer be required at "city facilities." It was written by a news station and does not pass comment.

This anti-vaxx post links to an article that claims abortions are involved with making vaccines. Immunize BC, however states that "vaccines do not contain fetal cells and no abortions are performed to make vaccines. This includes COVID-19 vaccines." This tweet is misleading.
criticism_other: The use of fetal cells for testing vaccines and abortion
support_other: Banning the use of fetal cells in the vaccination development process

meaning: This is an anti-vaxx tweet that claims a major laughed when a pregnant police officer voiced her concerns about taking the vaccine while pregnant. The video does not reveal such a response from the mayor. The tweet generates COVID-19 fear with its connotations that politicians are laughing at vaccine hesitant people.

This tweet claims Moderna created COVID-19, which is a conspiracy theory. It also promotes the idea that vaccines are ineffective because fully vaccinated people still contract the virus, even though the vaccine intends to reduce illness risks only.
This is a repost of a story about a Pfizer employee who stole vaccine secrets when they left to another company. This story is published in other news sources, such as CTV.

This is an anti-vaxxer who says society is judgmental for calling anti-vaxxers "nazis" or "white supremacists" or other negative words. Clearly this person is critical of vaccine mandates yet does not want to be lumped in with extreme members of history's society.
criticism_other: labelling anti-vaxxers as nazi's or other negative terms

meaning: This is an informational post, notifying the public where they can get vaccinated in Greendale.

This post encourages people to donate their unwanted vaccines to the Global South, through a "Donate Your Dose" program. This is oriented towards people who don't want to be vaccinated, who want their vaccine to be used. The post is misleading because it claims that vaccines will "actually help" abroad, rather than here at home.
support_other: Donating one's unused vaccines to the Global South

meaning: This post shares graphs about how Omicron has lead to less ICU cases, due to the effectiveness of vaccines.

This is a sarcastic tweet that asks if Ukrainians have to follow vaccine and mask mandates. This implies an anti-vaxx, anti-mask sentiment because there are much larger concerns in Ukraine at the moment.
This tweet criticizes TV show host, Greg Gutfeld, for shutting down an anti-vaxxer who started to make vaccine hesitant comments on his show. Clearly this tweeter is an anti-vaxxer.

This tweeter is opposed to vaccine passports and uses Belarus, an authoritarian regime, as an example of what he views to be a successful approach to managing the pandemic. That country did not exercise lockdowns, and it removed the mask mandate two weeks after instating it.
This is a news post from about the New York Fire Department, whose members wanted to lift the vaccine mandate. It is information and not a commentary on vaccines.

This anti-vaxx post shares another tweet from someone who witnessed a white worker kick an unvaccinated black family out of a restaurant for not being vaccinated. The tweet is twisting racial tensions to promote the anti-vaxx cause.
support_other: Twisting racism to support the anti-vaxx cause

meaning: This tweeter criticizes pharmaceutical companies for blocking a wider production of COVID-19 vaccines. He wonders if the people responsible for that profit model will get higher paying jobs within the company. This is a critic on patent distribution and promotes universal access to COVID-19 vaccines.
This seems to be an informational post about Biden's vaccine mandates, and the mixed responses the public has. This tweeter has only two followers and does not appear to be a credible news source.

This tweeter says that vaccines are effective before infection and that treatments after getting infected are also effective. This is not clearly pro-vaccine, as it could be supporting alternative remedies, but judging on other comments this tweeter made in the thread, they appear to support vaccination.

This anti-vaxx tweet implies that the pandemic was planned, because the WHO released a video in 2015 about the importance of having a vaccination plan in Europe. This sentiment ties in with some conspiracy theories, that the pandemic was invented.

This tweet, posted by the the Director of Global Health criticizes the U.K. for delaying the vaccination of children ages five to eleven. She says it would have prevented illness and time off school if kids had been vaccinated earlier.

This is a statement of disbelief about an article that claims the army invented a single dose COVID-19 vaccine. The story is published on defenseone.com, and it appears to be a credible news source. The tweet passes no comment or judgement other than curiosity.

This tweet is a bit misleading because it says vaccines were never mandated in the work place, yet they were for a period of time. The tweet is pro-vaccine though, because it is a rejection of an anti-vaxxer's words. This tweet tells the anti-vaxxer to stop being a "rebel."
This is an informational post about Pindi Cricket Stadium. It tells readers that they can attend events if they have a vaccine passport. This is inherently pro-vaccine.

This post is not blatantly pro-vaccine, however it is not anti-vaccine. The post is a comment to another person about COVID-19 contraction being stressful for older people, even if they have the protection of a vaccine.
This anti-vaxxer promotes his religious "vaccination card" which is just a printed piece of paper from his church that says he has been vaccinated by the lord.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is replying to a person who is opposed to "forced" vaccines. The discussion was about asylum seekers and whether they should be mandated to take vaccines. This tweet reminds the anti-vaxxer that no one is being forced to take vaccines.
This tweeter writes that getting vaccinated should be a personal choice, not a mandate. They write that their parents chose not to get them vaccinated against measles, mumps, or tuberculosis.
This tweeter is against vaccines and asks why so many unvaccinated people have not died from Covid19.
This MD commented on testing, rather than on vaccines. She is pro-vaccine based on her Twitter profile, however this post is strictly regarding testing.
This tweet contains false information about COVID-19 vaccines substantially increasing the chances of miscarriage. USA Today reported that there is no evidence that vaccines create miscarriages.
This is a news story, originally written by AP -- a credible new outlet -- about two nurses who faked vaccine passports. This tweet contains no person opinion.

This post appears to be a comment on Canada's contributions to COVAX, or something related. Canada purchased the most vaccines per capita in the world and some critics accuse this country of hoarding. This tweeter seems to be asking for clarity on why we're not providing vaccines to those in need.

This post does state fact, although the two-hour-long posted video contains some misinformation, about the use of fetal cells in developing the vaccine. This post is used to promote an anti-vaxx narrative. National Geographic reported in 2021 that "It’s true that [fetal] cells have been used either in the testing or development and production of COVID-19 vaccines. The cells are grown in a laboratory and were derived from a few elective abortions performed more than three decades ago."
criticism_other: The use of fetal cells to make vaccines

meaning: This person is declaring that they absolutely do not want to take the vaccine. No reasons as to why are provided.
The original post that this question, about who owns the vaccine, has been deleted, so it is difficult to read the tone of this post. It does not pass comment, rather it asks who owns the vaccine.

This is a re-post of a quote that was printed in news articles from India's president, Modi. It does not pass personal opinion, it is simply a post about his comments which are inherently pro-vaccine.
This is a government post that offers information to the public on booster shots. It focuses on allowing the public to understand which target groups are eligible for the shot.
This tweet replied to a tweet that is now deleted. This tweet is calling out misinformation about COVID-19 vaccines killing people.
This unvaccinated person is suspicious of medical staff who asked them why they have not taken the vaccine, when they went to the hospital for an anxiety attack.

This tweet questions why, amid widespread anti-science aggression, Bill Maher was allowed to speak on CNN when he has been consistently wrong about covid-19, ivermectin, and vaccines. The tweet includes a link to a Forbes article entitled “Bill Maher Defends Ivermectin Despite Lack Of Scientific Evidence As Covid-19 Treatment”.
This tweet says that getting rid of masking mandates too early is anti-science and political ideology.
This retweet of Covid-19 cases published by BNN suggests that vaccines have failed to bring down Covid-19 numbers in the Netherlands.

This is a reply to a tweet that claims many people regret getting the vaccine. The tweeter challenges this argument and says that the vaccine does not cause any long-term harm beyond feeling unwell for a day.
This tweet incorrectly claims that the Covid19 vaccine is highly likely to cause antibody dependent enhancement, or ADE, which would speed up a Covid19 infection rather than fight it.
This tweeter claims that in an employment situation, vaccinated employees who believe the vaccine works have no reason to sue an employer who allows the unvaccinated to continue working.
This tweeter says that vaccines and masks are effective overall, even if they do not stop every single infection.
This tweet says that information about how long mask mandates would last has been unclear and continuously changing.

This post claims that a jab should not be called a vaccine unless it prevents transmission and total immunity to COVID-19. This is disinformation because a vaccine is intended to reduce illness if a vaccinated person is infected.
This tweet reveals upset towards a family member who faked a vaccine passport. This tweeter is clearly a pro-vaccine person.
This is a post by the Irish Times that notifies the public about sites opening for online vaccine bookings.

This tweeter is promoting the idea of intranasal vaccines, which are currently in development. He states that he spoke to a biochemist about how such vaccines could establish a front line immune response.
This tweeter promotes keeping communities safe while more information was being released about Omicron and its risks. The post promotes masking and social distancing.
This tweeter says school kids should not be required to get the vaccine in order to attend school. This is personal opinion and it reveals an anti-vaxx sentiment.
This tweeter is asking politicians to be more direct about saying vaccination will end the pandemic. He wants those politicians to promote that the vaccines are safe and effective.
This person declares that they are getting vaccinated on this day.
This is an informational post about vaccine mandates going to court.

This person is making fun of people who have been social distancing and wearing "uncomfortable" masks upon the release of news that some humans have super-immunity to COVID-19. The tweet suggests that all of those precautions were for nothing, even though it's not clear how many people actually have "super-immunity" to COVID-19, as per news reports.
This tweet says that vaccines killed Irish people, as well as injured the vaccinated.
This post is promoting fears that children are dying from the COVID-19 vaccine. France24 reported that loosening measures in schools may have lead to move infections, not the vaccine.
The Bill Gates foundation announces a $150M donation to securing vaccines for the national and international level.

This tweet is just a question and appears to not pass comment. It doesn't fully relate to the previous tweets of the thread it is in, so hard to read the tone. But the person is asking a question about viruses forming vaccine-resistant traits.
This tweet by Mike Pompeo, former CIA Director under Donald Trump claims that vaccine mandates will not stop the pandemic. It calls Covid19 the Wuhan virus.
This is a journalistic post from a CNN reporter. It relays study data that 12-15 year old children receive 100% efficacy from the Pfizer vaccine.

This woman is blaming Biden for worsening flights, due to vaccine mandates the government imposed. She makes a prediction that flights will become dangerous by Christmas 2021, due to vaccines, which is misleading.

The article posted in this tweet is an opinion piece by a writer who sympathizes with the trucker convoy. The tweeter disapproves of that article, stating that the Wall Street Journal supports a small Canadian minority with unnacceptable views.

This tweeter is comparing vaccine mandates to coercion and genocidal policy. He also shared a graph, that has no source information, to display that vaccinated people contract the virus more often than non-vaccinated people without other details. This is misleading because it's not clear where this data came from.

This tweeter is posing a question to data that came out on Labour Day 2021. News outlets reported that the infection rate was 300% higher than the year before. This tweeter wants to know why, given people had been vaccinated. This is an anti-vaxx post because it does not acknowledge that vaccination reduces illness rather than making 100% immunity.
This tweet criticizes Rick Hillier's vaccine roll-out. The tweet is pro-vaccine and says that the only news space that Hillier deserves is for a letter of apology.
criticism_other: Rick Hillier, Canada's vaccine roll out

meaning: This anti-masker and anti-vaxxer says they will find a new church to attend if they are asked to wear a mask or be vaccinated to attend service. This tweet is in response to another person's post about being removed from a church for not wearing a mask.

This is a pro-vaccine post that says society has deemed vaccination as a worth cause to mandate. The tweeter says humans have been mandating vaccines for centuries, and those mandates are nothing new - which was also reported in the BBC.

This tweet shares a link that came out around the time of the trucker convoy. The tweet is anti-vaxx and claims that Canadians do not support the vaccine, likely as a gesture of solidarity for the trucker convoy.
The link in this tweet is currently broken. But the tweet promotes #PureBlood as a hashtag for symbolizing an unvaccinated status.

This anti-vaxxer is declaring that everyone should choose who to trust about medical advice. And the person this tweeter trusts, they say, only recently became the bad guy. It's not clear who that person they trust is.
This tweet is a response to an anti-vaxx comment. This tweet basically communicates that anti-vaxx conspiracy theories are ludicrous.
This tweet is a basic question asking if China developed and tested a COVID-19 vaccine. No commentary provided.
This poster says it requests people to be vaccinated and double masked. It also rejects religious and political gatherings. The location of the poster appears to be in India.
This tweet promotes vaccination over natural immunity and states that vaccines have been used for over 300 years. The intention is to remind viewers that vaccines are tried and true.

This tweet is a repost of information on vaccine mandates and how that could effect the number of staff at a particular venue. This tweet was made by journalist Dave West and passes no personal comment.

At first the tweet appeared to be from a community-based organization promoting positive awareness about vaccinations, but upon checking the profile page there were repeated claims about conspiracy theories and anti-government slogans. The video attached shows people presumably at a school board meeting where AIM advocates were attempting to convince parents not to vaccinate.

This is a response to a tweet expressing frustration that people still refuse to get vaccinated in light of all the information we have about safety and efficacy. The user appears to be a strong religious conservative, and mainly posts about sports and culture rather than current events and politics.

This tweet claims there is a searchable database of those vaccinated that employers can search by social security number when making hiring decisions. It is responding to a tweet from a suspended account, and in the replies the user admits the anecdote is from personal experience, not a verified source.
criticism_other: the government collecting citizens health data
support_other: being skeptical of the government and their aims in collecting data

meaning: Tweet is from a local Boston news station relaying information on new vaccination clinics in the area and when they will open.

Hard to parse, the video is in English, but the twitter page and website is all in German. If the video is taken at face value, it is pro-vaccination, but it is hard to evaluate context. Maybe Sarah could review since she speaks German?

This anti-vaxxer is accusing media outlets of lumping all people who are opposed to vaccines into the "anti-vaxx" category. This is a common complaint from anti-vaxxers and it holds no weight. The tweet also criticizes journalists for doing "cut and paste" journalism.

This anti-vaxxer is blaming a news initiative that combats the spread of disinformation for spreading disinformation. This tweeter is twisting the narrative and generating distrust for not only vaccines, but also journalists.

This post appears to be pro-vaccine but it is not because it calls MRNA vaccines "experimental," which generates distrust for vaccination. The link featured in this tweet features the Bayer President, and he does not use the word "experimental" himself.
This human rights lawyer lists off various things that he finds not good about Virginia's republican party. Some of those points include lifted vaccine mandates and ending mask mandates at schools.
This is a posting of an academic paper called "Impact of yellow fever virus envelope protein on wild-type and vaccine epitopes and tissue tropism." It passes no personal comment about vaccines.
This is a nonsensical post. The person seems to claim they will be getting vaccinated, but that there is something to be nervous of, but it's not entirely clear.

The tweet links to an announcement that the President of Western University (Alan Shepard) has stepped down for a week after sudden heart problems. The second half of the tweet explicitly links the heart problems with vaccine side effects, and notes how Shepard pushed for vaccine mandates on campus. The user has a PhD in ethics and ancient philosophy, and has recently come out with a book that advocates against vaccine mandates.
support_other: Asking questions about vaccine side effects (regardless of the answers already available)

meaning: Tweet is the headline of a linked video about vaccines killing children. Link was blocked on my computer because of potential spam or misleading content.
support_other: Not getting vaccinated becuase of unverified threats to childrens health

meaning: User argues the vaccine targets a virus that is not widely circulating. Replying to a tweet from Republican representative in Minnesota arguing people who have already recovered from Covid do not need the vaccine because it is "therapeutic in nature." Video attached to the original tweet is of WH press briefing with Jen Psaki, but text claims many triple vaccinated folks are still getting Covid, so the vaccine is no longer needed.
This tweeter posted a petition to stop school kids from being harassed by anti-vaxx protests. This is highly likely to be a pro-vaccine tweet, although there is no personal comment in the text.

This post is inherently anti-vaxx because it spreads disinformation about Trudeau fleeing the capital during the Trucker Convoy. This "fact" has been fact checked by outlets such as USA Today: There was no evidence that the Trudeau's fled. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2022/02/10/fact-check-no-evidence-canadian-pm-fled-amid-trucker-protests/6653761001/

This tweeter believes that vaccine passports are a form of control, and that they will control every aspect of a person's life if not kept in check. The tweeter posts a video of Trudeau talking about passports for Canadians, and says that U.K. residents should resist them.
This tweet promotes vaccination and says that kids in the U.S. can receive the vaccine for free regardless of their insurance or immigration status.

Tweeter posts a collage of videos supposedly of vaccine protest. The sources of the videos cannot be verified. Also, he wrongly claims that mainstream media does not report on vaccine passport protests.

This tweeter claims that Prime Minister Trudeau says COVID-19 boosters don't work because he announced that he contracted COVID-19. This is disinformation because the tweeter is implying that vaccines stop the virus completely. The tweeter put words into the Prime Minister's mouth to project his own ideas that vaccines are not effective unless they completely stop contraction of the virus.

This tweeter posted a statement saying that vaccines can damage brain cells and the immune system. Their tweet contains a link to a website that is blatantly pro-freedom, which sources a study that has not been peer reviewed.
This tweeter is rejecting Steven Del Duca's requests for adding booster shots to the vaccine passport system. The tweeter says they also disapprove of lockdowns, QR codes and vaccine certificates.
This tweet fact checks an anti-vaxx site. The tweeter says that the site only has one registered nurse involved with its platform, even though the site claims to have more medical officials on board.
Tweet from the NYT official account posting a story they wrote on vaccine mandates. Covers a federal judge overturning Biden's vaccine mandate in November 2021
Tweet from the NYT official account posting a story they wrote on vaccine mandates. Covers a federal judge overturning Biden's vaccine mandate in November 2021

User says if they new their doctor/nurse chose not to get vaccinated, they would trust that provider less to provide other care. Advocating for healthcare professionals demonstrating trust in their colleagues and the discipline as a whole.
criticism_other: healthcare workers who refuse to get vaccinated

meaning: Tweet at first appears to be meme satire of the vaccine discourse. User's profile seems very positive (lots of sunrises and good morning messages), as well as pro-environmentalist, explicitly democrat, and supportive of Biden-Harris admin. It's probably just a grandpa' man's idea of what a meme is.
Tweet claims that HIV virus is tied to vaccine side effects, and that side effects of the vaccine are potentially more dangerous that the actual virus.
tweet is a hypothetical about vaccine side effects implying it can kill without warning.
Tweet contains a link to a Daily Mail article claiming Biden wants to dishonorably discharge unvaccinated troops. Politifact and other sources have flagged this claim as false.

Tweet part of a threat that claims conflicting information about vaccines and the severity of Covid means science is unreliable. Seems to imply that the promotion of Ivermectin and other altnernative remedies means the virus is serious, but also says the virus is "just the sniffles" and can be fought off naturally.
This tweet promotes vaccines. It says that the death rates due to Omicron would have been much lower if more of the population had been vaccinated.
This tweet says that no people died of COVID-19 in two years, which is absolutely wrong. The link they posted goes to a man's personal blog and does not appear to be reputable.
This tweeter declares that he rejects vaccine mandates. He says he wrote to his MP to communicate his opinion.
Tweet claims that vaccines are giving people AIDS, and that exposing children to vaccines constitutes a genocide.

Tweet claims there is serious cardiovascular risk from the vaccine. The tweet is from a man who claims to be doctor of "physics, nuclear-cardiology, biology, psychology and more." Appears on a website associated with the Alex Jones show.
Tweet claims the vaccine lowers or supresses immunity, and claims staff who are vaccinated are now Covid positive, while those who are unvaccinated remain fit and healthy.
This post asks whether vaccination causes COVID-19. The tweeter posts a few charts of spiking cases around the world.

Tweet is claiming that by sensoring anti-vaccine news sources, public health officials are bringing the efficacy of vaccines into question. Circular logic claiming governments are the real antivaxxers.
This is a repost of a quote from author Baroness Brady. It does not pass personal opinion. The quote can be found on Baroness Brady's Twitter account and has not been altered in this tweet.

This pro-vaccine post displays concerns for members of the public who are not vaccinated. It shows a graph, that is not sourced, that reveals cases are on the rise. The tweeter says unvaccinated people are playing with fire.

This woman described her experience getting vaccinated with the J&J COVID-19 and the flu vaccines all in one day. She said she had a positive experience with no side effects and thanked Joe Biden for promoting vaccines.

This tweet asks whether Trudy (Trudeau?) is "sneaking" the COVID-19 vaccine into the criminal code, in order to mandate it. The tweet is asking for information on this, but clearly comes from an anti-vaxx perspective. It is misleading because it implies that the government is sneaking around, when such discussions or ideas have been public, yet not instated.
This tweet is criticising out an anti-vaccine politician because they tweeted about a school shooting, arguing they did it to avoid discussing the COVID outbreak and vaccine hesitancy in their area.

This tweet is comparing biometric identification and potential climate lockdowns to vaccine mandates, arguing that vaccine mandates and passports impose on freedom the same way that a biometric tracker would.

Tweet is claiming that by sensoring anti-vaccine news sources, public health officials are bringing the efficacy of vaccines into question. Circular logic claiming governments are the real antivaxxers.

This tweet promotes anti-vaxx, anti-mask and anti-lockdown sentiments. The tweeter posts a video of a trucker convoy member who speaks about conspiracy theories, such as that China created the virus and that the vaccine is an experiment.

Both tweet and user are difficult to pin down. Tweet seems to claim that vaccines are effective against Delta, checked the profile and found both pro and anti-vax statements, claims Biden is responsible for high gas prices, pro-Tesla, Elon bro type tweets, and a Trevor Noah segment on why the stock market is a rich people scam. I think this particular tweet is pro-vaccine, but the user is all over the place.

This is a post from discredited scientist Dr. Robert Malone. The quote reveals his distrust for the COVID-19 mRNA vaccine. Malone promotes freedom of choice while claiming that he invented the vaccine, but numerous news outlets have debunked Malone's role in developing the vaccine.

This tweet posts a picture of Biden getting vaccinated, with a title that reads "The Truman Show." The Truman show is a psychological movie, depicting Jim Carrey being trapped in a strange reality where nothing is real. This tweet implies that the vaccine is fake, or not grounded in the real world.

This post states that vaccines should be abolished because they spread the virus, which is not true. The link posted along with the tweet is about Molnupiravir, an antiviral medication. The tweet does not pass comment on Molnupiravir, only on vaccines.

Greg Abbott of the Texas Militia promotes his rejection of Biden's vaccine mandates. Abbott says he is suing the Biden Administration. He posted his letter which communicates that along with this tweet.

This post criticizes Dr. Jha, the White House Coronavirus Response Coordinator. The post implies that the vaccine does not work because people are still getting infected in the U.S., despite being vaxxed. The tweeter seems to claim that unvaccinated teachers and kids are not contracting COVID-19 in their classrooms.
This tweet appears to be pro-vaccine yet it claims that people are not dying from COVID-19. This tweeter wants to live life like normal now that he's vaccinated.
support_other: Living life as normal once vaccinated

meaning: This tweet is a reply against vaccine mandates and the politicians that implement them, but doesn't really make sense as a response to the pro-vaccine tweet.

This is a direct tweet of an article from an anti-vaccine publication, but the tweet itself is just an explanation of how the vaccine mandate case will make its way through the supreme court and federal courts.

This tweet promotes social distancing and masking, and etc., after vaccination. The post reminds people that the vaccine does not prevent contraction of the virus, rather it simply reduces the risks of contracting COVID-19. The tweet does not clearly state a pro or anti-vaxx stance.
criticism_other: People who don't social distance or mask after getting vaccinated.

meaning: This is a news article by the Toronto Star. It does not pass personal comment, yet it reports that medical workers in Toronto would not be "forced" to get vaccinated.

This anti-vaxxer is criticizing a public health physician, Robert Strange, for his statements on vaccine effectiveness. The tweet attempts to discredit health officials and vaccines for not providing full immunity to the virus.

This tweet posts an article featuring Martin Kulldorf, a researcher behind The Great Barrington Declaration. It has been rejected by the WHO for being reckless in it's promotion of natural immunity. And this tweeter's claim that vaccinated people are more likely to show symptoms of COVID is reported in the Washington Post: "More than 15 studies have demonstrated the power of immunity acquired by previously having the virus. A 700,000-person study from Israel two weeks ago found that those who had experienced prior infections were 27 times less likely to get a second symptomatic Covid infection than those who were vaccinated."

This tweeter is relaying information that their pharmacist gave them about receiving the COVID-19 booster, as well as the flu and pneumonia vaccines. The information appears to be accurate and it is clearly pro-vaccine.

Tweeter is calling out another tweet, which says that Nigeria with low vaccination has fewer deaths from COVID compared to countries with high vaccination rates. Quoting such misleading tweets can further spread misinformation.

This man, who says he's a medical student on his Twitter profile, encouraged the public to get vaccinated and to use masks. He said the hospitals were at risk of not being able to treat patients due to rising COVID-19 numbers.
Tweeter is sharing a commercial he directed to encourage seniors in India to get vaccinated, debunking misinformation.
This tweet is made by a reputable reporter and addresses a quote from Johnson & Johnson regarding the spread of a COVID-19 variant. No personal opinion is injected into this quote.

Tweeter shared her interview with a retired ENT specialist who questioned COVID vaccines' effectiveness against the Omicron variant and criticized the UK public health's stance on vaccinating children aged 5-11.

Tweeter is replying to a tweet that taunts baby boomers for supporting vaccines. He notes, unlike other generations, baby boomers received several vaccines for diseases, so they have a better understanding of how vaccines work.
This tweeter reports that two of his friends just died of COVID-19 and he urges others to get vaccinated and to stay safe.

This post is critical of the CDC for changing their definition of a vaccine. The Miami Herald reported that "Before the change, the definition for 'vaccination' read, 'the act of introducing a vaccine into the body to produce immunity to a specific disease.' Now, the word 'immunity' has been switched to 'protection.'” This tweeter also uses a number of 16% that I could not find in a reputable source, in reference to Israel's research on vaccine effectiveness.
This is a response to a tweet about air travellers bringing Omicron from South Africa to Amsterdam, implying that choosing to get the vaccine is worse for public health than just getting tested.

This tweet is a reply to a direct tweet of an article about how politicians caused deaths by saying the AZ vaccine is ineffective. It's arguing that the media was harder on Trump about comments regarding COVID than they were on other politicians.
This tweet is saying that a pharmacist has seen the vaccine kill people, calling the vaccine poison making it seems more dangerous than the virus itself.
A reply to a tweet saying that vaccines don't work, linking to an article about how vaccines are effective at reducing contraction.
A direct tweet promoting an article from TIME about a vaccine researcher who they call a hero.

This tweet is pointing out that a single experience does not indicate how safe or effective the vaccine is in general. It's part of an argument with an anti-vaccine user that has since been suspended.
A direct tweet linking to a gofundme page that is somehow going to prevent vaccine mandates in Australia, they have over $100,000 raised so far.

This anti-vaxxer is saying that vaccines are a problem and not a solution. The tweeter links vaccines to suffering children but gives no explanation as to why they believe that, other than that the school year was chaotic.

This simple statement could be a comment about getting sick after taking the vaccine, or it could be a bigger anti-vaxx statement to discourage the public from getting vaccinated. Based on the content hosted on this tweeter's wall, he is an anti-vaxxer and supports the trucker convoy.
This woman shared information about vaccinating her children. She states that her kids have received various vaccines -- one got the COVID-19 shot -- and all has been fine with their health since.

Due to the lack of context around this tweet -- it is not possible to see it live on Twitter anymore -- it's hard to understand the tone and whether it is promoting or criticizing masks, Biden/BLM and vaccines, etc.
This tweeter is passing a personal comment on police who refused to take the vaccine. He seems to disapprove and equates the refusal of wearing a mask or getting vaccinated to murder.
It is not clear what this tweeter means. She says that mandates and vaccines are two different things, which is obvious and sounds nonsensical.

This simple question about whether there will be an end to vaccine passport requirements for entering the U.S. comes from an anti-vaxx perspective. Such a question would not need to be posed by a vaccinated person.

The tweeter used quotations but did not provide a source, yet when googled the quote is found to belong to Dr. Lindsay Weaver. Although the post provides no personal comment, the tweeter is anti-vaxx based on the content they share on their wall.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is making fun of Jim Corr, who claimed to be an anti-vaxxer, for actually being vaccinated. Corr used his vaccine passport to enter a restaurant on Christmas Eve. This appears to be verified in various tabloid news sources.

This tweeter says she is envious of Canada for making the vaccine available to children before Manchester had. She says that COVID-19 was running rampant throughout her community's schools and that the vaxx is needed.
criticism_other: Tardy vaccination availabilities for kids in the U.K.

meaning: This anti-vaxx post claims that there are people hiding the "true" and "adverse" effects of the COVID-19 vaccine. Part of the tweet is intangible and must be referring to specific conspiracy theories. The tweeter also accuses someone -- likely public health officials or pharma companies -- of fabricating reports.
This tweeter claims that there is damage being done by COVID-19 vaccines. There is no evidence to support this tweet. The tweeter says he does not want to ignore this risk of the vaccine any longer.

This anti-vaxxer is making fun of people who don't know what the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System is. The tweeter implies that pro-vaccine people are not aware that there are risks associated with vaccines.

This anti-vaxxer gives examples of vaccine failures to support his cause, yet his information is misleading. Moderna was not withdrawn from Europe. Reuters reported that "this is partly false, since only some countries in Europe [had] paused the use of the [Moderna] vaccine." Pfizer is not hiding the data, they said they cannot release trials until personal names and private information are blacked out, which may take up to 75 years. And AZ has not been withdrawn from the market.

This tweeter disapproves of anti-vaxxer football player, Aaron Rodgers, and State Farm Insurance -- who placed Rodgers in their ads. The tweet implies that vaccination is the best insurance we have, and therefore criticizes Rodgers and State Farm for being divisive.
criticism_other: Aaron Rodger's and State Farm Insurance

meaning: This post is somewhat nonsensical but seems to be saying that paranoia exists before and after the vaccine is administered. It's not clear what ATP refers to, but it could mean adenosine triphosphate. Urban dictionary lists ATP as the giver of life, so the tweeter could be correlating ATP to being unvaccinated. It's not clear.

This tweeter quotes Peter Doshi, who appears to be a discredited, anti-vaxx doctor. The tweeter uses this doctor as fuel to discredit public health official, Fauci. The tweeter says that the public was lied to regarding vaccine efficacy.
A tweet blaming the BC NDP government for someone's family contracting COVID despite being double vaccinated.
A tweet linking to a Pfizer FDA information release about vaccines in kids 5-11. It links to the FDA information, and explains that the benefits outweigh the risks.

This tweeter says that people are dropping dead from the COVID-19 vaccine. They did not provide any evidence of this. They also say that the initial sicknesses in China were a result of vaccine experimentation.

This tweeter says that Trump is pushing the vaccine and that his supporters are not listening. She says that such supporters are getting credible information elsewhere, therefore this is an anti-vaxx post.
This is a pro-vaccine post with information on how many vaccine doses had been administered in India.
This anti-vaxxer implies that Biden was installed to facilitate vaccine mandates, which this tweeter views as a form of corruption.
This MD is criticizing doctors who spread harmful information about COVID-19 vaccines. She states that those doctors should be stripped of their licenses because they are a threat to the public.
criticism_other: Doctors who spread disinformation about COVID-19 vaccines

meaning: This is a informational post from India's Bank of Baroda. It awarded money to various people for conducting an effective COVID-19 vaccination program.

This tweet regards freedom of press. A photojournalist's video of another journalist getting attacked for covering an anti-vaxx rally was removed from Twitter. The tweeter seems to imply that Twitter was in the wrong for censoring the video that was removed.
This anti-vaxxer is providing information about people who were refused service, somewhere, for not having vaccine passports.
A tweet about a statement made by England's Chief MO heavily criticising anti-vaccine misinformation, especially from high profile celebrities like Nicki Minaj.

A tweet about European government officials making statements arguing that vaccines are unsafe and mandates are tyrannical. It also calls these statements historic despite how common their misinformation is.

A reply to a tweet which includes a statement that says being BIPOC is a risk factor for COVID and non-white people are being prioritised for vaccines. This tweet argues that everyone had a chance to get vaccinated and white people shouldn't complain about this prioritisation.
This tweet includes vaccine safety on a list of exaggerated issues used by Republicans to stir up controversy and garner conservative votes.
Tweeter is warning that anti-vaxxer groups are organizing locally at the grassroots. They may have the backing from foreign powers but it is more concerning that they are emerging locally.
Tweeter is responding to a question about getting three doses of COVID vaccines and not testing positive ever.
Tweeter is replying to three other tweets saying that they presented fallacious reasons for their rights to remain unvaccinated and put everyone else at risk.

A tweet following Kyrie Irving's choice to go unvaccinated. It argues that individuals should be held accountable for actions that affect the health of others, in this case it was a 50K fine to the nets because Irving was in the change room.
A direct link tweet to an article, which is just a list of every instance where the CDC reported a possible issue with the vaccine, or a case of a new adverse reaction.
It's a nonsensical joke about the Russian military having affirmative action and Putin forcing soldiers to get the vaccine. It doesn't really make sense but the anti-vaccine sentiment is there.

Tweeter shares a Brietbart.com article that aggregated different news stories by mainstream media outlets to imply that vaccine mandates are causing staff shortage, flight disruptions and people's suffering.
The tweet is by a Jamaican news outlet saying that the Jamaican government has not given pharmacists permission to administer the COVID vaccines.

Tweeter, a PPC politician, is calling to end vaccine passport requirements by sharing a CP24 report where Ontario's Chief Medical Health Officer said the need for vaccine passports should be re-assessed.
The tweet is by Uganda's health ministry. It claims that a media report on the expiration date of COVID vaccines at government storage is false. I could not verify which party is right.
Tweeter is saying that the economy could open up again because the people of Sydney got vaccinated.

This is an anti-vaxx post which promotes conspiracy theories. It claims that the governments of the world are involved in a diabolic plan to hurt people with the vaccine. The tweeter claims that COVID-19 and its vaccine existed before 2019, before the official start date of the pandemic.
This tweeter is not vaccinated. They said that some of their co-workers are back at work, while they are not, and standing with their other unvaxxed friends.
Tweeter quotes a piece of news about potential side effects of two COVID vaccines implying that vaccines are not safe and effective. He does not highlight that such side effects are very rare.

This tweeter is comparing COVID-19 to a cold, while making fun of a small boy who wears three masks. That boy could be metaphorical or real, what matters is that this tweet is meant to discredit the severity of COVID-19.
support_other: That COVID-19 is just a cold

meaning: Tweeter is saying that President Biden cannot make vaccines mandatory because the authority lies with the States. But the tweeter does not say that the President made vaccination mandatory only for federal workers and contractors.
Tweeter is implying that there is something sinister in the CDC's action of changing the definition of vaccination.

This anti-vaxxer claims that COVID-19 is nothing more severe than a bee sting, and that "Nobel Prize" winning institutions were merely playing around with a vaccine. He also celebrates Raj Chetty, an economist, although the reasons as to why are not explained in the tweet.
This post claims that a body builder died four days after getting his second COVID-19 vaccine, yet this information was not verifiable in any reputable news searches upon a quick google search.

It's not clear if this is an anti- or pro-vaxxer. What is clear is that this tweeter is asking another twitter user to clarify her menstrual side-effects as a result of taking the COVID-19. This tweet is asking that woman to comment on whether any menstrual side effects resulted from taking other vaccines.

Based on what is posted on this twetter's profile, he encourages the use of masks and discourages reliance on the vaccine to stop transmission. His tweet is in response to people who say vaccines reduce the transmission of COVID-19 -- a fact that is still being studied. This tweeter believes that vaccines don't stop transmission and that masks must be worn. He also says some people can't get vaccinated so he appears to be freedom of choice, not pro- or anti-vaxx.

This tweet is not well written and it's slightly nonsensical yet it clearly implies that there is no link between COVID-19 infections and hospitalizations. The tweeter seems to be calling someone out for being afraid of the virus during lockdowns as well, yet because the original tweet was deleted it's hard to verify this.
criticism_other: Lockdowns, COVID-19 fear, Severity of the virus

meaning: The New York Times tweeted an opinion piece about a recent court case on Biden administration’s workplace Covid vaccine rule.

Tweeter is replying to a tweet quoting a graph that shows COVID deaths were much higher in the U.S. compared to Canada. Tweeter is claiming the difference is due to higher vaccination rates and more lockdowns in Canada.
Tweeter is saying localized public health intervention should be used instead of long-term indiscriminate ones to save the economy.
Tweeter is asking another user for update about a COVID vaccine being developed by the U.S. Army.
This app shows where vaccine appointments are available in Los Angeles on the day of the tweet.
