CP24 News tweeted a story about why some businesses will still require customers to show proof of vaccinations.
Tweeter is saying she and her children are now treated as outcasts and second-class citizens because they are unvaccinated.  It is a reply to another tweet from a suspended account.
Tweeter shares an incomplete image that is supposed to prove that vaccinated people are more at risk from the Omicron variant. He does not share the link to the picture.
Tweeter criticized a UK MP who wants to make vaccination mandatory for healthcare workers, saying without proof that vaccines are not effective against the Omicron variant.
A local news outlet from Newfoundland and Labrador tweeted when the third dose of COVID vaccines became available for immunocompromised people in that province.
Tweeter is insinuating that the COVID-19 vaccine was responsible for the singer Keith Martin death from acute myocardial infarction.
Tweeter retweets a Bloomberg interview of World Health Organization's Chief Scientist on issues related to COVID-19 and global response.
Tweeter is replying to a thread where users were debating whether mask mandates should be lifted.
Tweeter, a UK politician, is sharing NHS's vaccine drop-in clinic information.
Tweeter, a UK politician, is sharing NHS's vaccine drop-in clinic information.
Tweeter, an Australian reporter, quotes the Victorian Premier's comment on Novak Djokovic's refusal to abide by the Australian vaccination mandate.
Tweeter, who said she lost both her parents to COVID, is frustrated that the mask mandate is being lifted in her community with low vaccination rate and vulnerable population.
Tweeter appears to mock right-wing or conservative stances on different issues including vaccines.
The tweeter's post about a race car driver inventing a vaccine can be construed as disinformation.
Tweeter is implying that all anti-vaxxers and anti-lockdown conservatives support the PPC party in Canada but their support would not increase the party's seat in the parliament.
News media outlet The Hill tweeted an article about employees suing United Airlines to block the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter is implying that unvaccinated employees will increase the risk of infection in a workplace.
Tweeter is implying that Trump and Republicans are spreading vaccine disinformation and death from COVID will not stop unless people refusing vaccination get vaccinated.
Tweeter is insinuating that democrats and public health officials have something to do with the spread of new variants because they want to vaccinate people forcefully.
A tweet by the U.S. Dept. of State about sending COVID-19 vaccines to Morocco.
Tweeter quotes a report from Daily Mail, which often uses questionable source, about a FOX News host not refusing a position at the channel's talk show because of vaccine mandate.
Tweeter is supporting another tweet that said NHS health workers are not getting the vaccine because they already have natural immunity and the vaccine does not work against the Omicron variant.
The New Europe tweeted one of their opinion pieces from Dec 2021 when the Omicron variant was causing havoc. The writer is saying that Britain did not share enough vaccines as Boris Johnson claimed.
Tweeter jokes about vaccine side-effects after getting vaccinated.
Tweeter is implying that vaccines are not 100 per cent  safe for pregnant women.

A Ugandan news outlet tweeted a report about a group of university teachers opposing the Ugandan government's bill to punish unvaccinated people instead of trying to encourage citizens to get the shots.
This is part of a long thread where the tweeter picks parts from a NHS booklet on vaccinating children and questions the safety of the vaccine.
Tweeter is implying that New Zealand PM shut down a press conference because vaccines are ineffective. He does not mention that the PM was heckled and that no vaccines are 100 percent effective.

The tweeter is implying that a person who believed in disinformation about vaccines is suffering from COVID and her father died from the disease. But she does not mention COVID-19 explicitly in her tweet.
Tweeter posted a CNN article about FDA planning to mix and match booster jabs.
Tweeter is saying people need to get booster shots as vaccinated people can get infected by a person with COVID-19 symptoms.

Rand Paul, the U.S. senator for Kentucky, told his audience that he wanted the FDA to speed up the development of safe and effective vaccines in Nov.2020. This post is pro-vaccine, yet it criticizes mask use and social distancing, by deeming it as ineffective.
This tweeter praises vaccines and says they are safe, effective and that they save lives.

Tweeter is implying that President Biden's vaccine mandates are hypocritical by quoting the press secretary's comment from June about a countrywide vaccine mandate. But tweeter does not note that September mandate was only for large corporations, not states.
Tweeter appears to be criticizing Jamaicans' vaccine hesitancy saying that they should send their AstraZeneca shots to Haiti.

Tweeter quotes a report by the Federalists, a far-right news media, implying that a Democrat candidate refused to answer questions about vaccines because there is something sinister about vaccine mandates.
Tweeter posts an NYT article about agencies and companies that enforced the vaccine mandate before Biden's push for the mandate.
Tweeter is implying that Australia's Queensland government's enforcement of the vaccine mandate is similar to what settlers did to aboriginal people of Australia in the 1800s.
Tweeter does not seem to be happy about getting a third shot but it is not clear why.
Tweeter is implying that Indian State Tamil Nadu's decision to enforce a vaccine mandate is wrong as both vaccinated and unvaccinated people can transmit the disease.
The tweet is by a New Zealand news outlet that booster shots will become available to high-risk populations.

This tweet is a response to another tweet about the trucker convoy. This tweet implies that the truckers had no reason to get so upset about vaccine mandates because they still had access to essential services while not being vaccinated.
This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccines are poison and a form of medical genocide. This tweet essentially promotes the idea that vaccines are harmful and dangerous.

This is an informational report by a U.K.-based journalist that states information about vaccines being donated by that country abroad as foreign aid. She reports that those vaccine costs will be budgeted for, and could cut U.K. spending by 1.4 Million GBP. She does not pass comment on this matter.

This tweet is part of a thread about vaccinations. He says he is not vaccinated but is serious about masking in a previous tweet. This tweet expresses his concern towards people who judge those who are not vaccinated.

This anti-vaxxer posted a link to an article in a news source that is not well known about how military doctors are raising the alarm about vaccine side effects. The tweet implies that people are arrogant to hope that vaccines will not damage the individuals who take them.

This tweet states that pharmaceutical companies had been hoarding vaccines, yet that they would start allowing South Africa to produce two of them in 2022. The tweeter then says that South Africa has a responsibility from that point onwards.
This tweet implies that vaccinated people need a passport because they can spread COVID-19, and therefore need to be documented.

This tweeter is a conspiracy theorist who believes politicians, or the government, or public health officials have made a vaccine to kill people and to make profits. This tweet is critical of the news too, for spreading pro-vaccine information.

This tweet refers to athlete Aaron Rodgers, who has made the news for being anti-vaxx. This tweet asks why Rodgers should get vaccinated. The tweeter promotes the idea that COVID-19 has a zero percent chance of death.

This post implies that Fauci is responsible for "thousands of monthly" COVID-19 deaths because he placed emphasis on vaccines, not no "therapeutics." The post also states that Senator Rand Paul is a physician and he criticized Fauci's approach.
This post criticizes Australia's leader, Scott Morrison, for not ordering enough vaccines. It was reported in 2021, by various news outlets, that Australia had not secured enough vaccines.
This person believes that vaccines are "junk" because those who are injected still contract the virus, even though the vaccine only lowers the risk of severe illness.

This tweeter says that compulsory vaccines are an assault on the body. Austria had proposed compulsory vaccines, yet the BBC reported in 2022 that "Austria has decided to suspend its mandate for compulsory Covid-19 vaccinations for over-18s, days before it was due to start enforcing it."

This is a news post from Newsweek. It's about Republican Representative Madison Cawthorn who "introduced a new bill, the JAB Act, which would prohibit OSHA from enforcing vaccine mandates issued by the government." The post includes no personal comment or opinion on this matter.
This woman says that children should be vaccinated and that HEPA air filters should be installed in classrooms because the COVID-19 cases amongst kids were rising.
support_other: HEPA air filters, vaccination of kids

meaning: This anti-vaxx comment is currently deactivated on Twitter, so it's not possible to follow the thread. It is clear though that this tweet reveals skepticism towards the safety of vaccines in relation to fertility. Various news sources reported that severe infections of COVID-19 are dangerous to reproductive health and that vaccination mitigates those risks.

This anti-vaxxer claims that aborted fetuses are in vaccines, but that is not correct. Immunize BC says "The fetuses [involved with vaccine production] were not aborted to make vaccines." This tweet also promotes anti-government sentiments, along with vaccine disinformation.

This is an anti-vaxx post because the tweeter says they "unfortunately" got the first two vaccines, yet they will refuse the booster. The tweet also shares a video that has misleading information in it, such as that vaccines include aborted baby fetuses.
This tweet explicitly says that people who are in favour of vaccine passports are devils.
The link in this tweet is broken. It contains a quote without a source that states a large number of deaths, crated by the vaccine, have not been accounted for.

This tweeter supports vaccine passports yet says the CDC released mixed messages about waning immunity and the need for booster shots. He promotes a six-month valid passport, as Israel had, to encourage people to get boosters. He criticizes the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for dropping the ball on this booster issue.
criticism_other: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, CDC, mixed messaging

meaning: This post is pro-vaccine. It says that all vaccines are good, not matter what company manufactured each respective one. The tweet encourages people to roll up their sleeves, to take whatever jab is available to them.

This person feels that vaccines are being worshipped. The tweet criticizes people who post pictures of themselves and kids getting vaccinated, because they present themselves as heroes. This is clearly an anti-vaxx post and it undermines the severity of COVID-19.
criticism_other: Vaccines and people who pay attention to COVID

meaning: This tweet implies that vaccination was a failure because the COVID-19 rates rose heavily in 2021, despite people being vaccinated. The post implies that the government "sold" us a fake product and does not acknowledge that vaccines simply reduce illness rather than prevent it.
This tweeter posted a news article about a new vaccine in Australia that prevents four flu strains, along with laughing face emoticons. This is clearly an anti-vaxx post.
This anti-vaxx tweet is laughing at a pro-vaccine tweet, which is pasted inside this tweet. The main tweet is mocking the pro-vaccination person for getting angry at anti-vaxxers.
This tweet states that a U.K.-based pharmacy school is following public health guidelines regarding the importance of vaccinating people. The link supplied in this tweet is broken.

This tweeter is a trucker convoy support who is angry at GoFundMe for banning Trucker Convoy donations from their platform. He says that BLM and other causes were permitted on GoFundMe. He says that it's not equal to ban trucker sympathizers from donating.
This post is a repost of a news article. It reports that the pandemic could become an endemic in the U.S. if the vaccination rate is high enough.

This tweet was made by an anti-vaxxer, based on their Twitter profile. It's not clear what they are communicating with this tweet, other than that they believe the vaccine is not effective because it doesn't keep anyone safe unless a person's vaxx status is declared publicly.
This anti-vaxxer is criticizing France's vaccine passport system, by criticizing a broadcaster who resigned in 2021.

This pro-vaccine person is sharing information about the vaccine by way of a quote from an article released by the University of Minnesota. No personal comment is provided with this quote, however the tweeter is pro-vaccine based on their profile.
This reverend says that vaccine equity and distribution is important given mask mandates were lifted in March 2022. She says that churches have a critical role to play in the pro-vaccine mission.
This is a schedule of time slots available for people who need to be vaccinated in West Delhi.
This anti-vaxxer posts a link about Whoopi Goldberg and Bill Maher complaining about what he calls "medical tyranny." This post is clearly anti-vaccine mandate.

This is a repost of an anti-vaxxer's quote. The quote is used to promote anti-vaxx sentiments -- yet there is no personal comment attached to this quote, so it could be considered a news post, although the tweeter clearly has anti-vaxx biases.
This post reveals skepticism for vaccines because the tweeter asks to see how vaccination has flattened the curve.

This tweeter criticized Trudeau and asks why the government cannot simply ask people to show a negative COVID-19 test, rather than a vaccine passport when entering what appears to be sporting events (based on the previous tweeter's post).
This post claims that a person was drugged with Xanax, then given the COVID-19 vaccine, only to die hours later.
This anti-vaxxer implies that politicians should volunteer to administer boosters in order to free up hospital staff.
This anti-vaxx post shows contempt towards police who detained someone for entering a museum without a vaccine passport. The tweeter voices his opinion and feelings of shame towards those officers.
criticism_other: Police arresting people without vaccine passports

meaning: This tweeter reveals contempt towards members of the trucker convoy who equate COVID-19 mandates to living under the holocaust. She explicitly says it is not O.K. to make that comparison.
criticism_other: trucker convoy, equating COVID-19 mandates to the holocaust

meaning: This anti-vaxxer relays a story about a young "black" man who was hard working and could not get into a University in California due to being unvaccinated. The tweet claims Ted Cruz helped that unvaccinated man get into a Texas University. The tweet twists racial injustice issues for the anti-vaxx cause.
This anti-vaxxer says that vaccinated people are walking around as if they are bullet proof, spreading the virus. The post intends to discredit vaccines for not being 100% effective.

This is a news post that does not pass personal comment on vaccination, although it is clearly pro-vaccine. It reports that "Russian Empress Catherine the Great urging for her subjects to be vaccinated against smallpox has been unveiled in Moscow."
This post claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is not actually a vaccine. Therefore this post is anti-vaxx because it undermines the COVID-19 vaccine.
This tweet promotes vaccines and asks people to get vaccinated. The post implies that other measures, like masking and social distancing, are good but that vaccination is the most important.

This tweet ponders questions around vaccinating children. The tweet quotes Dr. Srinivas Kakkilaya, who was arrested in India for not wearing a mask in a grocery store. That MD is clearly discredited and therefore the information quoted from him in this tweet are grounded in disinformation.

This is a comment from someone who appears to have contracted COVID-19. The tweeter states no opinion on vaccines but says they think they got COVID-19 from their youngest child, before vaccines were available.
This pro-vaccine post is simple: It says that vaccines save lives.

This is a news article post from The Daily Beast. This is a reputable news source and the post passes no opinion on vaccination. The post regards Neil Young leaving Spotify due to them hosting Joe Rogan.
This post claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is not actually a vaccine. Therefore this post is anti-vaxx because it undermines the COVID-19 vaccine.
This post seems to be pro-vaccine because the tweeter expresses happiness that an anti-vaxxer was not included in the sports line-up.

This tweeter states that the person does not recall an influenza flu vaccine passport system, which means they consider COVID-19 as nothing more than the flu. The post is not clearly anti-vaxx, yet it discredits the severity of COVID-19.

This tweet seems to be a promotion for Ocugen, a high-risk investment company that is developing COVID-19 vaccines among other things. This post is not clearly pro- or anti-vaxx, but it is clearly promoting that Ocugen is going to replace Pfizer's products on the market.

Tweeter is implying that CBC did not do a good job of correcting misinformation and wrong information about vaccines during the pandemic because of the news media's apparent bias towards the conservative party.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines are not safe because they would supposedly worsen the disease. Tweeter shares a link that no longer exists.
Tweeter is implying that people in Northern Ireland do not want vaccine mandate and  a Tory member left his party because his party no longer listens to the people.
Tweeter is implying that people's concern about Puerto Rico's unreliable healthcare system drove them to get vaccinated.
This tweet calls for greater support for those experiencing side effects from the COVID19 vaccine.
support_other: support for those experiencing side effects

meaning: This is a news post about how the UN decided to send 60 Million vaccines to North Korea. No opinion or judgement was passed.

This tweeter claims that the elderly are most at risk for getting very sick from COVID19, that they should be the ones getting vaccinated, and that the vaccine is not very effective for healthy adults and children.

It's not clear what stance this post takes, because the original tweet that this comment responds to was deleted. However, this tweeter claims that someone was vaxxed and that she is playing a role. So this post could be referring to an actor.
This is an anti-vaxx tweet. It claims that vaccines are ineffective and damage businesses. It also claims that vaccines have cost "a fortune" with the implication that it has not paid off.
support_other: Economy over public health and safety

meaning: This tweet calls COVID-19 mandates "fear porn." The post claims that the vaccine is ineffective because it requires boosters and because it doesn't facilitate 100% immunity.
This is information from the Botswana Government, stating that vaccination roll-out for children ages 18 to 29 will begin.

Tweeter, a republican, is twisting White House Press Secretary's reply about private companies' compliance with the vaccine mandate to imply that mass vaccination was just a tool to control people not keep them healthy.
Tweeter is implying that vaccination causes injury and thus is not safe.

Tweeter is implying that vaccines are not safe by sharing an article by a media outlet that aggregated news about Nordic countries halting the administration of the Moderna COVID vaccine, but left out part of the explanation from experts.
Tweeter is implying that he was worried about contracting COVID for the last year and half until the youngest member of his family got fully vaccinated.
Tweeter points out the disinformation Trump-era former U.S. National Security Advisor  Michael Flynn spread about COVID-19 and its vaccines.
criticism_other: Former  U.S. National Security Advisor Michael Flynn

meaning: Tweeter is asking why the truckers who were protesting at the Canada-US border need proof of vaccination to crossover to Canada?
This is a news post about how vaccination travel lanes were extended for flights into Cambodia and Thailand. No personal judgement was passed on the post.
This tweet was made by an anti-vaxxer, based on the content of this person's wall. This tweet claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is not actually a vaccine, and that it is gene therapy.
This tweeter posted a comment saying that the "purpose" of the vaccine has been revealed. She says vaccination is a form of obtaining obedience over citizens. This is clearly an anti-vaxxer.
This tweet provides information on where to get vaccinations in Kelston. It is clearly pro-vaccine because it promotes vaccination.
This tweet worries about the number of fake vaccine certificates and how this makes it difficult to know how many people are actually vaccinated.

This tweeter says she is married to someone who wants her to be vaccinated, in order to attend social gatherings with him. She says though, that she does not want to get vaccinated due to her heart issues, which reveals her vaccine hesitancy. She also says she beat COVID-19 with water and sleep.
This person celebrates that they are now full vaccinated. This is clearly a pro-vaccine post.
Tweeter, an American football team, is tweeting about their proof of vaccination policy in accordance with the New York State vaccine mandate.

This tweet, which is in reply to a letter written by Canada's Minister for Transport Omar Alghabra to Conservative Member of Parliament Melissa Lantsman about vaccine mandates for truckers, writes that vaccines are ineffective and that Omar Alghabra is a liar.

This tweet is a comment on airlines being luxury goods. The tweeter seems to support equal distribution of vaccines by way of equating them to air travel, which the tweeter views as inaccessible for many citizens of the world.

This tweet is a doctor, yet has very controversial beliefs. Her twitter profile claims that individual rights come from god, not from government. It's not clear if this post contains false information, but it intends to discredit vaccines.

This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccination does not achieve herd immunity and that vaccination campaigns are not scientific. She provides no backup or facts to this information, which is grounded in disinformation.

This tweeter says a business in Belfast has been negatively impacted by COVID-19 passports. This tweet reveals their anti-vaxx status, and implies that the economy is more important than public health.

Although this tweeter claims he is not anti-vaxx, he is because he supports an anti-vaccine mandate protest. Anti-vaxxers tend to manipulate the public into thinking they are not anti-vaxxers, rather freedom fighters. This tweeter prioritizes the economy over public health.

This post is not really promoting or criticizing vaccines, it simply states concern that vaccine efficacy is not as great as we hoped for double vaxxed people. The tweeter expresses concern about children returning to school, and concern over hospitals likely becoming flooded.
criticism_other: Concern for children going back to school

meaning: This tweet criticizes the vaccination of children. It shows an image of Fauci next to an image of a man wearing a shirt that states false information about the risks children face due to vaccination.
This tweet claims that COVID-19 is just like a flu and that vaccines don't prevent illness.
This post does not pass judgment on vaccines, rather it promotes a lecture by Jene Jardine, who appears to be a reputable obstetrician.
This tweet explains that nurses and medical workers have always been required to be vaccinated, to improve the safety of the workplace.
It's not clear who this post refers to, but it makes a comment about an unvaccinated person and says that the person should have gotten vaccinated.
This trucker convoy supporter claims that Trudeau politicized vaccines, to win voters over. This tweet clearly supports the Trucker Convoy and discredits the need for vaccination.
This tweeter wants more vaccines to be sent to Vietnam where the population is generally pro-vaccine but lacking doses.
Many COVID19 vaccine manufacturers have not sent vaccines to those in need globally because of the financial risk to them.

This tweet criticizes CBC and the Trudeau government for their response to the Trucker Convoy.  The tweet calls CBC propaganda, which is why I labelled this post as misleading. The tweet addresses the lack of testing at borders to replace vaccine mandates.
This post does not pass judgment on vaccines, rather it promotes a lecture by Jene Jardine, who appears to be a reputable obstetrician.

This post appears to be pro-vaccine because anti-vaxxers would not use the words "conspiracy theorist" in their post. Nor would anti-vaxxers use the term "anti-vaccine" in their post. The post is about a talk by Dr.Shiva, who the tweeter labels as both of those things.

This tweeter is frustrated with anti-vaxx freedom fighters. She implies that their complaints are ridiculous because they can't enter restaurants they wouldn't want to visit without a vaccine passport.

This post is pro-vaccine but it is misleading because it claims that Sweden refused to vaccinate kids under 12. Reuters and other reputable outlets reported that "Sweden has decided against recommending COVID-19 vaccines for kids aged 5-11." The post also criticizes images that depict children looking scared while being vaccinated in Swedish media.
criticism_other: Sweden's youth vaccination policy and media

meaning: This is an informational post about information that OSHA released. The tweet does not include any personal opinion.

This tweeter is critical of U.S. government official Ron Klain, who he refers to as a president for some unknown reason. The tweet expresses concern about the liability shield that protects vaccine manufacturers in the event something goes wrong with their doses.
This tweet calls vaccine mandates as "unconstitutional." Therefore, this is an anti-vaxx tweet.

This tweet, which states that vaccine passports are illegal in Belgium is misleading. The tweet is not accurate. Various news sources reported that "A court has ruled a Covid pass in a region of Belgium is unlawful and has fined the district more than £4,000 per day until it stops enforcing it." This means that a court ruled that the passport as illegal in one small region of Belgium only.

This anti-vaxxer posted a graph from the Ontario government which depicts COVID-19 cases in Ontario, in correlation to vaccine status. The graph appears to be verified yet the comment this tweet makes is misleading because he claims that vaccinated people are the problem and that their movement should be restricted.
This is an informational post about the vaccination rate in India, which was nearly 76% by Oct.30, 2021.
This tweet reminds viewers that smallpox is no longer a topic of discussion because a vaccine was made to eradicate it.
This is an news post that contains no personal opinion about an ESPN new anchor who quite due to vaccine mandates.
This tweet calls vaccine mandates as "unconstitutional." Therefore, this is an anti-vaxx tweet.

This tweet implies that COVID-19 is not severe and that Denmark has no need for vaccine mandates. He uses the word "cases" in quotation marks, to imply that there are no actual cases of note related to COVID-19.

This tweet claims that there are many "excess" deaths created by the vaccine. And it links to an article that is not peer reviewed, which is posted on Steve Kirsch's -- a high tech entrepreneur and philanthropist's -- website, to support it's cause.
This post claims that vaccines are an experiment, therefore the tweet criticizes not only vaccine safety, but politicians and public health mandates, within very few words.
This is an informational pro-vaccine tweet, yet it's clearly pro-vaccine. The tweet reports that Nigeria will soon start COVID-19 vaccine production, which is verified in other news sources.

This is an informational post about a vaccination program for kids in India. The tweet contains no personal comment, it simply provides a link of information. The link contains information about how vaccine brands must not be mixed.

This post tweets about the deep state, which is a conspiracy theory regarding government figures. It also says that there's a vaccine war, and that the U.S. economy is in a "death spiral" as a result of the pandemic.

This tweet regards complaints from people who are upset about being denied entry into an event for not being vaccinated. This tweeter explains that vaccination is not required, but that a negative COVID-19 test is, if an individual is not vaccinated.

This tweet is written in garbled English. However, it appears to promote vaccines because it says that the FDA approved a booster, then it appears to question if Republicans in Missouri will protect people. Based on this tweeter's profile, they support Joe Biden and the democrats, so this tweet likely challenges the next moves made by republicans.

This tweet seems neutral at first glance, yet it is anti-vaxxine. The article this person posted first appears to be a rehash of a NBC article, yet it's very biased and ends with "Good luck moving 8 million tons of potatoes without truck drivers," meaning it's pro-Trucker Convoy.
It seems that the tweeter is worried that the vaccine will make her feel sicker, but it is not clear if she is talking about side effects.

This anti-vaxxer has an issue with various words used to describe vaccines, such as "pro-vaccine," "booster," and "mandate." What is not clear is why this tweeter takes issue with the word "Trump." He could be a member of the left who doesn't believe in mandates.

This tweet celebrates Elena Kagan, an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, for her defense of vaccine mandates. Kagan gave a speech, which is included in this tweet, about the necessity of defending people during these unusual times.
support_other: Elena Kagan's defense of vaccine mandates

meaning: This is a pro-vaccination tweet. It links to an article about athlete Aaron Rodgers who "had lied about his vaccination status, and his team had likely provided cover for his deception," according to The Atlantic. The tweet disapproves of this and implies that famous people can get away with murder.
support_other: Accountability for athletes who lie about their vaxx status

meaning: This tweet makes fun of people who believe in alternative remedies, such as Ivermectin, as a form of replacement for taking the vaccine. The post is in response to a sporting event, where many (likely unvaccinated) people were expected to attend.
This is an informational pro-vaccine tweet, yet it's clearly pro-vaccine. The tweet reports that Nigeria will soon start COVID-19 vaccine production, which is verified in other news sources.

This is an informational post on the Biden administration relying on vaccines, rather than a mass testing program. This news was reported in various reputable outlets. This tweet passes no personal judgment.

This trucker convoy supporter posted a tweet about the events in Ottawa. He is clearly a supporter based on his twitter post, although this post sounds neutral - yet it hints at contempt towards vaccine mandates.

This tweet claims that the U.S. government contracted and owns the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine, but that isn't correct. USA Today reported that "All in all, U.S. agencies committed about $2.5 billion to help develop Moderna’s vaccine and buy doses." So, U.S. government programs did contribute, but they didn't contract nor buy the vaccine in full.

This is a confusing post, yet it appears to be anti-vaxx. Anti-vaxxers typically do not like the term "anti-vaxx," so it's likely this anti-vaxxer is refuting this terminology by labelling it as an oxymoron when combined with the word "leftist." He likely chooses other words to describe his "anti-vaxx" beliefs.

This woman says she is vaccinated, however she promotes an anti-vaxx mentality because she says that she had to get vaccinated because of her job's requirements. It's not clear who she is replying to, and what was said earlier in the thread because Twitter deleted the previous comments.
This is a promotional tweet for vaccination services for children ages 12 - 15.

David Martin was featured on the "Plandemic," a movie praised by conspiracy theorists. He is not a credible source, and this tweeter refers to him as if he is. The tweeter also bashes Trump for pushing vaccines.

This tweeter claims that the jab is not actually a vaccine. He's responding to a talk show host who also appears to be anti-vaxx, so it is not clear why he's attacking her by asking why she allows that kind of "BS" to go unchecked.
This tweeter says that he suffered side effects from the vaccine. He also posted a link to a similar story about Michael Robison, on a site that does not appear credible, to back up his story.
This anti-vaxxer is questioning vaccines and their effects on the heart by posing two questions that indicate his skepticism towards the jab.

This tweeter is complaining about the 55 year wait time that is required to received FOI documents regarding vaccine trials by way of the FDA. This time is accurate, according to Reuters, because the FOI must be sifted through and information must be redacted before the trials are released to the public. The tweeter is skeptical of vaccinating children due to an inability to access these records.

This post criticizes moms who are anti-vaxx, yet who were vaccinated as children, for putting their own kids at risk of disease without the protection of vaccination. The post is a bit extreme saying that those anti-vaxx moms' kids will die, so I flagged this as misleading.
criticism_other: Moms who are vaccinated and who deny their kids of vaccines

meaning: This post claims that pharmaceutical companies pay money to the FDA to approve their vaccines. The post implies that there is corruption between government and "big pharma" and that vaccines are not effective.
This tweeter says that the Liberal approach is to make mask and vaccine mandates while implying that they don't actually work because cases continue to rise.
This anti-vaxxer is angry with people who are vaccinated, and who judge anti-vaxxers. The tweeter says those people should be more upset about the vaccine not being effective.

This original tweet was deleted from Twitter, likely because it spreads vaccine hesitancy. The tweet contains jumbled information that it claims comes from Pfizer -- although I could not find a verifiable source on this -- regarding joint pain in kids.

Nick Corbishley is the other of scanned, a book that this tweeter promotes. That author defines himself as a journalist, however he promotes the use of Ivermectin on a blog, which has been reported as having no effect on curing COVID-19. This tweet claims that digital passports are an invasion of privacy and "personal freedom."
This pro-vaccine tweet says that vaccines are intended to stop people from dropping dead if they contract the virus. The tweet asks "what is wrong" with people who don't understand that.

This post claims that a lot of people have been negatively effected by the COVID-19 vaccine, even though they were previously fit. The post links to an athletes wall, who claims he can't run like he used to after being vaccinated. This is clearly and anti-vaxx post.

This tweet questions "liberal democracy" due to the enforcement of vaccine passports. The tweeter asks why vaccines are being mandated even though they don't stop transmission, which discounts the benefits of vaccines. The tweet also promotes the idea of other "alternative" options to support "liberty."

This tweet criticizes Hall-of-Famer Charles Barkley, who said "First of all, you don’t get the vaccine for yourself, you get it for other people.” Although transmission is still possible between vaccinated people, this tweet is of course anti-vaxx because it targets a public figure who supports vaccines.

This tweet is critical of anti-vaxxers who refuse to be vaccinated, yet receive antibody treatment. The tweeter says those people are making costs soar for the public, in a previous tweet. He says that people who receive the treatment should be required to be vaccinated in order to receive the treatment.
criticism_other: People who get monoclonal antibody treatment but not vaccinated
support_other: Vaccine mandates for people who chose antibody treatment

meaning: This tweeter is making fun of an anti-vaxxer who says that vaccination of the Global South does not prevent the spread of COVID-19 variants. The line "this guy on twitter reckons he's wrong" refers to the other tweeter criticizing a scientific statement, and the tone is tongue in cheek.

This actor is complaining about his union, SAG-AFTRA (Which represents performers and broadcasters) for making him take boosters. This post is misleading because it implies that vaccination requires endless amounts of boosters.

This is an anti-vaxx post. It claims that vaccine "administers" are getting targeted and that the media has been hiding that. This could at first appear to be sympathetic towards health workers, but this tweet intends to show that the public is not happy with vaccination and that there is reason for violence.

This post appears to be pro-vaccine, although it is more of a philosophical criticism to reporting. The tweeter seems to be taking a jab at how mainstream media reports stats. Ultimately this post passes comment on news reporters, not on the vaccine itself.

The tone of this post is slightly difficult to read, but this tweeter's profile is clearly in support of the democrat party: So, this tweeter's profile seems to be saying that if vaccines are not available for vulnerable children, he is happy to continue taking booster shots.
Tweeter is saying that COVID-19 vaccines are untested and poisonous, and also implying that vaccine advocates are killing children, and will be tried like war criminals.

This tweeter claims that swine flu vaccines lead to many less deaths than the COVID-19 vaccine. That is misleading though. Fullfact.org reported that their reporters "could not find a confirmed number of deaths reported after a swine flu vaccine in 1976, but reports suggest that a number of the deaths could not be directly linked with the vaccine. The rollout was halted because of a number of reports of Guillain-Barré syndrome, and the fact the swine flu cases never reached pandemic levels."
This pro-vaccine post is in response to an anti-vaxx post on twitter. This post emphasizes that vaccines reduce severe illness as a result of contracting COVID-19.
This woman believes that the government made vaccines in the form of microchip injections to track the public. This is a conspiracy theory.

This post claims that Fauci, and other health officials, said that the vaccine would stop transmission, which is not true. According to Reuters, "Fauci explain[ed] that it is not yet clear how effective the current vaccines are at curbing the spread of the virus from an immunized person to others. In other words, a vaccine will prevent the recipient from getting sick, but that person may still carry the virus and expose those who have not received the vaccine."
Tweeter supposedly used World Health Organization data to create a graph to imply that vaccine and mask mandates do not work.
Tweeter seems to imply that since the person Case is fully vaccinated it would not be risky if he is in close contact with someone who tested positive.
Tweeter appears to taunt vaccinated people by replying to an image of obese Black women, saying they were given the COVID vaccine because they refused to eat salad.
Tweeter shared a news article from Crooks and Liars about seven doctors who went to an anti-vaccine conference and contracted COVID-19.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines do not work and the policies around vaccine mandate, COVID safety precautions do not make sense.
Tweeter posted a video of a market but it cannot be verified whether the video is from a Christmas market in the Netherlands in December 2021.

This tweeter seems to be criticizing vaccine mandates by blaming such mandates for a team not being able to get into the playoffs. This tweet has been deleted and it's not possible to view the entire thread for more information.

This tweeter is comparing COVID-19 to aliens that visit from outer space. Basically, this tweeter feels that COVID-19, and its severity, is imagined. The tweeter raises anti-vaxx sentiments in this post as well.

This tweeter asserts that vaccines work, and that a controversial American politician -- Marjorie Taylor Greene -- does not. Greene is famous for promoting conspiracy theories and for showing support for QANON.
Tweeter is criticizing Republican politician Marjorie Taylor Greene for spreading disinformation. The context of the tweet is not clear.

This tweeter is a football reporter for ESPN. This post clarifies information about Aaron Rodgers, who misled the public about his vaccination status. The information contained in this tweet has also been reported by other reputable news providers, such as the CBC.

This tweeter says that a professor "admits" COVID-19 won't stop vaccines, indicating the tweeter's anti-vaxx status. He posts a video featuring Prof Salim Abdool Karim and highlights his quotes to support his anti-vaxx cause.

This tweet has an anti-vaxx bias because it says there is a protest in NYC regarding "mandatory vaccines." Vaccines have never been made mandatory in North America, although a passport system was invented.
Tweeter posted an unverified piece of news about Christina Parks, a scientist and an educator from Michigan, that she supposedly started a Vaccine Injury Treatment Alliance.
Tweeter is implying without any proof that people, who are skeptical about vaccines, also justify Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
Tweeter quoted a news article from the Hill about U.S. Marine Corps dismissing 103 marines for refusing to take the COVID-19 vaccine.
Tweeter is accusing UK news media Daily Express and Telegraph of potentially spreading misinformation about the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in future.
Tweeter is expressing his opinion about vaccine passports but does not explain why his elderly relative does not like the system or why one of his acquaintances could not obtain a vaccine passport.
Tweeter posted a video of Korean boy band 2PM. One of their members was absent in the video because he was not feeling well after taking the vaccine.
Tweeter is making a general statement about some Americans, who refuse to take Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine but sign up for an experimental trial of anti-viral drugs.
Tweeter is spreading the conspiracy theory that Bill Gates created COVID-19 so that he can sell vaccines to cure it.
This is a tweet by the Health and Family Welfare department in India's Odisha state encouraging people to take the vaccine even if they had already contracted COVID-19.
Tweeter is just posting information about COVID-19 vaccine appointment availability in San Diego.

Tweeter is implying that the safety of COVID vaccines is a lie because Democrats would have opposed the vaccines if they were approved during the Trump era. But tweeter fails to point out that the current vaccines are also approved by the World Health Organization not just by the FDA and CDC.
Tweeter is implying that vaccine proponents lied when they supposedly said the pandemic will be over once vaccines become available.
Tweeter is sharing her experience of talking to a Libertarian, who was offended that she asks others about their vaccination status.
Tweeter shared a news article from Freedom Bunker, that aggregates news from libertarian chatter dailies. But the news could not be found on the website.
The health department of Ohio, U.S.A is sharing a tweet about the work they are doing in vaccinating people at educational institutes.
Tweeter is implying that children who did not get vaccinated are at risk of contracting severe COVID-19.
Tweeter is praising Navy Seals who in January refused to obey the vaccine mandate on religious groups and sued the Biden administration over it.

This tweet was deleted, so it's difficult to understand the context of this comment. The tweeter appears to be pro-vaccine but believes their vaccine is only effective if others are immunized. The tweeter does not understand that being vaccinated also reduces the likelihood of severe sickness from the COVID-19 virus within one's self.
The tweet by Auschwitz Museum is condemning anti-vaxxers' claim that their situation is the same as that of the Jews who were persecuted during the Nazi regime.
Bloomberg news tweeted their feature on the number of COVID vaccines administered worldwide.
Tweeter shared a video of English comedian Russell Brand to imply that conservatives are not the only ones opposing vaccine passports.
Tweeter is implying that only Candance Owens speaks the truth and everything else including vaccines, mainstream media, current government is untrue.
Tweeter implied that people were dying from COVID in thousands in September 2021 because many did not have access to vaccines.
This woman is pro-vaccine and is replying to a tweet regarding Australia's measures. This woman seems to imply that Australia needs more tangible COVID-19 mandates, that are achievable.
Tweeter finds it foolish that people, who refuse to take the free COVID-19 vaccine and obtain a free proof of vaccination card, are paying for a fake card using their bitcoins.
Tweeter is sharing her own experience of contracting COVID-19 but it is not clear if she tested positive or if she has been fully vaccinated.
Tweeter is replying to a GOP post about the Biden administration withdrawing its vaccine mandate on employers, saying that the pandemic would be over if everyone got vaccinated.
Tweeter is implying that the COVID vaccines are not safe by citing a news report from a German media website, which is behind a paywall. Tweeter's claim about the full report could not be verified.
Tweeter is baselessly claiming that vaccines do not work.
Tweeter is saying that U.S. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy of the Republican Party is responsible for people remaining unvaccinated and dying from COVID-10 in Bakersfield, California.
Tweeter is implying Texas Governor Abbott intentionally did not do enough to stop the vaccine mandate on employers.

This tweet includes a link to a Southwest Airlines related tweet, where another tweeter said Biden forced employees to be vaccinated, while the SW Airlines CEO denied that. This post claims that tweet is a lie, which seems to indicate a pro-vaccine status. This tweet also says there was no executive order on federally mandated vaccines, yet various news reports said there was, so this tweet is misleading.
This post is not promoting or criticizing anything. The tweeter simply said that they are triple vaxxed, typically healthy and still feel very sick as a result of contracting the virus.

This is ultimately a pro-vaccine post, yet it is grounded in misleading information. The tweeter says that the U.S. should have approved COVAXIN even though "Covaxin has been facing criticism back home in India for not sharing its Phase-3 trial data, despite being approved by India's top drug regulator," reported the Hindustan Times. The tweeter also claims COVAXIN was approved by the WHO, but that was only on a emergency basis, and the WHO suspended the use of COVAXIN in 2022.

This is a criticism on Republicans. There does not appear to be vaccine content in this post, yet the article has a pay wall. The tweeter says Republicans don't put America first. The article appears to be about Republicans slowing aide to Ukraine.

This tweet is not promoting or criticizing anything, it is simply asking what effectiveness three boosters have against Delta, while throwing out some unsourced numbers on what they believe that effectiveness to be. The tweeter said that three vaccines are "less than 80%" effective against the Delta variant. But that is misleading as per the CDC numbers: https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7104e3.htm
This tweeter believes that the vaccinated are passing COVID-19 around "for fun" -- because the vacinne does not prevent transmission -- and that vaccine passports are discriminatory.

This tweeter claims that Biden, the CDC and the FDA mandated a one size fits all situation regarding vaccinations. The post is misleading because it makes no sense to tailor vaccination requirements to specific individuals within the public.
Tweeter is saying that pharmaceutical companies and rich nations are responsible for not sharing the COVID-19 vaccines in a timely fashion with the Global South.
Peter Charles Doherty is an Australian immunologist and Nobel laureate. This post is scientific information on how vaccines are helpful to preventing severe illness.
This woman appears to be pro-vaccine based on her Twitter profile, therefore this tweet appears to be celebrating Sony Pictures for enforcing the vaccine mandate at their theatres.

Tweet links to a video of a paramedic expressing frustration after receiving a letter saying he would not be able to work if he did not get the vaccine. User who reposted the tweet works as a GP for the NHS and does radio interviews, much of the information on her page is firmly anti-vax, though she does seem to be an actual doctor.
Tweet claims that the reason heart complications were listed as a symptom of omicron was to cover up the fact they are actually a symptom of the vaccine.
Tweet implies that public health officials bribed children to get the vaccine so that they could run a Santa-themed commercial over the holiday season.

This tweeter promotes COVAXIN, rather than mRNA vaccines and says that there is science and data to support it's reputation as a good vaccine. The WHO however suspended it's use in 2022, and the U.S. did not approve of it's use in America because the manufacture was not able to provide it's 3rd trial results.
Tweet is a quote from a right-wing account followed by a link to a national review article explaining how the vaccine mandate in NYC is organized. The user is the opinion editor for Newsweek.

User claims that the reason govts and companies waited to release vaccine data was because they knew it had little use and many side effects. User also claims the vaccine doesn't stop you from getting Covid and implies the side effects make it not worth the risk.
Tweeter wants the University of Manitoba to continue with vaccine, mask and isolation mandates beyond the Winter 2022 term.

Tweeter appears frustrated that England did not take measures to close borders or isolate South African travelers when the Omicron variant was detected in SA. She also seems to imply that vaccines were not working against that variant.
The tweet is by ACT, an anti-immigration, anti-Muslim, conservative group, calling people to sign up to stop vaccine and mask mandates and lockdowns.
Tweet is a link to the Royal College of Midwives encouraging people to share pro-vaccine information to midwives so they can pass it on to pregnant women.

It's not clear what this twitter means by "withdraw on a vaccination" but her tweet is responding to a post that shows a video of Biden being vaccinated. This tweeter's profile is filled with questionable material, that points towards her anti-vaxx status.
This tweeter makes a joke about casual dating, saying that by dating an anti-vaxxer, a person can achieve a short-term dating arrangement. This implies that the anti-vaxxer may not live for long.
Tweet is a series of hashtags under a tweet that no longer exists. Tags claim that vaccines permanently maim and kill, and should be kept away from children.

This tweeter believes that democracies around the world have destroyed the economy for a virus that is not threatening. He believes that the virus is no more than a flu. He also questions whether the "CPP will release something deadlier," which hints at his conspiracy theories.
Tweet seems to be from a public health department in a province of India providing information on what percentage of the community has received their first dose.
Tweet references a case in the Australian vaccination database for adverse events where a seven year old died of a heart attack. It advocates trying to prosecute the company Pfizer for the death.
support_other: prosecuting phrama companies for vaccine deaths

meaning: This tweeter is accusing governments and pharmaceutical companies of corporate slaughter for hoarding vaccines and vaccine patents in the west. He refers to this "medical apartheid" as "corporate slaughter." He posted some stats on the vaccination rate of countries in Africa, versus the U.K. vaxx rate.
support_other: Supplying vaccines to the global South

meaning: This tweeter appears to be anti-vaccine and is creating a smoke screen about his beliefs in science. He claims that being anti-vaxx is not about disbelieving science, rather that science is constantly changing. Therefore his anti-vaxx beliefs are justified through his belief that something will change with the vaccine's effectiveness.
Tweeter is implying that people in Australia are eligible for booster shots but are not getting the third dose.
Tweeter is hinting at the hypocrisy that an anti-vaxxer is okay with getting a foreign organ in his body through a kidney transplant but would not get a vaccine shot.
Tweeter, a conservative journalist, shared a news report by Reuters about a U.S. court freezing Biden's vaccine mandate on employers.
Tweeter is hinting that there is something sinister in the promotion of vaccines and that health officials will keep on imposing new rules on people to track and trace their every movement.
Tweeter criticized a BBC political presenter, who tweeted about British elites helping Russian kleptocrats, implying that he also lied about the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines.

This tweeter reveals anger at anti-vaxxers and says that if they don't believe in science, they should die in the streets. The tweeter posted an article regarding an America war veteran who died because the hospitals were full -- due to COVID cases -- and he could not get treatment.
This pro-vaccine post ultimately communicates that vaccines save lives and encourages COVID-19 vaccination of Africa.

This tweet is an observation and it does not promote or criticize. The tweet states that members of the left tend to be critical of "big pharma" for their profit making goals, rather than the effectiveness of their vaccines. This could be a pro-vaccine post, but it is not entirely clear.
This post encourages the public to get a booster shot as soon as they are elligible.

This tweet does not clearly take a stance on vaccines, rather it makes a comment that vaccines and COVID-19 could effect women's reproductive health. The tweet complains that women's reproductive health is under researched.
criticism_other: Under researching of women's reproductive health

meaning: This is a tweet that links to a GETTR post about how mandates will end soon because of alternative medications, at least one of the medications listed is proven to be ineffective. It also implies that mandates are part of a large conspiracy between the government and big pharma.

This is a tweet from someone who claims to have lost a parent to an adverse reaction to the AZ vaccine. They also claim there was no support from the government. It seems they are part of the minority who have been affected by adverse reactions.
This tweet misrepresents the findings of a medical study about natural versus vaccinated immunity to make the argument that firing the unvaccinated is discrimination.

This tweet is a reply to a tweet about private sector vaccine mandates in New York. It argues that vaccine mandates don't reduce infection rates, and that Florida is safer because of a lack of vaccines.
This tweet argues that the vaccines have not been adequately tested, saying that vaccine programs to get college students vaccinated is a conspiracy amongst the government to test it on the public.

unable to reference the original tweet, but user is claiming that there is an 80% single dose vaccination rate, and 55% with a double dose. User does not specify who is the vaccinated population, what the time frame is, or where they are getting their information from, making it difficult to determine context.
Tweeter is implying that employee walkouts against the vaccine will work as a similar walkout made Netflix CEO reconsider his stance on a transgender issue.
This tweet is not a supporter of mRNA vaccines. It suggest that America and the EU should be using COVAXIN, although the WHO recently suspended it's usage in the Global South.
This woman is asking what restaurants will still require proof of vaccination -- while mandates were lifted -- likely because she wants to feel safe wherever she dines out.

This tweet uses Dr Maloney, a now discredited scientist who claims to have invented the mRNA vaccine, as a beacon of hope for the anti-vaxx cause. The tweeter says Maloney said the vaccines were rushed, but Maloney has been publicly denounced by members of his team who developed the vaccine.

This woman is replying to a post that says "we have the tools [vaccines etc.] to prevent" the spread of Delta. This tweet is skeptical of vaccines because she posted a chart that shows the number of COVID-19 cases rising, despite people being vaccinated. The woman does not mention that vaccines lower the virus' impact on a patient's health.
This tweet contains information about school-based vaccination clinics, and is therefore pro-vaccine.

This tweet argues that government and the Queen made up her COVID case to trick people into taking the vaccine. It also argues that the vaccine is ineffective and is not the reason why the Queen beat COVID.

This is a reply to a tweet about a fully vaccinated Homeland Security official getting COVID, the tweet implies that the headline left out his vaccination status on purpose to hide vaccine inefficacy.
This tweet makes the argument that although vaccines work and people should take them, forcing people to take them is problematic.
This tweet asks about vaccines causing AIDS, which is a suggestive and ridiculous question to pose at all.
This tweet is critical of anti-vaxxers, arguing that prioritising freedom over public health is a motivated by ignorance and privilege.

Tweet is a response to several other users claiming that it is not right to "force" people to get a vaccine, and that her choice not to get vaccinated was informed by her experience supposedly getting an autoimmune disease from a previous vaccine.
A tweet promoting a public official's town hall meeting about a city employee vaccine mandate.

User appears to be arguing with several other users and the BBC about something related to vaccines. User claims "the masses" believe the vaccine is the 100% cure to the pandemic, and that news outlets are purposefully using old data.
User is implying that the reason Governor Gavin Newson hasn't been seen in two weeks is because he is suffering side effects from the vaccine, calling it karma for other policies he has enacted.

A tweet about a local restaurant owner who isn't taking vaccine passports, she says in the video she is pro-vaccine but doesn't mention the police visits discussed in the tweet. The tweet is much more inflammatory than the woman in the video.
A direct tweet of an article about Abbott's decision not to enforce vaccine mandates on the National Guard.
This tweet says some confusing things, namely that the vaccine isn't really a vaccine and that it hasn't been tested properly. It compares government vaccine mandates to snake oil salesmen.

A reply to a tweet arguing that ending mandates limits the freedom of people who are vulnerable to COVID, because they have to stay home to stay safe. This tweet argues that because they are vaccinated this is untrue. It seems to support vaccines but also supports the end of vaccine mandates.

It's an exchange between a reporter and someone else, the question is about officials who say children shouldn't be vaccinated. The interviewee says that children should be vaccinated, and anti-vaxxers are conspiracy theorists.

This is a pro-vaccine post, yet the claim that vaccines prevent transmission may be a stretch. Various news reports say that fact is still being studied and the BMJ reported that the "UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA)... didn’t say outright that covid-19 vaccines prevent transmission.“

This pro-vaccine tweet breaks down the numbers of deaths in a particular area of the U.S., while stating that most of the dead were unvaccinated. The tweeter concludes that greater vaccination rates would have saved lives.

This conspiracy theorist posted a link, to an article that is not reputable, which attempts to prove a link between Bill Gates and Neil Ferguson (an epidemiologist who supported lockdowns). The tweet implies that powerful figures were behind vaccines for the purpose of controlling the population.
It calls the anti-vaxxers at the freedom convoy protests anti-social and selfish and promotes the benefits of being vaccinated.
User claims to know three Nurses who are skeptical of the vaccine and have turned it down, calling them heroes.

User is skeptical of an article from Yale Medicine claiming vaccines remain about 90% effective against different strains of Covid. User is implying that if vaccines are so effective, we shouldn't need masks or lockdowns, and that natural immunity is effective against Covid and viruses in general.
Tweet refers to a variety of conspiracy theories about Covid being a bioweapon, Fauci and the U.S working with Ukraine biolabs, and Russia destroying evidence before vaccine data is released.

User is replying to an article by the UK times about a top public heath official calling for children over 12 to be vaccinated. The user responds with a link from a Jerusalem post article about ongoing research in to long term effects and implies the vaccine is unsafe. He also refers to the public health official as a pedophile.

Tweet refers to the Bradford County Coroner ruling a recent cause of death as Myocarditis. The quote posted does not refer to vaccines, but in the caption the user links the death to vaccine side effects.
This tweet is part of a gross thread that likens vaccine mandates to rape, it calls the logic behind vaccine mandates irrational.
The tweet implies that the vaccine isn't real and that it is some kind of conspiratorial attempt from the government to commit genocide.
The tweet makes an unsupported claim that the covid vaccine causes an extremely rare immune disorder, which is being covered up by the government.
This user says they will not be getting the vaccine.
It says people should know how vaccines work by now.
It explains that even if you had COVID you should get vaccinated once your natural immunity starts to wane, around 12 weeks after recovery.
A tweet as part of a thread with lots of unsourced data the significance of which is only partially explained. It is supposed to prove that vaccines don't work.
A tweet of mantras about being a patriotic, vaccinated, freedom and science loving Canadian.
A tweet about protests against vaccine mandates in Europe, calling mandates tyrannical.
This is a pro-vaccine tweet that says vaccines will be manufactured in the U.K. The tweet says that is a good thing.
This tweet is anti-vaxx. It shows a graph of COVID-19 deaths, and shares a tweet that asks why people are dying in a country with a high vaccination rate.

This tweet does not seem to take a clear stance on vaccines. It says that vaccine uptake at the hospital is high and that cases are high, but there is no personal comment as to whether this person is anti-vaxx or not. The original tweet is deleted, so it's not possible to gain more insight.
A tweet about someone who passed after getting vaccinated, saying most vaccine side effects result in death.
This post is asking if a booster shot is required if a vaccinated person contracts COVID-19 and recovers. There is no personal inflection to indicate this persons' bias towards the vaccine.

This tweeter is re-posting an article about a pro- and anti-vaccine quarrel between Nicki Minaj and Joy Reid. Minaj told the media that she wanted to do "more research" on the vaccine before taking it. The tweet itself does not reveal any opinion.
This tweeter claims that Rachel Maddow gets paid 30K an episode by Pfizer to promote vaccines. There was no evidence of that anywhere in the news.

This is a reply to a tweet with a map of the U.S showing waves of COVID in different areas at different times. The tweet argues that the difference between a high impact and a low impact is vaccination rates.
This tweet contains information about India's travel rules, regarding foreigners entering the country. There is no personal comment inflicted upon this post.

This post promotes vaccines by sharing an article from the New York Times that reported that by speeding up vaccine distribution we can slow transmission of the virus. The post also states that humans must act accordingly to prevent the spread of the virus.

This post is anti-vaccine because I was not able to find any verified reports in reputable news outlets that vaccines were tested on Uyghurs by China. This tweet is not specifically about vaccination, it is about Uyghurs rights.

This anti-vaxx post questions the safety of COVID-19 vaccines for being developed so quickly. The post brings up a medication called VIOXX, which did kill people in 2004 before being pulled from the market.
This man is anti-vaxx because he claims that members of BLM are smarter than LGBTQ people, because BLM vaccination rates are lower.
A tweet linking to an article about a book excerpt where Pfizer's CEO explains that the US government tried to hoard vaccines ahead of distributing them to the rest of the world.

A part of a thread about how to tackle vaccine misinformation. Arguing that fear is our motivator over logic, people don't get vaccinated because they fear the vaccine and people get the vaccine because they fear the virus. How do we make that fear appropriate to the situation?
This person is arguing that there is not sufficient proof that vaccine boosters work. Saying essentially that there are too many variables to know for sure how much vaccines help.
This post contains a link to a news site that is not reputable. And the tweet says that the CDC and the UK government released proof that vaccines don't work. This information is not accurate.

This tweet cites a hoax created for a mockumentary, the 'FunVax 2005', as proof that vaccines have had hidden contents before. FunVax was a hoax that people, including this user, thought was real rather than a parody theory.

A tweet of a video about the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation, twisting a video about reproductive health programs into a conspiracy theory about the Gates' creating vaccines to control the population.

This tweet is a reply to someone asking what people will do on their holidays, to manage the risk of COVID-19. This tweet is pro-vaccine and says that everyone in their family is vaccinated and that COVID-19 infections are low in their area due to people following public health measures.

This tweet regards press freedoms at the trucker convoy in Ottawa. The tweeter was told she required a security guard to cover the trucker convoy. The tweeter says it's remarkable (in a bad way) that someone would need a security guard in a G7 country, to cover a protest.
criticism_other: Lack of press freedoms at Trucker Convoy

meaning: This is a quote taken from a scientific article that has not been peer-reviewed, therefore I flagged this as misleading. The information claims that mixing booster doses may be a good thing, yet the information is not yet reliable. This does appear to be a pro-vaccine post.

This tweeter is angry at Prince Harry for speaking out against Joe Rogan's anti-vaxx comments. The tweeter says that Harry is a guest in America and that he should "mind his manners." This is clearly an anti-vaxx post.
This tweeter criticizes anti-vaxxers and explains that vaccines help the immune system. The tweeter says that anti-vaxxers don't understand what the vaccine is for.

This post discusses the vaccination of children and what percentage of parents support vaccination of school children in Chicago. The tweet posted a graph, to break down what particular ethnic backgrounds support vaccination.

This tweeter replied to a woman who said her friend became impotent after taking the vaccine. This tweeter is anti-vaxx because he declares that it was of course the vaccine that made the man impotent, if he never had issues with that before he took the vaccine. The tweeter doesn't wonder if that information is even correct.

This tweet is badly written, but it is in response to a post regarding medical workers in the U.S. who would be fired if unvaccinated. This tweeter's wall contains COVID-19 disinformation, so he is certainly an anti-vaxxer.

This post questions the safety of vaccines by saying a GP had the "courage to say no to vaccines." The tweeter posted a link to an article that is not reputable. The doctor they refer to is likely discredited.

This tweet is asking how there could be breakthrough infections when people are masked and vaccinated, it's a fair question but it is part of a thread where the user is taking an anti-vaccine stance criticising public health policy.

This anti-vaxx tweet calls out Lou Haigh, the Labour MP for Sheffield Heeley for instating vaccine passports. The tweeter argues that they are useless because COVID-19 rates continue to sky rocket even though people are getting vaccinated -- with the goal of undermining the public's trust in vaccine effectiveness.

This tweeter, Candace Owens, is a right-wing pundit. She is anti-vaxx and promotes the idea that vaccines are ineffective because they don't prevent transmission of COVID-19. She doesn't mention anything about the vaccine reducing the risk of severe illness as a result of contracting the virus.

This tweeter criticizes Premier Doug Ford for supporting vaccine and mask mandates. The tweeter is also critical of Doug Ford's support for Trudeau's public health protocols, therefore this post is anti-vaxx and anti-liberal. The tweeter calls for "change" yet provides no insight on how to cultivate change.
This tweet asks why vaccines have not been released for kids under five years old, which is the headline of the article he posted. This is a pro-vaccine post.
criticism_other: Slow development of vaccines for kids under 5

meaning: This tweeter is critical of the Supreme Court for ruling mixed messages on COVID-19 mandates. The tweeter is pro-vaccine because he says that federal regulation is badly needed.

It's part of a thread criticising Joe Rogan's podcast for misinformation, the tweet supports pharmaceutical companies and praises them for acting more swiftly than the government. It gets the date slightly wrong for Moderna's testing start date.
This tweet claims that vaccines are a genocide implying that there is a vaccine death cover-up.

It's a direct tweet to an article about someone who was arrested for locking a vaccination centre closed, preventing hundreds of people from getting vaccinated. It is unclear in the tweet whether it supports the vaccine centre or the criminal.

User is angry that they know multiple people who have had to postpone surgeries because of the many Covid patients still being admitted to hospitals. User is implying their loved ones could get surgery if more people were vaccinated against Covid and the hospital could adequately care for them.
This conspiracy theorist is calling the pandemic a "Scamdemic." This tweet is in reply to a doctor, who the tweeter says is a pimp for "big pharma." The tweeter also calls vaccines "experimental."
This man is anti-vaxx because he claims that members of BLM are smarter than LGBTQ people, because BLM vaccination rates are lower.

This tweet makes a statement about Bill Gates, but Reuter's fact checked similar tweets and reported that "Bill Gates’ words have been taken out of context. He did not say COVID-19 vaccines are not working very well; rather, he said preparation for the next pandemic will likely include research on vaccines that stop virus transmission, something they do not do now."
The user sharing their experience of getting covid, saying that the vaccine made it feel like just a bad case of the flu.

This tweet has a lot of misleading information, most importantly it blames China for COVID implying that someone released the virus on purpose. It also implies people with natural immunity do not benefit from getting the vaccine.

This report by the Daily Beast says Trump's son will talk at an anti-vaxx conference. The fact that the reporter used "anti-vaxx" means that they are pro-vaccine because anti-vaxxers often get angry at the use of that word. The reporter says the speech will target the "fringiest" members of the American public.

A direct tweet to an article about a video posted by Krista Ford where she makes a lot of false claims about public health interventions. The article and tweet use language to discredit Krista's statements in the video.

This tweeter is "anti-vaccine mandate" due to their profile. This tweet refers to their support of Julian Assange, who leaked information about the U.S. military. This tweeter likely supports Assange because they see him as a whistle blower for government corruption.
This tweet is part of a discourse about the FDA approval process for the booster shots. It questions the vaccine's efficacy and the rationale behind booster shots despite breakthrough infections.
This tweet is a response to a call to get children vaccinated, it claims that vaccines do not prevent COVID-19.
This tweet says that the Moderna vaccine is better than Pfizer, especially for immunocompromised people such as cancer patients.
This tweet is from a classic conspiracy theorist, saying that the vaccine is an attempt from the powerful to kill us.
A tweet relaying highlights about the BA.2 strain, telling people that getting bi-annual vaccines for COVID is going to be the new normal.
A tweet from a YouTube channel promoting a video where they examine and explain the latest COVID-19 data, looking at vaccine efficacy against new strains of the virus.

A direct tweet to an article about a judge's ruling that kids in schools in Illinois don't have to wear masks or get vaccinated. The headline is a quote from the judge calling mask and vaccine mandates a form of tyranny.
This tweet blames a new wave of infections on vaccines and public health policy. It also discredits doctors urging people to get vaccinated.
A tweet linking to a video of Alan Sweeney, calling him sexist, homophobic, right-wing, and anti-vaccine. It also implies that he would be a good fit for pharmaceutical companies.
A tweet from NHS London warning how COVID can spread more easily in Winter, and advises people to get vaccinated.

Part of a reply chain where someone recorded a video implying that vaccine data is being hidden, misrepresenting the vaccine's approval process, and implying that there is a conspiracy behind the vaccine.
It's a message of hope to persevere and continue with public health interventions, including vaccinations, despite new COVID waves wearing on people's patience.
It reiterates and supports the conspiracy theory that Bill and Melinda(spelled Belinda) Gates created the vaccine to kill people to reduce over-population.
The tweet argues that the vaccine is ineffective and dangerous. Saying that new vaccines are not going to boost immunity.

Tweet is a response to Joe Biden's announcement that clinics are now open that will vaccinate the whole family and provide booster doses. User is critical of the U.S and other wealthy countries hoarding vaccines making it harder for less wealthy countries to achieve high vaccination rate. Also angry at antivaxxers for refusing life-saving medication and prolonging the pandemic.
It is a quick summary of Joe Rogan's vaccine misinformation controversy, exaggerated but generally accurate.

User is referring positively to the U.S Army creating a vaccine at Walter Reid that allegedly fights all Covid variants. Its been reported on some DoD websites, Forbes, and the Toronto Sun, as well as some analysis from McGill that is cautiously optimistic. There is technically a basis for this claim, but I do feel its still misleading.
A tweet from a news outlet announcing Australia's approval of the Bharat Biotech Covaxin vaccine.

This tweet links to an article where someone disproves a conspiracy theory about covering up vaccine deaths, it seems the user did not read the full article and just read the headline without realising the article disproves the statement.
A tweet linking to an article about the US federal court blocking the vaccine mandate for federal employees. The user says they are unsure about their stance on the decision.
It says Biden's mandates are illegal and asks for retweets.
This tweet implies that vaccines are just as dangerous as opioids, and the same people are responsible for both products.
A direct tweet of an article about the CDC recommendation to avoid cruises because  COVID spreads easily in close quarters.

This tweet is saying that someone with COVID actually has pneumonia, and that the vaccine is not a vaccine and doesn't work. It also tells people to do their homework but doesn't provide any information sources.
A tweet about a school board giving parents the option to send their kids to school unvaccinated despite the government mandates. It also says the school would rather not enforce a vaccine mandate.
User is referring to the vaccine depopulation conspiracy theory, and comparing the current state of emergency to the state of emergency Hitler declared to seize power in Nazi Germany.
User claims that over 95% of those who get Covid are vaccinated, and seems to be heavily involved in some culture war debate about flags.
It argues that the vaccine passport was rolled out without people noticing. It implies that the government intended for people not to notice.

User is correcting an antivaxxer who was using data in a chart of data on cases and hospitalizations in NYC. Original poster implied mask mandates and vaccines did not work, the user that replied seems to have interpreted the data correctly.
Someone who says they are a doctor arguing that not all health care workers are vaccine experts, and people ought to be careful when listening to people who call themselves experts.
criticism_other: White coat effect amongst health care workers
