meaning: This tweet links to a clip, out of context, of a pharmaceutical executive discussing the term gene therapy. The tweet argues that companies intentionally misled the public.

User is an engineering PhD sharing a study from the University of Illinois showing that vaccines reduce transmission rate by 70%. The graphs shown in the tweet are difficult to parse, but I found simillar claims about transmission rates by other public health groups.
A tweet with fear-mongering language misusing the word species in an effort to scare people about the vaccine. It links to an interview that does not make sense.
At the time of this tweet Astrazeneca was selling the vaccine at cost. It's part of an argument with a conspiracy theorist about how 'big pharma' is making booster shots to make money.
The user says that the latest data at the time showed that vaccines are effective against severe disease even after its effectiveness against transmission wanes.
It points out that it arguing against COVID mandates doesn't make sense because the US mandates vaccinations for pets.
This tweet argues that deaths are increasing because vulnerable age groups have lower vaccination rates than healthier age groups.
A reply to a rant about how the vaccine kills people, it calls the vaccine the worst of all time implying the vaccine is deadly.
This tweet from a suspended account claims that big pharma lies to the public to make money and pays fact checkers to hide the truth.
This tweeter is angry at those who refuse to get vaccinated and argues that we all need to do our part to protect those who are not able to be vaccinated yet including young children.
This tweet implies that freedom of choice does not equal freedom from consequence and that those who choose not to get vaccinated must deal with not being able to access some public services.
This tweet by a former Member of European Parliament argues that vaccine passports are a violation of freedom, individual sovereignty, and autonomy.
This anti-vaxxer is replying to a tweet about Eric Adams. He complains about how an unvaccinated athlete, Kyrie Irving, cannot play at home in NYC, yet traveling players who visit NYC can.
This anti-vaxxer claims they convinced a group of women to not get vaccinated by showing them their vaccine exemption pass. The tweeter implies that vaccine mandates are illegal.

This tweeter posted a link to a website that is not reputable. The link claims that a military doctor warns of the damage the COVID-19 vaccines can do. The tweet is clearly anti-vaxx and the post is misleading.
A direct tweet of an article about a senator who got COVID despite being triple vaccinated. The article is misleading but the tweet itself is factual.
It argues that unvaccinated people should not complain about COVID because they are not using the solution.
A tweet calling out misinformation from a conservative MP in the UK house, linking to further debunking of his statement that thousands of people have died from the vaccine.
A tweet encouraging people to get vaccinated, crediting mandates with saving hundreds of thousands of lives.
This tweet advertises a webinar given by scientists and public health professionals about the global implications of COVID19 vaccine equity.
This tweet is in favour of disciplining medical professionals who post false information about the COVID19 vaccine on social media.
This tweet links to a news article the Deccan Herald which criticizes the high number of vaccines that have been wasted across India.
This tweet claims that the government plans to force vaccinations on the population under military supervision.
This tweet criticizes those who question the safety of vaccines and who link health problems to the vaccine without context.
This tweet criticizes the strict vaccine mandates that require Canadians to present a vaccine passport to enter restaurants.

This tweet is anti-vaccine passport, and therefore quite possibly anti-vaccine. The tweeter posted an opinion piece about how the U.K. risks altering life for good if they don't remove vaccine mandates (as of October 2021).
This post reveals no personal opinion, it only shows a graph regarding vaccination rates of children ages 5 - 11.

This anti-vaxxer says her husband is vaxxed and got COVID-19. She implies that vaccines are not effective because transmission is still possible, which is misleading. Vaccines simply reduce the risk of death.

This tweet shared information from a news article released by the Economist. The tweeter wrote that only 13% of Africans had been vaccinated. The post is inherently pro-vaccine because the tweeter implies that it's bad that some vaccines have been "laid to waste."

It's not clear what this tweeter is promoting, but he is sharing an article from a tabloid newspaper about how the Canadian government fuelled vaccine hesitancy. This publication is not necessarily reputable and the article's main message is that inconsistent messaging made people vaccine hesitant.
Doug Emhoff is married to Kamala Harris. He promotes vaccines in this tweet, stating that they are safe and effective, and that they are the route to getting back to real or normal life.

This tweeter supports the Trucker Convoy and was critical of the Emergency Measures Act being instated due to protests in Ottawa. He says that people will choose the path of being difficult, rather than taking the "annual vaccine."
criticism_other: Trudeau and the Emergency Measures Act

meaning: Forcing employees to either get vaccinated or be fired is unreasonable, especially when the safety of vaccines is unclear.

This anti-vaxxer claimed that not all anti-vaxxers are pro-Putin. He posted a link to a commentator who said there is a surprising overlap between Pro-Putin and anti-vaxxer sentiments. Yet, he is clearly in support of Russia -- and he's also an anti-vaxxer -- while he dresses up his support by expressing a desire to not want WW3.

This tweet is in response to another tweet that states a matter of opinion about the desire to have vaccine mandates and lockdowns removed from society. The tweeter says that he agrees that vaccine mandates and lockdowns should be removed from society, but that masks should stay. He made a joke that masks are required during Halloween and muggings.
This tweeter says that Trudeau is encouraging "forever" vaccines, by mentioning that boosters will be required in the "coming years." He posted a link to a far-right website, which is not reputable.

This tweet is a bit unclear in terms of bias. It seems to be pro-vaccine, but then the tweeter attempts to prove a point that someone only has a 10% chance of contracting polio if unvaccinated against polio. It's not clear where that percentage came from, nor is it clear why this tweeter is discussing this (and in which context), because the tweet was deleted.

This tweeter is a Trucker Convoy supporter and he claims that if a Nazi was at the protest he would tell the Nazi to "f-off." The tweeter says he would join the protest because he doesn't support vaccine mandates.
This anti-vaxxer is telling people "you do you" in regards to taking the "Chinese vaccine." He is implying that the vaccine is not safe nor effective and he refers to doctors as "gnomes."

This tweeter posted a video from U.K. congress regarding a debate about immigration polices, and then implied that "forced" vaccines will become prevalent if the Human Rights Act is removed. This person implies that it is a human right to refuse a vaccine.
This tweet links to a news article that criticizes the relaxing vaccine requirements in Israel, where the number of critically ill COVID patients continues to be high.
This tweeter is responding to another tweeter who claims they got  pericarditis from the vaccine. This tweet then reveals fear about getting their second vaccine.

This post claims that Project Veritas is good -- that is a far-right conspiracy based "news" outlet -- and that the Phoenix Indian Medical Center did something wrong. Over two years ago, that center shut down rapidly and left pregnant women hanging without support. It is not clear what the meaning of this post means in regards to vaccines, but it labels vaccinations as a "sekrit" problem and is therefore anti-vaxx.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine because she says that vaccines can help bring out the sun after a pandemic has cast a shadow over the world.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is upset that anti-vaxxers are jamming up hospitals and taking vital services away from people who need them most.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine and critical of this opinion article posted by NBC. The article shares a person's criticism of the J&J vaccine, it's blood clots and the ever changing plot twists involved with the pandemic.
This tweeter says that people who are in remote communities have no choice but to get vaccinated. He uses a critical tone and is clearly an anti-vaxxer.

This anti-vaxxer says vaccines are not effective because they don't stop the spread of the virus, which is misleading. He also says that if mandates are not going to be enforced, why have them, while posting a link to celebrities at a football game while unmasked.
This tweeter is anti-vaccine, her bias is clear because she shared an article on an untrustworthy news site about how Biden's vaccine mandates are not enforceable.
This tweeter implies that vaccines were developed to destroy the body's "innate" immunity. This implies that vaccines were invented with a malicious purpose and that they are not safe and effective.
This tweeter replied to another tweet about the effectiveness of Ebola and other virus vaccines. This tweeter implies that the COVID-19 mRNA vaccine is dodgy, and that it's not a real vaccine.

This tweeter wants vaccines to be available for children more quickly. They also want the third dose for adults to become available. This is clearly a pro-vaccine tweet and it calls the BC NDP amateurs for being tardy.
criticism_other: Tardiness of vaccine availability, BC NDP

meaning: This tweet was removed from Twitter. It proclaims that another person has a swollen heart and is close to death after taking three Pfizer vaccines. No evidence or proof of this is provided, therefore it's misleading.
This is an informational post regarding the end of vaccine mandates in Newark.
This is an informational post about the number of vaccines administered in India. It contains no personal comment yet is clearly pro-vaccine.
Tweeter is talking about gathering more resources to fight vaccine mandates in court. Tweeter does not support the vaccination of children.

Tweeter is countering a study on Ivermectin's ineffectiveness to prevent/ cure COVID-19 by saying, without any context or proof, that two states in India with low vaccination rates eradicated COVID-19.
Tweeter is implying that another user, who said he had no vaccine side effects, did not get the real vaccine but just a saline solution.
Tweeter is rebutting the claim of another user about COVID vaccines' safety by noting that most people now hospitalized with COVID are unvaxxed.
This anti-vaxxer says that military members who are not vaccinated should not be discharged unless it's an "honorable" discharge. This tweeter is clearly not in favour of vaccine mandates.

This tweet relays the numbers of vaccine doses administered in India. He uses a measurement called lakh, which equates to one hundred thousand. The tweet appears to be pro-vaccine because it does not pass judgement on vaccination.
This appears to be a news repost. I attempted to fact check whether 2300 Kerala teachers actually chose to not be vaccinated, the story came up in various news sources that are not famous.

It's not clear if this video is accurate. Various news reports reveal that Argentina had a number of protests regarding "VIP vaccination," meaning that people with less income were not able to access the vaccine and could therefore not work. Reuters reported in March 2021 that people had been protesting for universal access to vaccines.
This anti-vaxxer says he found peace when he started dating another person who is anti-vaxx. He implies that people need to stick to those who have similar beliefs.
criticism_other: Dating people with different vaccine beliefs

meaning: This tweeter appears to be unsure about vaccines because she says she tested positive "even though vaxxed." This indicates that she distrusts the efficacy of vaccines and does not acknowledge the vaxx reduced her illness.
This tweet posts a video featuring Denver Hume, who promotes vaccines to young people. The video is clearly pro-vaccine.

This is a news post from Sean Hannity, which contains content reported in other outlets such as NBC. It regards children being vaccinated, and those ages 5-11 had to show proof of vaccination in San Francisco to enter indoor events. The post itself does not contain any opinion, although Hannity is an activist for "freedom" (the far-right).

This tweet is pro-vaccine because it shares an article about COVID-19 deniers who refuse to acknowledge COVID-19 is real, even during the process of dying from the disease. The article states that many of those people refuse to get the vaccine despite that life and death experience.

This anti-vaxx post promotes freedom of choice by using Gibraltar (which has a nearly perfect vaccination rate) as an example as to why vaccines are ineffective. The post claims that infections are on the rise even though people in that country are vaccinated, and does not mention that vaccines lower the intensity of illness.

This tweet is a dissaproving reply to Jimmy Kimmel's joke about an anti-vaxx woman. This tweeter says Dr. "Fraudci" (referring to Fauci) is a monster conducting malicious experiments, therefore the tweeter is anti-vaxx.

This tweet implies that a vaccine mandate in Germany is being delayed because the government does not want to incur liability for vaccine side-effects. It also implies that pharmaceutical companies and governments are hiding their legal responsibility even though it has been public information for years.
It makes three unsubstantiated, incorrect statements about the vaccine. It says the vaccine is not a vaccine, which aligns with and promotes conspiracy theories.
A link to a New York Times article about how vaccine mandates are working to increase vaccination rates, generally promoting the article and the mandate.
A reply to a tweet about Hilary Clinton's COVID diagnosis, questioning whether she actually has it or there is some conspiracy of famous people lying about COVID to push the vaccine.
A tweet criticising Kyrie Irving and other anti-vaxxers for risking the health of others by attending public events.
An infographic showing a COVID case count update with high vaccination rates.
A tweet from an NPR radio station about an imam promoting vaccines despite anti-vaxxers seeking religious exemptions.
Part of an exchange where people told stories about how isolating and vaccines work to prevent infection even when someone in the same household has COVID.
It supports the convoy and its various complaints about public health policy. It argues that people are sick of being locked down and many Canadians support protesting as a reaction.
It argues that politicians are too preoccupied with bipartisan issues to make the vaccine rollout efficient.
A tweet that makes it seem as though people who had COVID don't need to get the vaccine, ignoring everything we know about natural vs vaccinated immunity.

A tweet about opposition to an effort to increase global cooperation on vaccine production. The user criticises governments who have a contradictory stance on vaccine production and export, as they don't support production unless they are the ones importing it.
A tweet about how 70,000 health care workers quit because of mandates, implying that they know best therefore the vaccine must be unsafe.

A sarcastic response to someone pointing out that vaccinating children is common. The tweet argues that there was no testing for the vaccine and inaccurately argues that every other vaccine had been tested for decades before use.
A tweet about how parents get COVID but cannot isolate from their children, and the policy to isolate doesn't work for families with young children.

It alleges that Moderna is banned in Finland, it is only restricted for men under 30. It also implies that Pfizer's request to hide their data for 75 years it was a conspiracy to cover up deaths, despite the fact that the request was fought in court and the FDA is releasing the data..
A direct tweet from the Washington Post of their article about the UN debate around vaccine mandates around the world.
A link to an article from a Chinese state newspaper about China's 3.14 billion vaccine doses. Other sources corroborate that number shortly after the tweet date.
It twists the words of a CDC official about breakthrough cases to argue that vaccines are completely ineffective.
A tweet updating people about 4th dose availability, heralding the news as a good thing.

A tweet in a long thread about the cost and efficacy of vaccines. It inaccurately states that Walgreens asks people to pay out of pocket, but their website says it's is free to the person receiving the vaccine.
A tweet about how Omicron is scary because the vaccine is less effective, eliminating the semblance of normalcy that was beginning with high vaccination rates and high vaccine efficacy.
An article about an unreliable study about Russia's Sputnik V vaccine. It says Sputnik is twice as effective as Pfizer, where some reports say it is less than half as effective.
A person supporting Djokovic's choice not to get a vaccine to play the Australia Open, it says he got a home made vaccine in Serbia that is equally effective which is not true.
A tweet railing against mandates in the public and private sector, the user also brags about never getting a flu shot.

A direct link to an article about an unvaccinated conservative radio host who had COVID and was taking ivermectin. The article explains that ivermectin is an ineffective treatment and that the host has had COVID before as well.

A tweet which says vaccinated people spread COVID more than unvaccinated people. It also argues adverse reaction cover-ups is part of The Great Reset. It also uses the actual VAERS numbers to imply the vaccine is more dangerous than the virus.
A tweet promoting a global response where the everyone gets dosed rather than Americans getting 4 doses, criticising the New York Times for not reporting on the US sending vaccines around the world.
A reply in an argument trying to say that vaccines are ineffective because they only give you 95% protection.
A tweet using misinterpreted numbers to show that the vaccine is more dangerous than the virus. The source of the numbers shows that the claim made in the tweet is inaccurate.
A tweet questioning the logic behind public health policy, arguing that it is not based in science despite them seemingly ignoring the available science.
A full-blown mix of every imaginable conspiracy theory, alleging the rise of fabricated pandemics, wars, famines, disasters. Implying COVID is a fake disease and the vaccine is fake medicine.
The tweet shares an article from CNN about second dosages of the COVID-19 vaccine.
Tweeter, who is the director of information and public relations for the Indian Administrative Service, is sharing COVID-19 statistics.
The tweeter is criticizing a tweet that said a patient who is immunocompromised and in need of a transplant should be allowed to choose not to get vaccinated.
The tweeter shares tips, based on his own experience, on how to avoid exposure to COVID-19 at home when someone in your family has tested positive.
The tweeter questions why children can get vaccinated in schools but not vaccination centres. The tweet seems misleading, but may just be very specific to their personal experience.
criticism_other: Rules for vaccinating the 12-15 age group, Vaccines in schools

meaning: This anti-vaxxer is upset that the department of HHS financed a large confidence boosting campaign regarding vaccines. He calls this a propaganda campaign for "big pharma" and globalists.

This woman criticizes anti-vaxxers because they equate vaccine mandates to the holocaust, yet vaccines were used as a form of resistance during the holocaust, she says. She posted a link to an article about this history, the link is not a well known news source though.
criticism_other: Anti-vaxxers equating vaccine mandates to the holocaust

meaning: This tweet promotes fear around vaccines and asks what the rate of vaccinated people (1 versus 2 shots) is amongst COVID-19 deaths. This tweeter then refers to Canada to say that COVID-19 "fear porn" is coming out of this country.
According to recent news, social media influencers have been offered money to spread anxiety around getting vaccinated.
A tweet linking to an article about how sterilising immunity is unachievable and expecting total protection is unrealistic.

A tweet about an article that misinterprets another article, which is ironically about misinformation. It says that vaccines and masks did not help reduce infections, even though the NYT writer, who no longer writes for NYT, didn't say that.
The tweet refutes anti-vaxxers, who were criticizing the effectiveness and safety of COVID-19 vaccines, as well as vaccinations for children.
The tweeter blames WHO for lying about the pandemic and effectiveness of vaccines, and negatively affecting hospitals with mandates and protocols.
The tweeter is debunking another tweeter who claimed COVID-19 vaccines alter people's genes.
The tweeter insinuates that the Foo Fighters drummer, Taylor Hawkins, died from the COVID-19 vaccine.

This woman is angry at someone (the original tweet is deleted) for criticizing vaccines. The main tweeter asks if that woman is an anti-vaxxer and questions why that other tweeter would say that vaccines don't help the elderly.
This is an informational tweet that regards the effectiveness of vaccines against Delta. This information was reported in other reputable news sources and appears to be legitimate information.

meaning: This tweeter articulates his dismay with anti-vaxxers. He can't understand why they don't view the vaccine as effective when he's viewed data that clearly supports vaccination. He shared some of that date within the post.
A news organization tweets an article about a Texas Attorney General blocking mask and vaccine mandates implemented by Biden.
Tweeter writes about COVID-19 infecting animals and how they are now being vaccinated. Talks about how it is an amusing conversation.
Tweeter shares a study saying that COVID-19 vaccines kill immune systems and damage cells.
Tweeter says the vaccine is safe, prevents COVID-19 and saves lives. Post is in Spanish and English.

This tweeter claims that pro-vaccine people attempt to divide themselves from anti-vaxxers by viewing the unvaccinated as threats and dangers. The tweeter believes that the vaccinated are capable of killing the unvaccinated.
criticism_other: Hate and divide between the vaxxed and unvaxxed

meaning: This is an informational post that notifies readers how to report spoofed (fake) emails that claim to offer fake vaccine passports. This post is inherently pro-vaccine because it attempts to combat scams regarding public health.

This tweet appears to be a joke about anti-vaxxers. It claims that the guy in the picture is attempting to broadcast a signal, although it looks ridiculous. The tweeter makes a tongue in cheek comment about this man's approach not working, unless there is a vaccine microchip inserted the key. This feels sarcastic and pro-vaccine, based on this tweeter's Twitter profile.

This quote is likely being used to propagate anti-vaccine sentiments. The original tweet was deleted and it's not clear where this quote came from, yet an anti-vaxx podcast used it to promote conspiracy theories about the New World Order on a podcast: https://music.amazon.com/podcasts/a977213b-c589-4470-ae31-38882110a6fa/episodes/4bd998b7-0645-4b75-b986-5ecbc03cd584/nteb-bible-radio-rightly-dividing-nteb-prophecy-news-podcast-bayer-pharma-president-drops-truth-bomb-says-mrna-is-gene-editing-marketed-as-a-vaccine-to-'gain-public-trust'
This tweet is misleading. Various news reports verified that Trudeau did not flee Ottawa at the time of the the trucker convoy protests.
This post does not contain personal opinion. It simply states that vaccines are required to enter proms in New York City.
This is a report from a journalist at The Atlantic and appears to be credible about vaccine effectiveness. The information does not contain personal opinion.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx because he claims that teenagers who are seropositive -- they have antibodies to COVID-19 -- suffered from restrictions for no reason.

This pro-vaccine tweeter relays a conversation he heard between two anti-vaxxers who happened to work at a hospital. Those individuals said that vaccines help the virus flourish in a patients' body. This tweeter responded with "yikes" to those beliefs.
This tweet is anti-vaccine. It replies to another tweet that was deleted. It seems to call Trump's support for vaccines into question and it instead promotes god.
This tweeter is angry that unvaccinated doctors are not able to work as per vaccine mandates. The tweeter shared a CBC article that said two doctors were suspended for being unvaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says he is doing all he can to prevent the spread and contraction of COVID-19.
This post is anti-vaxx because it shares a video of people giving support for anti-vaxx or anti-mandate protests in Belgium.

This post appears to be pro-vaccine, because COVAXIN is a vaccine, but it promotes distrust of mRNA vaccines. COVAXIN has been embraced by people who fear the new mRNA technology. According to various news sources, there’s little data to support that COVAXIN is better than the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines.
This tweet shares a news story that declares that without proof of vaccination, individuals will not be allowed to enter the Joint Admissions and Matriculation Board (JAMB) facilities in Nigeria.
This post promotes vaccination availabilities in Jersey City.
This is a journalistic report from CNN that says teachers in New York must be offered "non-classroom" assignments if unvaccinated, rather than be fired.
We need to better protect children from becoming ill with COVID19 in Sweden by making vaccines available for them and discussing other measures in addition to vaccines.
The Trump administration was more effective at preventing deaths due to COVID19 than the current democratic government, yet the media does not talk about this.

The logistics of the COVID19 vaccine rollout in the UK have been chaotic. While 12 to 15 year olds were being vaccinated, younger children were getting COVID and the influenza vaccine was getting delayed.
This tweet questions whether professional golfer Nelly Korda, who was diagnosed with a blood clot, was forced to get vaccinated by the PGA tour.
This anti-vaxxer says that vaccination is way to get control over people. The tweeter implies that vaccines mess with mother nature and that they should be avoided.
This is a news article, posted by Politico, that states COVID-19 may outpace global vaccination efforts. The article does not include personal information but it's inherently pro-vaccine.
This tweeter says that it's not right to mandate vaccines because people lose their right to food and shelter by losing work. The tweeter is anti-vaxx and suggests that the chart he posted is wrong.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is upset that the Global South did not have access to producing their vaccines. The tweeter believes that variants would have slowed if vaccine hoarding and monopolies of production would have not existed.
support_other: Allowing the Global South to produce vaccines

meaning: This sarcastic tweet blames mainstream media for making the pandemic seem more deadly than it is, and the vaccine more effective than it is.
This is an informational post that does not pass judgement about anti-vaxxer Djokovic.

This tweeter seems happy that they got their second vaccine done. They state that Australia, where they're likely based, got their doses later than other countries. The link posted in this article is now deactivated.
This is a badly written tweet and it's not clear what the entire content regards, but the tweeter is pro-vaccine because he says someone will be safe because they're vaxxed.
This tweet shares a news story about a vaccine clinic in London, UK that was forced to close when their shipment of vaccines did not arrive.
Anybody, whether vaccinated or not, can catch coronavirus but those who are vaccinated will be able to fight the virus off more quickly.
The omicron variant has not killed anyone, yet leftist news outlets are spreading propaganda that makes omicron seem dangerous in order to justify more vaccine mandates.
COVID19 vaccines are killing people and this is President Biden's fault, who has not been protecting Americans.
Liberals have lied about major events and ideas, including masking, vaccines, and mandates, and will not get away with it anymore.
Neither the vaccine nor vaccine mandates such as the vaccine passport are effective at stopping the spread of COVID19 and those who disagree are delusional.
This tweet by conservative Graham Allen calls into question the legitimacy of vaccines, and writes that they are being forced upon Americans, and that he prefers natural immunity.
This tweet is in reply to an article about Irish medical care workers who didn't take the vaccine. The tweet supports them and says that vaccinated people are "pissed" that they took the vaccine.
This tweet makes a comment on the U.S., that the country didn't have data on vaccination rates before deciding to lift mandates.
criticism_other: Lack of data in U.S. before lifting mandates

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweet celebrates an article that reports vaccines may not be needed in the future as COVID-19 variants become weaker. The tweet posted an article from the Daily Mirror, which is a tabloid outlet.
This is a tweet from a BBC reporter who discusses the zero COVID policy embodied by the Chinese government. The post presents quotes and information, not personal opinion.
This tweeter is critical of Trudeau and calls him a "prick." The tweeter is clearly anti-vaxx because he celebrates that Trudeau said vaccine passports could be divisive in Canada.

This tweeter seems to be pro-vaccine because they're saying that an anti-vaxx protest was no where near as big as it claimed to be. Some anti-vaxxers were spreading false depictions of their protests to make them look more successful and populated than they actually were.
support_other: Accurate observations on the size of anti-vaxx protests

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter is critical of COVID-19 vaccines because they were developed so quickly. The tweeter posted a chart listing other vaccines, with a time frame as to when those viruses emerged and how long their respective vaccines took to develop. No source is listed with the chart and it's not possible to know if that's reputable information.
criticism_other: The quick development of COVID-19 vaccines

meaning: This tweet implies that soldiers are not patriotic if they refuse to defend their country against a virus that can kill. A CNN article was posted along with this tweet to communicate that 103 service members were discharged for refusing the COVID-19 vaccine.

This is a journalist's post on Twitter. She is a CNN correspondent who reported that BIDEN said COVID-19 no longer controls our lives. She posted a link to COVID-19 resources, that BIDEN had mentioned.
This is a post about where to get information on boosters. The tweet was made by a legitimate news site.
This anti-vaxx tweet is a reply to information about Omicron spreading quickly. The tweeter claims that the vaxxed are carrying the virus more than unvaccinated people.
This tweet advertises availability of vaccine doses at a vaccination clinic in India, encouraging people to come get vaccinated.

This tweeter believes that "many doctors" don't know the ingredients in vaccines, and that doctors make "mistakes all the time." This tweet is anti-vaxx while it promotes conspiracy theories that propaganda is being used to sell vaccines.
This tweet seems pro-choice but it's pro-vaccine because it's making fun of anti-vaxxers who wear tin foil hats at a protest.
This is a news article repost that states Moderna, a vaccine provider, is one of the fast growing brands in 2021. The post contains no personal opinion.
This is a news article by CNN that is inherently pro-vaccine because it reports that COVID-19 was the leading cause of death among police as of Fall 2021.
This tweeter claims that pro-vaccine people are on a moral high horse and they use their morality to control the masses by encouraging vaccination.
criticism_other: Perceiving oneself as moral for being vaccinated

meaning: This tweet is no longer live on Twitter, however it appears to be a judgement on vaccinated people. It appears this is an anti-vaxxer who is annoyed by vaccinated people who encourage anti-vaxxers to get vaccinated. This tweeter implies that vaccination status shouldn't matter for the safety of vaccinated people, and that people should learn how to manage their anxiety.
This anti-vaxxer claims that thousands of people were killed by vaccines and lockdowns.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx and is making a snarky comment about vaccines being the "way out of this pandemic." The tone appears to be facetious.
This tweeter says that a person who was injured by a vaccine didn't get enough compensation for the damage. The tweeter says the "victim" should bring a civil claim against the doctor.
This tweeter replied to an anti-vaxxer and COVID-19 denier. They assert that masks, vaccines and NPI's are responsible in terms of preventing millions of deaths.
This anti-vaxxer tells readers to not trust public officials about vaccines because they are "poisonous" and ineffective.
This tweeter is asking another tweeter if the stats that tweeter provided include COVID-19 cases within vaccinated people.

It's not entirely clear what this Tweet implies, because the original thread has been deleted. But the tweet is clearly promoting conspiracy theories about vaccination -- that the jab is somehow a tool of war.
This anti-vaxxer is concerned about the CDC's interest in investigating vaccine "injuries" and deaths. They claim that "people don't want the COVID-19 vaccine" because of this.

This anti-vaxxer supports comments made by a professional athlete. He also calls people who believe in vaccines "retards" for taking the jab while transmission is still possible even amongst the vaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccines are being wasted by conservative provinces, not Canada as a whole.
This tweeter says that vaccines are not safe nor effective. But he also says he's not a scientist and that twitter readers should not believe what he says.
This anti-vaxxer equated vaccines to a form of sorcery and clearly stated that they will not take the jab.
This anti-vaxxer says vaccination is "criminal," especially because kids are being jabbed.
Tweeter is implying that vaccines do not eradicate a disease by giving the example of tuberculosis but fails to note the lower fatality from the disease in present days.

Tweet claims a Carnegie Melon study found the highest rates of vaccine skepticism among those with PhDs. Includes a link to an article in the American Thinker about antivaxxers being vindicated, written by an MD.
Tweeter is reiterating the conspiracy theory that the COVID 19 pandemic and the subsequent vaccination of people across the globe are all part of a ploy by the Chinese Communist party to kill people.
Tweeter is implying that the pandemic was not real because he, himself, and the people he knows, never got sick in spite of not following any COVID-19 protocols unless in situations where he had to.

User is referencing an article claiming Lithuania canceled a shipment of vaccines to Bangladesh over political tensions with Russia. The user argues it is immoral to cancel vaccine shipments over political disagreements, but this allegedly happened in March and has still not been picked up by any major outlets. Story may be fabricated.
criticism_other: uneven vaccine distribution across wealthy and poor countries

meaning: This tweet criticizes professional tennis player, Novak, for his anti-vaxx views. The tweeter wonders why he is so meticulous about what he puts into his body, yet is willing to contract the virus without protection, at the risk of spreading it to other communities.
This tweeter says they read a lot about vaccines and that the more they read, the more "failure" they find within vaccination. This is an anti-vaxx post that promotes doing one's own research.

This tweeter wants there to be a tragedy regarding vaccination of children in order to set a legal precedent. The tweet implies that this needs to happen to support freedom of choice regarding vaccination of children.

meaning: This post claims that republicans are doing a lot of damage regarding ending the pandemic. The tweeter is clearly pro-vaccine and is critical of the lack of leadership within the republican party throughout the pandemic.
This anti-vaxxer says Biden is a liar because he claims that vaccines prevent COVID-19.
This anti-vaxx tweeter wants vaccine mandates to be removed.

This post promotes vaccination of children and celebrates a doctor -- Sabka Prayas -- who will "defeat the pandemic."
This tweeter is anti-vaxx because they claim that the vaccine will not save New York City.

The tweeter claims Norwegian Cruises lifted their vaccine mandates but that is not true. In early November, the cruise line publicly stated that "the company's sweeping mandatory vaccination policy will be extended "indefinitely" in the near future."
This tweeter says they are Christian and that they believe in god and therefore will not take the vaccine.

This tweet quotes John Mc Afee, a controversial U.S. figure, who said told the public to not take the vaccine under "any circumstances." A godly image was placed with this tweet to make it appear regal and holy.
This anti-vaxx tweet says that vaccine mandates are tyrannical. He says he will eat in the state of Virginia, rather than in DC, to avoid vaccine mandates.

meaning: This tweeter is pro-vaccination of children. She says vaccination is works well and that masks are difficult on children because the kids touch their faces and contaminate the masks often.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that vaccine mandates are wrong and uses Corbyn as an example of a person who supports this view.
This tweeter says that people who vaccinate healthy children are cowards. This is an anti-vaxx post.

Part of a super long argument covering a whole range of vaccine related topics, this tweet points out that people have to get vaccines all the time so COVID mandates are not really a significant milestone in terms of rights and freedoms.

A tweet with a message from a school board attached where the school board says they will allow students to opt out of the vaccine. The tweet tries to argue that because this school board says vaccine mandates are illegal, all mandates are illegal.

A tweet criticising Prime Minister Morrison for not taking more decisive action to keep infection numbers low in Australia, arguing that he should have mandated masks and vaccines before there was an outbreak.

It criticises the narrative around vaccines arguing that the vaccine doesn't work or provide protection against COVID. It does not acknowledge the fact that new variations of COVID are different than the virus the vaccine was developed to fight.

A tweet about the statistic which showed 5 times more police officers died from COVID than from gun violence. Arguing that way too many police officers subscribe to the conservative, anti-vaccine ideology.
The user says they followed vaccine mandates and still got COVID, arguing that this proves the vaccine doesn't work.
A tweet from the company behind Sputnik promoting their positive results against Delta. The efficacy percentage was confirmed by Reuters.

This post is a bit misleading because it does not give specifics on what type of domestic travel Biden was looking at in regards to instating a vaccine passport. It's clearly created by an anti-vaxxer.

Dr.Mercola, the author of this tweet, makes money from selling supplements to the public. He is not a credible doctor. His tweet states that Australia is not sure why their hospitals are full of COVID-19 patients, given their high rate of vaccination, which intends to discredit vaccines.
This anti-vaxxer says they don't support vaccine mandates. This tweet was made in response to a pro-vaccine post.

This tweet is anti-vaccine. It criticizes police for enforcing vaccine mandates against fellow unvaccinated police. The tweeter posted a link to demonstrate this point but the video is no longer online.

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweet criticizes religious people for following god and not science. The tweet implies that anti-vaxxers will lay on their death bed while their family members sort out the complications, often at a huge expense.
This anti-vaxx tweet highlights an example of AstraZeneca producing blood clots in two U.K. patients to support vaccine hesitancy.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccines provide instant protection against COVID-19. The tweeter is criticizing Australia's government for not getting the vaccines fast enough.

meaning: A tweet linking to an article about a clip of Dr. Fauci on CNN saying that, at the time of the tweet, the durability of natural immunity against COVID was something that had to be studied further before making vaccine policy for people who have been infected.
It points out that even educated and intelligent people can be anti-vaccine implying it's because the arguments against the vaccine are emotional rather than logical.

A tweet about support in Brazil for their president's anti-vaccine stance. It includes a video that apparently shows a crowd in Brazil cheering for their anti-mandate president, despite a high vaccination rate in Brazil.
A bot account that finds vaccine appointments posting about some availabilities at CVS in San Diego. It links to the site to book an appointment.
A direct tweet with a link to a Globe and Mail story about the TDSB mandating vaccines for staff. The tweet could be either for or against the decision to lay off unvaccinated staff.
A hopeful tweet arguing that we are equipped to weather oncoming waves of COVID because of vaccines and other medical science.
A direct link to an article about an accusation that Pfizer is disaster profiteering now that the world is reliant on their vaccine.
A link to an article about the Chicago Police Union head telling his officers to defy the vaccine mandate and go on strike. The pull quote implies the tweet and article support his call to inaction.
A reply which says that people in public service, especially military and police, should be willing to get vaccinated in order to protect the communities they serve.
This tweet is a repost of a story regarding a Jewish person who can't find anything in Judaism proscribing vaccination.  The tweet contains no personal opinion but could be viewed as anti-vaxx.

This tweeter believes that aborted fetuses are used in vaccines, but that isn't correct. The fetuses are not aborted according to Immunize B.C. This is an anti-vaxx post that attempts to raise suspicion about vaccines, and it could come from a Christian perspective.
This post is pro-vaccine and it encourages people to get vaccinated and to put their masks up. The tweet posted a Reuters article about vaccination, which is reputable.

This post appears to be pro-science yet it creates the feeling that vaccines and natural immunity are both ineffective as long-term solutions to the pandemic. The tweeter may be implying that social distancing is the only answer to ending the pandemic, but it's not clear.

meaning: This tweeter is anti-vaxx. He claims that the vaccine is profitable for some people and that's why they're sold. The tweeter say "vaccination doesn't mean anything."
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccine equity is an issue. They promote that equal access to vaccines around the world would help reduce surprise variants from emerging around the world.
This tweeter claims that mask and vaccine mandates are not working in New York, therefore this is an anti-vaxx or anti-mandate tweet.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that anti-vaxx protests are "dumb." The tweet also makes a comment about France versus Australia that is not understandable because the original tweet was deleted.

This anti-vaxx tweeter criticizes "compulsory vaccination" and says that informed consent is not possible for under vaccine mandates. The tweeter promotes vaccine fear because they say vaccines harm and/or kill.

meaning: This tweet does not support or criticize anything. The tweeter is vaccinated and said he experienced fevers and chills as a result of his second dose. He also stated that Moderna was founded in 2010, which is true.
This tweet is not entirely understandable but it implies that vaccination is not effective because the tweeter used quotes around the word vaccination, which means they're mocking the jab.
This woman appears to be anti-vaxx because she cried about a TV show character's dreams, which were related to the vaccine. That implies the vaccine was scary.
This pro-vaccine tweeter made a joke about the type of people who spread vaccine disinformation: Trump supporters who can't spell.

meaning: This anti-vaxxer encourages doctors to investigate dead babies and their mothers, to see if vaccination was the cause of death. The Tweeter posted a link to a BBC article that said a rise in dead babies happened in 2021.
This tweeter is making comments about their vaccine. They got the jab, so they are pro-vaccine -- yet they state that the vaccine gave them pain.

This anti-vaxxer is promoting disinformation about vaccines. He says that people are dying from them, and that vaccines are not effective. He put a photo of a book within his tweet, to promote is views, asking readers to read the book.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx because they are promoting information that vaccinated people now make up a large portion of hospitalized patients. The link is reputable, however the tweeter doesn't acknowledge that vaccination severely reduces the possibility of death.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that they're vaccinated with three doses but that "unvaxxed" people gave them a severe infection of COVID-19.
This tweeter says that cops in New York who don't want to be vaccinated should go home without pay. They posted an article about New York's top cop urging other police to get vaccinated.
This tweeter talks about the need for boosters when people travel (for other viruses) or when the immune system forgets an old virus, and therefore this tweet is pro-vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that people should look up what an autopsy looks like if they don't get vaccinated. The point is to shock people into understanding why vaccines are necessary.
A tweet telling vaccinated people that the vaccine is a con, that it doesn't work and is dangerous. Implying a widespread conspiracy to trick people into taking a fake vaccine.
It strongly disagrees with Biden, his federal mandates and the size of the fine.

A direct tweet linking to an article mocking an anti-vaxxer for spouting outrageous conspiracy theories. At first glance it may seem like it is promoting conspiracy theories, but it's reposting it ironically to incite ridicule.
A tweet from NSW Health showing the new vaccination statistics from teenagers and children, 5-15.
A tweet arguing that we should focus on developing a new vaccine for the new strains as opposed to getting more doses of the same vaccine.
It promotes vaccination for everyone. Arguing public spaces like movie theatres are the kind of environment that spreads the virus which is why everyone needs to be vaccinated.
Tweeter says they warned that opting out of organ donation would cause the presumption that the government owns your body. They suggest it's the same with mandatory vaccines.
Tweeter is comparing the flu vaccine to the COVID-19 vaccine. They suggest that the flu vaccine doesn't prevent the flu and say that it's not true that vaccines only prevent sickness.
Tweeter is reposting and quoting an article from the New York Post about how the CDC is hiding the date.
Tweeter shares NY Times article about Moderna and the US fighting over vax distribution. Additionally, tweeter says how much tax money Moderna got and how much the inventors are worth.

This is a news report about a person who challenged having the picture of India's president, Modi, on his vaccine passport. The tweet takes no stance on this and does not display any personal opinion.
Even though this tweeter says she has taken vaccines, the tweet comes across as anti-vaxx because she says that her blood is no longer pure and therefore contaminated as a result of being vaccinated.
This tweet shares an academic paper that reveals how Fox news has spread vaccine hesitancy more than other news outlets. Therefore this is a pro-vaccine post.

This tweet is minimal, but it's pro-vaccine. It's rejecting an article that shares disinformation about the dangers of taking the vaccine as a pregnant woman. The tweet was made by a fact checking organization.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx because they say that seat belts are a good analogy for masking. But the tweeter asks why they should believe that analogy relates to vaccines.
Tweet seems to be a mix of religious-based conspiracy theories centred around Uganda.

This tweeter has been vaccinated but promotes anti-vaxx views because they contracted COVID-19 despite being vaccinated. The post is misleading because the vaccine doesn't stop transmission, it only reduces illness.
A tweet applauding the people in the Sarawak region in Malaysia for vaccinating their children in mass numbers.
It points out that the vaccine causes heart problems. It could have been more accurate but it is true.
A tweet saying that Ontario would bar unvaccinated voters from the polls, even though they said they would not and did not.
A tweet linking to an article promoting Japan's 4th vaccine donation to Taiwan. Implying that a global, collaborative response is necessary.
Tweeter compares the different COVID-19 rules/restrictions in different provinces and the US. They say how politics doesn't make sense and this is a "crime".
Tweeter says they believe Illinois has a large number of unintelligent people because of the lack of vaccinated people. They say if the vaccine doesn't save you, what would be the point.

Tweeter shares a video of experts talking about the vaccine. The expert can't answer a question about if the vaccine has killed people and scrambles to find an answer.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that scientists should study the death rate based on vaccinated and unvaccinated people. The tweeter implies that the vaccine is not safe, nor effective.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccination is not a political issue and that people should get vaccinated. He says the virus is also not a political issue.
This tweet seems to promote vaccines because it points out that vaccination rates are low in "poor countries." Yet it promotes conspiracy theories that China made this virus.

This tweet is anti-vaxx because it claims that vaccines are about profits. And the tweeter posted an article regarding a doctor who is discredited. Dr. Liz Mumper is referred to in the shared article and is associated with the anti-vaxx organization Children’s Health Defense.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine because they are calling out Joe Rogan for spreading medical disinformation by giving an example about an issue around myocarditis. The tweet is situated within a thread where another person supports Rogan.

This is an anti-vaxx post because the tweeter is trying to scare the public by saying many VAERS reports have been made about the COVID-19 vaccine. McGill University reported that "the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System or VAERS is being misused by anti-vaxxers to terrify the public" though. This post is misleading and likely no where near accurate.
The mayor of New York City announces vaccine mandates. This is a pro-vaccine post.

This tweeter is waiting for more information about myocarditis resulting from vaccination. The CDC reported that "Data from multiple studies show a rare risk for myocarditis and/or pericarditis following receipt of mRNA COVID-19 vaccines." This post is not misleading, rather it reveals that the tweeter is waiting for answers before proceeding with vaccination.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is baffled as to why someone would give up their job out of refusal for taking a "life saving" vaccine.

This tweeter is shocked that anti-vaxxers won't take a vaccine but will risk "huffing" COVID-19 without really knowing what could happen. The tweeter shared a post to Marjorie Taylor Greene, a famous conspiracy theorist and far-right U.S. politician, to illustrate his point.

This anti-vaxxer assumes that science has many debatable sides and that vaccination should be open for such open discussions. She wants experts to publicly disagree and challenge each other, which means she doesn't support public health policy.
Tweet is quoting a Toronto public health official in favour of mandating vaccines in schools.
User is claiming anti-vaxxers warned about the threat of vaccine mandates and people did not listen.

User is expressing frustration at white people holding NYE celebrations during Covid while Omicron is spreading. User is possibly implying that measures like vaccine passports and masks will not stop the spread of Omicron.
User is expressing concern about a celebrity (?) who received a vaccine. References an "anomaly in the matrix", but no other context is available.
Tweet is a headline from a right-leaning news site covering a judge blocking the Biden Administrations vaccine mandate in Texas.

Tweet claims that the FDA and CDC have found evidence that vaccination increases risk of myocarditis by 13,000% in children. Image includes the claim, the logos of FDA and CDC, and a photo of a syringe going into a heart.
This anti-vaxxer tweeted a legal case to support his anti-vaxx cause (his Twitter profile reveals his far-right leaning views). The legal case was between a leading anti-vaxx group and the CDC.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine. He says that the far-right and anti-vaxxers have emerged to undo "decades of public health progress."
Tweet is a link to an article by Yahoo News about anti-vaxxers getting vaccinated and then trying to undo it.
Tweet is a link to a Vancouver News article about Canadian service members being turned out of the military for refusing to get the vaccine.
User is linking to an article that credits Indian President Narendra Modi with the success of one of the vaccination campaigns in India.
User is pointing to the Pope's pro-vaccine stance to call out Catholics who ask for religious exemptions to vaccines.
User is predicting that wealthy nations will begin dumping their J&J doses to poorer countries now that its safety is in question.
User seems to be asking another user which vaccines are available at a specific location. Profile seems to be pro-vaccine in general.
User is claiming that vaccine hoarding by wealthy countries has extended the pandemic by preventing segments of the global population from being vaccinated.
Tweeter is referring to someone who seems to have passed away from COVID-19 because they were unvaccinated. The tweet seems to be mocking said person because they were unvaccinated.
The tweeter claims COVID-19 variants were purposefully released so more people would get vaccinated.
Tweeter is encouraging people to get their fourth vaccines.
User is arguing that if vaccines work, they will protect those who are unvaccinated as well.

Tweet claims healthy children will hardly be affected by Covid, and should not have to get the vaccine. User implies vaccinated adults are pushing children to be vaccinated so they themselves will not have to take as many safety measures.

Tweeter is concerned about vaccination rates for children under five in Indiana. The tweet also shares data from a professor in Indiana.
The tweeter disagrees with vaccine mandates for large group gatherings and spreads misinformation by saying COVID-19 vaccines are ineffective.
Tweeter is mocking commercials for vaccinations.
Tweeter tells a supporter of the Democratic Party that they can earn respect by opposing vaccine and mask mandates.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says he hopes vaccines will soon be available for his daughter who will turn five years old soon.
This tweeter says that vaccines are like a seat belt because they reduce the risk of death if the virus is contracted.

This tweeter makes fun of anti-vaxxers for their evolving claims about COVID-19 risks (or lack there of). This tweet is part of a thread and her original post wonders why anti-vaxxers go to so much work finding alternative remedies, when they could just easily wear a mask.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine because they went to a hospital for the COVID-19 booster. But they were turned away after waiting in line for an hour, because it was only available for an older age group. The tweeter communicates their annoyance with the lack of messaging around eligible age groups.
support_other: Effective communication about who can get boosters

meaning: This tweeter is not clear on his stance about vaccines, yet he seems to imply that COVID-19 exposure can create "lifelong immunity" which is not true. Many people have contracted the virus multiple times.

This anti-vaxx tweeter shared a CBC article about how many hospital staff in Windsor, Ontario, refused the vaccine. The tweeter says this should make the public wonder because these medical workers must believe in science, yet they still refuse the jab.
This tweet criticizes another tweet that makes fun of anti-vaxxers. This tweet states that there are mishaps and failures associated with the vaccine.

This anti-vaxxer says that a global takeover is being planned by way of vaccines. He refers to vaccine critic Dr.Malone as "the inventor" of the mRNA vaccine -- which is misinformation -- to support his conspiracy theories and anti-vaxx cause. Malone took part in the development along with many other scientists.
This anti-vaxxer says that the vaccine is not effective after two years of the virus being in the world. It is misleading because the vaccine does reduce illness.

The link in this post is no longer active, however it appears this tweeter says that profits from the J&J vaccine are on the rise. This indicates his anti-vaxx stance, because he is critical about people making money from the vaccine.
Tweet is a reply to a thread about vaccination rates in the Maori community. User claims the uneven vaccine rollout in minority communities is a breach of treaty obligations.
criticism_other: failure of vaccine rollout in minority communities

meaning: Tweeter quoted California's public health official's message on the importance of vaccination of children.
This tweet is by a business entity promoting an event in which participation requires proof of vaccination.
A tweet linking to the conversation between Peter McCullough and Joe Rogan which is rife with misinformation.
User is relating rumors circulating in the Telugu community to a PhD researcher who studies vaccine misinformation.

A tweet complaining about public health policy in B.C, arguing that the vaccine is not a vaccine and mandates and passports are hurting families. It links to an article with an announcement that B.C will continue enforcing mandates and passports.

This tweeter does not pass comment on vaccines, rather she is re-posting information she read about vaccines in the Boston Review, while also celebrating a piece by the New York Times, which is posted above her tweet.
support_other: The New York Times, Boston Review

meaning: This anti-vaxxer claims that the vaccine is infecting people with COVID-19.
This post contains information about the upcoming vaccination of kids ages 5 to 11. The tweeter says there will be no scarcity of vaccines expected. This is clearly a pro-vaccine post.
This woman re-posted an article from The Daily Beast that indicates her pro-vaccine stance. The article reports on GOP law makers that have absurd claims about the vaccine.
criticism_other: Conspiracy theorists and GOP law makers

meaning: User is critiquing a Kyrie Irving for his refusal to state whether he is vaccinated, referencing the athletes beliefs in other conspiracy theories, like flat earth.
A tweet promoting the availability for the third dose of the vaccine in Jamaica, as well as the protocol for health care workers for the administration of those doses.

A tweet arguing that the vaccine is making it safe to get infected with COVID, effectively reducing deaths and hospitalisations. It also argues that COVID isn't going anywhere and life ought to adjust.
A tweet linking to an interview with Dr. Fauci about a non-existent vaccine pill pointing out it's misinformation.
A tweet promoting a school immunisation program, urging people to get their kids vaccinated and trusting people to make the right choice with the available information.
A tweet from Business Insider promoting their video about vaccine hesitancy, criticising people who spread misinformation and don't believe in vaccine science.

A part of an argument with a suspended account, this tweet argues that the variety of vaccine options makes it possible for everyone to get vaccinated. It also criticises people, especially health care workers, who don't believe in science.

A tweet from a Fox News editor arguing that the media over reports on children with COVID and under reports on complications from the vaccine. It implies that the vaccine is more dangerous for children than the virus.
A reply to an argument about freedom, pointing out that unvaccinated children have been denied education for years.
A tweet arguing that people who value their freedom over their health ought to suffer the consequences. Implying that if people don't want the vaccine they can get the virus.
A tweet criticising people who wilfully spread misinformation. Arguing that people who run media organisations that misinform people ought to be criminally charged.
A tweet urging people to just get vaccinated because without the vaccine the world can't get back to normal.
User is thankful he will not have to self-isolate over Christmas despite working in a vaccination clinic. Tweet itself is not antivaccine, but the profile more broadly is.
User is thankful he will not have to self-isolate over Christmas. Tweet itself is not antivaccine, timeline is mostly other interests with anti-lockdown posts mixed in.

Tweet is a link to an article from a right wing news source about how totalitarian government intervention forced a woman to be vaccinated in order to visit her child's school who then allegedly died from complications with the vaccine.
User is praising Jacinda Ardern for cancelling her wedding even though most of the population is vaccinated in order to comply with new restrictions and set a good example to the public.
support_other: Jacinda Ardern for personally following the guidelines she set in place

meaning: A tweet about the University of Florida's decision not to enforce a mask or vaccine mandate at the request of Gov. DeSantis.
A tweet linking to a video of misinformation promoting the lie that the vaccine somehow directly causes cancer.
It's a reply to an argument with an anti-vaxxer, it just says to get a vaccine.
Tweet summarizes key findings from an Ipsos/axios poll showing broad support for vaccine mandates and other public health measures in the United States
Link to an MSN article about an antivax advocate and mother of four who died from Covid complications.

A tweet arguing for virtual schooling because kids get sick often and with the precautions necessary for COVID-19 it makes them miss class every other week. Virtual school or a hybrid model seems like a good suggestion for public schools.
A tweet questioning the public health policy and arguing that it's authoritarian, claiming that they are going to move to a country where freedom is more important than public health.
This tweeter takes the fact that vaccines do not reduce viral charge out of context to try to show that vaccines are ineffective.

It calls for the execution of pharmaceutical executives, and everyone enforcing vaccine mandates. Saying that vaccine mandates are war crimes. Arguing that there have been millions of deaths from the vaccine, implying widespread conspiracy.

A reply to conspiracy theories and an argument that natural immunity means someone doesn't need to get the vaccine. This tweet says science has shown people who have been infected and have natural immunity still ought to get the vaccine.
A tweet criticising the Premiers of the Atlantic provinces for worrying about their own health but not enacting health policy that would protect kids in schools and other public spaces.

Tweet contains link to USA Today article about Covid deaths in 2021, user argues more deaths in 2021 compared to 2020 mean the Biden administration is not addressing the pandemic properly and the media is complicit in blaming Trump when they should be blaming Biden.
A tweet outlining a hypothetical three step conspiracy to make the vaccine mandatory and then extort the public into taking it for a massive profit.
A reply supporting a tweet from Hilary Clinton announcing that she had COVID but was feeling safe and secure because the vaccine will protect her from serious illness.
A tweet telling people that to enter the city council chamber in Moose Jaw you need to be vaccinated.

A tweet criticising Greg Abbott's law against mandates in small business. It argues that taking away a business' ability to enforce a vaccine mandate is a hypocritical thing for a limited government ideologues such as republicans.
User is making some kind of point about vaccines and communism being linked. Profile shows a far right Trump supporter mostly concerned with personal liberty and freedom.
A tweet from a Rebel News reporter arguing that medical officers are tyrants and vaccine passports are a conspiratorial effort to coerce people into taking the vaccine.
A tweet arguing that a program to vaccinate special needs children and their care givers is a good start, implying there ought to be more effort to vaccinate people with special needs.

A tweet listing four bits of misinformation, it says the vaccine is not a vaccine, that masks don't work, public health policy has no effect on the spread of a virus, and democrats and liberals are fascists trying to destroy America.

A tweet about how both vaccinated and unvaccinated people are suffering socially and economically because of the virus so people ought to have the right to choose whether they want to have their health affected as well.

A tweet mocking vaccinated people because the mandates and lockdowns are lifted, implying that the only reason to get vaccinated is the social restrictions implemented during the height of the pandemic.
Tweet is a statement from a coalition of mayors arguing for increased access to vaccines and calling on international organization to help facilitate the rollout.
A tweet of someone who claims they are working on vaccine development as well as other treatments for COVID, likely as part of an argument that has since been deleted.
A tweet arguing that the reason other medicines did not treat the virus is because of a widespread conspiracy to push vaccines through supposedly for a profit.

A tweet including a table showing the efficacy of various vaccines, saying that the COVID vaccine has one of the better efficacy rates compared to other medical interventions that prevent serious illness.

A tweet arguing that there is nuance to the vaccine situation and implies that people are too argumentative which is counter productive when it comes to the effort to vaccinate people and reduce the harm caused by COVID-19.
Tweeter calls on four politicians to act on COVID-19 by joining forces with ACT Accelerator to get more tests and vaccines.
Tweeter shares a video of apartments being barricaded in China. Says it happens when you don't have your vax QR code.
Tweeter says there is no hard evidence to support that Omecrom is less harmful than Delta without a vaccine.
In reply to a newscast, tweeter calls out Winsome Sears for not wanting to get vaccinated and questions their leadership.
This tweet questions whether Nadal Djokovic was honest about his vaccine status or not.  The tweet does not pass comment on vaccines in general.
Tweeter writes a conversation he had with his manager. Manager said the vaccine is not FDA approved, tweeter disagreed.
This tweet is anti-vaxx because it criticizes mRNA vaccines. It likely supports COVAXIN because it says the Polio vaccine is effective - and that was not an mRNA vaccine.
In a reply to tweet about not getting vaxed, tweeter says they believe in the science of vaccines and the risks that come along.

This tweet claims that real doctors say vaccines kill more people than they save. The tweet links to an article that is not reputable, which supports the tweeter's anti-vaxx beliefs. Reuters released a fact-check report a few days after the linked article was released to say that vaccines to do not kill more people than they save.
Tweeter is angered that grandchildren are being asked to get a flu shot saying it will affect their immune system.
This anti-vaxx / anti-lockdown tweet claims that nine out of ten people oppose lockdowns and vaccine mandates. The tweet links to an article that is not reputable, so this is misleading.
This tweeter believes that children should not be vaccinated and that the public should vote politicians out if they support the vaccination of children.

This tweeter claims that vaccines are no effective because their neighbours contracted the virus despite being vaccinated, from other people who were also fully vaccinated. The tweet is misleading because it neglects to say that vaccines reduce the risk of serious illness.
Tweet is from the official CNN account. It is a link to an article explaining that party-goers in Times Square on New Years Eve will be required to be vaccinated.
User is comparing various aspects of the Covid epidemic to a cult/religion. Convoy hashtag present at the bottom.

Tweet is from the Caribbean African Health Network encouraging people with questions about the vaccine and how it relates to pregnancy to call a help number staffed by Black doctors. Seems focused on building trust between communities of colour and the medical establishment through community outreach.
User is claiming the Freedom Convoy protests are about fair pay for drivers rather than vaccines.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine and wants pregnant women to be vaccinated for their protection. He says they are at higher risk and should be a priority during the pandemic. The CDC reports on their website that "If you are pregnant or were recently pregnant, you are more likely to get severely ill from COVID-19 compared to people who are not pregnant."
Although this is a retweet of a Fox News tweet, it is inherently anti-vaxx because it raises awareness to Bongino's voice. He is a right-wing political commentator.
This parent is anti-vaxx and says they would not make their kid take the vaccine because they believe it isn't safe.

This tweet is anti-vaxx and makes a sarcastic remark in reply to a news article that claimed fully vaccinated seniors still died in an American care home. This tweet implies that vaccines are not effective because of that.
This tweet contains information about how to get vaccinated, including children. It is inherently pro-vaccine.

This tweet does not really provide personal comment on vaccines, although it could be vaccine skeptical because it shows interest in a letter about someone's complaint that vaccines are "experimental." The tweeter is seeking to clarify information within the letter, which another tweeter posted.
This post says that the virus is more deadly than the shot and encourages people to social distance and get vaccinated.

This tweet claims that the public should be wary of the COVID-19 vaccine because Moderna was a new company that never had history of approving products before 2012. The tweeter posts a document from DARPA to highlight his point.
User is making a joke about being passive aggressive to an unvaccinated family member.
Tweet is from a government official in India who is pleased at the progress of the vaccine rollout in India, directed by President Modi.
support_other: getting vaccinated to keep the community safe

meaning: Tweet shows Justin Trudeau in Parliament wearing clown make up with a caption accusing him of buying and hoarding vaccines so he can give kickbacks to his friends.
Tweeter is implying that President Biden supposedly broke a promise of never mandating vaccines on Americans.

This Tweet is a repost from the Epoch Times, which is a right-wing news source. The tweet regards the Australian president's urge for 80% of the public to get vaccinated. No personal opinion is included in this Tweet.
This tweet is not really about COVID-19 response, rather it is a complaint about "remainers" within the Brexit conflict. This tweeter is a pro-Brexit person and reveals anti-EU sentiments.
This tweeter says he's never been vaccinated since 1998 and has not coughed once since. He's indicating his anti-vaxx stance and mocking a post made by the White House website.
Tweeter is implying that Moderna made money out of the COVID vaccine but the American people did not get benefitted from its vaccine.
Tweeter quoted a news link of the questionable media source The DC patriot to imply that a huge protest took place in New York against the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter is claiming that Dr. Fauci is lying about the effectiveness of COVID vaccines because COVID variants apparently come from vaccinated people.

This surgeon says that his work won't pay him for taking leave upon contracting COVID-19. This post is a criticism of that. He encourages the public to wear masks and get vaccinated in a later Tweet so that medical workers don't lose their incomes due to this.
criticism_other: Health workers are not given paid COVID-19 sick leave
support_other: Paid sick leave for COVID-19 patients in the medical system

meaning: This post is anti-vaxx and it raises a question about why Ontario decided to let nurses keep working while vaccinated and COVID-19 positive. The tweeter questions why healthy, unvaccinated nurses are not allowed to work.
criticism_other: Allowing infected nurses to continue working

meaning: Tweeter is implying that the COVID vaccines are not effective because many vaccinated people are getting infected with COVID; hence there should not be any vaccine mandate.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx based on the content of their Twitter account. This post is a bit confusing as it seems to say there were better reasons as to why the PM of St.Vincent's was stoned at a protest. But perhaps the Tweeter implies that vaccine mandates are worse than anything else that PM has done.

This tweeter made up information about England's Chris Whitty saying that South Africans have natural immunity and low vaccine rates. This is an anti-vaxx post that provides no proof of this being true and the information is not verifiable in news sources.
This Tweet expresses concern that the vaccine is potentially less effective in light of new variants such as MU that popped up.
This tweet criticizes anti-vaxxers by saying that they involve BS.
This anti-vaxxer shares a video of a man in Jharkland being required to take a vaccine to support their cause as to why vaccines should not be forced. The man in the video looks clearly distressed.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines are not safe and something sinister will happen to vaccine proponents and vaccinated people some day.

This tweeter is not clear about his stance on vaccines. His wall is full of libertarian and pro-gun content, yet I was not able to find his stance on vaccination. What is clear is that he's making fun of a person who said the vaccine was in the works for ten years. He's calling that person out for spreading a ridiculous conspiracy theory.
This tweeter is a "freedom" fighter who says that the pandemic was created to stifle North American rights. The tweeter is spreading a conspiracy theory and is also anti-vaxx.

This tweet is pro-vaccine but it is misleading because it fails to mention important information about the Sputnik V vaccine -- Putin was angry that G20 countries refused to purchase his vaccine. Sputnik V lacks regulatory approval in the EU and the US. And has not been authorized in other countries as well.
criticism_other: Purchase of Sputnik Vaccine by other countries
support_other: Global purchasing of Russia's Sputnik Vaccine

meaning: This pro-vaccine Tweeter says that a high vaccination rate in Japan significantly lowered the COVID-19 infections in that country.
Tweeter implies that there is a global COVID vaccination pusher nexus and people like Novak Djokovic are heroes to stand up against them.
Replying to a post about the number of COVID cases and fatalities in two Australian provinces, tweeter implies that the infected people are anti-vaxxers and spend their time in freedom rallies.
Replying to a thread about the American government imposing regulations on citizens, Tweeter compares drafts to vaccine and mask mandates, noting the latter are much easier.

This anti-vaxxer hints at vaccines being an experiment and he makes a sarcastic joke about signing liability waivers for getting vaccinated. This is accompanied with a graph about vaccine related illnesses from Vaers, which anti-vaxxers have flooded with misinformation.
This is an informational post that does not pass judgment on vaccines. It states that Japan is passing a fourth booster.

Tweeter is saying that Maxime Bernier should not endorse conservative MP Pierre Marcel Poilievre unless he ends vaccine mandate, rehire people who lost job because of it and act upon other conspiracy theories.
Tweeter is implying that vaccines are not effective and pharmaceutical companies are apparently preventing people from talking about it on social media.
Tweeter retweeted a link to an article from the questionable Epoch Times,  which claims that the UK government is preparing for vaccination damage payouts in 2022.
Tweeter is implying that there is a difference between vaccine-hesitant and anti-vaccine conspiracy theorists and explains why he is blocking the latter.
Tweeter is retweeting a news report about the Indian government's effort to vaccinate its population.
CNN tweeted an opinion piece about the role Robert F. Kennedy is playing in spreading misinformation about COVID-19 vaccination.
Tweeter is asking for information about vaccination centres.

This is an informational post about vaccine mandates in California, written by a local journalist. It provides a quote from a doctor as to why the mandate was instated (rising COVID-19 rates after Thanksgiving.)
