Tweeter implied that there is apparently new data that vaccines do not work and unvaccinated people will not forget how they were apparently punished for not taking the supposedly ineffective vaccines.
This tweet is by a U.K.-based non-profit organization raising donations to vaccinate slum-dwellers in India.
Tweeter shared a video about a Walmart store in China going into lockdown after one customer's Chinese QR code vaccine passport turned red. The authenticity of the video could not be verified.
Tweeter is implying that scientists mostly belong to the left and were wrong about vaccine efficacy. The video link provided in the tweet is from a suspended account.
Tweeter criticizes vax passports in the UK and says there should be a statement in legislation that says when the Emergency Legislation is used, it will last three weeks.
Tweeter states that China doesn't have the right vaccines to fight new varients and that the new wave of COVID-19 there will affect the rest of the world as well.
Tweet talks about Canada's promise at G20 summit to donate 200 million Moderna vaccines around the world but didn't deliver on their promises before.

This is a re-tweet of a public health announcement. It says that information will be logged regarding the vaccines aftereffects in South Africa. The tweet does not disclose personal opinion so it's impossible to know if it was posted by a pro- or anti-vaxxer.
This pro-vaccine tweeter proclaimed that they got vaxxed.

This pro-vaxx tweeter posted a video of a doctor who speaks about the risks anti-vaxxers face if they land in the hospital. The doctor says that the drugs required to rehabilitate a serious COVID-19 infection are more serious than the vaccine itself. The tweeter celebrates this doctor for dismantling typical anti-vaxx arguments for not getting vaccinated.
This tweeter claims that another vaccine injury has happened, without giving any proof of that statement.
This tweeter celebrates India for administering 1 Billion vaccines.

Tweeter is calling out proponents of vaccines. The tweet is in reference to another user who criticized people for not wanting to take the booster shots.
Tweeter is using the abortion right's slogan - my body my choice - to justify her choice of refusing a vaccine.
Tweeter is a journalist who is sharing his own article about how the NBA and NFL essentially gave up enforcing vaccines for players.

Tweeter is looking for small local businesses that create a vaccine that is natural and doesn't test on animals.
This tweeter implies that vaccine mandates shouldn't be enforced and that vaccines don't actually work. This is an anti-vaxx stance.

This tweeter promotes the idea that vaccines aren't safe and that money making is the primary goal of the government. And he urges people to investigate the FDA, while discouraging the vaccination of 5-11 year olds.

This tweet appears to be a neutral post about the vaccine not preventing transmission, however this tweeter is clearly anti-vaxx based on the content posted to his wall.

meaning: Martin Daubney, the leader of a far right wing party in the U.K., is criticizing the labour party leader for supporting the Tory government in enforcing the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter quoted a tweet by the wife of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., where she condemns her anti-vaccine campaign.
Tweeter is replying to another user saying she prefers her grandchildren to get vaccinated despite the possible risk of heart disease because a COVID infection can be worse.
This tweeter criticizes Biden's vaccine mandates and claims that those mandates won't affect the supply chain.
criticism_other: Firing truckers for being unvaccinated, BIDEN

meaning: This tweeter promotes longer quarantine times in early 2022. They say five days is not enough. The link they posted is reputable and reported that 10 days was not sufficient in 1 out of 10 cases.

This is a repost of a news report about the Prime Minister of New Zealand. It's sourced from a tabloid, the Independent, which reported that she was not disturbed when being chased by anti-vaxxers. The post contains no personal opinion.

Tweeter is saying that a group of people who violated COVID protocols should have been taken off a Sunwing Airlines flight, but the news that tweeter replied to mentioned they were not allowed to board the flight.
Tweeter has provided a link to Ontario government's recommendation on booster doses.
Tweeter is claiming that the COVID mRNA vaccines are not safe because thousands of healthcare workers are apparently refusing to get vaccinated.
Tweeter is implying that right-wingers supported Nikki Minhaj after she spread lies about the harmful effects of vaccines but the support may be short-lived.
Tweeter is mocking anti-vaxxers by saying that they would end their anti-vaccine, lockdown protest in Ottawa if police threatened to vaccinate them.
Tweeter is implying that the COVID vaccine is apparently not effective because it cannot stop transmission. Tweeter fails to understand how COVID transmission occurs.

This is an anti-vaxx tweet that promotes a Blaze TV news episode about vaccine mandates. The episode talks about how "insane" it was to fire or suspend unvaccinated workers. Blaze TV is a right-wing entertainment news channel.
This tweet appears to be an attack on Ted Cruz and two other tweeters for spouting anti-vaccine sentiments.
Tweeter is claiming that the number of people spreading misinformation about vaccines is apparently increasing.
This tweet is providing information about vaccine appointments in San Diego, U.S.A.

It's not clear what this post promotes because this tweeter has controversial posts on his profile, but nothing explicitly about vaccines. This tweet could be pro-vaccine, but it could also be an anti-vaxx joke about vaccines.
This tweet promotes a scientific website that isn't famous and also promotes the Pfizer vaccine. It says the vaccine can "neutralize variants of concern."

Tweeter is comparing Japan's non-enforcement of a vaccine mandate with Canada's vaccine mandate without mentioning that Japan had a higher vaccination rate in November 2021 compared to other G7 countries.
This tweet is a vaccine promotion ad by New Zealand's department of conservation.
Tweeter on Jan 2022 shares a piece of breaking news from AP that Moderna's COVID vaccine has been approved by U.S. health regulators , but does not mention the age group the vaccine is meant for.
Tweeter is supporting another tweet about vaccine injury by saying that the vaccines are apparently untested, speedily approved by the Trump administration, and embraced by Biden's government.
The context of the tweet is not clear as it is no longer live.

This tweet makes a joke about how anti-vaxxers think vaccines inject the blood with nano robots. But the tweeter is clearly pro-vaccine because he says he loves having the vaccine and that the Vancouver convention centre clinic where he got vaxxed is well organized.

This tweeter said very little in response to Deutsche Telekom building a COVID-19 app for the WHO. But his response shows that he is skeptical. He used an emoticon with a dismayed face and spectacles to indicate a desire to examine the situation more closely.
This tweeter says that he's disgusted because U.S. troops were fired for not being vaccinated. He's anti-vaxx and promotes "natural immunity."
This tweeter says that vaccines are ineffective because vaccinated people must still quarantine.

Although this tweet does not contain any misleading information but only announces a scheme to compensate African people in the unlikely event of a vaccine injury, anti-vaxxers are likely to leverage it for creating more conspiracy theories.
Tweeter is explaining the misinformation that more vaccinated people are hospitalized with COVID compared to the unvaccinated with a Venn Diagram and noting how data is misinterpreted.

This anti-vaxx tweeter posts an article that refutes the idea that vaccines save lives. The article is not from a reputable news source. The tweeter also implies that pro-science people claim 1 is larger than 1000.
This tweet was posted by TMZ, a tabloid news source owned by Fox. The post asks if mandates have any sense given Kyrie Irving, an anti-vaxxer, stands in a crowd of fans.
Tweeter is telling a Youtuber that vaccination status cannot be requested. The context of the tweet is unknown as the tweet is no longer live.
Tweeter mocks the explanation of why the percentage of vaccinated people hospitalized is higher than the unvaccinated by misinterpreting the explanation.

Tweeter shared a meme of Dr. Anthony Fauci designed to look like a wanted poster for apparently lying about COVID to U.S. public and implied that Dr. Fauci is an accomplice of Bill Gates in the supposed vaccine conspiracy theory.
Tweeter, a far-right blogger, is insinuating that vaccination drives are leftist campaign and their logic behind the need for everyone to get vaccinated is flawed.
Tweeter is implying that people who oppose vaccinating children against COVID do not consider the benefit that vaccinated children will be less likely to spread the virus among adults.
This pro-vaccine tweet says that COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations are down due to vaccines.

This anti-vaxx tweeter accuses the "left" of attacking the "working class" by disapproving of the trucker convoy. This is misleading because some members of the left were in support of that protest. The tweeter also criticizes the left for supporting global vaccination efforts.
This tweeter encourages hospital workers to get vaccinated because they are working with the weak and low immune.

This tweet is pro-vaccine yet misleading because it claims the Taliban has a more inclusive vaccination policy than the U.S. This is a ridiculous claim, given the Taliban did not allow health care workers into Afghanistan for three years before the fall of 2021.
Tweeter is implying that walk-in clinics are offering vaccines to teenagers because immunization programs at schools are apparently not working. The link shared is from a suspended account.
This is a news report from Reuters about how New York lifted vaccine mandates for athletes and performers. The post contains no opinion, it's a reputable outlet.
This tweeter promotes vaccination by showing the real world consequences soldiers faced in the past, not only during COVID-19, for not getting vaccinated.

Tweeter is insinuating that government health officials apparently drove the vaccine campaign to treat COVID despite the supposed existence of other treatments because they own shares in pharmaceutical companies.

Tweeter is implying that Maine's Governor's vaccine mandate for welfare recipients is apparently a way to control people, but tweeter did not mention that the governor opposed vaccine mandate for healthcare workers.
Tweeter is saying that children are apparently being vaccinated with unapproved vaccines.
Tweeter is saying that the Filipino government should have vaccinated students before imposing a vaccine mandate to attend in-person classes in colleges.
Tweeter seems to mock the Australian government's treatment of Novak Djokovic by posting a tweet by the Australian open showing Rafael Nader and Djokovic's grand slam titles.

This anti-vaxx tweeter shared a post about how travellers into Canada, except those from the U.S., would no longer have to share their vaccine status at the arrival airport, rather they'd have to be tested for COVID-19. The tweeter celebrates this with sarcastic disbelief.

This pro-vaccine tweeter makes fun of "freedom" fighters. He says that their approach to freedom -- which is primarily the desire to have mandates removed -- is not relevant to fighting for actual freedom.

This tweeter supports Modi, India and the vaccine Modi took: Covaxin. The tweet is in response to someone who was critical of the Pope for hugging Modi, while Modi has not been vaccinated with a WHO approved vaccine.
A tweet about how people are afraid to get the vaccine but their sexual habits are more likely to get them sick or kill them.
This anti-vaxx tweet replied to a conspiracy theory about how the government is tracking unvaccinated people through a data base. This tweet implies that there's more scandal to find.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine and says that she's not aware of a religion that would promote anti-vaxx beliefs. She also scoffs at another tweet about a nurse who refused to get vaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweet asks the public to share stories about why they got vaccinated, and who they did it for. This tweet promotes community.

This tweeter expresses anger at Bongani Bingwa, a radio host in Johannesburg, for hanging up on an anti-vaxxer caller. The tweeter asks why there isn't room for debate on differences of opinion on vaccination.
This pro-vaccine tweeter takes a jab at conspiracy theories about Bill Gates and beliefs that Trump truly won the election. He also says that various politicians such as Ted Cruz support Putin.
criticism_other: Ted Cruz, Josh Hawley, Tom Cotton, Ron Johnson, Putin, conspiracy theorists

meaning: This tweeter criticizes the BMJ for running an opinion article by Peter Doshi, who made claims that the vaccine is not nearly as effective as the FDA reported it to be. This tweeter is pro-vaccine and is fighting disinformation.

A cynical tweet about how the pandemic will never end because people are too selfish to actually coordinate a global response where people in countries that can't afford the vaccine can get it anyways.

This pro-vaccine post says that vaccination is a good choice for pregnant mothers and their babies. It provides a government link for finding out more and advises the public to talk to health professionals if patients have any questions.

This tweeter is angry at Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Qanon supporting politician, for promoting disinformation about the vaccine and for not being vaccinated. The tweeter is clearly pro-vaccine and is worried for the public's safety.

This anti-vaxx tweeter doesn't like Trump and declares this in this Tweet. The tweeter also doesn't like vaccines, and links that to a reason as to why he doesn't like Trump. The picture posted is in response to another tweeter who posted pro-vaccine comments and insults towards him.
This pro-vaccine tweeter asks how many patients will demand that their care workers are vaccinated in light of information that unvaccinated workers can work in certain healthcare sectors.

A tweet including a video of Governor candidate Nikki Fried talking about abortion rights, the video was tweeted by Governor DeSantis' spokesperson thanking her for speaking out against vaccine mandates. It's unclear if it was a mistake because the video is out of context or if it is a sarcastic way to compare abortion rights to being unvaccinated.
This tweet from the United Kingdom National Health Service announces the hours and location of a vaccine walk-in clinic.
A tweet about the British Royal Family promoting vaccine equity in support of a global response.

A tweet about a cruise where 10 people got COVID, arguing that the vaccine and vaccine passport did not protect anyone. It ignores the fact that without the vaccine everyone on the cruise would be severely ill.

A tweet criticising people and organisations who publicly speak against the vaccine but privately have been vaccinated or comply with daily testing. It argues they wilfully ignore the harm they cause by denying vaccine science.
This is an informational post from a law organization about vaccine mandates in Ohio. And it says registration fees paid to attend the workshop will be used to support Afghan refugees.

It's a reply to a tweet about how vaccines don't prevent infection just how seatbelts don't prevent car crashes but they both save your life. This is a tweet about how the vaccine has not been researched enough, it also says it's made of HIV and aborted foetuses.
This tweet celebrates the fact that the show Sesame Street has been advocating for vaccines since 1972.
This tweet by the National Health Service Bolton Clinical Commissioning Group is announcing COVID19 vaccination clinic locations and hours.

This tweet shares a news clip of Steven Hatfill, Trump’s pandemic advisor, saying that mass vaccination was never the right answer to preventing the spread of the virus. A more relaxed approach that relies on medication for treating COVID19 is advocated for.
This tweeter advocates for the freedom to choose whether to get vaccinated.

This tweeter claims that despite Facebook's pledge to stop recommending health groups to its users to help combat medical misinformation, it has not stopped doing this and is even recommending anti-vaxx groups.

This anti-vaxx tweeter posts an article that is not a reputable new source (Children's Health Defense.org) It promotes conspiracy theories about Bill Gates, Indian vaccines and vaccine safety. And it claims a AZ vaccine killed a 23-year-old

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that Maxime Bernier is the only leader who is against war, as well as against vaccine mandates. This is misleading because war cannot easily be de-escalated without actions that may result in violence. The anti-vaxx movement has strong pro-Russian sentiments.
criticism_other: Violence, fascism, war, all politicians except Bernier

meaning: This tweet questions how exemptions from vaccine mandates for personal reasons will be regulated in California.
criticism_other: Lack of regulation of vaccine exemptions

meaning: This tweet by a UK based human rights activist group announces a gathering to protest vaccine inequity and injustice.

This is a pro-vaccine report. It quotes a headline from a medical outlet that reports "The accelerated development of several vaccines has helped in the fight against the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)."

This tweeter is anti-vaxx because he claims vaccines don't work because they become outdated each time a new variant comes around. He says that variant-specific vaccines are not effective and he calls them "health additives."
A tweet about a protest against vaccine mandates in Glasgow. It criticises the public health officials and government who enforced the mandate.

This tweeter appears to be pro-vaccine while he says hospital workers aren't leaving their jobs due to vaccine mandates, rather due to the lack of support and difficult working conditions the pandemic put them in. The tweeter appears to be debunking propaganda from anti-vaxxers who claim health workers don't want to be vaccinated, in order to gain credibility for their cause.
criticism_other: Lack of support for hospital staff

meaning: This tweeter is fearful that vaccine mandates will soon be implemented by the government for homeschooled children.
This tweet by USA Today shares a news piece about Prevea Health ending its partnership with football player Aaron Rodgers because he made false claims about the COVID19 vaccine and protocols.
This tweet quotes an emergency physician saying that the Pfizer vaccine for children aged 5 to 11 is the same as the adult vaccine in terms of efficacy and effect, and only differs in dosage.
This tweet claims that the Pfizer vaccine is unsafe and should be pulled from the market because more than 1200 people died from the vaccine in the first three months of use.
This tweet blames the COVID19 vaccine for a lung cancer diagnosis in a young women who is a non-smoker.
This tweeter calls for news about vaccine mandates to change the narrative from blaming the unvaccinated for not complying with mandates to more empathetic wording.
This tweeter rudely explains to another twitter user that the ingredients in vaccines are safe and effective as long as one is not allergic to them.
A tweet explaining that a booster shot is just another dose of the vaccine.

This tweet writes that the safety study for a common Hepatitis-B vaccine was conducted on 148 children over 4-5 days, and that this is not sufficient for determining a vaccine’s safety. We should be scared to give newborns this vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter posted this in response to an anti-vaxxer thread. The graph they posted indicates that vaccination rates helped reduce deaths.
This post is informational yet inherently pro-vaccine. It reports that public health mandates are in effect at schools and agencies in New Jersey without passing negative judgment on those mandates.
This tweet makes fun of the United Kingdom government's plan to organize pop-up vaccine clinics in places of worship.

This tweeter has picked out some specific data from a Centre for Disease Control study about post-vaccine rates of myocarditis to show they have tripled since vaccine rollout, thereby showing that vaccines are unsafe.

This tweet by the conservative activist group Judicial Watch includes a news piece explaining that records have been obtained that show the American Federation of Teachers and the National Education Association conducted their own vaccine research and influenced CDC decisions.
This tweet by BBC news Northern Ireland writes that the COVID19 vaccine passport mandates helped increase vaccination rates.

This tweet calls for more trust in science, criticizing the Biden administration for contradicting the World Health Organization’s call to halt booster shots in rich countries until poorer countries receive enough first doses.
This tweet by the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations, CEPI, calls for additional funding to cut down the time needed to develop new vaccines in the future.
This tweet jokes that some great jobs will become available soon because people are refusing to follow their employers’ vaccine mandates.
This tweet uses data of vaccinations in different countries to attempt to show that vaccines do not work, that hydroxychloroquine is effective, and that the pandemic and COVID19 are a hoax.
This tweet is in favour of scrapping the vaccine passports so parties can be attended by anyone again.
A tweet about a 400 million dollar credit from the World Bank to Nigeria.
This tweet by the Department of Health in Northern Ireland announces the number of new positive cases, deaths, and vaccinations administered over the last 24 hours.
A tweet explaining how the COVID vaccine was developed more quickly than the polio vaccine because, obviously, medical technology has advanced a lot since polio.
This tweet criticizes another user for advocating against life-saving vaccines during a pandemic.
This tweet by a scientific research institute is announcing the locations and times of sites offering free COVID19 vaccines for children.
An example of the argument that vaccinated people should be prioritised over unvaccinated people in the health care system.

A tweet arguing against the idea that the vaccine is experimental of ineffective. It includes a chart showing the cases and deaths of unvaccinated compared to vaccinated people. The chart is unsourced, poorly scaled, and the title is confusing.
This tweet claims that vaccines are unsafe and ineffective, linking to a news piece about a young boy developing Stevens-Johnson Syndrome after the second dose of a Pfizer vaccine.

Tweeter noted that not everyone can get vaccinated for medical reasons in relation to a thread that apparently showed a large gathering of University of Michigan students, to which another user commented that everyone in the crowd is vaccinated.
Tweeter is sharing a piece of news about the hacking of EU COVID-19 digital certificates.
Tweeter is implying she is leaving Texas, which did not enforce a vaccine mandate, to escape vaccination because she claims her brother developed heart problems after getting vaccinated.

This tweet by a Toronto Star columnist Heather Scoffield shares a news piece about the trucker convoy protests, questioning whether they were just about vaccine mandates or something more such as conspiracy theories.
This tweet by a Trump supporter links to a Fox News story about basketball player Shaquille O'Neal’s opinion that people should not be forced to get vaccinated.

A tweet against the Chinese government, implying that Twitter is in cahoots and conspires with the Chinese government who manufactured COVID and the vaccine in an effort to kill the general population.

A tweet using a slippery slope fallacy to argue that mandates will lead to further invasive mandates like STD testing. It's also arguing that people who have been vaccinated shouldn't argue because they ought to be completely safe by their own logic.
This tweeter writes that they will only wear their mask selectively after mandates are lifted. They believe in getting vaccinated and getting healthy.

This tweet shares a New York Times article about Moderna selling up to 110 million COVID19 vaccine doses to African countries, not nearly enough, in response to pressure from the media, government, and activists.
This tweeter criticizes Australia’s Gold Coast City Council for not disclosing their councillors’ vaccination status while demanding that others disclose theirs.
A tweet about a protest against the vaccine mandate in Australia, it includes a video of police using excessive force on protesters including pepper spray.
This tweeter asks if they can purchase a booster dose from Pfizer, in reply to an Associated Press article.

This tweet by Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot announces that mask mandates and vaccination requirements will be lifted for some places on February 28 thanks to the progress Chicago has made in terms of cases.

Tweeter quoted a news report from far-right media, Just the News, about U.S. lawmakers supporting NAVY seals who were seeking a religious exemption from vaccine mandate. The heading does not mention that all the lawmakers are republicans.

Tweeter quoted a video by Dr. John Campbell, who has recently spread misinformation about vaccine efficacy on his YouTube channel, and implied that people with no pre-existing conditions are not at risk of fatality from COVID-19 so they should not take the vaccine.
Tweeter is replying to a post about the COVID-19 home test kit saying that he would just stay at home if he gets sick since the vaccine is not effective in preventing re-infection.
Tweeter is implying that anti-vaxxers are responsible for taking up ICU beds in hospitals and infecting other people with COVID-19.
This tweet makes fun of Nicky Minaj’s false claim that the COVID19 vaccines causes testicle swelling.

Peaceful protests against COVID19 mandates were ignored by the media for months, and only now that violent protests against mandatory vaccination in Austria have broken out, has the media begun reporting on this.
A tweet linking to an article implying that there has been falsified data regarding the vaccine in an effort to cover up vaccine deaths that occur two weeks after vaccination.

This tweet includes a video by the Corona Investigative Committee about mRNA Gene-Therapy, which was taken down by YouTube. There is also a link to a video
which summarizes the group’s investigation into the federal and state governments for imposing harsh restrictions.
This tweet criticizes and blames the vaccine passport for creating a two-tiered society.
A tweet trying to make the point that masks and vaccines don't work against Omicron or Delta variants.
A tweet about an interview with the Governor of Colorado about how he wanted to end mask mandates because vaccines have made them unnecessary.
This tweeter questions the effectiveness and safety of the AstraZeneca vaccine and claims the elderly in Australia were forced into getting AstraZeneca.
This tweet claims that the COVID19 vaccine is based on plasma from those that have recovered, unlike the Ebola or SARS vaccine which were based on trial and error.
Tweeter shared an AP news story about U.S. baseball player Aaron Judge, who refused to share his vaccine status.
This is a tweet by Asian News International on the Bhutanese PM thanking the Indian PM for sharing COVID vaccines with them.
Tweeter wrote about only the negative impacts of enforcing a vaccine mandate to imply that it is a bad thing for business and society.
This tweet claims that a tweet by the Big Bird twitter account about the importance of getting vaccinated is a lie, misleading, and disinformation.
This tweet celebrates the revoking of vaccine mandates at Red Deer Polytechnic, a college in Alberta, happy that negative rapid tests will be accepted instead.

This tweet by the New Hampshire Democratic Party announces that Republican politician Victoria Sullivan was unable to attend a debate because she refuses to be vaccinated and has bought into conspiracy theories.
This tweet argues that vaccines are designed to prevent serious illness, not prevent someone from contracting COVID19 in the first place.
A reply arguing the vaccine doesn't reduce the spread of COVID only the severity of infection.  It implies the vaccine is a selfish thing to get and doesn't help the overall public health.
In response to a CDC announcement about illness from recalled baby formula, this tweeter asks the CDC to disclose vaccine injuries.
A tweet about Ghana's preparations for the development of their own vaccine. Praising the president's efforts towards developing their own vaccine, despite his administration's controversies.
This tweet by Reuters includes a news piece about the first major study into whether a second round of COVID19 boosters will help with the Omicron variant.
Tweeter appears to equate anti-vaxxers with far-right groups while replying to another user, who posted about the division in the society between the vaccinated and the anti-vaxxers.

Using the word hidden tweeter is implying that CDC has some sinister ulterior motive in not publishing large portions of COVID-19 data. Tweeter did not share the NYT article which details what data was withheld and why.

Tweeter is being sarcastic about the COVID vaccines by quoting a piece of news about Joe Rogan canceling his show because of the vaccine mandate. Rogan has been called out for spreading vaccine misinformation.

This frustrated tweeter argues that the unvaccinated have been coddled and convinced enough and that it is time to let them decide for themselves whether to get vaccinated, fired, or pay for weekly testing on their own dime.
This tweet by an anti-vaxxer celebrates the ending of a vaccine mandate in Australia.

This tweeter writes that their dog is vaccinated against canine parvovirus and that their vaccine manufacturer will pay for the veterinary bill should the dog need treatment for parvo. All vaccine manufacturers including those making COVID19 vaccines should take this stance.
This tweet by an Ontario physician criticizes the Ford government for stopping vaccine and health mandates and leaving employers to struggle to protect their workers.
This is a repost of a news headline from the Washington Post and does not provide personal opinion.
This tweet sarcastically shares a CTV News story about the mostly mild side effects found in Pfizer’s pediatric vaccine, questioning the story’s truthfulness.
This tweet claims that vaccine passports are a conspiracy and that they are not needed given that the natural immunity from COVID19 infection is more effective than the vaccine.
This tweet advocates for a fast response by the United Kingdom government to waive vaccine patents so that South Africa can produce their own vaccines and improve global vaccination rates.
This tweet reply argues that Football player Alphonso Davies became ill due to a COVID19 infection, not from getting the COVID19 vaccine.

This tweet by Premier of British Columbia John Horgan thanks British Columbians who have gotten vaccinated, emphasizes that vaccines are the most important way to protect against COVID19, and encourages the unvaccinated to get their shots.

This tweet is anti-vaxx, although it contains a misleading pro-vaxx thought (that the vaccine may reduce "short-term" risks.) But the tweeter says overall that there are long-term risks to the COVID-19 vaccine and that vaccinated people transmit the virus.
This tweet supports vaccination and urges higher vaccination rates in the Dominican Republic.
This anti-vaxx tweeter is upset about vaccine mandates, given that some jobs that require vaccination pay minimum wage.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine. It seems to comment on anti-vaxxers who blame the vaccine for bad things. The tweeter says that people should blame COVID-19, not the vaccine, for heart conditions.

This post celebrates an anti-vaxx doctor, Matt Shelton, and links to a video of him speaking. He's based in New Zealand and has been suspended for promoting disinformation about vaccines, so this post is misleading.
Tweeter talks about how great it is now that vaccinated people can do more things, meanwhile the anti-vaxers are mad they are being left out.
Tweeter misinterpreted a World Health Organization tweet on the importance of mask and hand washing since vaccines alone do not prevent COVID 19 by saying that health officials do not trust vaccines.

This tweet includes a video interview with Lieutenant Governor Josh Green, who says that an anti-vaxxers who protested outside his home contracted COVID-19. He is sympathetic towards the anti-vaxxers yet says he is glad they learned the severity of COVID-19.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that they got vaccinated and that they only had back pain and a slight fever as a result of that. The tweeter encourages people to stay calm and not panic about vaccination.
This tweet celebrates people who got vaccinated for the first time at a vaccination centre.
This tweet by the World Health Organization Somalia chapter announces the number of new vaccinations administered and encourages followers to continue following mask and handwashing protocols.
This tweet celebrates the Democrats’ response to the pandemic, including getting high rates of vaccinations, making vaccines available to children, and being able to relax lockdowns once again.
This tweet by a clinical researcher encourages people to continue following the vaccine program and take precautions amid possibly higher transmission and lower immunity against omicron.
This tweet by an Iranian and West Asian news account announces that a new Iranian vaccine is effective against the Omicron variant.
This tweet is inherently anti-science because it claims that the CDC is instilling fear and doubt into society. This post inherently promotes fear by claiming government instills fear.
This tweet promotes vaccine equity and criticizes pharamceutical companies and the EU for not allowing the Global South to produce mRNA vaccines within their countries.
criticism_other: Vaccine hoarding, vaccine manufacturing rights, EU

meaning: This tweet does not disclose personal opinion about vaccination, rather it reports that Southwest Airlines struggled with having enough employees to run flights. This post is not misleading because it says people speculate that mandates were the problem, while Southwest declared that vaccine mandates were not the cause of the issue.
Tweeter states that vaccines do not work and instead they should be called abominations.
This is a news repost from Reuters that says Israel will offer the forth booster shots. No personal opinion is involved.

This tweet lies within a thread. He's replying to an anti-vaxxer who claims that "Funeral directors and insurance companies claim a 40% increase in deaths for ages 18-49 years since 2021." This tweeter attempts to debunk that, and also calls out conspiracy theories that people are dying of COVID-19 vaccines earlier in the tweet.
Tweeter is implying that both vaccine proponents and opponents spread misinformation, thus tweeter prefers to look at the source of the information.
Tweeter is implying that since vaccines and masks are apparently not stopping the coronavirus spread there should not be any such mandates.
This tweet by a Philippine digital news site celebrates the successful vaccination campaigns in Bacolod City, which have led to high vaccination rates and increased safety for children.
Spotify will be parting ways with Joe Rogan because he had vaccine critics on his show and big pharma does not like this and will make sure he gets cancelled.
This tweet by a youth led organization thanks its volunteers for running campaigns that have helped improve COVID19 vaccination rates in some regions of Pakistan.

This tweeter is misleading because it claims that Russians don't need to be vaccinated to visit France. But travel information sites such as https://airheart.com/travel-restrictions/france-from-russia-vaccinated 
say that vaccination is required. This tweet is misleading and it spreads love for Putin and anti-vaxx mentality.
support_other: Putin, Travel without vaccine passport restrictions

meaning: This is a news headline repost, from a New York Times article, which contains no personal opinion. It reports on the easing of social distancing and masking restrictions.

This tweeter debunks an anti-vaxxer who posted a video. The video was shot in China, but the anti-vaxxer claims it was a scene from Australia. This post is pro-vaccine and calls out people who spread disinformation.

This tweeter calls out DeSantis for descending into anti-vaxx "crazytown." A tweet to a Hill article was included with this post which reports that DeSantis "proposed [a new] law that would make businesses liable for medical harm resulting from mandatory vaccines."

This tweeter promotes an anti-vaxx stance and says that health care workers should be allowed to work even if unvaccinated. This discussion comes amidst talks about mandates being instated int he workplace. This tweeter believes patients will be left untreated due to staff shortages if mandates are pushed through.
criticism_other: Mandating health care workers to get vaxxed

meaning: Tweeter quoted a Seattle Times news report about U.S. Federal Aviation admin chief dismissing flight cancellation as a consequence of Biden administration's vaccine mandate but does not mention that Republicans posed those questions.
Tweeter is sharing headlines of reports on COVID 19 published in Brantford Expositor in February 2021.
Tweeter, a journalist, is sharing U.S. parents' concerns about the long-term effect of vaccines in children under 5, as reported in a survey.
This tweet is by the Mississippi state health authority about who can get booster shots, and where.
This tweet promotes vaccines by offering information on how cervical cancer risks can be mitigated through vaccination.

This tweeter writes that based on their own research, they found that the Gates Foundation gave fifteen million dollars to create a COVID19 vaccine for South Africa, listing the grant topic as HIV, pneumonia. It questions the effectiveness of vaccines and the trustworthiness of those funding them.
This anti-vaxx tweet proclaims that vaccines have killed many many Americans. But that is not true. This tweet intends to raise fear about vaccination.
This is a pro-vaccine post that encourages people to get vaccinated and to get their boosters, especially as Christmas approached.
This tweet is unsure about the vaccine. While it praises long-established vaccines, like the polio injection, it says people are skeptical of the COVID-19 vaccine because it's so new.
Tweeter is replying to a list of things that did not exist 20 years ago and adding a list of COVID-related things that didn't exist two years ago.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says there are better arguments for supporting the anti-mandate cause that what someone posted ahead of him in that thread.

This anti-vaxx tweeter is not a doctor yet promotes ideas on why or why not vaccines or boosters may be effective within a thread about the possibility of boosters being mandated. Ultimately, this tweeter promotes freedom of choice.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine. He calls Trump an "idiotus" and exclaims at how he woke up and recommended vaccines to the public.
This post reports that the CDC recommends COVID-19 boosters for at risk Americans.
This pro-vaccine tweet explains to the public what is required for a senior citizen to keep a fully-vaxxed status in Malaysia. The tweet says that any booster is good, no matter what the make is.
This pro-vaccine tweeter expresses dismay at misinformation regarding COVID-19, while also providing information on how vaccines work to reduce risks of contracting the virus.

This tweet is in response to a fight that broke out in an airport. No police or security were present at the fight. This tweeter makes an anti-vaxx joke, saying police are too busy enforcing mandates.
criticism_other: Police and security enforcing pandemic related issues

meaning: This is a pro-vaccine post. It promotes vaccination as a way to obtain economic recovery.
This pro-vaccine tweeter criticizes Spotify for pulling Neil Young, who stood up for science and asked Spotify to pull Joe Rogan's podcasts from their platforms.

This anti-vaxx tweeter is asking a pro-vaxx tweeter to justify a comment about how vaccines are like seatbelts, then continues to question why an "experimental" vaccine is required to work certain jobs.
This tweet provides information on under what circumstances the public should contact police.
support_other: Calling police for the appropriate reasons

meaning: This pro-vaxx tweeter is dismayed at how some people have slipped through the vaccine mandate cracks by presenting fake passports. The tweeter supports mandating vaccines within sports leagues.
criticism_other: Lack of enforcement of vaccine mandates in sports

meaning: This tweet promotes walk-in vaccinations at a South London leisure centre.
This tweet is pro-vaccine. It says that vaccination doesn't affect female or male fertility. And it contains a link to the CDC website to support that comment.
This anti-vaxxer is complaining about Eric Adams. The message of the tweet is not entirely clear but it seems to be saying that Eric Adams should not have allowed vaccine mandates in the first place.
It says mandates and passports don't work because the vaccine is not a vaccine and it doesn't provide immunity.

A reply to a tweet about how COVID is still a novel disease that has serious affects. This tweet says the vaccine is more deadly. It includes raw numbers about vaccine reactions, citing over 42,000 adverse reactions amongst billions of doses administered.
It says the vaccine is completely ineffective, it also implies the vaccine is dangerous and the government is afraid of lawsuits related to vaccine reactions.
A tweet from a medical organisation urging people to get their kids vaccinated. It links to an interactive graph showing the COVID numbers in the US.
This anti-vaxx tweeter rejects Biden and vaccine mandates. It also promotes the 3%, which is a pro-gun, anti-government group.

This pro-vaccine tweeter correlates low vaccination rates, to freedom fighting mentality, to poverty and low levels of education in West Virgina. This tweeter is skeptical of Senator Joe Manchin for promoting a "no pressure" approach to the pandemic.
This pro-vaccine tweeter calls out Parexel, to say one of their employees is spreading disinformation.
This anti-vaxx tweeter is spreading misinformation about vaccines killing people. There is no evidence or proof to back up this statement, that a man named Warnie died.
This is a pro-vaccine post that promotes the flue vaccine and provides information on that.
This anti-vaxxer says Biden is to blame if the food supply chain is clogged up.
This is an economic report that mentions COVID-19 cases are on the decline. The post contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx because they share a post about NYPD suing the city over vaccine mandates. The link provided within the tweet is deactivated.
This anti-vaxxer says that vaccine mandates are not a British concept. The tweeter is critical of the British Prime Minister for pushing that forward. And she says Britain needs rescuing.

This tweeter is calling out Marjorie Taylor Greene for supporting National Guard workers for protesting vaccine mandates. The tweet is pro-vaccine and suggests that she should be "booted out of congress."
A reply to a claim that only vaccinated people currently have COVID. This tweet asks for the source behind that claim, and promotes vaccine efficacy.

This anti-vaxx tweet claims that more vaccinated people have died of COVID-19 than unvaccinated, which isn't true. The tweeter also shares a graph to say that the AZ vaccine is not effective after a certain period. The BMJ reported that "The longer it takes to effectively vaccinate the global population, the greater the likely risk of vaccine resistant strains developing."

A piece of a thread about how the vaccine is ineffective and is a treatment rather than a vaccine. It also agrees with a tweet about how the mainstream media is deceiving the public about the vaccine.

A tweet linking to an article about vaccine efficacy in children, and how the vaccine is far less effective against Omicron. The tweet argues that the mainstream media have altered facts about vaccine efficacy, however the tweet does not consider the fact that Omicron is a different virus than the original virus the vaccine was developed to protect people from.

Dr. Urso, the tweeter of this post, has been reported for malpractice. He was a supporter of hydroxycloroquine and has also made strange claims about COVID-19 and its treatment. It's hard to understand this post, but it's anti-vaxx. The post contains confusing information to confuse readers.
A tweet calling to end mandates and passports in the name of freedom, also calls vaccinated people slugs.

This tweeter says that a video featuring public health information about vaccines is propaganda. The tweeter seems to promote non-mRNA vaccines, saying that new vaccines will create fear for old tried-and-true vaccines.
This pro-vaccine tweet states that most Americans believe at least one lie about COVID-19 vaccines. She says that misinformation has real-world impacts and supports truth.

This anti-vaxxer posted a meme depicting a woman with kids. They all hold knives and the caption to the photo says that the vaccine is hiding in their blood, waiting to "kick the shit out of me together."

This tweet is uncertain in its view of vaccines. On one hand, the tweeter says a guy who helped at a vaccination centre for kids was loved. On the other hand, that tweeter put scared emoticons next to that text. So I flagged this tweet as unsure about vaccination.

This tweeter complains about vaccine mandates and says the vaccine doesn't stop transmission. The tweeter also plays the race card by saying that people of colour are being discriminated against for being denied entry into businesses if unvaccinated.
criticism_other: Denying people of colour access to businesses without being vaccinated

meaning: Although this tweet is somewhat pro-vaccine, it is also inherently anti-vaccine because it rejects vaccine mandates. The tweeter suggests that vaccines are only good for a certain vulnerable age group, and that vaccines are only remotely effective in preventing serious illness, which is not true.
A tweet arguing against ending the vaccine mandate in DC, it includes the announcement that the mandate is ending.
A reply tweet arguing the vaccine is not a vaccine because it's not 100% reliable against every variation of COVID.
This tweeter wonders why she should get the vaccine when her neighbours had side effects from it, she says. She does not provide any proof of the side effects. But regardless, she is anti-vaxx.

This tweet provides information on what The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) (regional development organization in East Africa) did on Mar.23, 2022. That includes some pro-vaccine discussions.
This tweeter says that the vaccination booking system in Korea is inefficient. It's based on birth days and the tweeter said their friend had to wait three months to get vaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is happy that the U.S. military didn't grant any religious exemptions for vaccination.
This is a pro-vaccine post because it was made by the President of the European Council, which has a pro-vaccine stance. The post links to a live feed with information about mRNA technology.
This pro-vaccine tweeter criticizes anti-vaxxers, or "freedom fighters," for complaining about not being able to fly.
This tweeter says that two Australian officials would have created many more COVID-19 deaths if more people had listened to them.

This anti-vaxxer replied to a post about vaccination of children under five years old. He says that the vaccine could kill a child and he throws a bunch of scientific nonsense, that the public couldn't begin to understand, to gaslight readers. This post is deceptive.
This tweet is pro-vaccine because it promotes locations where a person can receive vaccines in Calgary.
This pro-vaccine post promotes information on how vaccines were donated to Uganda. And it also mentions news about Tanzania.
This pro-vaccine tweeter shares their experience about getting vaccinated. They say they had side effects after the jab, but that not everyone would have them.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is angry at anti-vaxxers for spreading disinformation which is harmful to society. He says that in the future, when "we're all fine," that anti-vaxxers may realize that they failed.
A news bulletin tweet including a headline about a vaccine mandate for children.

A tweet arguing the vaccine is not a vaccine, and that it is killing countless people. It supports the argument by adding unsourced data from unnamed life insurance companies which allegedly show a 40 per cent rise in deaths.

A tweet linking to an article from the NYT about New York hospitals. This tweet is from a doctor from New York who praised vaccines, community, and public health officials for keeping hospitals running during the pandemic.
This tweeter makes a joke about vaccines and how some are linked to middle class status, such as Pfizer. The tweeter questions why this is true yet promotes vaccination.
This pro-vaccine tweeter criticizes nurses in the ER who revealed anti-vaxx sentiments and revealed anti-mask comments to her.

This tweet claims that Moderna's new mRNA flu vaccine has more side effects than the normal vaccine. This tweet is inherently anti-science because it is skeptical of new technology. And the tweet is misleading because I was not able to find any reputable news reports to support claims that this new mRNA flu vaccine is dangerous.
This tweeter refers to the trucker convoy as a "pussy protest." This is clearly a pro-vaccine tweeter. She's shocked that grown men would be afraid of the mask and vaccine.
A tweet saying the vaccine doesn't prevent transmission so getting vaccinated doesn't help your community, it doesn't include any kind of source or data.
A tweet linking to the study showing that the vaccine is 12 per cent effective in children against omicron.

This anti-vaxx is misleading. The tweeter posts a video to try to prove that the Red Cross won't accept blood donations from COVID-19 vaccinated people. This intends to support the anti-vaxx cause by saying vaccines are dangerous. But Full Fack.org reported that "The American Red Cross has stopped accepting donations of plasma containing Covid-19 antibodies from anyone as it has enough supply. It says people who have been vaccinated against Covid-19 can still give blood."
This tweeter defends Adele, the singer, for having a pro-vaccine stance. Another tweeter had made fun of her and had posted a tabloid-esque article about her.

This tweeter doesn't express or pro- or anti-vaxx stance, rather he says that there will always be a new variant and that people should relax and try to live life. This is in response to a tweet about Bill Maher, and this tweeter is defending that public figure.
A quote from Dr. Malone about how pharmaceutical companies have made an outrageous amount of money from the COVID vaccine, and how prior to the pandemic vaccine production was far less profitable.
A tweet criticising the government for vaccine mandates and its immigration policy. The priority for this user is American freedom over the global response to the pandemic.

A tweet including an unsourced graph about how unvaccinated people are less likely to get COVID than vaccinated people. It also includes some assumptions about the data in an effort to make it seems legitimate.
A tweet arguing that a lack of choice for vaccines in Australia is because of government oversight. It's using the pandemic to try to swing voters in the next election.
A tweet promoting a vaccine clinic for teenagers in Mysuru.
A tweet praising a hockey league for mandating vaccines, warning them about backlash from anti-vaxxers.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine. She replied to an anti-vaxxer who was spreading disinformation, by saying "don't spread misinformation."

A tweet saying that Dr. Fauci is worse than the Nazi Dr. Mengele. Promoting the conspiracy theory that Fauci funded a research project which initially created COVID. A jackpot of misinformation, exaggeration, and madness.

A tweet calling out a politician in British Columbia, pointing to non-existent data about vaccinated people becoming sicker than unvaccinated people. The user also claims they had myocarditis which cannot be verified, but the other claims are verifiably false.

A tweet linking to a study about adverse reactions to placebo vaccinations, the main reasoning is to tell people vaccination can cause adverse reactions in some people and the COVID vaccine itself is totally safe.

A tweet about how people should resist the vaccine because the government shouldn't blackmail or coerce people into getting vaccinated. It implies you should fight for your freedom rather than comply with public health measures.
A tweet from CTV about Quebec's vaccine mandates and passports, as well as speculating what kind of passport policy Ontario might implement.

A tweet alluding to the conspiracy theory that COVID was manufactured as a bio-weapon. It also includes a link to misinformation making common fainting after vaccination seem like a dangerous side-effect that people are trying to cover up.
A tweet about a republican politician, William Marsh, who switched to democrat because of anti-vaccine republicans.
A tweet criticising the fact that officials have been advising several doses of the vaccine to keep immunity up to date. It implies the vaccine is ineffective compared to other vaccines.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says the government has been hiding something and recently "spilled the beans": That double vaccinated people cannot achieve natural immunity. This is completely bogus, the vaccine is a lower intensity and safer version of the virus to contract.
This pro-vaccine tweeter replied to another pro-vaccine tweeter who says we should re-open everything amidst the Omicron surge. This tweeter is in favour of not re-opening too quickly.
This post does not appear to promote or criticize anything. It regards some information about the healthcare system in New Zealand and that vaccination is not required to seek health services.
Tweet quotes an ethics professor who was fired for saying ethically you can not coerce someone into getting the vaccine.
This tweeter says that Rodgers was a safer person in the NFL because he tested frequently due to his vaccine status. This is anti-vaxx because it promotes testing rather than vaccination.
This anti-vaxx tweeter promotes Ivermectin (a horse wormer) as a cure for COVID-19. They refer to vaccination as a form of genocide and psychopathy.
This tweeter doesn't disclose personal opinion about the vaccine mandates. But they do comment on how some individuals exploited the situation by posing as lawyers on his company website.
criticism_other: People posing as lawyers amidst vaccine mandates

meaning: A tweet criticising the change of the definition of vaccine, it also put vaccine in quotes implying it's a fake vaccine. Ignoring the irony of the fact that they changed the definition to clear up this user's exact misunderstanding.

A tweet about a Washington state trooper who went viral for defying the vaccine mandates and quitting his job, he was praised and celebrated by conservative anti-vaxxers.  The tweet is about how he recently died of COVID but includes the context.

A tweet saying that just because someone doesn't trust the COVID vaccine doesn't mean they are against vaccines. It criticises the efficacy of the vaccine as well as the media for using 'fear mongering tactics.'
A tweet including a quote from an anti-vaxxer about how they are sympathetic towards people who got the vaccine because they fell for the alleged conspiracy.
A misleading tweet about how natural immunity means you don't need to get vaccinated because it lasts forever.
A tweet about the various debunked treatments for COVID such as ivermectin, it also claims other previous tweets about the same thing were deleted.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says his 14-year-old got vaccinated. He describes her as a real "freedom fighter."
This tweeter is anti-vaxx and uses a story about his wife, who's a nurse, to promote fear about vaccinating children. He said his wife is uncomfortable with some of the vaccines.
A tweet about how vaccine mandates are evil, it also says that PCR and rapid tests are dangerous somehow.
A tweet from a Scottish member of parliament about quarantine and vaccination mandates for travellers returning to Scotland.
A tweet criticising public health policy, arguing that we ought to look for various solutions and question whether there is a better method to prevent the spread of COVID.
A tweet about how breakthrough cases are rare and the vaccine is effective. It also links to a Toronto Star article that supports vaccine efficacy.

This tweet is a reply to a clip of someone being secretly fed human flesh on a game show. But the clip is actually from the prank show 'Fameless'. This user seemingly doesn't know the clip is fake, and spirals down conspiracy theories starting at vaccines and ending with 'Soylent Green'.

This anti-vaxx tweeter shares information about the Supreme Court blocking the Biden administration from enforcing vaccine mandates at large private companies. This news was reported in leading outlets like CNBC.
OutKick, the author of this tweet, has a right-wing bias and isn't the best at fact checking. This tweet is anti-vaxx and uses Aaron Rodger's story to promote an agenda.
This is a news post, which doesn't disclose any information, about public health mandates being lifted in Europe and Turkey. Andalou Agency, the tweeter, is a reputable news organization.
Tweeter states that Israel data shows that COVID-19 survivors were more protected then those who had a Pfizer vaccine.
One American News says that there will be a paramedic shortage in NYC because of vaccine mandates.
Tweeter is implying that Quebec's premier is supposedly getting paid by vaccine manufacturers to implement strict vaccine mandate rules and impose a tax on those who refuse to get vaccinated.

Tweeter insinuated that the Oscar slap incident between Will Smith and Chris Rock was apparently an ad to promote Pfizer's new alopecia drug,  to distract people from the drug's and COVID vaccine's supposedly harmful effects.
This tweet is by CTV Ottawa about a man arrested for flaunting a sword while he disputed a vaccine passport requirement at a restaurant.
This anti-vaxxer replied to a pro-vaccine person within a thread. This tweet communicates that vaccines kill people, which is misleading.
Tweeter reacts to an article about Pfizer CEO authorizing the fourth vaccine and states only two per cent of the population is at high risk. They hashtag it goblins.
Tweet from NGO about how getting the vaccine reduces the risk of getting long covid and its another reason to get it.
Tweeter is calling NYT out for spreading apparent misinformation about China's COVID vaccines' effectiveness.

Tweeter reacted to a news report by The Hill on Pfizer's CEO talking about the need for a 2nd booster shot by saying the decision to get vaccinated should be left to individuals and parents of young children.
This tweet is by a U.S.-based biotechnology company announcing they applied to the Canadian public health authority for approval of their protein-based COVID vaccine.
Tweeter is praising the Indian foreign affairs minister's tweet about getting the success of vaccines developed by India.
Tweeter is replying to a thread about the evolution of coronavirus, antibodies and vaccines.
This tweet is by a radio news channel sharing snippets of their programme content with audiences.

This anti-vaxx tweet is misleading. The tweeter claims that the CDC doesn't consider the COVID-19 shot a vaccine, but that isn't true. It's listed as a vaccine on their website: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/index.html. The tweeter shares this information to raise mistrust towards vaccination.
This tweeter passes no judgment on COVID-19 vaccines, rather he presents the COVID-19 case counts, number of vaccinated people and number of deaths for Dec.6, 2021.
Tweeter is criticizing corporate employers for enforcing the vaccine mandate.
This tweet doesn't proclaim a pro- or anti-vaxx stance, rather a question about what a 150% vaccination rate is. But this tweeter is clearly anti-vaxx based on her twitter feed.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is making a joke, but it's slightly misleading. He says that if health officials gave an oxycotin pill to anti-vaxxers, that would convince them to take the vaccine. This equates most anti-vaxxers to drug addicts, which is misleading.
Tweeter retweets an Op-Ed about how religion should not be a reason to not get vaccines anymore.
This tweet is by a news website on Spotify's response after musician Neil Young and others protested the streaming of certain contents that spread vaccine misinformation.
By quoting a cartoon that shows President Biden vaccinating a child, tweeter is insinuating that children are more susceptible to harmful effects of the COVID vaccines for their lower body weights.
Tweeter is implying that people will apparently be required to take COVID vaccine shots yearly if governments make booster shots mandatory.
Tweeter implied that U.K's healthcare workers opposing the vaccine mandate are right because the vaccine is apparently experimental and thus can be harmful.
Tweeter retweeted a Guardian report about scientists' concern over the UK government's plan to sell a government-funded vaccine development facility to private owners.
Tweeter is thanking vaccinated people and criticizing so-called experts on COVID and vaccination who use social media to spread misinformation.
Referring to a study shared on a suspended account tweeter claimed that COVID vaccines are apparently causing heart attacks and injuries among footballers.
This is an ad by a pharmacy or clinic saying that they have appointments available for booster shots.
This anti-vaxx tweeter celebrates the fact that over two million elderly people have not been vaccinated in the U.K. as of Oct.2021. A link to a tabloid article is provided to prove that stat.
Tweeter is debunking a claim by another user about Pfizer CEO apparently admitting that the COVID vaccine does not work.
This tweeter does not disclose a stance on vaccines, rather they say that people should not be mocking death in relation to vaccine status.
criticism_other: Anger towards vaccine status, joking about death

meaning: This anti-vaxxer shares a graph from Our World in Data and claims that vaccine mandates have not made much of an improvement on vaccination rates in America. The tweet is clearly anti-Biden as well, because it mentions that he announced mandates.
This tweeter doesn't disclose a clear opinion about vaccination, but rather criticizes the news. They say the news polarizes everything and makes people hate everything including vaccines.

This is a news repost and the tweet contains no personal information. The tweeter simply reposts a headline from a Washington Post article that reads "Thursday briefing: One month of war in Ukraine; Moderna’s vaccine for kids; Madeleine Albright’s legacy; March Madness; and more."
Tweeter replys to a tweet about poorer countries not having a vaccine and questions why EU vaccines aren't being given to them, despite needing those vaccines when applying for a visa.
Tweeter is claiming that world leaders are on trial for the supposed crime of enforcing vaccine mandates. The tweet implies that the supposed harm such a mandate did is the same as the Holocaust.

Tweeter is mocking Republicans' opposition to mask and vaccine mandates by implying that if they believe China released coronavirus as a bio-weapon, republicans are supporting China by opposing measures, which would keep Americans safe.
Tweeter is talking about measures the Indian government should take to prevent a third wave in that country.
This tweet is by Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, a proponent of herd immunity, criticizing New York's governor for promoting COVID vaccination of children.
Tweeter implied that UK PM Boris Johnson is a child because he said temporary vaccination clinics will pop us like Christmas trees, which take many years to grow.
This pro-vaccine tweeter criticizes a politician, Matt Hancock, for using the wrong communication style with anti-vaxxers.
Tweeter is implying that an American basketball team did not perform well because they had to lose a player because of the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter shared that he is going to get his vaccination shots.

Tweeter criticized the Indian PM Modi for taking credit for immunizing the country's huge population by saying that Modi did not address the nation during India's 2nd wave and is not paying health workers properly.
This pro-vaccine tweeter uses a letter by Benjamin Franklin to illustrate why parents should vaccinate their kids. The letter describes his choice to not vaccinate his child, who died of smallpox.
criticism_other: Anti-vaxxers who put their kids at risk by not vaccinating them

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweeter says people are not talking enough about the long-COVID symptoms many children are facing in the U.K. She says everyone talks about boosters, but not about vaccinating children.

This is a news tweet from a news source that isn't well known. It contains no personal opinion. Politico also reported "The Biden administration and members of Congress are pointing fingers at one another over the stalling out of more than $15 billion in pandemic funds that are needed to continue combating Covid-19 in the U.S. and around the world" on the same day, so this information appears to be accurate.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the government is exercising control over the public by instating vaccine passports. They provided a link in their tweet to another tweet that claims Big Pharma is not working in the best interest of the public.
This tweeter argues that the definition of anti-vaxxers includes people who are vaccinated but oppose vaccine mandates more broadly.
This tweeter advocates for an end to all vaccines to save lives, claiming that once you receive one vaccine, you will always need vaccines to continue to live.
This tweet shares a news piece by Arizona’s Family, stating that a study has found that State lotteries did not motivate people to get vaccinated against COVID19.
Tweeter quoted a NYT report about the U.S. Supreme Court rejecting an appeal by a group of NYC teachers to block vaccine mandates in schools.
Tweeter is blaming rich countries and global vaccine inequity for the COVID variant that showed up in Africa.

Tweeter is reiterating a social media disinformation that New Zealand's High Court's declared vaccine mandate illegal, adding that police and army personnel who hesitantly got vaccinated will now be very angry.
Tweeter is insinuating that the number of fatalities from COVID are happening among vaccinated people.

This anti-vaxx tweeter promotes natural immunity. They say that natural immunity is more effective than vaccination. They list off a number of percentages for survival rates of people who have contracted COVID-19 -- who are unvaccinated -- which are misleading.
Tweeter is retweeting a MSN news report on former US basketball player Kareem Abdul Jabber calling on the NBA to ban anti-vax players.

This anti-vaxxer writes about a number of developments around the world, regarding the lifting of vaccine mandates to illustrate his cause. He implies that anti-vaxxers are starting to win because governments around the world are easing restrictions.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that anti-vaxxers are posing a threat to kids, that they are irresponsible, and that a vaccination is needed for five year olds.
This pro-vaccine tweet was made by the International Organization for Migration. It provides information about how vaccination clinics were set up to vaccinate migration-affected communities.
This tweet asks whether the brand of vaccine for the COVID19 booster shot makes a difference in the shot's effectiveness at building immunity.

This tweeter criticizes another account for posting misleading information about COVID19 vaccine side effects. He argues that although some people do have negative side effects, the majority do not and presenting data out of context is dangerous.
criticism_other: Presenting COVID19 data out of context

meaning: The tweeter writes that he uses code names for words like COVID and vaccine in his podcast so that YouTube does not take it down for spreading disinformation. The tweet includes a screenshot of a review of the podcast, which claims the code names create even more disinformation.
This tweet shares a New York Times article about the development of nasal vaccines around the world, and emphasizes the progress being made by the company Bharat Biotech.
Tweeter is explaining what the vaccine does but provided a link that is from a suspended account.
This pro-vaccine tweet encourages people to appreciate India's vaccination efforts.

This is a news tweeter from a military reporter with the Washington Post, yet it is inherently vaccine. He posts a story that he wrote for the Post about how various states tried to instill a voluntary vaccination policy within the National Guard. He reports that goes against the Department of Defense's policy.
This tweeter claims that the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says masks do not work and the COVID19 vaccine is not effective against new variants.
This tweet by the Government of Prince Edward Island shares a website where people can get their questions answered about the COVID19 vaccine for children between the ages of five and eleven.

This tweeter criticizes anti-vaxxers for claiming vaccines are unnecessary and shares that she and her family have been vaccinated. The tweet also shares a list of the vaccines that have been required for children to go to school for years.
A reply to an article about an anti-vaxxer who caught COVID and nearly died. This user is arguing that they ought to apologise for spreading misinformation and endangering others.

A reply to an article about immune compromised people and their fear about getting COVID. This tweet argues that their concerns, and the story are unwarranted because COVID is just as bad as the seasonal flu.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says they feel safe in not taking the vaccine, among other things related to pro-vaccine mentality.
This pro-vaccine tweet is a reply to an anti-vaxxer within a thread. The tweet attempts to discredit that anti-vaxxer, who defended pro-Russian values.
Tweeter is praising India's vaccine drive.
Tweeter is implying that health authorities should consider antibodies from getting COVID-19 the same as the level of immunity that vaccines provide.
Tweeter is criticizing the mask mandate, mocking that it is a reward for vaccinated people, implying that vaccines are not effective in keeping the vaccinated people safe.
This tweeter compares the vaccine passport to the social credit system, writing that both are mechanisms that control and regulate who can participate in society.
Tweeter is implying that vaccinated people have engaged in psychological warfare along with the government against anti-vaxxers.
This tweet supports tennis player Novak Djokovic in his choice not to get the COVID19 vaccine.
This tweet by Fox News Host Sean Hannity claims that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration – OSHA -suspended vaccine mandates due to multiple lawsuits.

A reply to a conversation where one user said unvaccinated people in Singapore have to pay their own medical bills, and another replied that this should apply to smokers and overweight people. This tweet argues that the Singapore policy is different because food and cigarettes are taxed whereas the unvaccinated have not been taxed.

A tweet supporting the border blockade back in February, arguing letting in unvaccinated truckers would have a small impact on public health while the blockade was costing the economy millions so just let the truckers in.

A reply to an article about how the vaccine still works, and was never able to completely prevent infection. This reply says the vaccine isn't really a vaccine, it implies there was a conspiracy to create trust in a faulty product.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that their work was slow since vaccine mandates were instated. This implies that people stopped coming due to those mandates, which may or may not be misleading.
This pro-vaccine tweeter provides a link to current COVID-19 outbreaks, and lists a link to data about those outbreaks.

This freedom of choicer posted a graph, which has no source and no information on the side bars as to what the graph displays, to support an anti-mandate agenda. They claim that full schools, stadiums and lack of mandates don't rise COVID-19 rates.
Tweeter is claiming without substantive evidence that the COVID vaccines are not effective and they create new variants.
The Indian PM Modi tweeted something in Hindi about making vaccines in India.

This is a news report by a Canadian news website about a side effect of the COVID vaccines apparently becoming a growing concern among vaccinated people. But it has been described as a rare side effect on another news website.
This tweet by Elijah Schaffer says that the democrats are losing patience with anti-vaxxers not because they aren’t getting vaccinated but because they aren’t being obedient.
A reply to a tweet that compared vaccine mandates to Jim Crow laws, this user is saying people should be proud of making the moral choice to get vaccinated.

A tweet in reply to an article about long COVID in children, it argues that although kids can get long COVID it isn't proven to be a common occurrence or major concern. It also supports vaccinating kids.

This tweet criticizes "big pharma" and says that those companies can't face legal consequences if a side effect results from taking their vaccine. This tweeter intends to stoke the anti-vaxx cause, along with some conspiracy theories that vaccines are a crime against humanity. CNBC reported that "Under the PREP Act, companies like Pfizer and Moderna have total immunity from liability if something unintentionally goes wrong with their vaccines."
This pro-vaccine tweeter supports vaccines and says that there should be a universal vaccine available. She also says that the less times a person contracts COVID-19, the better.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine and promotes boosters, vaccinations, masking and testing. She reports that there is transmission within the US, among people who haven't travelled internationally.
A Canadian news website is reporting about U.S. state Florida's public health body deciding not to recommend the COVID vaccine available for healthy children.
Tweeter is suggesting to another user that places that are against vaccine mandates and other COVID protocols should be boycotted.
This tweet by a pharmacy is sharing information on how pharmacists can communicate with vaccine-hesitant people as well as anti-vaxxers.
Tweeter is insinuating that there's something sinister in the U.S. Food and Drug administration delay in providing their full approval for the COVID vaccines.
This tweeter is looking to follow more accounts that vote Democrat, and believe in vaccines and masks.
Tweeter is implying that the U.S. government is crossing its limit by enforcing the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter is implying that some celebrities are anti-vaxxers or spreading misinformation about vaccines.
Tweeter is implying that the vaccine may not be safe for children by quoting U.S. Food and Drug Administration chief's reservation about COVID vaccines for children last fall.
A tweet mocking anti-vaxxers with sarcasm, masking fear and frustration over the rise of a new version of Omicron.
A tweet about how someone had COVID in 2020 and says they still have natural immunity and don't need a vaccine.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that they're going to lose their job due to mandates in the work place.

It's not clear what this tweeter is promoting but he shared a pro-vaccine post. The tweeter could be indicating heart break over the divide vaccines have caused because he posted broken heart emoticons next to the words "this vaxx."

This tweet is by an Israeli news media reporting that the country's health minister recommended people getting the Pfizer vaccine to avoid strenuous activity for a week  because of the possibility of myocarditis.
Tweeter is retweeting a news report about L.A. county requiring proof of vaccination in certain public places.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines are likely to cause dementia, remove natural immunity and are just a ploy by big pharma to make more money.

This tweet criticizes French president Macron for excluding the unvaccinated from many public places in France, and argues that the the government is lying about vaccine effectiveness because cases are still so high.
In response to a news story about Bruce Willis stepping away from acting due to a Aphasia diagnosis, this tweet claims that Aphasia is a side effect of the COVID19 vaccine.

This tweet is in support of a tweet by an anti-vaxxer, claiming that because the United States is a free country, anti-vaxx opinions are allowed to be voiced on twitter. The tweet also insults another user who spoke up against sharing anti-vaccine information online.
Tweeter is saying people should be left to decide whether to get vaccinated for COVID or not similar to people's choice about taking the flu shots.
An Indian news media tweeted about an inoculation drive proposed by an Indian city mayor.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines do not prevent transmission, which means vaccinated people can spread the virus too now that mask mandates have been lifted.

Tweeter, a scientist, shared a snippet of a report on vaccine effectiveness but non-scientists can misinterpret the tweet and conclude that vaccines are not effective, whereas the full report says otherwise.

This is a news report about Ukrainian refugees and it doesn't pass personal opinion, yet it is inherently pro-vaccine. The article says Ukrainians will be allowed to take pets to the UK, and that they will receive free vaccines and quarantine upon arrival into the UK.
This anti-vaxxer says that dying from vaccines could be fashionable. This is a critique on the safety of vaccines.

This tweet by Anglican Deacon Calvin Robinson writes that vaccine passports are illiberal and discriminatory and that there is no evidence they work. It includes a link to a UK government call for feedback on a vaccine passport proposal, inviting followers to have their say.
