Tweeter is implying that children and healthy people do not need vaccines for COVID protection, so the U.K. government was apparently wrong in enforcing lockdowns, mask and vaccine mandates.
Tweeter is replying to a doctor who tweets about the apparent dangers of COVID vaccine, but the context of this particular tweet is not clear as the tweet is not longer live.

Tweeter quoted a report by a news outlet with questionable sources about Red Cross apparently refusing blood from vaccinated donors. In actuality Red Cross asks people who do not know the name of their vaccines to wait two weeks before donating blood.
This tweet from a user in the United States writes that a world-wide vaccination program should be implement after COVID19 has been eliminated in the United States.
This post includes a link to a news piece by the Guardian announcing that the World Health Organization has endorsed the use of the first ever Malaria vaccine in Africa.

This tweeter says that vaccine passports are a form of control. And that there will be more forms of control in the name of COVID-19 in the future. This is inherently an anti-government post, although it doesn't specifically mention government being the problem.
This is a news report, based on an FDA online post about Moderna's Spikevax being approved. There is no personal opinion attached to this news, yet it is inherently pro-vaccine.

This tweet is anti-vaxx because it doesn't approve of COVID-19 vaccines, although the tweeter does support polio (and etc.) vaccines. The tweeter is skeptical of mRNA vaccines and claims the CDC couldn't define the mRNA vaccines as such, which isn't true.
This anti-vaxx tweeter spreads vaccine hesitation by claiming the vaccine could maim or kill someone. The tweeter also says the vaccine is ineffective.
This post asks another twitter user to wake up and learn the truth about vaccines before it´s too late.

This tweeter replied to a previous tweeter who said that groups with the word "mom" in their titles tend to have something controversial going on. This tweeter agrees and says that there was an anti-vaxx group called Moms Across America.

This anti-vaxx tweet is skeptical of vaccines. He is also skeptical of Reuters fact checking, which reports that Fauci did not make the virus. The tweeter is promoting conspiracy theories and vaccine hesitancy, by claiming there may be side-effects popping up in five years within vaccinated people.
This tweet does not contain personal opinion. It's informational and is a statement about the end of vaccine mandates in Saskatchewan, and it links to a verified news video to prove that.
It seems tweeter is criticizing the termination of healthcare workers because of the vaccine mandate.

Tweeter is supporting a tweet that claimed that the fatality rate from vaccination is apparently higher than the fatality rate from the Omicron variant by criticizing vaccinated people and vaccine mandates.
This tweet questions why governments are not financing factories in developing countries to make vaccines under license.

This tweet is anti-vaxx. The quote is from a discredited doctor who pushed hydroxychloroquine at the beginning of the pandemic. It claims that there's an ugly truth to the vaccine and that media push it on TV.

This post writes that if groups such as college students, teachers, and nurses went on strike against vaccines instead of complying, there would be no vaccine mandates. It claims that by sticking together, anti-vaxxers can control the narrative.
This anti-vaxxer says that COVID-19 public health protocols are all a form of tyranny. He doesn't agree with mandates.

This tweet is pro-choice in terms of vaccines. It is not flagged as anti-vaxx because the tweeter says he is vaccinated, and that a person he's discussing is vaccinated. But the tweet does promote freedom of choice at the same time.
This tweeter tells anti-vaxxers that they don't need to sit around complaining about mandates, when they could just get vaccinated and not deal with being excluded from going to restaurants.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx. In a previous tweet within this thread, he calls vaccine passports a form of tyranny. This tweet shows disdain at not being able to board a flight without a vaccine passport.
criticism_other: Lack of ability to fly without a vaccine passport

meaning: This post by DD News announces the latest vaccination numbers and the number of new COVID19 cases in India.

This anti-vaxxer says they won't support a business because they likely have vaccine mandates in place. The tweet is not well-written or clear, but it does indicate that the tweeter prefers to be "vaxx clean."

This pro-vaccine tweeter uses Obama as a guide as to why the public should get vaccinated. She's either implying that COVID-19 is real because he got it, or that he didn't die because he was vaccinated.

This pro-vaccine tweeter makes a comment on anti-vaxxers. He says that they consider vaccines as a threat. He uses a GIF of a man holding a baseball bat, covered in barbed-wire, as an example of what those anti-vaxxers see when they think "vaccine."
Tweeter is retweeting a report by an American news website about a group of California parents protesting the vaccine mandate for school children.
New Hampshire health authority is sharing where people can get inoculated.

Tweeter is implying that there is something sinister in the fact that the Scottish government shares private health information with 3rd party data processor companies such as Amazon through vaccine passports.
This user writes that social distancing and masking are important for preventing widespread infection as vaccine protection wanes and some areas in the world continue without access to vaccines.
This tweet reply to a medical doctor claims that the vaccine does not work because at a care home in British Columbia there are 81 out of 95 residents infected and 12 dead.
This tweeter seems to be asking that vaccines should be mandated for a number of services, including government assistance and unessential services. The link in this tweet is broken.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says there's corruption between TEGNA and Pfizer. He says news outlets push vaccines due to that corruption, which is misleading.
This post writes that the vaccine triggers an immune response without getting ill with COVID19, while the unvaccinated could get sick with COVID19 multiple times over.

This tweeter promotes "freedom" and claims that Biden's government just began restrictions by way of COVID-19, and that life will never return to normal again. He lists off aspects of COVID-19 goalposts that he finds problematic, showing his disdain for inconsistent messaging.

This post criticizes soccer player Sergio Aguero for encouraging COVID19 vaccinations for children and then collapsing on the field due to heart disorder, which the tweeter claims is a side effect of the vaccination.

This tweeter supports the trucker convoy, and is therefore anti-vaxx. He tells them to hold the line because although a vaccine mandate was dropped for attending businesses, Canadians could still be fired for not getting vaccinated.
This anti-vaxxer says the vaccine is an experiment and that the second jab will kill.
This tweeter contains no personal opinion about vaccines, it just states that in areas where there's a higher voter turnout for Trump, vaccination rates are lower.

This post by a nurse questions another twitter user’s claim that the medical and research community have developed new therapeutics for COVID19 since early 2020. It claims that the difference between now and early 2020 is the pushing of vaccines.
This post is in reply to a tweet that claims T cells from the common cold are enough to protect against coronavirus. It writes that T cell are not considered a vaccine.
This post criticizes leftist New Yorkers for taking so long to realize that vaccine mandates and other health measures are ridiculous and make no sense.
This tweet is not promoting or criticizing anything. It is flagged as pro-vaccine because the tweeter said she's vaxxed. She says that she felt COVID-19 even though she's vaxxed.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that lockdowns and vaccine mandates don't work because Australia's cases rose despite having those mandates in place.
This post by an anti-vaxxer writes that illegal immigrants should be vaccinated.

This tweeter supports vaccine mandates. He says that the conservative government undermined vaccine mandates. He implies they should not be trusted on their judgment of science because the conservatives took to long to aknowledge climate change is real.

This post celebrates the closing of a medical clinic due to staff refusing to get vaccinated against COVID19. It claims that workers will win the war against illegal vaccine mandates by not complying with them.
This anti-vaxxer claims that COVID-19 was created for the vaccine, not the other way around. This is a conspiracy theory that claims the whole pandemic was orchestrated.
This post criticizes lockdowns, vaccine passports, and masking. It calls those who enforce these mandates dictators.
This post claims that it is difficult to discern a bad reaction to the vaccine from long COVID and that prediabetics have bad reactions to the vaccine.

This tweet is nonsensical but it promotes some kind of anti-vaxx conspiracy theory about how vaccines will be spread through the food supply. The tweeter claims that a Pfizer official is blowing the whistle on this situation.
criticism_other: mRNA vaccines through the food supply?, mRNA vaccines

meaning: This post is in response to a tweet by Bernie Sanders. It criticizes him for calling out Walmart’s move to cut employees’ paid leave while ignoring the company’s move to fire people who refuse to get vaccinated.
This anti-vaxxer says that doctors are covering up severe injuries from the COVID-19 vaccines. This is a conspiracy theory.
This tweet regards social distancing and testing measures that the venue put into place. This tweeter promotes public health protocols.

This tweet doesn't promote or criticize anything, it just says that a guy from a Tik Tok video has been controversial for years, and that the COVID-19 commentary is a new addition. The video depicts a prof who supports social distancing, who is rather crude in his reasons for wanting to execute ZOOM videos, rather than in-person sessions.

This anti-vaxxer's claim that 10,000 Americans experienced tinnitus as a result of vaccination was reported by ABC. What was seems misleading about this tweet is that they claim the CDC and FDA don't care about this. The tweeter is using this tweet to spread vaccine fear.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is calling out an anti-vaccine-mandate tweeter within a thread. This tweeter tells that person to stop lying, and that being triple vaxxed does reduce transmission.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that freedom of choice should apply to vaccination. They posted a video about a woman standing up for womens' rights to choose abortion, saying they wish this was the case for vaccines.
This is a pro-vaccine tweeter's opinion post. They claim that Trump and the GOP have killed many Americans with their failure to take the pandemic seriously.

This pro-vaccine tweeter asks why anti-axxers and anti-abortionists  align in their beliefs of freedom of choice, when the government dictates what women can do with their bodies when saying no to abortions.
criticism_other: Anti-abortionists who also say no to government

meaning: Tweeter did not get vaccinated but stays at home so as to not spread the virus. She is telling an unvaccinated user how COVID 19 can spread.

Tweeter implied that an NBA referee's refusal to get vaccinated on religious grounds is baseless. Tweeter is claiming that there is apparently no religion that prevents people from getting vaccinated.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is angry at anti-maskers and anti-vaxxers for prolonging the pandemic. They posted a comic drawing to depict this dynamic, showing a man without a mask yelling at Biden (who wears a mask).

This tweeter is critical of pharmaceutical companies for hoarding vaccine manufacturing rights. The tweeter wants a global response, where other countries have better access to manufacturing vaccines. This is a critical tweet of the Global North for hoarding vaccines.
This "freedom" supporter says that mandates will kill the economy among other things. He calls public health interventions "lunacy." He also believes such mandates will lead to "societal collapse."
This tweeter is anti-vaxx and claims that the vaccine is unsafe. Other tweets this individual made in the thread clarify this, because this tweet is a bit ambiguous.
This tweet is not criticizing or promoting anything. The tweeter simply says that her country has received so many boosters already, and asks if the island states have as well.

This anti-vaxx tweeter seems to be promoting conspiracy theories while she says "they admitted" that COVID-19 was here (a reference to government or doctors). She also says that natural immunity is great, because she got COVID-19 in the beginning phases and is fine today.
Tweeter is insinuating that there is a conspiracy to ID people digitally by enforcing public health measures and vaccinating the masses.
This tweet is by a news website about Pfizer seeking U.S. approval for COVID vaccines for children under 5.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines are apparently not effective, and pharmaceutical companies' tactics to make more money.
Tweeter is equating abortion rights to the rights of an individual to refuse a vaccine that would help prevent the transmission of coronavirus and keep the society safe.

In this tweet, Jay Sobel from the People's Party of Canada writes that he no longer trusts any level of government, the medical profession, or big pharma. It advocates for the PPC to be in power in Canada.
Tweeter is implying that getting infected with COVID provides better immunity than vaccines and that governments enforcing vaccine mandates are apparently dictators.
This is an anti-vaxx tweet. It shows how activists in Australia formed a trucker convoy to protest vaccine mandates in Canberra.

This tweet writes that the World Health Organization has called on the countries and companies that control the global supply of COVID19 vaccines to immediately begin sharing doses through the COVAX program, and to facilitate the sharing of technology, know-how, and IP.
This anti-vaxxer says that mandates have created a "shaming blackmail" culture towards people who chose not to get vaccinated. The tweeter implies that this is undemocratic in a country like Italy.

This tweet shares a video of Dr. Fauci being asked why the Indian COVID19 vaccine Covaxin, which has been proven to be effective and safe, is not being used globally. It celebrates the fact that Covaxin may soon go global.
This tweet writes that there is no way to prove that the COVID19 vaccines reduce symptoms or death and that saying so is merely comforting, not true.

This post criticizes anti-vaxxers in Ghana, writing that they have likely received three or four vaccines before adulthood but are now choosing not to use common sense and instead to believe that vaccines are bad and from the devil.

This post criticizes Novak Djokovic for not getting vaccinated. It writes that soon the athlete will be dropped by sponsors and perhaps fade away into early retirement because of his choice to remain unvaccinated.

This recruitment post by the National Primary Health Care Development Agency announces that individuals who are trained or licensed in giving vaccine injections are needed for COVID19 mass vaccination efforts in Nigeria.

This post writes that according to new research, COVID19 vaccines are forty times less effective against Omicron, yet the Israeli Prime Minister has proposed mandatory vaccination amid surging Omicron cases. It call politicians stupid and evil.

This post by journalist Holly Doan announces that federal employers in Canada are reviewing vaccine mandates and that more than a thousand workers who declined COVID19 shots have been suspended without pay.

Video link with a caption implying a professional football player was unfairly harassed for "asking questions" about athletes having strokes and heart attacks after getting the vaccine. Implication is that the vaccine is dangerous enough to regularly kill or incapacitate professional athletes and the media is covering it up.

Subject of the tweet is an Indian politician that stoked vaccine fears and politicized the issue by referring to it as the "BJP vaccine." People close to him are now refusing to get vaccinated because of his public resistance. Unlclear if the user thinks this is a good or bad thing.

Tweet is about a handful of European countries suspending the Moderna vaccine while research continues on heart issues. The actual tweet is not particularly misleading, but the user's dashboard is completely full of conspiracy theories about myocarditis, ivermectin, and climate change. No posting since March.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is critical of a claim made by conservatives that liberals made a mistake in vaccine communication. The twitter is calling another tweet out for promoting this political gaslighting.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is discussing their level of immunity, as a boosted vaccinated person, in light of the Omicron surge. She says she never got Omicron.

This anti-vaxxer claims that "breaktrhough" COVID-19 cases are the norm, which means a person contracts the virus two weeks after being vaccinated. This tweet intends to say that vaccines are ineffective. Breakthrough cases are not "the norm" so this tweet is misleading.

This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that forced vaccinations are happening in their country. They say that is criminal. It's not clear where this is supposed to be happening because the link is deactivated -- but it could be Australia -- and therefore the tweeter is misleading because no such thing happened there.
This pro-vaccine tweeter provides information on where kids ages 5-11 can go to get vaccinated.

This anti-vaxxer says the pandemic is not real. And that coercion wouldn't need to be used in terms of getting people vaccinated if it was. This tweet promotes conspiracy theories about the whole pandemic being a form of propaganda.

This anti-vaxxer says that the vaccine is not real because people weren't informed that boosters would be required after taking the first dose. This tweeter has lost trust in medicine due to the evolving nature of how the vaccine developed.
This anti-vaxxer is complaining that vaccination flip flops from being a choice, and then not being a choice.
This tweet links to a news article by the Guardian that examines the latest data to see which protects more against COVID19: vaccination or prior infection.
This post writes that the propaganda around vaccines and COVID19 has distracted them from keeping up with the hype around bitcoin and El Salvador.
This post by a UK charity helping teenaged cancer patients announces that anyone over the age of sixteen who is severely immunosuppressed can now book an appointment to have a COVID19 booster shot.

This tweeter writes that they began seeing the lies early on in the pandemic, when scientists first warned of the dangers of rushing vaccines, and then changed the narrative to vaccines being safe and effective.
This tweeter writes that they wish anti-vaxxers would just disappear instead of overwhelming hospitals and medical staff.

This tweeter shared a Newsmax TV clip, which is a right-wing channel that doesn't have a high standard of fact checking. The tweeter seems to be promoting anti-vaxx principals, by highlighting a quote about how some lawyer said it's a constitutional right to travel without a vaccine passport.
criticism_other: Mandating vaccines for flying on airplanes

meaning: This post calls for those in Victoria, Australia to wake up and realize that people are dying from the vaccine and the police is torturing people.
This post argues that vaccines weaken the immune system and keep the pandemic going for longer than it otherwise would. It claims that only the vulnerable should be vaccinated if they want to be.

This tweeter is an immunologist who is a Nobel Prize winner. He shares a chart with information about the risks of myocarditis resulting from vaccination versus from contracting the virus. The risks are revealed to be lower from the vaccine.

Judicial Watch, the tweeter of this post, is a right wing foundation that criticizes Biden. This post says that vaccine mandates were once not in the interest of the federal U.S. government. The tweeter said that because that changed, the issue will be brought up in court.
This post contains information about how many people India has vaccinated. This is inherently pro-vaccine. A link is provided to a web page with data to illustrate this.
This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines don't prevent against transmission, which he believes was proved after the mask mandates were lifted. He claims that mRNA shares are going to go down.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is making fun of anti-vaxxers and anti-maskers who say "trust the science." The tweeter refers to them as trolls under a bridge.
This is a news post from a Georgian paper about how civilians turned their backs on vaccination in that country. There is no personal opinion involved in the post.

This anti-vaxxer says that the vaccine causes problems with fertility, among other things. She also hints at conspiracy theories within this tweet, mentioning how gene engineering and human breeding are acceptable. It's not clear what this means.

This tweet is a bit confusing, but based on this tweeter's profile, this man supports vaccination. He doesn't seem to support mandates though, while he says that vaccination rates are falling despite having passports in place.

This post argues that it is stupid to oppose mandated vaccines like the Republicans are doing because in the past, vaccine mandates around chicken pox, measles, and polio have saved us from these illnesses.
This post criticizes the Food and Drug Administration, FDA, for claiming they need 55 years to make information about the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine available.
This post criticizes an athlete for not getting vaccinated, likely due to a religious exemption, but now has to adhere to health protocols with a third of his teammates.
This tweet criticizes those who are vaccinated, masked, and are afraid of coronavirus, claiming they are stupid.
This is a pro-vaccine joke that involves Ted Cruz. I don't fully understand it, however the intention is to mock Ted Cruz.
This tweet by a BBC Political Correspondent announces that more relaxed COVID19 restrictions will begin in hospitality, including new rules around vaccine passports and capacity limits.
This post announces that the vaccine mandate for private companies has been reinstated, and that this will have implications for some businesses.
This tweeter is upset about vaccine mandates. They share a personal story about how their partner is a nurse, and how she is leaving her job because she refuses the vaccine.
This tweet is pro-vaccine by nature because it shares intriguing information about containers that were converted into COVID-19 vaccine factories.
This pro-vaccine post celebrates a huge arrival of vaccines at NAIA airport.

This tweeter says that four out of five people that died of COVID-19 were vaccinated, which is not true. The tweeter uses a news post to support their anti-vaxx cause. It reports that vaccines may be created to cover all strains in the future, because they may otherwise not be effective towards certain strains. The tweeter sees this as a sign that vaccines are ineffective.
It's not clear what this tweet is promoting other than that it's anti-vaxx and regards something about vaccines not being safe. The text is incoherent at times.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says no to lockdowns and vaccine mandates. He also says no to an African politician, Ramaphosa, who likely supported such public health measures.
This tweeter says he is vaxxed, so he is pro-vaccine. And he is asking the public what his new handle should be, which is unrelated to vaccines.
This person complains about the fact that they have to get vaccinated in order to keep their job, even if they do not believe in the World Health Organization’s conspiracy.

This tweeter is annoyed at the fact that two anti-vaxxers filed a lawsuit for six million dollars each for alleged harm caused by Boston’s indoor vaccine mandates. It links to a news article that explains the couple had to travel outside of Boston for their weekly night out.
This post quotes a Military Doctor who claims that the increased incidences of miscarriages, cancer, and disease are due to COVID19 vaccinations.

This tweet is a reply to someone who criticized the allocation of scarce medical resources to people based on race. The tweeter says that vaccines were allocated to people based on race, yet it's not clear what the tweeter's stance is (the post is more informational).
criticism_other: Allocating scarce resources based on racial status

meaning: With a word game, this tweet claims that by google searching certain keywords, people can learn the truth about vaccines, which is that they cause illnesses and death.
This anti-vaxxer says he doesn't feel like he should have to prove that vaccines are not safe. He says that public health officials bear the burden of proving they are safe and effective.

This tweeter posted a link from a news outlet, The Scottish Daily Express, which is not excellent at fact-checking. The article says that vaccination is a data mining project, and therefore the tweeter uses this to breed vaccine mistrust.
This tweeter promotes Biden's vaccine mandates by saying they are not out of line with previous supreme court rulings on the matter.

This tweet is not really clear, because there is little information. But the tweeter is anti-vaxx because they declare themselves as a freedom fighter in their profile. Their username is also "wake up we're being taken for a ride."

This anti-vaxx tweeter tries to twist a quote from the Financial Times about vaccines, which was that vaccine "protection begins to wane three months after vaccination," to suit her cause. She says that a vaccinated person has the same immunity as an unvaccinated person 12 weeks after receiving the jab.

This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that the vaccine killed Clint Arlis. Entertainment Tonight reported on his death and this anti-vaxxer believes it's from the vaccine even though there is no evidence of that.

This anti-vaxxer claims that an FDA whistleblower said the U.S. government is rounding up unvaccinated people to put them in camps, like Germany did. This promotes conspiracy theories. She also says a nurse died of vaccine side effects, and provided a questionable link within the tweet to verify this.

This post announces that Romania no longer requires travellers to show proof of vaccination or a negative test to enter the country. It comments that countries are falling like dominoes now in terms of lifting travel restrictions.

This tweet is a reply to someone who criticized the allocation of scarce medical resources to people based on race. The tweeter says that vaccines were allocated to people based on race, yet it's not clear what the tweeter's stance is (the post is more informational).
criticism_other: Allocating scarce resources based on racial status

meaning: This tweeter announced that they are triple vaxxed, and with an exciting and happy GIF. This indicates a pro-vaccine stance.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is upset that Australia was pushing boosters rather than promoting vaccine equity (sharing vaccines with other nations). She refers to ATAGI for support of her comment. ATAGI did state that "a relatively small cohort of individuals, such as those with severely immunocompromising conditions, are likely to require a third dose as part of their primary course of vaccination to ensure optimal vaccine effectiveness,’ the statement reads."

This post claims that the World Health Organization purposefully changed their published definition of herd immunity in order to please the government and pharmaceutical companies, and force more people to be vaccinated.

This post shares a quote from the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, which says that 25 percent of blood cancer patients do not produce detectable antibodies after their second vaccine. The post wants people to stay informed and safe.
This tweeter is celebrating the use of Covaxin and Covishield vaccines in India.
This triple-vaxxed tweeter says that COVID-19 is not just a mild cold.
This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that most New Yorkers are skeptical of the vaccine. She also says that the COVID-19 vaccine is not a vaccine and that it's proven not to work.

This anti-vaxxer is promoting an article about how 40% of vaccine appointments are no shows. The link she posts is made by LBC, which seems like a reputable British station, yet her intention in posting this is to spread hesitation towards vaccines.

This tweeter replied to a pro-vaccine post. They are angry that pro-vaccine people don't acknowledge the fear anti-vaxxers have for taking what they call an "untested" vaccine. This word "untested" is misleading, because the vaccine was approved after going through trials.
This tweeter celebrates a pro-vaccine military officer in Portugal who encouraged the population to get vaccinated.
This tweet is in reference to anti-vaxxer Novak Djokovic. This tweet is misleading because it states that Djokovic is in good health and therefore doesn't need the vaccine. That isn't true.
This pro-science tweeter shares a link about the rest-of-the-year COVID forecast.

This tweeter claims that it's not fair that congress was not mandated to take the vaccine. This is misleading because "Biden can't mandate vaccinations for Congress; order covers executive branch only," reported USA Today.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that there's a difference between anti-maskers and pro-maskers: People who don't want to keep their community safe, and others who do.
This anti-vaxxer claims that COVID-19 itself is less severe and contains less risks than the vaccine.

This post is inherently freedom of choice because it calls out the necessity of masking by noting that there's a high level of vaccination rates. This means the tweeter is questioning the effectiveness of vaccines.
This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccines are dangerous and the the government is corrupt for pushing the jab. He also believes citizens have lost trust in public health. All of these claims are false.

This tweeter makes a joke about vaccine mandates by posting a video of a scared cartoon character jumping off a bridge. The tweeter likens that character to governments who "double down" on vaccine mandates. This is inherently anti-vaxx.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine. He takes a jab at Canada's 2021 federal election but also praises it for instating vaccine mandates, which he says will end the pandemic.
Tweeter is implying that a vaccine mandate for domestic travellers in the U.S. would have prevented flight cancellations by Alaska Airline due to a shortage of staff on sick leave because of COVID.

Tweeter quoted a statement by an Australian union against vaccine mandate in response to another user who called on the country's Prime Minister to take action against anti-vaxxers after they attacked the union office.
Vocal vaccine critic Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is implying that vaccines are not safe by tweeting a letter written by an ICU physician on vaccine injuries she empirically observed.
This tweeter says that Canada shouldn't have mandatory vaccines and that the passport should be ended. He's angry that health care workers who are unvaccinated will be laid off.
criticism_other: Unvaccinated health care workers who get fired

meaning: This tweeter is upset about nurses getting fired for not being vaccinated. They also say they support "natural immunity" and that the vaccine does not prevent infection. He also says vaccination is a form of politics, which is misleading.
criticism_other: Firing health workers who won't get vaccinated

meaning: This tweeter is pro-vaccine and reminds readers that the pandemic is far from over. He shares a graph that illustrates an uptick in BA.2 infections. He recommends people use N95s and have good air filtration systems, and etc.
This tweeter says that the vaccines are not effective in terms of preventing transmission. This tweet is situated within a thread about Djokovic.

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines are an experiment. They pose a question about how many boosters are required, to highlight that COVID-19 vaccines are an experiment, because the answer to that question is unknown.
This tweeter shares a link to Big Broth Watch, a UK-based civil liberties group, which is quoted to report that vaccine passports are "illiberal." They also say that vaccine passports are dangerous.
Tweeter is implying that healthy people do not need vaccination against any disease.
Tweeter implied that people are dying from COVID because of the lies Donald Trump is telling his followers about vaccine safety.

Tweeter propagated the conspiracy theory that Bill Gates is profiting from the pandemic by selling vaccines, that the FDA deemed harmful. So Bill Gates and politicians, promoting the vaccines, will apparently be tried for killing people.
Tweeter is mocking vaccine mandates by insinuating that vaccinations did not protect him or her from getting COVID so it is apparently ridiculous to punish anti-vaxxers.

Tweeter, a YouTube based Canadian media website, is urging people not to vote Doug Ford because he apparently failed to prevent COVID transmission through vaccination, which tweeter seems to imply, is not an effective strategy.

This anti-vaxxer reports news that people without boosters in Israel and Bahrain risk loosing their vaccine passports without getting vaccinated. He's disapproving of that and uses this news to support his "freedom" fighting mandate, which is revealed on his profile.
This anti-vaxxer is upset that kids will be vaccinated and that passports may be required for them. He says "this is an avenue we've gone down," to express concern.
This is an informational post about how vaccine boosters are being prescribed to some immunocompromized people in New Zealand. This is inherently pro-vaccine.
This is an informational post from a venue that says proof of vaccination is required to enter. The post also requests that attendees wear masks.
Tweeter implied that Nigeria did not properly test or inoculate its citizens with COVID test or vaccines the U.K. shared, so the latter banned flights from the African nation during the Omicron wave.

Tweeter is supporting anti-vaccine sentiment by sharing a video of a Kuwaiti man who can be seen protesting the vaccine mandate and criticizing doctors for recommending vaccines over natural immunity.
Tweeter suggested another user write that anti-vaxxers do not qualify for the vaccine because they do not understand the value of life extension it provides, just like organ transplants.
Tweeter is sharing a petition to Spotify to cancel Joe Rogan's podcast, which spreads COVID misinformation.
This tweet is by Reuters about FDA approving COVID vaccine booster shots and vaccine mix and match.
Tweeter is contesting a data quoted by another user that 70 per cent of Australians have been vaccinated by saying that the number should be 50 per cent.
Tweeter is suggesting that vaccine mandates for going into public places are unnecessary as many places require patrons to test negative before attending an event.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says she's happy she got her booster shot because Delta slammed the population.
This pro-vaccine tweeter replied with shock to an AP news article. It's about an unvaccinated woman who was denied a kidney transplant because she doesn't have a vaccine passport.

This tweeter claims that republicans are not promoting anti-vaxx mentalities. But this is misleading. Ted Cruz and Marjorie Taylor Greene are among various republicans who promote anti-vaxx sentiments. I flagged this post as pro-vaccine because the tweeter seems to support vaccines.
This pro-vaccine tweeter replied to an anti-vaxxer who is spouting disinformation about the jab. This tweeter says she is trained and also critical of the government, yet supports science.

This tweeter declares that the COVID Vaccine Is a Death Plot. They also say that Jewish people are the enemies of jesus, and that the war between Russia and Ukraine will undo America and Russia. The video depicts a preacher who says he doesn't support vaccination.
This tweeter says that people should worry about COVID-19 affecting their kids in a bad way, rather than worry about the vaccine.

This anti-vaxxer posted a link to a 28-year-old's story in a non-reputable tabloid news source. The story is likely not true, and it's about how she received various health issues from the Pfizer vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is criticizing some conservative politicians for promoting anti-vaxx sentiments. She also mentions something about those conservatives promoting racism.
Tweeter is debunking the myth about mRNA vaccines being released too early, as claimed by a doctor who came to the Joe Rogan show on Spotify.
Tweeter is suggesting that the antibody in the COVID vaccine is showing up in the home kit as positive when a child took the test a week after getting vaccinated.
Tweeter implied that the vaccine is not effective in preventing COVID-19 infection.
Tweeter is insinuating that vaccines are created by Jewish people,  COVID-19 is actually flu and vaccines do not work.
Tweeter quoted a tweet by the White House COVID 19 data director about the number of vaccine shots administered in the U.S.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says she attended a conference about vaccine manufacturing in Nigeria. She celebrates vaccine equity in this tweet.

This tweet is pro-vaccine on one side and anti-vaxx on the other. The tweeter agrees that vaccination of adults is the right thing to do. But she doesn't want her infant vaxxed for at least five years. So this post is flagged as "unsure about the vaccine."
This pro-vaccine tweeter promotes the vaccination in children by listing off the infection rates associated with being vaxxed.

Candace Owens is a far-right political commentator. She is anti-vaxx and says we're living in scary times because the government is mandating a vaccine that is not effective in preventing transmission of the virus. She doesn't acknowledge that the vaccine reduces the risk of death.
This tweeter is a democratic party member. He criticizes Ron DeSantis and Ashley Moody for lifting vaccine passports on cruises, among other things.

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccine mandates shouldn't happen. They provided a link to what would happen if the mandates continue, but it's no longer active. This link is titled "nomoresilence.world" which seems to refer to the "muzzling of scientists" that anti-vaxxers fall back on to support their arguments that doctors aren't being listened to.
Tweeter is propagating the conspiracy theory that many athletes are dying from myocarditis after getting vaccinated by sharing a video from an unverified source.
Tweeter quoted CDC's VAERS report without providing a link to the data and claimed that several children apparently died or became disabled after getting the COVID vaccine.
Tweeter, a local U.S. politician, is sharing a news report about the vaccine mandate, promoting vaccines.
This anti-vaxxer says that the courts should be expanded to accommodate people who fight against COVID-19 mandates.

This is an informational post from a political party member in India. He says that drones are now being used for a COVID-19 vaccination supply. No personal opinion is included in this post, so I flagged it as "unsure."
This anti-vaxxer makes a snide comment about an immigrant "hostage taker" who crossed into the U.S. border. This seems to be an anti-immigration tweet in addition to an anti-vaxx tweet.
This pro-vaccine tweeter asks if there is vaccine equity in South Africa. This is inherently a pro-vaccine post.

This tweet appears to be pro-vaccine, but it's not. The tweeter implies they only got vaxxed in order to travel. They say that they need to travel before the vaccine looses effectiveness, meaning they don't believe that the jab is effective.

This person writes that although they believe vaccines might be a permanent solution, vaccines currently only protect the recipients and do not stop infection or transmission. They argue that mass vaccination is not important.
Tweeter says the Pope advised people to get vaccinated and Jesus said to protect others at all costs, this leads them to say this man is not a Christian.
This post criticizes an anti-vaccine account and argues that the vaccine is not the problem, the fact that people didn’t follow the mask mandates is the problem.

This tweet seems to disapprove of vaccine mandates. The tweeter asks about Trinidadian and Tobagonian politician, Rowley's, mandates and shows a gif that reveals an office man freaking out along with the tweet.

This tweeter is asking a question about vaccines. It's a follow up to his previous post that claims the French government recommends the Pfizer, not Moderna, vaccines for people under 30 due to a slight risk of myocarditis. This tweet asks if that is due to the dose of the respective vaccines.

This tweet isn't promoting or criticizing anything. It discusses a woman who has flu like symptoms. The tweeter says she likely doesn't have COVID-19 because she's been careful about public health measures. But this is misleading because of course if someone contracts a flue or cold, they could also contract COVID.
This anti-vaxxer says that most young nurses don't want to be vaxxed, which is misleading. He says that its unfortunate that there will be a lack of nurses to serve patients due to mandates.
This post criticizes another user, calling for them to provide evidence to back up the claim that four people have died from getting vaccinated against COVID19.
Tweeter shared an NYT article on the number of children who received the COVID vaccine to reassure people that the vaccine authorized for 5 to 11-year-olds in California should be safe.
This is an informational post from the Government of Yukon. It provides a link to daily COVID-19 case counts and says that the government will no longer post that information on social media.
This anti-vaxxer believes that most vaccinated people will soon die, whether it's from COVID-19, vaccine reactions or natural causes.

This tweeter mentions Dr. Peter Marks, the director of the Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research (CBER) at the FDA. The tweeter says he's the leader of "Operation Warp Speed." It's not clear what tone this tweet is using because the original thread and link included in the post is missing. So I flagged this an unsure about the vaccine.
criticism_other: Moving too quickly with vaccine development

meaning: On her profile, this pro-vaccine tweeter lists herself as an advocate for COVID-19 safety measures. This tweet says that vaccines are great, but that without masking and social distancing, immunocompromized people are still at risk of contracting COVID-19.
support_other: Stricter social distancing mandates especially within schools

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that there's a news article that reported that Pfizer's vaccine isn't effective in stopping Omicron infections. But, no link is provided to support this. This anti-vaxxer is making information up to spread vaccine hesitancy.
This post from an account in the USA writes that getting vaccinated against COVID19 is patriotic.

This post writes that vaccine mandates are madness, that they need to end as soon as possible, and that Italy is not enforcing the vaccine requirement for tourists, so the unvaccinated should travel there.
This post shares a news piece from the guardian about vaccine mandates in Australia and Austria, implying that they are harsh and oppressive.
This post encourages people to get vaccinated and boosted as soon as possible as this is the best weapon we have to fight the COVID19 pandemic.
This tweeter says it's not fair that unvaccinated people don't receive medical help. He says that masking can be something to mitigate the risk when an unvaccinated patient is treated.
criticism_other: Withdrawing medical care based on vaxx status

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweet promotes more tracking, vaccines, tests and treatments for COVID-19 globally.

This tweeter says that doctors and scientists should focus on finding a cure for a certain blindness, rather than on finding a vaccine for COVID-19. It's not clear if this is anti-vaxx or pro-vaxx, so I flagged this post as "unsure."
support_other: Focusing on the cure for blindness, not COVID-19 vaccines

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that booster shots will have to be bought by the public in the future. He implies that the free vaccines we've already been given were an experiment leading up to a profit-making scheme lead by the government and/or Big Pharma.

This tweet calls out Sajid Javid, Secretary of State for Health and Social Care in the UK, for claiming that the user’s previous tweet about getting a Moderna booster shot instead of Pfizer, was disrespectful to the NHS.

This tweet calls out anti-vaccine advocates including Veronica Wolski and the televangelist Marcus Lamb, writing that both promoted Ivermectin and other remedies for fighting COVID19, and both died from the illness.

This post criticizes the UK government decision to continue providing free COVID19 tests to anyone, rather then direct them to the vulnerable, while also promoting the end of mass vaccination and a new plan to simply live with COVID19.
support_other: Access to COVID19 testing by vulnerable populations

meaning: Tweeter states that the Democratic party should push to have masks and vaccines as a matter of personal responsibility.
Tweeter is responding to someone who is selling soccer tickets saying they are vaccinated and would like to go.
This post celebrates Serbian athlete Novak Djokovic for organizing vaccinations for fellow athletes when vaccines were not available.
This post argues that we should only have vaccinated the most vulnerable populations. It says that herd immunity cannot be achieved because too many people are vaccinated.
Tweeter is comparing statements from Biden and Fauci about vaccine effectiveness. They are questioning which politician is spreading misinformation.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is criticizing the democrats and Biden for not contributing enough vaccines this year.

This post writes that the argument that we accepted getting vaccinated in the past so we shouldn’t start questioning it now, is silly. We have never given employers, stores, and other public places personal health information before, they argue.
This retweet of a post by a sceptical nurse quotes a doctor who had said in a Radio 4 interview that vaccines should not be mandated.
This tweet criticizes the $100 COVID-19 Vaccine Incentive Program in Alberta, Canada for being ineffective and difficult to track its progress.
Tweeter is sharing a location in San Diego where people can get vaccinated.
Tweeter is comparing statements from Biden and Fauci about vaccine effectiveness. They are questioning which politician is spreading misinformation.

This tweeter is suggesting that some even go on in the "hood" where vaccine mandates aren't being enforced. It's not clear what her opinion on vaccines is, because she works for Warner Media, which is a journalism house that supports democratic values. So this tweet could just be a joke.
This anti-vaxxer is supporting Fox News indirectly by saying the network didn't "push" vaccines. This tweet is in reply to another tweeter who says Fox pushed the vaccine.

This tweeter is upset with Lithuania for cancelling shipments of vaccines to Bangladesh, due to their support of Russia in the Ukraine conflict. This is a pro-Russian tweet, and Russia has fuelled the anti-vaxx movement with propaganda -- but this tweeter appears to be pro-vaccine.
This tweeter says that Jesus was sensible and that a woman with the last name Court is not. Court is anti-vaccine and says the blood of Jesus saves, so this post is pro-vaccine.

This tweeter suggests that consistent messaging about voluntary vaccination would motivate people to get vaccinated more than mandates do. This tweet is therefore flagged as "unsure" about the vaccine, because it's not clear if the tweeter is vaccinated himself.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx, based on other tweets they made in this thread. This tweet is not misleading, because it says that the vaccine doesn't offer 100% immunity. Yet given the context of this tweet, situated within the thread, the tweeter is anti-vaxx.

This anti-vaxxer criticizes the COVID-19 vaccine by saying that it doesn't stop transmission. This tweet is misleading because the vaccine does reduce severe illness, and is therefore not ineffective.

This anti-vaxxer says that reported stats about COVID-19 related deaths are all manipulated, which is misleading. He links those "manipulated" numbers to instilling vaccine passports, so he hints at corruption within the government.
This tweeter celebrates a vaccine mandate protest in Montreal. He says it's an inspiration for Toronto. Therefore, this tweeter is anti-vaxx.
This tweeter says that sane doctors recommend vaccines, implying that only insane doctors wouldn't.

This tweeter makes a comment about right-wing press. He calls it "rabid," while saying it's been shredding the city apart for years. He says conservative media has a role to play in the differing vaccine mandates between Sydney and Melbourne.
The post by a government of India account announces a COVID19 vaccination drive being organized for 15- to 18-year-olds, encouraging them to get vaccinated soon.

This tweet says that pastors who give misinformation about COVID19 and discourage people from getting vaccinated should be held legally accountable. It writes that there is allegedly a pastor in Kentucky who claims one out of 100 people die from getting vaccinated.
support_other: Holding those who share misinformation accountable

meaning: This tweet by the US Department of State announces a partnership between the USA and COVAX to donate more than 3 million COVID19 doses to Sub-Saharan Africa.
This post criticizes vaccine passports and the fact that people are being arrested for protesting against vaccine passports or using fake ones.

This post makes fun of the vaccinated, writing that while the unvaccinated are not afraid of COVID19, the vaccinated are. It questions why the vaccinated don’t have faith in the vaccine they promote so highly.
This post celebrates doctors, nurses, and consultants for promoting COVID19 vaccines even despite the poor treatment they have been receiving from the government and the media.

This tweeter tells people to get the vaccine. She also says that people should vaccinate their kids as soon as it's available. And she says that the anti-vaxx "side" of the argument is wrong, and that therefore there's only one side of that vaccine debate.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is happy that a theatre is still asking for proof of vaccination.
This tweeter says that sane doctors recommend vaccines, implying that only insane doctors wouldn't.
This anti-vaxx tweeter shares an article about Tennis Pro Pat Cash. Cash relays a story about his mom, who he claims had an onslaught of adverse health affects resulting from the vaccine.

This tweeter is making fun of a couple who got married and kissed with their masks on. The tweeter is critical of the government, who wanted to slow the spread in 2020, given that two years later we still have vaccine passports and boosters going.
This post claims that those vaccinated against COVID19 are dying of vaccine injuries and that this is often recorded as unvaccinated or died of COVID19.

This post writes that COVID19 is real and detrimental to some, but that lockdowns and masks don’t work, and that vaccination should be a choice not a mandate. It argues that opinions about the pandemic are not binary but fall on a spectrum.
This post writes that on September 17, 25 million doses of the COVID19 vaccine were administered in India, 80% of the total vaccines given on that day worldwide.

This post writes that willful blindness is going on when it comes to evaluating the risk of COVID19 transmission in schools. If people acknowledged the risks, they write, it means also acknowledging that delaying the child vaccine was the wrong decision.

This post criticizes the TwitchCon account for posting ambiguous language about safety measures at an upcoming Twitch convention. It writes that vaccines and masking remain the best safety measures and that this should be clearly communicated to attendees.
This post writes that new COVID19 variants come from those who are vaccinated. It directly blames the vaccinated for new variants appearing.
This anti-vaxxer calls vaccination a "medical experimentation." He says he won't submit to it. And he mentions the Nuremberg Code in the tweet, which hints at vaccination being like the Nazi regime.

This tweet shares a bogus news article titled: "Massive Study of 145 Countries Finds Huge Increase in Death Following Vaccinations." And then the tweet claims that mortality is higher among vaccinated people, which is not true.
This tweet relays information about the number of people getting vaccinated in India.

This tweeter complains about the "inconsistent rules" around public health regulations. He also says he's not worried about dying from COVID-19 while he clearly undermines its severity. He also considers the vaccine ineffective because it doesn't stop a person from getting COVID-19.

This post shares a news piece from expose-news.com, a known website for misinformation. It claims that a scientific study conducted by FDA and CDC scientists has found that the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine significantly increases the risk of myocarditis.
This post criticizes another user, claiming they are suffering from the side effects of the so-called Pfizer brain vaccine.
This post argues that the vaccine does not stop transmission and that refusing to pay the unvaccinated for sick days if they get COVID19 is unscientific and discriminatory.
This tweeter announces that a vaccination centre in Inverness, Scotland is holding a drop-in clinic with no queues, and that folks in the area should go get vaccinated.
This post criticizes Donald Trump for having had three COVID19 vaccinations, claiming it makes him a liberal in bad clothes.
This sarcastic post questions science and scientists, claiming they have not been handling the pandemic or vaccinations well.
This post argues that many who self-identify as skeptics have always been susceptible to conspiracy theories including those about autism and vaccines.
This tweet promotes masking during the COVID19 pandemic, writing that it has been effective in reducing deaths in some Asian countries where vaccinations were delayed.

This anti-vaxx tweeter supports the trucker convoy. The tweeter mentions that the convoy protested mandates, the emergency measures act, Trudeau and he mentions that CBC was part of the problem. He asks "what aren't they protesting?" meaning that he feels the government is over reaching on all aspects of the pandemic.
criticism_other: Trudeau, emergencies measures act, freezing bank accounts, CBC

meaning: This is an informational post that was confirmed in a local news source. It reports that criminals in the Baton Rouge area can have their criminal records removed if they get jabbed.
This racist tweet condemns mandatory vaccination for American citizens, especially while the government is allowing illegal and unvaccinated immigrants into the country.
This tweeter posted a link to a bogus anti-vaxx PDF. That PDF's purpose states that it reveals "the real risk of an unprecedented genocide." It's designed to terrify people about getting vaccinated.

This tweeter was made by a group of investigative journalists. It says that misleading data can lead to misleading reports about vaccine efficacy. This is a pro-vaccine post, trying to debunk claims that vaccines are not working.
This tweet claims that the unvaccinated have not become ill in 2020 or 2021, and that vaccines are experimental, toxic, ruin the immune system, and cause dangerous adverse effects.
This anti-vaxxer says that the government is authoritarian for requiring boosters to keep a vaccine passport active.
criticism_other: Requiring boosters for a vaccine passport

meaning: This post celebrates the high number of vaccinations administered in India on September 17, the Indian Prime Minister’s birthday. Let every day be Narendra Modi’s birthday so that mass vaccination may continue, it writes.

This post writes that the first case of the omicron variant has been reported in Nigeria. It encourages people to stay safe and get vaccinated as soon as possible because the vaccine increases survival rates.
This post writes that the Nevada Wolf Pack Football team should avoid travelling to states where vaccination is not taken seriously, such as South Dakota, in order to stay safe.

This post by journalist Philip O’Connor says that Olympic athlete Sebbe Samuelsson is not skeptical or anti-vaxx, and calling him this is idiotic. Sebbe has had two shots of the COVID19 vaccine and has simply chosen to wait until after the Olympic games to get the booster to avoid side effects while training.
This post shares a conspiracy theory that there are two types of vaccines, one for the powerful elites and one for regular people.
This post claims that the vaccinated will die or become very ill from the vaccine because of harmful ingredients including antigen.

This post shares a graph from Our World in Data and writes that in several countries, the data shows that you are mostly likely to die from COVID19 if you are unvaccinated, and least likely to die if you are boosted. It encourages people to get vaccinated as soon as possible.
This pro-vaccine tweeter tells a group of anti-vaxxers within this Twitter thread, that they are wilfully ignorant. She says that if the vaccine actually caused death, there would be data on that.

This anti-vaxxer opposes vaccine passports. She says though, that they can be good because kids can avoid quarantine after travel if travelling with vaccinated parents. She makes a statement that seems misleading: That kids have to quarantine completely alone under the federal system. I was not able to find any links from the Canadian Government to verify that.
This tweeter says that "natural immunity" is 13 times better than the vaccine. This is false and dangerous.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is promoting more extreme public health measures in the Sydney LGA. She says that cases are on the rise and that mandatory masking, curfews and limitations on outdoor events need to be instated.
criticism_other: Laxx restrictions in the Sydney LGA

meaning: This post argues that vaccine mandates for cross-border truckers are stupid because vaccines don’t prevent infection. Protests against these mandates are equivalent to protesting stupidity, it writes.
This post criticizes a pro-vaccine tweet, arguing that the vaccinated do not even understand the science of how vaccines work and that natural immunity is more effective than getting vaccinated.

This post criticizes tennis player Novak Djokovic for attempting to get an exemption from the COVID19 vaccine requirement. It celebrates that he failed to provide evidence for the exemption and is now unable to play in the Australian Open.
This post claims that the reasons for getting the COVID19 vaccine do not make sense. Getting vaccinated does not protect others for example, it argues.

This post criticizes vaccine mandates and people in Germany, writing that Ukrainian refugees had to spend the night in a train station in Stuttgart because hotels would not let them enter without proof of vaccination.
This post claims that the data shows a spike in COVID19 cases and deaths immediately after vaccination in Alberta and across different countries. No actual data is provided.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that more vaccinated people have died than unvaccinated people, which is misleading. They posted an image to support this statement, which was debunked by a Reuters fact-checking team. Reuters reported that: This graph "has misrepresented UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) data on deaths by COVID-19 vaccination status and overlooks context about high vaccine coverage."
This post by CBC News includes a link to a news piece about the unprecedented disagreements among doctors on how to triage those who refused the COVID19 vaccine.

This tweet regards a mythical figure. It's not clear if this is promoting pro-vaccine sentiments, so I flagged this as "unsure" about the vaccine. The tweeter is responding to a drawing of a super hero named Vax.
This post criticizes those who choose to stop masking because they are vaccinated and boosted against COVID19, writing that vaccination does not stop transmission.

This post by a New York City Police Officer criticizes New York because someone could steal a car at gunpoint without punishment but a victim must show a vaccine passport and be masked to seek safety inside of a business.
This post criticizes the pharmaceutical company Pfizer for benefiting financially from making and selling COVID19 vaccines to the world.

This post by journalist Tracy Sherlock writes that new vaccines and treatments for COVID19 are coming, including Novavax, a protein sub-unit vaccine that could be effective for those who have had side effects to mRNA vaccines.
This tweet shares a YouTube video that claims sudden hearing loss has been reported as a COVID19 vaccine side effect.

This post criticizes Republican leaders in the USA for convincing their supporters to not get vaccinated, and Republicans more broadly for causing suffering and death while blaming Biden for his efforts to mitigate this through vaccine mandates.

This anti-vaxx tweeter likens vaccine mandates to tyranny. He is angry at Doug Ford for listening to the Chief Health Officer, who was caught on a hot mic saying she just reads to the public what she's told to read. This tweeter is also upset that vaccines are required for boarding flights, even though transmission is still possible amongst fully vaxxed people.
This anti-vaxxer says he wants politicians to be arrested and charged for pushing "unsafe" vaccines.
This anti-vaxxer says people should ignore vaccine mandates because he can't get a beer, due to all the closed restaurants around his town.

This post claims that liberals criticized Trump for causing vaccine deaths because he left decision making to the states, but now that Biden has given states some decision making power, the liberals and the media are quiet.

This post by a Canadian doctor criticizes Justin Trudeau for fostering a Canada where peaceful protests against government policies are labeled white supremacists, where doctors who advocate for informed consent are labeled anti-vaccine, and where scientific evidence against government policies is labeled misinformation.
In response to a tweet by President Joe Biden about a new Cancer Cabinet in the USA, this post asks whether mRNA vaccines will be stopped since they accelerate cancers.
This post claims that the coronavirus was introduced intentionally, followed by a fake and mandatory vaccine, all in order to divide the country.
This post, which includes a link to a news piece by the AFP News Agency, writes that according to the World Health Organization, omicron spreads faster and weakens vaccine effectiveness.

This post writes that natural immunity after being infected with COVID19 is stronger than immunity from the vaccine and therefore that those with natural immunity, whether vaccinated or not, should be able to enter restaurants.

This post shares a news piece about a physician who developed tinnitus after getting the COVID19 vaccine and now calls for further research into this side effect. It shares a quote from the article about folks emailing to say they plan to take their own life because of how much tinnitus has affected them.

This post is in reply to a thread where vaccines and GMOs are being blamed for allergies. It says that allergies were documented by the ancient Greeks and that they are not caused by vaccines or GMOs.

This anti-vaxxer believes that vaccines can bring much more harm to people than the lack of hand washing amongst staff at a restaurant could. He replied to another pro-vaccine tweeter who made an analogy about hand washing and vaccines, as preventative measures.
criticism_other: Analogies about hand washing in relation to vaccine mandates

meaning: This tweeter says that unequal access to vaccines in South Asia is making children vulnerable. The tweeter says mental health is worsening because of it too, and that child marriage is on the rise.

This is an informational post, that quotes some lines from the Rolling Stone about how the NBA is dealing with anti-vaxx players such as Kyrie Irving, and others who support him. No personal opinion is included in this tweet.

This post promotes a conspiracy theory, claiming that current public opinion in Canada says that pushing for mandatory vaccination or vaccine passports is grounds for jail time given the latest data that was previously hidden.
This post announces the new number of COVID19 cases in Ontario and writes that a breakdown of the numbers by vaccination status will be available soon.

This tweeter is replying to a thread about data that claims to state death rates based on Vaccination status. This tweeter asks if the "unvaccinated" status includes the two week period after the jab. She says that if it does, data is skewed in favour of the vaccine - meaning she says that vaccinations could lead to death but not be accounted for in the data.

This anti-vaxxer basically says that anyone who supports mask or vaccine mandates is clueless, or has lost their mind. They also say that people who support vaccine passports are not following the science.
Tigray is a region of Ethiopia. This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccines and medical supplies are lacking in the region. She says that degrades the level of health care.

It's not clear if this tweet is pro- or ant-vaxx. But it's clear that he is promoting testing of people who enter the UK from flights. He says that vaccines don't prevent transmission and therefore testing is required to stop the spread.

This tweet comes across as tricky and manipulative. It's a reply to a pro-vaccine person who criticizes Joseph A. Ladapo, who was appointed by seemingly anti-vaxx political figure, DeSantis. This tweeter rejects the criticism made by the pro-vaccine person. It's a bit too tricky to fully unpack, but it is anti-vaxx.
This tweet promotes vaccine equity, while the tweeter posts an article she wrote about how vaccine hoarding is contributing to new variants.
This is a news post asking whether a fourth booster of COVID-19 is necessary. No personal opinion is included. The tweet links to a "news" site that doesn't look credible.

This scientist says he worked on a study that measures the benefits versus the risks of vaccinating youth. His tweet includes a link to the study. The tweeter also says that the benefits of vaccinating youth ages 12-17 with two doses outweighs the risks of not getting jabbed.
Tweeter posted a quote, by an unknown source, saying if the vaccine doesn't get recommended for children, people can sue the company as it doesn't have liability protection.

This tweeter celebrates a "sign" that he saw being used overseas. The message of that sign communicates that people will not be discriminated against, based on their vaxx status, at the establishment where the sign hangs.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is upset at Twitter for allowing an anti-vaxxer to promote medical disinformation on her wall.

This tweeter called out Hawk Newsome, an American law school graduate and co-founder of Black Lives Matter in New York, for spreading vaccine skepticism. The tweeter also says Newsome has created a gateway for conspiracy theories, by way of using his public status to influence people.
This anti-vaxx tweeter is angry that CARFAX requires a vaccine passport from employees. They ask if that is legal.

This tweet from Fox news reports on a public figure who posted anti-mask type sentiments on Google, then google censored it. It also contains a headline about "propaganda" in the form of a pro-vaccine song, that plays on Google. This post promotes freedom of speech, without limits. And it's inherently anti-vaxx.
support_other: Free Speech even in the name of disinformation

meaning: This tweeter is not anti-vaxx persey, because they say that they got the vaccine. But they are complaining about nurses being fired for being unvaccinated - therefore I flagged this post as unsure about the vaccine.  This tweeter claims that she wasn't told by her vaccine giving nurse that she's less likely to transmit the virus after vaccination.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the vaccine is spreading COVID-19 to people. He says people shouldn't vaccinate babies and toddlers.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that vaccines are fake, and that the pandemic is a "plandemic," which is the title of a conspiracy theory based film.
Tweeter says they had COVID-19 and after recovering, we're unable to get vaccinated for six months. They go on to say it's not working anyways as infection rates are extremely high.

This tweeter says that VAERS is not a great resource, or indicator on vaccine risks, because anyone can post vaccine side affects on there. The tweeter posted a screenshot of a VAERS report, where a person listed ludicrous side effects such as turning green and turning into an alien as an example of why to not trust VAERS.
This pro-vaccine tweeter lists various reasons as to why she is a Liberal voter. Among those are vaccine mandates and the COVID-19 response.
support_other: Tough on Guns, Climate Change plan, LGBTQ rights

meaning: This post doesn't promote or criticize anything. It was made by a boy who lists himself as a journalist on his profile. It simply states news that an anti-vaxx protest happened in Toronto in early Feb. 2022.
This is a tweet by a physician-scientist tweeting about the nature of the Omicron variant.

This tweeter is not making a comment on vaccination, rather a comment on the certain questions that may come up when a racialized person gets vaccinated, or has to fulfill paperwork that requires vaccination.

This pro-vaccine tweeter tells people to stop protesting at anti-lockdown sites. The tweeter says the COVID-19 cases in those cities are going down, and that the protesters need to back off to give those flattening curves a chance.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine. He posted a question that someone asked him, whether he'd get fined for hosting an event that requires a vaccine passport to attend. And the tweeter explained why he won't be fined and that he supports a safe event.

This tweeter says that vaccine passports are an extension of the Patriot Act, which allowed powers to deter terrorist acts. This implies that vaccine passports are authoritarian, or play into the government's surveillance abilities.
Tweeter wants scientists to look at what the vaccine is doing to people's brains because they were seeing comments from people who are vaccinated and how they are still scared of COVID.
This tweeter shares information about the Pope. She says that he promoted vaccination to promote the caring of each other.
Tweeter states that the FDNY closed 26 stations because of a lack of staff. they allude that the reason is because of vaccine mandates.
Tweeter shares a bunch of stats from the Utah Department of Health about COVID-19 showing the number of infections, vaccinations and hospitalizations.

This tweet does not contain any personal opinion about vaccination, rather it reports that vaccine mandates could be brought into the vehicle-for-hire industry. A link to the Toronto Sun was provided to support this information.
Tweeter quoted a HR management firm's explanation of what the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration is going to do about vaccine mandate and other COVID safety measures in the future.

This tweeter says that vaccine mandates are not legal. He says those mandates belong to BIDEN and that "lamestream" media is pushing his narrative that they're legal, even though those mandates have been seen in court.
Tweeter is implying that COVID 19 transmission rate is lowest in Florida because apparently, people there have natural immunity, which according to the tweeter, is more effective than the vaccine.

This tweet is anti-vaxx, because although it may be true that vaccines don't prevent transmission, vaccines have other benefits that the tweeter neglects to mention, such as reducing severe illness. This tweet is in reply to an Alabama stat about how vaccinations are low in that state, and cases are high.

This tweeter seems to be criticizing anti-vaxxers for claiming that a match was stopped due to a vaccination injury. It's not completely clear, but this tweeter says that medical emergencies are normal at a match and that there should be no conspiracy around that.
Tweeter states that students who are unvaccinated in Germany are not allowed on campus despite the vaccination rate being over 90 per cent.

This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that scientists don't have enough data on how vaccines affect people with failing hearts. He says more data needs to be collected to ensure vaccination of those people is safe. But this tweeter is not a medical professional, so this post is misleading.
Tweeter says people in Russia are freer than people in Canada because he was unable to take a bus to Alberta without a vaccine.
Tweeter asked if it is possible for Taiwan to receive vaccines. They say by receiving these vaccines, it shows that the government is powerless.
Tweeter writes about a man who said vaccine murder is murder. They go on to call them extraordinary for saying that statement.
This post criticizes the CEO of Novavax for claiming that their vaccine is ideal for boosting and for being too focused on becoming rich.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is defending public health mandates within a thread. In this particular tweet, he is commenting on the rise in case counts, by saying they only rose because restrictions were lifted in Auckland to accommodate people who had nearly given up on mandates. The tweeter also says vaccines were the best way to reduce case numbers.

This post by Laura Lynn Tyler Thompson celebrates that her father has survived COVID19 without being vaccinated, having been treated with ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine. It writes that he now has natural immunity.
This is a news post about Ice Cube turning down a highly paid movie role after being asked to take the vaccine. Ice Cube refused vaccination.
Tweeter believes that Pfizer's PR team will announce that the fifth or sixth dose of the vaccine will perform better.
Tweet shares that Costa Rica asked for children to be vaccinated but not everyone is happy about it.
Tweeter responds to a doctor, original tweet unfound, and states that what the doctor basically said was that vaccines don't work.
Tweeter shares 22 ways to stop vaccine passports and instructs people to make these choices.
Tweeter states that if someone is overweight or smokes and then gets the vaccine, it won't protect them as well.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the PHS stopped reporting daily COVID-19 counts because it reveals how ineffective vaccines are. This is not true: another online resource was devised by the PHS to show the public data.
In reply to a post that celebrates protesting vaccines and claims they kill people, this post writes that Trump is the one who kills people and vaccines are safe.

This anti-vaxxer says the pandemic is not just of the unvaccinated. They list off a bunch of numbers about myocarditis, claiming Pfizer caused them after the vaccine roll-out. They also say there was a death with the intention of promoting vaccine hesitation.
This tweeter says that Virginia's Governor Elect, Winsome Sears, won't be elected again due to her spreading of conspiracy theories.
This tweeter says vaccines are experimental and posts a story about football player, Liam Jones, who left football due to vaccine mandates.

This anti-vaxxer says that complying with COVID-19 mandates does not equate to freedom. They posted a picture of the airport, revealing COVID-19 testing cubicles, and say that it's like herding cattle.
Tweeter says vaccine and mask mandates are a joke.
The tweet is promoting a new vaccine from Russia called Sputnik Light.
Tweeter points out that there wasn't a vaccine for COVID-19 before the pandemic.

This tweeter says that COVID-19 vaccines are not effective by asking what good they are, if they don't prevent transmission. She says that other vaccines do a better job of protecting, so this appears to be an attack on mRNA vaccines.

This tweeter implies that vaccines are ineffective by saying the U.K. had a high vaccination rate, yet hospitalizations soared in November 2021. CNBC reported though that "Experts say there are a variety of reasons for the U.K.’s steep COVID-19 numbers — ranging from the half-hearted mask adoption (even when masks are required, such as on public transport, the rule is rarely enforced) to large indoor gatherings that have allowed the virus to spread." The U.K.'s hesitation to vaccinate teenagers escalated cases as well.

This post shares a link to a news piece from News Punch, a known fake news outlet, claiming that New Zealand’s vaccine mandates were ruled a gross violation of human rights. It tags Justin Trudeau, saying he should take note.
This post jokes that a mandate to take magic mushrooms would be better than vaccine mandates.

This post by New Zealand based Newstalk ZB shares a news item about a legal challenge questioning the lawfulness of the COVID19 vaccine mandates for educators and health workers amid new anti-mandate protests.
This post claims that it is not possible to prove that being vaccinated reduces symptoms once someone is infected with COVID19.

This post writes that according to doctors, most COVID19 cases are now the Delta variant, yet vaccines against a different strain are being forced on people. Is also says the government is purging people who won’t comply.

This post questions why there is little to no information about booking a COVID19 vaccine for disabled or medically complex children. It calls on paediatric healthcare experts to advocate for this segment of the population.
criticism_other: Lack of information for disabled children

meaning: This post shares a BBC news piece about deaths due to COVID19 being rare among the fully vaccinated. It advocates for science and the vaccine as the best ways to protect populations.

This pro-vaccine tweeter shares information by way of a news article about antibodies. The article says that people who develop a fever after getting vaccinated have a greater chance of acquiring more antibodies to fight COVID-19.
