This tweet is confusing because it is pro-vaccine, yet the tweeter claims that higher rates of vaccinated people are dying in the U.K. in comparison to unvaccinated people. This is not true according to various news reports, such as a fact-check article by Reuters. 

This tweeter posted a chart to prove her claim that vaccinated people are dying more frequently, yet there is no source on that chart.
This post advocates for vaccine mandates because they protect others. It criticizes those who don’t follow mandates and laments the high death toll in Oklahoma.
This is an informational post about a large number of vaccines being given out in Pakistan. Although this is akin to a news report, this post is inherently pro-vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter, who is a GP, calls out an anti-vaxxer for spreading information that is illogical. She addresses some argument that anti-vaxxer made about spike-proteins.
criticism_other: Anti-vaxxers who spout bad science to support their cause

meaning: This post announces an in-person event in Duluth, with a disclaimer that proof of vaccination or a negative COVID19 test is needed to get in.
This pro-vaccine post provides information on Queensland's high vaccination rate. The tweet reported a 80% vaccination rate, and said that the borders are now set to reopen.
This post celebrates that India and China apparently denied Pfizer an Emergency Use Authorization because of their dangerous and sometimes fatal vaccines.
This post announces that the supply of paediatric vaccines is limited at clinics in the District of Columbia (USA), but that more are coming soon.

This post shares a video by the news agency Ruptly about new microchip technology that could be implanted into the arm for easy tracking of vaccine status. It criticizes this approach, calling for no vaccine passports of any kind anywhere.

This post by Assembly Woman Lorena Gonzalez in California’s district 80 announces that her team serves their constituents’ needs by helping with a number of things including booking vaccine appointments.
This anti-vaxx tweeter questions the effectiveness of vaccines and masking, while there's a rise in infections at hospitals, where staff are vaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweeter criticizes Claire Fox, a "leftist," for mingling with anti-vaxxers, QAnon supporters and generally far-right leaning people.
criticism_other: Claire Fox, QAnon, and far-right figures

meaning: Controversial figure, Ezra Levant - the tweeter of this post - says that mandates and lockdowns have no scientific basis. He also links Trudeau into this complaint. And he says vaccine passports are bigoted.

This post retweets a medical doctor, writing that COVID19 booster shots for young healthy people can be thought of as a financial product because they transfer wealth from society to shareholders for little to no gain in overall human health.
This post claims that the Australian government knows vaccines kill and cause serious injuries and that any more vaccine deaths should be considered premeditated manslaughter.
This post announces that a major grocery store chain in British Columbia is limiting its capacity to fifty percent to mitigate COVID19 risk.
This tweeter said 285 died in India the day before this post was made. And the tweeter wants the government to release their vaccination status, which indicates a pro-vaccine stance.

This post criticizes Bill Gates for donating millions of pounds to Imperial College London, claiming that the university has misled the UK government and driven lockdowns, and human rights and civil liberty violations.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is replying to a thread that discusses masking. She says that it's not fair that kids are being asked to wear masks, while adults can go to pubs and party without masks.
support_other: Masking at pubs, or closing pubs rather than masking children

meaning: This post writes that vaccines are bad but essential oils are good.

This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that Sweden suspended the Moderna vaccine indefinitely because patients developed a heart condition. The tweeter posted a far-right, non-fact-checked news source to support this. But CTV reported that "Scandinavian authorities... suspended or discouraged the use of Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine in young people because of an increased risk of heart inflammation, a very rare side effect associated with the shot." This information completes a more complete picture about Sweden's decision.
This post shares a photo of a COVID19 test centre, claiming it looks like a trap and that the needle does contain any vaccine.
This post jokes that when the Zombie apocalypse comes, millions of Americans will reject a vaccine that is safe and effective, screaming that it is their right to eat brains.
This post claims that the vaccines we currently have available are silly because scientists recommend too many boosters, meaning science failed in developing an adequate vaccine.
This tweeter replied to a pro-vaccine tweeter who said anti-vaxxers will get ill and die from the vaccine. This tweeter says the vaccinated people will die too.
This tweeter appears to be anti-vaxx because she made a comment about Trudeau backing down on the vaccine mandates in light of the trucker convoy.
This tweeter writes that they are upset they had to get vaccinated, that it has been coercion at ever level, and that they are unwilling to get a booster shot.
This tweeter doesn't make a comment on vaccines persay, rather he relays an article from The Telegraph. It's about how AZ's antibody treatment could be even more effective than vaccines.
This post writes that from personal protective equipment to vaccines, too much money is involved in COVID19, making it a value chain, and that this is why people are so obsessed with the virus.
This post claims that vaccines are not about health but about massive global depopulation, and that six billion people will be eliminated in the coming years due to forced vaccination.
This post shares and celebrates a news piece that says Chicago police officers could be disciplined or fired for not reporting vaccination status.

In reply to a tweet about the effectiveness of COVID19 vaccines, this post sarcastically writes that vaccines do work as intended if the intention is to forge obedience in the population and identify disobedient individuals.

This post promotes conspiracy theories, writing that those involved in bio-engineering the coronavirus, including the Chinese Communist Part (CCP) and Big Pharma like Pfizer, will eventually pay for what they have done. It also claims that vaccines will bring about worldwide changes in geopolitics, military, and economy.
This radio station is tweeting information on recommendations about getting children vaccinated with the Pfizer vaccine. This post is inherently pro-vaccine, although it's a news post.
This anti-vaxx tweeter is making a joke about an athlete. In the photo he looks puffed up and angry - so the tweeter asks if he's double vaxxed and boosted, or just puffed up on steroids.
This anti-vaxxer calls public health measures, such as gym closures, "tyranny." He wants the mandates to be lifted.
This post deplores the fact that given, current vaccination rates, only forty-one percent of Hondurans will be fully vaccinated by the end of 2021. It calls for a global approach and vaccine equity.

This post comments on the fact that vaccine certificates are being checked inconsistently in public places like coffee shops and suggests that getting a vaccine certificate printed on a T-shirt might be a clever idea.

This tweeter quotes a controversial epidemiologist, Dr. Alexander, on how COVID-19 vaccines don't stop transmission. This is true, yet vaccines do other beneficial things, so this tweet is being used to support the anti-vaxx cause. The tweeter linked a video of Alexander speaking.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccination of children is a good thing, even if COVID-19 can be mild in children.
This tweeter says that vaccine passports are unethical. He also says such mandates come at a large cost to the venues that must enforce them.

This tweeter is worried about some medical official who may be vaccinating children. It's not clear who this tweeter refers to, because this post replied to a deleted tweet, but the message is against vaccinating children.
This anti-vaxx tweet claims that for every person that was saved in the pandemic, at least two die of the vaccine, which is incorrect.

This post tags the representative for New York’s 21st district, Elise Stefanik, sarcastically asking her to launch an investigation into the Mayor of New York, and to find out how many anti-vaxxers and anti-maskers, who the tweet calls morons, have become ill from COVID19 in New York.

This tweeter writes that they kept their family from getting COVID19 from one sick person in the house by all being vaccinated, airing out the house, isolating the sick person, and wearing good masks.
This post announces that Italy has introduced mandatory vaccination against COVID19 for those over 50 years of age. It includes a link to a news piece by Euronews.

This tweeter supports vaccine passport requirements for travel. The tweeter says that such mandates have occurred before and brings up yellow fever as an example. Some countries require a yellow fever vaccination shot to be entered.
This tweeter provides information on how to download a vaccine certificate.

This tweeter celebrates the COVID19 vaccine, saying they got the first shot and the booster shot the day they were eligible. Vaccines, they write, are the greatest scientific achievement of the 21st century.
This post by Local 10 News South Florida anchor Louis Aguirre announces that Joe Biden received his second booster and has asked Congress to fund further vaccination efforts.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx and posted a hypothetical dialogue between Biden and America. Basically, this dialogue portrays Biden as pushing fear to get people vaccinated. And the dialogue then promotes that vaccines are ineffective because places with high vaccination rates are still suffering high case counts.
This tweet promotes vaccination hubs at two hospitals in the U.K. The tweet provides a link to book a vaccine appointment.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that anti-vaxxers and anti-maskers have gone too far in comparing a war zone to mandates. It's not clear what war zone they were talking about because the original tweet was deleted.
This doctor is promoting various public health measures, including vaccinations, boosters, ventilation of air, social distancing and etc.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that he believes everyone should get vaccinated unless they have a medical exemption. He also mentions that 87% of truckers in Canada are vaccinated.
This anti-vaxxer tweeted proof that vaccine mandates for the NYPD were blocked in court.

A tweet linking to an interview with a doctor who chose not to get vaccinated, but still argues that vaccines save lives. This tweet focuses on a misrepresentative quote from the doctor about vaccine related deaths, and questions whether it is true.
This post argues that vaccines against COVID19 prevent serious illness and that if all are vaccinated, COVID19 will become a much less threatening disease, such as a nasty cold.
This tweeter writes that after seeing a post by Big Bird about the importance of getting vaccinated, their five-year-old said they were no longer vaccine hesitant and ready to get the shot.
This post celebrates Uganda’s president Yoweri K Museveni for urging the public to get vaccinated so they can more quickly overcome the Omicron variant if they get infected.
This post by a medical doctor says that we need better education to raise vaccination rates. It links to a PLOS Medicine journal article about the Measles Epidemic in Texas.
This anti-vaxxer says that people tend to blame bad things on everything but the vaccine. This implies that the vaccine is dangerous or destructive, which is misleading.
This tweeter is concerned that unvaccinated children are at risk of contracting COVID-19 amidst mandates being lifted.
criticism_other: Lifting of restrictions and unvaccinated kids being at risk

meaning: This tweet writes that vaccines are among the most important tools for mitigating COVID19 right now, but that they do not stop transmission and that blaming the unvaccinated is therefore senseless. It also writes that vaccines will be bring an end to the pandemic.

This tweeter writes that where they live vaccination status of hospital admissions is not reported. They imply that vaccines are not effective in preventing serious illness, and that hospitals want to hide this fact by not reporting numbers.

This tweeter highlights that the trucker convoy members are making huge sacrifices for their beliefs. The tweeter appears to be pro-vaccine and jabs slightly at the truckers for their ludicrous sacrifices and beliefs.

This is a news retweet. Because it's from Breitbart News, one would be inclined to label this as anti-vaxx, yet the tweet is speaking more about delays in vaccination. The lead of the news article linked here is "Austria’s mandatory vax regime, which would have been the first of its kind in Europe has been delayed due to administrative issues." Therefore this tweet is flagged as unsure about the vaccine, not pro- or anti-vaccine.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says he respects health care workers for choosing not to get vaccinated. He says they have his respect.
support_other: Health care workers choosing not to get vaccinated.

meaning: This tweet announces that Minneapolis and St. Paul in the United States will require proof of vaccination to enter public spaces such as bars, restaurants, theatres, and gyms.
This tweeter writes that they caught COVID19 in March 2020 and that because it was so scary, they have been masking ever since and received all their vaccines doses.
This tweet writes that some European countries may allow expatriates to upload vaccine documents online to receive a European formatted certificate with QR code to make traveling more smooth.
This post questions how England’s Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty will be able to justify recommending vaccines for teenaged boys given potential side effects.
User claims she is thankful she has not been vaccinated but vague about why or what the dangers might be, saying "if you know, you know..."
This tweeter promotes vaccination and vaccine equity. The tweeter says the government needs to support the TRIPS waiver to deliver on COVAX pledges.
This post announces that United States doctor Patrick Soon-Shiong has opened a new vaccine plant, Nant SA, in Cape Town, which will produce 1 billion COVID19 vaccines annually by 2025.

This post sarcastically asks an anti-vaxxer whether the vaccine has caused them to become unkind. It is part of a thread where the anti-vaxxer criticized so-called pro-virus Covidiots for being selfish on World Kindness Day.

This tweeter celebrates hospital workers across the country. The tweet supports freedom of choice, although it's not anti-vaxx, because the tweeter says that they support vaccinated and unvaccinated workers.

This tweeter posted a video of an Indonesian trucker yelling, likely about vaccine mandates. The tweeter says that this trucker is being "squeezed" by "draconian" "plandemic" rules. This promotes conspiracy theories and anti-vaxx statements. The tweeter also says vaccines are useless in "many ways."

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccines and boosters work. This seems to be a reply to an anti-vaxxer who claimed boosters don't work. This person says that anti-vaxxer is spouting "nonsense on stilts."
This tweeter is unhappy about Australia being left behind in rapid test, not receiving enough supply, much like happened with the COVID19 vaccine.

This tweet writes that at least 69 athletes have collapsed in one month, some with fatal heart inflammation, which the tweeter claims is due to COVID19 vaccine side effects. It shares a news piece by Free West Media.

This tweet writes that too many people get their information about vaccines for young children from Facebook and Fox News propaganda, and that more parents should be reading accurate news articles to keep their kids safe.
This tweet asks what the plan is to keep children below the age of five safe, as COVID19 vaccines are not yet available for them in the United States.

This tweet criticizes anti-vaxxers, writing that most beg to be vaccinated when they are sick in hospital with COVID19, though by then it is too late. Anti-vaxxers, it says, put pressure on our healthcare system to the point where people’s other health issues cannot be treated.

This post by Rick Bright writes that he spoke on MSN BC about the Omicron variant. It encourages people to wear masks, get vaccinated, get tested, and distance to mitigate the effects of the pandemic.
This anti-vaxxer claims that they've seen a few cases of cancer resulting from the vaccine. There is no evidence to support this tweet.

This tweeter is into vaccines but also believes in freedom of choice. She posted a WHO video about vaccine equity and got upset that the voice over says "no one is safe until we're all safe." She calls that dystopian, indicating a freedom of choice stance. She also says she's been vaccinated with various vaccines.
This tweeter posted a blog post that unpacks the nuances between vaccine hesitant and anti-vaxx people, therefore this tweet supports the anti-vaxx mandate.
Tweeter is implying that information about COVID vaccine is not reliable as researchers and pharmaceutical company heads offer varying opinions about the efficacy of the booster shots.

This tweet shares a news piece about hospitals in the United States bracing for more staff shortages as a new vaccine mandate requiring medical staff to be vaccinated against COVID19 comes into effect.

This tweeter claims they have friends who have received the first two shots of the COVID19 vaccine but refuse to get the booster because of lasting side effects post vaccine. They write that these issues are common but don’t appear in the media.

This tweet from a conspiracy theorist account questions why in Australia the COVID19 vaccine is available for those 65 and over, but for Aboriginal populations for those 50 and over. It implies unfair treatment of non-Aboriginal groups.
This post writes that children do not benefit from vaccines, tagging Health Canada and linking to a news piece in The Telegraph for evidence.
This post writes that there is no vaccine shortage in the Indian State of Maharashtra as hundreds of thousands of doses of COVAXIN and Covishield are available.
This post claims that recent issues in Maricopa County, Arizona, including vaccine mandates, are all due to a stolen election and that those responsible need to be held accountable and decertified.

Tweet is a response to another tweet from a mother with long Covid and her daughter who both continue to experience symptoms. Mother is double vaccinated, and the reply asks if anyone in the scientific community is studying if people with "long haul Covid" are more susceptible to being reinfected than others.

Tweeter implied that the unemployment rate in the U.S. is apparently not low as the data does not include people who lost their jobs refusing the vaccine mandate and became ineligible to file for unemployment benefits.
This posts questions the effectiveness of the COVID19 vaccine, asking whether there are any other vaccines out there that need to be taken several times per year to be effective.

This post by a self-proclaimed citizen journalist criticizes Pfizer, claiming they under-reported the number of deaths during one of its clinical trials. It uses the hashtag Pfizer Gate #PfizerGate intended to uncover big pharma conspiracies.

A tweet linking to an article about how Moderna raised funds for the development of the COVID vaccine. It focuses on the business side of the vaccine production, and includes accurate information about the vaccine itself.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that many people may have left work places if mandates were not instated. He also posted a stat that 59% of RNs support mandates.

User is unvaccinated and having mild symptoms from Covid.  Replying to a discussion where another user said the same thing and received a reply that a case study of one was not any kind of proof. This user is seconding the argument that even if you are unvaccinated, symptoms are mild.

User is retweeting someone elses recap of an installment of the Guardian's "Lost to Covid" series about a man who chose not to be vaccinated and later died. The user advocates for more awareness on how social media and other platforms can lead to conspiracy theories and radicalization.
criticism_other: social media as a path to radicalization

meaning: This tweeter talks about some data sets (not clear which ones) that could reveal that vaccines are a greater risk to certain age categories. This is an anti-vaxx post, aimed at discouraging the vaccination of children.
A tweet linking to a Fox News video about Biden's vaccine mandates. It includes tow republican governors on the usual tirade about freedom, and how Biden is incompetent.
This tweeter says that the elderly suffered as a result of CDC inaction. This is a pro-vaccine post and says that COVID-19 rates went down when vaccination rates went up.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is telling an anti-vaxxer to stop sending abusive DMs to her inbox. This tweeter says that such anti-vaxx people are alive today because they received other vaccines in their youth.

This anti-vaxxer claims that the new COVID-19 vaccine was "ramrodded" into everyone that was willing. He also promotes Ivermectin, which is a horse wormer, as a cure for COVID-19, which has been proven as not effective in fighting this disease.
A tweet from a University promoting their community vaccination centres and advising that people continue to keep their vaccine status up to date.
A tweet about how there are tons of laws that mandate things for the sake of safety, ex. road laws, so vaccine mandates aren't an unprecedented breach of freedoms.
A tweet promoting resistance against vaccine mandates, supporting a high profile anti vaccine incident.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says protesters need to hit the streets to speak up against vaccine mandates. They believe that cops will also join the protests, because they are also angry about the mandates.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx. He says that the same person who mandated vaccines (BIDEN) is the same person who felt hesitant towards them when he was not in charge. This is misleading information.
This tweeter promotes the vaccination of children by showing photographs of children getting vaccinated at an outdoor clinic.

This tweeter posts a video of DeSantis speaking about how vaccine mandates create discrimination. The tweeter wrote that DeSantis is blocking those mandates, indicating a celebration for anti-vaxx sentiments.
This pro-vaccine post reports that drones were used in India to deliver vaccines.
This is a news report made by the BBC about tennis player Djokovic. They reported that he's willing to lose his career over not taking the vaccine. No personal opinion is contained within this post.
Stock market analyst for CNBC predicting markets will rise following good news about vaccine protection against the Omicron variant.
This pro-vaccine tweeter asks how they can report people who have fake vaccination cards.
A reply in an argument about the vaccine, this person says that the vaccine is not a vaccine, as well as the annual flu vaccines are not vaccines. I'm not sure where they are coming from.
The user says they are double vaccinated but they are still against vaccine passports implying it's ineffective and a breach of privacy.
A tweet about a study that found the vaccine is safe for people who are immunocompromised.
This tweeter encourages people to get vaccinated and boosted because they say vaccines prevent long COVID-19 as well as death.

This tweeter says they developed the vaccine and therefore need more payment for that. However this is misleading, because it's not clear who this agency is and if they had any part in developing vaccines.
support_other: Getting paid properly for developing a vaccine

meaning: This tweeter says they're suing their Wall Street employer for "fascist" mandates. They listed a price point of $10 million, but nothing about this was easily searchable in a reputable news source.

This tweeter says that Dr. Andrew Hill should die from the vaccine. A video is posted, but no context is really provided to what is being said, yet this tweeter is clearly an anti-vaxxer and is likely making a comment on pro-science comments from Hill.

This anti-vaxxer says that various we're living under a dictatorship during these times of public health restrictions. The tweeter asks for the "madness" to stop, and says that jobs can't be filled due to mandates.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the vaccine is spreading COVID-19 cases.
User is worried the Supreme Court will overturn their precedent establishing that mandatory vaccines are legal in certain scenarios.

User is writing about a colleague who was forced to retire after being diagnosed with heart issues. The doctor explicitly said the issues were not related to the vaccine, but because the symptoms appeared the day after his booster, this user thinks they are related.

This post is true, a student did loser her leg in Thailand as a result of the AZ vaccine. She received blood clots, then her left leg was amputated. This was reported in the Bangkok Post, yet the intention of this tweet is to spread vaccine fear.
A reply about how the government is planning to control the population using vaccines, it also links to a site that is filled with misinformation.
A tweet from the Botswana Government about drive through vaccination stations.
A tweet from Singapore's Ministry of Health promoting the Sinovac vaccine.

A tweet in response to Glenn who argued that most people took the vaccine for social reasons rather than health reasons. This user argues the same people who are against the vaccine trust medical science in other instances.
A tweet arguing that there ought to be more thought put into the timeline of vaccine mandates, that there should be a firmer schedule to end or re-examine mandates.
A tweet arguing governments can do as much as possible to prevent COVID but it seems it can spread anyways. It also argues that low case counts are too good to be true.

This tweeter says that a Trump-appointed person re-instated Biden's vaccine mandates. This tweet calls him "MAGA scum," therefore revealing his distrust for Trump as well as his contempt for vaccine mandates.

This tweet is not really promoting or criticizing anything, rather it says that there are a lot of factors that need to be considered when deciding how to vaccinate a nation. The tweeter mentions the cost of vaccination, for example.
This is a news post from a news station about how a police union is opposed to mandatory vaccination. The tweet contains no personal information, rather it relays information.
This anti-vaxxer posted a video of Boris Johnson talking about vaccines. He said that they don't prevent transmission, so this tweeter asks why vaccine passports are required.

This anti-vaxx tweeter makes a metaphorical statement about vaccines. She says that we shouldn't celebrate large vaccination numbers when large percentage of those numbers die from the vaccine. This is misleading.
Stock market analyst for CNBC predicting markets will rise following good news about vaccine protection against the Omicron variant.

User claims the United States has one of the highest triple vaccination rates in the world, yet the pandemic is still going strong. Unclear if this is anti-vax or a warning against becoming complacent. No hints in profile.
This tweet doesn't promote or criticize anything, rather it says things will unfold in an interesting way as a result of the Austrian parliament approving vaccine mandates in adults.

A tweet about a 15 year old who allegedly had a stroke two days after getting the vaccine, this tweet is arguing that those circumstances warrant investigating. It doesn't make any direct claims, it just argues for more information.
A reply to a tweet about the amount of doctors who quit over vaccine mandates, arguing doctors also refuse other vaccines so anti-vax health care workers are not a new trend.
A tweet linking to an article about the conspiracy theory that "poison gnome Fauci" manufactured COVID-19 as a way to make money by curing a disease 'they' created.

A tweet arguing the JCVI recommended that teenagers not get the vaccine, even though they have recommended teenagers get it. It is using this misinformation to imply there is a conspiracy to take advantage of people.
This post is not promoting or criticizing anything, rather it says only one vaccine requires one jab: The J&J Vaccine.

This person is against public heath mandates. They say that lockdowns only delay the virus from spreading, to imply that lockdowns are useless. They also imply that vaccine mandates are no good because they don't stop transmission.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says they are doing the sensible and right thing by getting vaccinated and boosted. The tweeter says he wants to move on with his life again. He also got vaccinated to protect his community and friends.
This is a pro-vaccine tweet that promotes a vaccination clinic.
This tweeter refers to vaccine mandates as unworkable. The tweet also criticizes the Scottish National Party (SNP) for having it out for hospitality.

User is upset that businesses are choosing not to check/mandate vaccinations for customers even when the majority of the population is vaccinated. He claims the percentage of those who remain unvaccinated is around 10%, which is not true.
criticism_other: businesses choosing not to require vaccines for customers or employees

meaning: Story about a friend who went on some dates with a woman who admitted she had omicron after he started having symptoms. The friend compared his experience to not disclosing an STD. User does not seem to have strong opinions on the vaccine itself, but the profile is heavily conservative in ideology.
This pro-vaccine tweeter explains to an anti-vaxxer that vaccines reduce the risk of death. This tweeter says he can't fix that anti-vaxxer's inability to understand facts.
User claims the vaccine will cause AIDS symptoms and give people AIDS unless they have "natural immunity."
User claims that vaccines are primarily responsible for the economic re-opening of New Zealand and Australia rather than interim measures like increased airflow in public places or CO2 monitors.

This is an informational post from a Global Health Strategies twitter account about how data regarding vaccine effectiveness is being tracked by the WHO in light of Omicron. No personal opinion is included in this tweet.

This anti-vaxxer says she loved the trucker convoy. She says that the freedom to travel is a god given right. And this tweet is in reply to another tweeter who likens mandates to communist restrictions.
This pro-vaccine tweet is an announcement about a vaccination clinic. It says people can get their boosters there.

This is a BBC news post. It's inherently pro-vaccine because it tells the story of a woman who nearly died from COVID-19. That woman encouraged other pregnant women to get the vaccine in this posts video. She wasn't able to get vaccinated because it was not yet available for expectant mothers while she was pregnant.
This tweeter claims that teenagers are dying as a result of vaccination. The tweeter posted a post from The Daily Skeptic, which is not a reputable news source, to prove this.

This tweeter is replying to a thread of anti-vaxxers who discuss how vaccines lead to myocarditis. This tweeter says that the risk of myocarditis resulting from vaccines is virtually the same as the risk of it resulting from contracting COVID-19. She posts a data driven article from Nature.com to illustrate this point.
A tweet about how children have a low risk when it comes to COVID and the vaccine doesn't provide enough protection to be worth taking. It implies there is more risk from the vaccine than from COVID.

A tweet about how the government is tyrannical because pushing people to get vaccinated because of a deal between pharmaceutical companies and the government. It also implies that big companies like Costco and Walmart are in on it.
This woman supports BREXIT and frowns upon England referring to the EU's vaccination plans. She says that the "globalists" are still in charge and that BREXIT was all for nothing due to this.
This post criticizes an anti-vaxxer, writing that they are a moron for supporting anti-vaccination, and that claiming their freedom has been taken from them is ridiculous.
Link to a Reuters article about a lawsuit brought by 11 states over federal contractors who are unwilling to get vaccinated in spite of the mandate.

This pro-vaccine tweeter explains that the worst vaccination rate is 87%. It's not clear what territories of the world this refers to, but the tweeter says mandates work because those vaccination rates are high. They posted a news link to a Politico article to prove this information.
This is a humorous pro-vaccine tweet about how the vaccine protects people against Marvel movies and The Beatles. The tweeter re-posted a quirky, unsourced news screenshot to illustrate that comment.

This tweeter says that it's wrong to require vaccines at schools but not at the Oscars. But this is misleading. Variety reported that "This year’s Academy Awards will require proof of COVID-19 vaccination for most — but not all..." Performers were not required to be vaccinated.
This tweeter says he got his booster shot and encourages others to do the same. He gave details on where to get the shot, and on how long it took.

This tweet appears to be anti-vaxx because it shows an article about how a pastor wants to administer vaccines from the pulpit of his church. This tweeter says that that individual will "push" vaccines, connoting an anti-vaxx stance.
A tweet about how the Indian Prime Minister's vaccine photo op doesn't count as an official advertisement so it doesn't break any rules about government endorsement.
A tweet alleging a vast conspiracy of Russia, central banks, and vaccine passports, which somehow benefits the world elite.
This tweet announces the start of home delivery of COVID19 vaccines in Ahmedabad, India.
This anti-vaxxer is angry that people are losing their livelihoods for not getting vaccinated. She believes that "tyrannical idiots" tried to "force" jab people.
This post criticizes anti-vaxxers for dragging out the pandemic by not wearing masks, not getting the vaccine, and not taking personal responsibility for their actions.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that child abuse comes in the form of refusing to vaccinate a child, or refusing to make them wear a mask.
This is a joke about vaccines. It doesn't contain any personal opinion. It just asks if vaccines set you free, and then exclaims that "conspiracy theorists" were right again.

This tweet is poorly written but includes some kind of conspiracy theory about China. It also makes an anti-vaxx comment about how nations are hoarding vaccines while simultaneously instilling vaccine mandates on flights. This is a manipulation of conversations around vaccine equity, twisted to support freedom of choice.
This pro-vaccine tweeter makes a joke about getting the vaccine. He says it doesn't matter though because he eats Burger King every night, meaning he will be unhealthy no matter what he does.

This tweeter says that there's a plan to amplify vaccine passports. This verges on conspiracy theories about government corruption. The tweeter posted a link to another tweet, but it's not very descriptive or relevant to this comment.

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccine mandates are madness and asks why New Yorkers are complying. They posted an article to a Kyrie Irving's story, regarding his inability to play due to vaccine mandates.
A tweet misrepresenting a study about vaccine hesitancy, it makes it seem like the study found people with PHDs had high hesitancy although they were among the groups with lower hesitancy.
A tweet promoting high vaccination rates in B.C, breaking it down statistically by age group.
A tweet arguing the government ought to prioritise the care of other patients over unvaccinated people in hospital.
This is a news tweet which is inherently pro-vaccine about how Quebec will intensify its COVID-19 vaccine strategies. A link is provided to their article.
This anti-vaxx tweeter promotes Omicron as a form of "natural immunity." They say everyone is going to get it and the jab shouldn't be the only thing "associated" with the jab.
This post states the COVID19 vaccine percentage rates across Canada's provinces and territories, specifically the percentage of the population with two doses.
This tweeter promotes the equal distribution of vaccines. A video is included, of a Parliamentary member speaking about the importance of vaccinating the world.

This tweet is in response to a short thread about how Idaho had a low vaccination rate, and how 90-95% of the people hospitalized due to COVID-19 were unvaccinated. This tweeter tells another tweeter to turn off Twitter because they're complaining about reading this depressing news while on vacation. The tweeter also said that Idaho has a low vaccination rate.
This pro-vaccine tweet celebrates CNN's John King for speaking honestly about why vaccines are important, especially for the immunocompromised. A video of King speaking was included in the post.

This anti-vaxx tweeter is angry at COVID-19 vaccine pushers for saying that their vaccines won't work unless all other people are vaccinated. This tweeter questions how good the vaccine is if that's the case.
This tweet shares a video from Rumble, a site known for sharing conspiracy theories and misinformation videos, that claims COVID19 vaccines are designed to kill and depopulate the planet.

This tweeter posted a graph that shows how Instant Fatality Ratios declined throughout the pandemic, as a result of vaccines. The tweeter explicitly said this is due to vaccines, therefore this is a pro-vaccine post.

A tweet criticising a news anchor for not reporting on the VAERS numbers, it also includes a photo of the VAERS numbers. It is part of a thread which includes misleading information but this tweet is factual.

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines are not effective. The tweeter posted a news post about how a vaccinated politician contracted COVID-19, despite being vaccinated, to illustrate why vaccines aren't effective.
This anti-vaxx post is a bit unclear but it revolves around saying certain people haven't prevented hospitals from having vaccine mandates.
A tweet where the user is making fun of anti-vaccine hate mail, arguing Kirk and the other captains in the Federation would support vaccines and mandates.
A tweet in response to a video of a woman judging someone advocating for mask mandates. This tweet is criticising the medical group the woman allegedly works as a nurse for.

This anti-vaxxer is angry at a news presenter for pushing Irish Green Party leader, Eamon Ryan, into keeping vaccine passports active past March, in addition to requiring booster shots on such passports.
This pro-vaccine tweeter replied to an anti-vaxxer. He basically tells that anti-vaxxer to research what a vaccine actually is.
This tweeter says that children may die due to their parents decision to vaxx them. The tweeter says that there is a form of payback, in the French Revolution style, involved in that.
This tweeter says that there should be a halting of and criminal investigation about vaccine mandates.
support_other: A criminal investigation about vaccine mandates

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweeter tells the public that there are "really no risks" in vaccinating women who are breast feeding. The tweeter posted an article released by the CDC to back this up.
This tweet celebrates someone in India for their use of technology to help during the pandemic. This is inherently pro-vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that the government is responsible for giving her COVID-19 because they re-opened businesses too quickly.
This tweet promotes vaccination in India. It lists off the large numbers of vaccinated people to date, as well as within the last 24 hours.

A Republican senator tweeted about the U.S. Supreme Court blocking Biden Administration's vaccine mandate for companies other than medical facilities and OSHA withdrawing the vaccine and testing Emergency Temporary Standard.
Tweeter is claiming that a certain doctor apparently confirmed that her husband's cousin died as a result of receiving the COVID vaccine. This claim cannot be verified due to a lack of information.
This tweet writes that Pfizer has blocked far-right United States Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene on twitter. It calls Pfizer childish and claims their COVID19 vaccine kills people.

This tweet doesn't really promote anything but it appears to be pro-vaccine by commenting on a controversial Australian senator, Alex Antic, for showing up to NOT vote on vaccine mandates. Antic is a critic of vaccine mandates.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that vaccines are experimental and a form of mass genocide. They also say that Fauci has no science to back vaccines up.
In response to a post about high COVID19 case numbers but low rates of fatality in Australia, this tweet celebrates high vaccination rates.
A sarcastic reply to a now deleted tweet, this user is telling someone to get another shot implying the vaccine doesn't work.
A tweet about a research project similar to this one getting recognised as one of the top 100 research projects this year.
A tweet from CNN about Arizona's attorney general suing the federal government over vaccine mandates.
A tweet arguing that any concessions to anti-vaxxer is an insult to health care workers and for every patient in the system.
A tweet showing an animated graph of the vaccination rate in Australia broken down by province.
This post shares an Associated Press News piece celebrating the fact that children in the United States can finally be vaccinated against COVID19 and resume some social activities again.

This tweeter replied to a thread of anti-vaxxers who equated the Australian government to a totalitarian state (due to mandates). The tweeter says that "freedom" fighters are making things worse by extending lockdowns by breaching them. They also say that Australia is not a totalitarian state.
This anti-vaxxer tells people to stop feeding "pharma." He also says that natural immunity is more effective than vaccines, which is misleading.
This is a pro-vaccine post from Ohio's governor. He says that he's offering a series of scholarships to encourage young people to get vaccinated.

This is an informational post written by a professional freelance journalist which includes no personal opinion. It states information about when the vaccine mandate in Austria was destined to come into effect.

This tweet is not entirely clear. It states that there are a group of vaccinated people (Group A) and a group of people who don't want to be vaccinated (Group B) and that as a consequence the government does not distribute vaccines equitably. This seems to be a comment on freedom of choice, because freedom fighters argue that vaccines should be distributed equally around the world if people here at home don't want them.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccines work.

Tweeter is quoting a news report from a news website with questionable sources that German insurance company analyzed its data and found two to three million people receiving treatment for COVID vaccine side effects.

This tweet is by an Australian journalist about an Aussie politician alleging that another political party member, who brought an anti-vaccine mandate bill to the parliament, harassed her for opposing the bill by sharing her phone number on social media.

This post tags two physicians, claiming that they have stopped calling the COVID19 vaccine safe and effective after a Pfizer data release came out. It says that their previous tweets are an accomplice to genocide.

This post claims that the vaccine attacks and replaces a person’s natural immunity to COVID19. Someone infected in 2020, it writes, will have lost their natural immunity if they got vaccinated in 2021.
This post from a suspended account claims that nuclear scientists are suing over vaccine mandates.

This tweeter lists herself as an anesthesiologist on her profile. She posted information about the ingredients in vaccines, separated into two categories: Egg-based vaccines and cell culture vaccines.
This venue tells readers that proof of vaccination and masks are required for entry into their "Fantastic Voyage" event.

This tweeter, judging on her twitter profile, is an anti-vaxxer. She posts a link to a conservative news source about how vaccine mandates in New York are "indefinite." This likely intends to instill anger in people about restrictions.

This tweeter appears to be pro-vaccine within a thread that discusses the Trucker Convoy. This tweeter replied to someone who said that other countries are going back to normal and that Canada should too. The tweet states that other countries have vaccine mandates at borders though, even if they are attempting to go back to "normal."
Tweeter appears to jokingly associate sleeping longer hours with COVID vaccines, which can be misconstrued by anti-vaxxers.
Tweeter is informing that she has received a third shot of the COVID vaccine.
Tweeter insinuated that the media do not publish news of deaths from COVID vaccines because the governments are apparently complicit in hiding a sinister truth about the safety of Pfizer's vaccine.

Tweeter is implying that vaccines are not effective in preventing COVID hospitalization by quoting portions of a Bloomberg report about some U.S. hospitals receiving many COVID patients even in states with high vaccination rates.

This post links to a video on Bit Chute, a site known for posting far-right and conspiracy theorist content, about a police station in Burpengary Australia being served Nuremberg Papers about criminal vaccine activity.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine and is angry at the BBC for not reporting that there was a good economic value in the vaccine roll-out. He's upset that they only reported the number of vaccines, 4%, that were thrown away.
support_other: Economic responsibility during the vaccine roll-out

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter posts a quote from activist Maajid Nawaz about how vaccine passports facilitated a "Checkpoint Charlie" (communist) society. This tweet therefore likens public health mandates to totalitarian regimes.
This pro-freedom tweet claims that vaccine mandates in the U.S. pose a threat to freedom.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that vaccine trials were exposed as being fraudulous. No evidence to support this statement were provided.
A tweet wishing unvaccinated people luck, but it seems to support their ability to refuse life saving medicine.

A tweet arguing that public health interventions are implemented but the government is not implementing economic aid during Omicron. It argues that if this wave is as bad as the others the same assistance should be provided.
Tweeter wants Biden to take more measures to control the spread of misinformation about COVID and vaccines.

This pro-vaccine tweeter promotes herd immunity through vaccination. He says that those who get vaccinated will protect those who cannot get vaccinated, which is not entirely true, because transmission is still possible among vaccinated people.
Tweeter is sharing how a religious group is helping to distribute masks and motivating people to get vaccinated.
This post by a healthcare consultant shares a CBC news piece about the call to focus more on mental healthcare in nursing homes as vaccines prove effective and physical health improves.

This tweeter discusses Omicron within a thread that is about how there was once rhetoric about how mild that variant was. This tweet discusses PIMS - pediatric inflammatory multisystem syndrome - which ocurred in some people who contracted COVID-19. The tweeter says there's more to learn about this and that there were dozens of PIMS cases in people who contracted various variants.

This tweet is situated within a thread of tweets. This tweeter spins out some confusing language about vaccines, in an attempt to sound smart. Ultimately though, this vaccine implies that there are side effects to getting the shot, which is anti-vaxx.

This anti-vaxx tweeter replied within a thread where all of the tweets have been removed by Twitter. This tweeter implies that vaccines are unsafe, and refers to incidents with the H1N1 vaccine, where people received side effects from taking it.

In response to anti-vaxxers questioning why people have randomly begun to unmask, this tweet by an investigative journalist argues that many factors such as increased vaccination rates, lower death rates, and the availability of Paxlovid are the reason.
This post criticizes Narendra Modi, the Prime Minister of India, writing that he illegally put money intended for vaccine development towards other projects.

A tweet from a news station in Australia including a video of a provincial Premier arguing Australians to continue to get vaccinated. Especially construction workers because of outbreaks in the industry at the time. It also condemns the actions of protestors rallying against vaccine mandates on construction sites.
A tweet about Pfizer's plan to develop a COVID vaccine that is equally effective against different variants.

This post by Kyle Becker, CEO of the far-right Becker News, shares an article that claims the Director of the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention has changed her story about vaccine effectiveness.

A tweet pointing to other vaccine mandates in schools and the military, arguing that not getting vaccinated contributes to the amount of COVID deaths. It also points out that if as many people died from other causes, anti-vaxxers would be outraged.

A tweet about how someone associated mostly with people who believe in alternative remedies, but the user says their vaccinated friend had short term memory lapse which the tweet attributes to the vaccine somehow.
A tweet about a program to vaccinate people in Nuevo Laredo, boasting 2,000 residents vaccinated per day.
A tweet about how an MP in India got his constituency to  virtually100% vaccinated.

This tweet calls out an anti-vaxxer for presenting an illogical argument. It says that people have received all the vaccines necessary to go to school in the United States, yet they incorrectly believe the COVID19 vaccine will kill them.
A tweet trying to argue that the vaccine is more dangerous than COVID, on the basis that there are more risks than just death.
A tweet about the announcement that France planned to require booster shots after 4 months, it doesn't seem to take a stance.

A tweet linking to an article that makes it seem as though the government is intentionally hiding incidents of adverse reactions to the vaccine. It says they are sweeping it under the rug, despite VAERS being publicly accessible to anyone.

This post by a Rebel News journalist writes that people who get vaccinated are either stupid or being bribed because, according to a clinical study, the effectiveness of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine drops to three percent after six months.

This post writes that anyone who has been vaccinated against COVID19 should be enraged. It shares a video of Malcolm Roberts, Australian politician, making claims that the vaccine causes terrible medical harm.

This post shares an article by the far-right News Punch which writes that mainstream media is outraged at low vaccination rates in the United States despite acknowledging that vaccines are not effective against COVID.
A tweet criticising people who got the vaccine. It also implies people are being misled by officials like Dr. Fauci.
A tweet urging people to get vaccinated and reduce vaccine inequity to end the tragedy caused by the pandemic.

This post by Pakistan’s National Command and Operation Centre announces new COVID19 vaccine statistics including vaccines administered in the last twenty-four hours and total vaccines administered to date.
A tweet in response to censoring doctors who provide fake vaccine exemptions. It argues that the vaccine is fake and experimental and doctors should be able to give people exemptions.
This post by Our Today News shares an article about tracking COVID19 cases in the Caribbean amid the Delta variant outbreak.
A tweet about how the vaccine may not entirely prevent infection but does reduce the severity of the illness.
A tweet arguing that children have no risk when sick with COVID, whereas they have a high risk when taking the vaccine. It also alleges some mysterious long term effects of the vaccine.
This post writes that governments will take away people’s freedom and jobs, and starve them in prison camps until all businesses ban unvaccinated people even for groceries and other essentials.

This post criticizes the effectiveness of the COVID19 vaccine against the omicron variant, and calls for no vaccine mandates or passports of any kind. It also implies that the omicron variant is made up.

This post writes that antivax misinformation is disproportionately affecting far-right Christian evangelicals. It includes a link to an NPR article about higher COVID death rates among Trump supporters.

This post by the Central Lancashire National Health Service encourages those who have had COVID19 to get their vaccines four weeks from the date of symptoms or the date of a positive test. It announces plenty of walk-in availability at a local clinic.

This post by the World Health Organization encourages people to ensure their vaccines are up to date including those for measles and polio. Vaccines work to keep us safe from these preventable diseases, it writes.
This post tells another user that they should avoid the rabies vaccine because for humans it gets injected into the wound after exposure multiple times over multiple visits.
A tweet about how Marjorie Taylor Greene has been banned from twitter for spreading vaccine disinformation. It is in response to an MSNBC video of someone criticising anti-vaxxers heavily.
This tweeter writes that they are vaccinated with Moderna but that getting COVID19 does not mean going to the hospital or dying. They criticize the media for making this idea widespread.
A tweet comparing vaccines to 9/11, in the sense that they are both conspiracies used to subdue the general population with fear.

A tweet including a photo of Whoopi Goldberg, it criticises her for supporting vaccine mandates. It also calls her fat and equates vaccine passports to a business weighing customers before they enter.
This post celebrates that India has made 1 billion doses of the COVID19 vaccine. It thanks Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as well as doctors and nurses for their efforts.
This post supports a kpop artist who has COVID19. It writes that they will get better, especially because they have been vaccinated.

This post criticizes the media attention that Chris Pratt’s vaccination status has received, writing that Hollywood studios deal with so many actor and actress demands, that this issue must be of low importance for them.

This post argues that if liberals promote mass COVID19 vaccinations as the only way to combat the pandemic, they should be tearing down the houses of pharmaceutical executives who refuse to waive vaccine patents.
criticism_other: Refusal to waive COVID19 vaccine patents

meaning: User is criticizing Democratic Senator Richard Pan for removing certain vaccine exemptions in the state of California. Pan is a doctor of medicine, which this user claims is proof he is working for big pharma.
Tweeter is claiming that vaccine passports will apparently give big techs control over people's lives.
This post announces that today marks the one year anniversary of businessman Rupert Murdoch getting the COVID19 vaccine, one of the first widely known people to get it.

This post writes that there are currently more deaths in general while COVID19 deaths are down. It argues that best case scenario, COVID19 is not a serious disease and worst case scenario vaccines are killing more people than they are saving.

This post argues that masks don’t work, they take away people’s freedom, and they're tyrannical. It also says that vaccines are not effective in stopping transmission or infection, that mandates are Nazism and evil, and that natural immunity is better than vaccinating.
This post by an infectious disease epidemiologist calls for family appointments to get COVID19 shots all together, rather than needing to go to a separate appointment for each family member.
A tweet pointing out that the vaccine may be less effective now than it was initially, but it still works against every variant so far.

A tweet using unverified VAERS data to argue that thousands of people have died after getting vaccinated. It doesn't blame the vaccine for all of those deaths but makes it seem more risky than it truly is.
A tweet of a Fox News interview where the subject actually supports vaccines and urges people to get vaccinated, arguing conservative media doesn't typically promote public health interventions.
This post by a far-right Republican celebrates Governor Ron DeSantis setting up monoclonal treatment centres throughout Florida, in addition to hundreds of vaccine sites.

This tweeter says that the toxic spike protein of vaccines is dangerous to the heart, in a round-about way. But FactCheck.org reported that there's no evidence that the spike protein in vaccines is toxic.
This post celebrate vaccine effectiveness, writing that according to the FDA Advisory Committee, it appears that two doses of mRNA vaccines protect against serious illness from the Omicron variant.
This post shares a video clip of a comedian criticizing anti-vaxxers, writing that this comedian is the voice of reason at a time where so many people refuse to get vaccinated against COVID19.
Tweet is explaining to another user why a particular graph does not provide evidence for the claim that Covid vaccines are killing people at a high rate.
Tweet is from a pathology lab encouraging people to get vaccinated by offering a discount in diagnostic(?) services if the client can show both vaccine doses.

A tweet requesting information about long-term affects of the COVID vaccine, it's part of a thread that is anti-vaccine. It implies there is no evidence supporting long term vaccine safety, even though there is data available and this user probably wouldn't understand it.

A tweet arguing that the COVID vaccine isn't safe and can't be compared to the polio vaccine because the COVID vaccine was developed so much faster, even though medical science has improved so much since the 70s.

A tweet about an executive order allowing health care workers who previously didn't have the qualifications to work in New York to work in New York; recent graduates, retired workers, workers from other states and countries.

This tweet is the headline of a Daily Wire article, which is about Scott Moe who backed the Trucker Convoy. This tweet is inherently anti-vaccine mandate, because Daily Wire is a conservative news site.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx because he's posting a Breitbart news article about border crossings without comment. The article is about how Biden will have a "supply chain nightmare" as a result of instating mandates at the border.

This tweeter says that public health measures are all about control and power, not about health, safety and science. They posted a link to data on California and Florida's infection rates, trying to prove a point that rates are not lower in places where there were more mandates, yet the data was unsourced.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx. They claim that HIV was added to vaccines via the spike protein, thus promoting conspiracy theories.

This tweet is a reply to something by right-wing pundit, Candace Owens. This tweeter says that anti-vaxxers have been silenced on vaccination of children for too long. This tweeter prays that the eyes of the world will open.

This is a news tweet by a data journalist. The tweet doesn't include personal opinion, yet it is inherently pro-vaccination of children due to it's message. The tweet says that COVID-19 cases are sky rocketing in kids, while there is a high percentage of unvaccinated kids in the U.K.

This pro-vaccine tweeter posted a news article about how republicans are spreading the virus by way of their refusal to instate vaccine mandates. The tweeter simply re-posted the headline of the article she linked to, which asks if Republicans can reap benefits from the spread of the virus.
This tweeter criticizes anti-vaxxers for their ignorance about the benefits of vaccines. He makes fun of how everything, for anti-vaxxers, goes back to Bill Gates.
This link in this tweet is broken, but the tweeter says that the inventor of the mRNA vaccine is working on the pan-COVID-19 vaccine. This is inherently pro-vaccine.

This tweeter promotes COVAXIN yet implies that mRNA vaccines are not effective, so I flagged this tweet as unsure about the vaccine. This tweeter says COVAXIN is a "true" vaccine, which is misleading, because the mRNA ones are too.

This anti-vaxxer says they may fire their vaccinated employees, and allow unvaccinated employees to continue working. They say they may change their mind if those unvaccinated employees stop getting boosters.

This anti-vaxx tweeter is upset with the inconsistent messaging involved throughout the pandemic. They seem particularly weirded out by boosters and what they perceive to be false promises of vaccine efficacy.
Seattle news station reporting on the number of transit workers across the state who have chosen to leave their jobs after the governor announced a vaccine mandate.
Tweet is responding to Wales implementing a Covid pass for vaccinated citizens. User calls the move "a dark day" and claims the vaccine is "experimental." Tweet posted November 2021.
Retweet of a U.S News headline from November 2021 about new federal vaccine mandates for nursing home staff in facilities that work with medicare and medicaid.

User is addressing anti-vaccine protests in her country and encouraging those who have been vaccinated to remain positive and remember that they have supported their community and frontline health workers by getting vaccinated.

Retweet of an Atlantic article discussing how repealing public health measures like mask mandates affects immunocompromised people. User is critical of the government repealing these policies after facing public pressure because Omicron is allegedly more mild.

A tweet about how the vaccine is ineffective and dangerous. It also criticises people who believe the unvaccinated ought to suffer for their choice. Another implication is that there is a secret group of powerful people pushing the vaccine onto people.
A tweet about how if politics were not so divisive people would be more inclined to trust the government and their public health interventions.
An direct link to an opinion piece about how the pandemic was not an emergency and mandates are an abuse of power. It also implies most people who got vaccinated were coerced.

This woman says that vaccines allowed the majority of people to live past the age of five. She asks if people remember the days when people had tons of kids, in the event that some were killed by viruses.

This tweeter says that she is vaccinated to prevent passing COVID-19 along to an unvaccinated student. This is slightly misleading because vaccination does not prevent transmission entirely, however her intention is pro-science so I flagged this post as accurate.

This pro-vaccine tweeter posted a link to a video of a famous anti-vaxx athlete who asked why people still get COVID-19 while vaccinated. This tweeter says that the vaccine helps protect people, without inducing the sickness, in a round-about way.
This anti-vaxxer replied to a tweet that is no longer visible. But he says that vaccines don't work because they aren't stopping the virus.

This user is responding to a post from a Fox news contributor about the inefficacy of masking to prevent Covid on airplanes. The original poster claims to be certified MD, but profile is full of vaccine misinformation and conspiracy theories. The person replying also seems to be involved in conspiracy theories and alt-right talking points (username is Trump75millionrealvoters)

User is claiming the vaccinated public are brainwashed and mindlessly following the government's orders on Covid procedure. Refers to "government vaccine hamster wheel" and calls himself a "grumpy old conspiracy theorist."
Retweet of a U.S News headline from November 2021 about new federal vaccine mandates for nursing home staff in facilities that work with medicare and medicaid.

Tweet is part of a thread by this user claiming that Anthony Fauci is pushing the vaccine for his own profit, and claims to offer evidence that he did the same thing during the Zika outbreak in 2016. User claims Fauci and Bill Gates are working together to scare the public and sell them vaccines they don't need, and that Bill Gates funds research into modifying mosquitos so that mosquitos can secretly vaccinate people.
A tweet expressing some concern about the vaccine mandate, specifically mandating boosters and changing the definition of fully vaccinated. It is not harshly critical just concerned over the future.

A tweet about how the government made the choice to enforce mandates in businesses, which is a loss of liberty. However in a previous tweet in this thread this user made a gross comparison between vaccine mandates and racial oppression.
A tweet attributing a false quote and circumstance to the death of a German doctor, saying he killed himself out of guilt for being part of the 'vaccine genocide'.
This is a news post, by ABC, that answers the question "Can your employer get the COVID vaccine?" No personal opinion is included in this post.

This anti-vaxxer says that Sonia Maria Sotomayor, an American lawyer and jurist, is not confident in mask and vaccine mandates. This tweet is in reply to another tweeter who said that "Justice Sotomayor is boycotting in-person attendance" at court.

This tweeter says that Macron promoted the vaccination of children because he claimed that she gave him COVID-19. But this anti-vaxx tweeter claims he was spotted shaking hands with other officials while maskless. This tweet intends to discourage the vaccination of children.
This anti-vaxxer says they lost their job and are no longer eligible for benefits - unless they apply for a certain number of jobs a month - due to being unvaccinated.
criticism_other: Benefits being stripped from unvaccinated people

meaning: This tweet could appear to be pro-vaccine, but I flagged it as unsure about the vaccine. He criticizes a quarantine rule instated for people arriving to the U.K., who were recently vaccinated in certain countries outside the U.K. The tweeter claims that this rule creates vaccine hesitancy, when in reality the vaccines provided in those certain countries may not be reputable.
support_other: Quarantine rules for people vaccinated in certain countries arriving to the U.K.

meaning: User is replying to CTV news channel claiming that events for fully vaccinated people will soon become super spreader events as well. Antagonistic tone, "who ya gunna blame then?"

Tweet is part of a long thread discussing whether antibody tests are triggered by the same antibodies administered in the vaccine. Several people are attempting to explain to this user that antibody tests are not triggered simply by the antibodies from the vaccine, but this user disagrees or does not understand. Profile page contains right wing rhetoric about transgender people and deep skepticism of the vaccine.
Tweet is replying to another user who is hesitant to get the vaccine. The tweet calls out the other user for saying they are being "bullied" into getting the vaccine.
A tweet about how allegedly the vaccine causes heart attacks in young people and there is a directive to cover it up. It promotes conspiracy in the health care industry.
A deleted tweet of a Fox News digital bulletin about Biden's response to an FDA decision to wait for more data before approving boosters for youth.
This tweet is very poorly written however it seems to say that Aaron Rodgers' commecial hiatus is over but that he still is prominent in the public eye. It's not clear what this tweet promotes.
This tweeter is not promoting or criticizing anything, rather they are discussing medical insurance with another tweet who is confused about whether the vaccine is free or not.
This tweet is inherently pro-vaccine because it promotes India's president, Modi, by featuring his discussion with members of a COVID-19 vaccination program.
This tweeter says that anti-vaxxers turn every tragedy into their agenda. For example, if someone dies, anti-vaxxers blame it on vaccines, he says.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx and accuses government officials of mandating vaccines while being rich -- he says one governor should enjoy her mansion. This tweet claims that COVID-19 transmission rates were going down and asks why vaccines are being mandated for health care workers.
criticism_other: Health care workers quitting due to mandates

meaning: This tweet reports that a pop-up vaccination clinic has "unfortunately" been postponed. But it says that there will be more chances to get vaccinated in the future days.

This tweeter is likely anti-vaxx because they posted an article by TIME Magazine, which is reputable, about how fake vaccines were administered in Indonesia. Another mass vaccination campaign was made with real vaccines. This is a real story, but the tweeter posted it with the intention of creating vaccine hesitation.
This tweeter is poorly written and hard to understand but it includes a pro-vaccine hashtag (#getvaccinated). The tweet discusses a new vaccine that could possibly be effective for all variants.
User claims that the highest rates of Covid infection are among those who are vaccinated, even when accounting for mask wearing and other safety measures.

Tweet is responding to a NYT article published in October 2021 saying unvaccinated children are at lower risk than the vaccinated elderly. User provides this as evidence for the argument that children should not be vaccinated, calling it "potentially harmful"

Tweet is part of a long thread by a user explaining how Bill Gates and other forces in big pharma have blocked low income countries from developing and manufacturing their own vaccines. User is critical of the U.S mantra that market forces are the best way to solve issues of supply and demand, and claims that wealthy countries restricting access to the vaccine has prolonged the pandemic.
User seems to quoting a popular figure who was remarking on how hesitant Black Americans can be about the vaccine. Appears to be facetious, but unclear if it is pro or anti vaccine.
criticism_other: the black community (for being suspicious of vaccination)

meaning: A tweet which is mostly word-vomit, but it criticises how vaccine mandates don't apply to elected officials.

A tweet about how the risk to reward ratio of the vaccine makes it reasonable for people to refuse it. It undervalues the protection it provides from severe infection and over-estimates the occurrences of adverse reactions.
This is a news article that contains no personal opinion about vaccines. It announces that booster shots were cleared for use by the FDA.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is promoting vaccines by debunking the words of an anti-vaxxer within a thread. This tweet says that unvaccinated people spread COVID-19 more frequently than vaccinated people. They also say that the vaccine is not 100% to be realistic.
This anti-vaxx tweeter, who's listed as living in South Africa, says no to vaccine mandates.
This tweeter doesn't really take a stance about the vaccine, rather they say that people have lost their minds over vaccine mandates.
This anti-vaxxer claims that a young girl had a vaccine injury - multiple sclerosis - as a result of taking the COVID-19 vaccine. A link is provided to a bogus website to support this tweet.

This is a part of a thread about how people ought to be concerned about the long term effects of COVID, and how masks are a better defence against COVID than vaccines. They argue it is better to prevent transmission, and masks effectively do so.
A tweet in response to inaccurate data, correcting the statistics and the effect that the vaccine had on Sweden's COVID death rate.
A tweet criticising Trump for his response to the pandemic, arguing that his actions directly caused the deaths of 800,000 Americans and who knows how many others abroad.

A reply to a video of police checking vaccination status and enforcing fines. It ridiculously equating vaccine hesitancy and public health measures to racial discrimination. Arguing that Black people are unvaccinated and Democrats would be for their right to deny the vaccine because of their race.
A tweet linking to an article that is factual, but deceiving because it discusses the possibility of Myocarditis as if it is a probable outcome of getting vaccinated rather than a rare side effect.
A tweet about how a health group withdrew the need for their doctors to be vaccinated, but still encouraged them to get the vaccine even though it is no longer mandated.
Tweeter implied that natural immunity, which is supposedly superior to COVID vaccines, is not being promoted because of an insincere motive.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines are safe because he had very mild side effects after getting a booster shot.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is scoffing at Sweden for dropping COVID-19 testing, while Denmark considers instating COVID-19 passports and testing to prevent the spread. A link to a Danish news article is included in this tweet.

This tweeter says that the leader of Tonga doesn't support vaccine mandates. Bitcoin is also mentioned in this tweet. Because Bitcoin is mentioned and no judgment is passed on the leader of Tonga's position on vaccine mandates, it's clear this tweet was made by an anti-vaxxer.

It's not entirely sure what this tweet is referring to, because a tweet earlier in the thread was removed, yet this tweet is pro-vaccine. The tweeter says their family members are all anti-vaxx and places a sad emoticon next to that sentiment to express dismay.

This tweet says that people complained about not getting vaccines, and then when they arrived, they went to waste. A letter from the Port of Spain was issued to say that those vaccines expired, and that a delay will happen before new ones arrive.

This tweet says that triple vaccinated people don't reflect on their choices after contracting COVID-19. The tweeter implies that vaccines are not effective because transmission still occurs, despite the fact that vaccines reduce the risk of serious illness.

A part of a sarcastic thread mocking conspiracy theorists. This user, part of the parody cult 'Church of the Subgenius', is making fun of people who thought there are aluminium based aliens / bacteria in the vaccine.
A tweet in reply to a chart of COVID deaths per million. This user does some mental gymnastics to assert that the vaccine is ineffective, and somehow increases the spread of COVID.
A tweet supporting anti-vaccine truckers, arguing we ought to let them make their choice otherwise the effects on the economy would be disastrous. It also says federal mandates are illegal.

A direct tweet of an article from the Guardian about an Australian politician who was harassed by an anti-vaccine 'journalist'. The article generally supports the politician and disregards the anti-mandate journalist.
A tweet arguing that children under 5 ought to get vaccinated, it makes it seem like it was a choice rather than a decision to wait for sufficient data to support the vaccine's safety in children.
A tweet about a vaccine clinic that's open late into the night.

A tweet alleging that the vaccine can spread from person to person. It's also part of a thread about how the vaccine was developed to secretly to harm to the general public and so it somehow spreads on its own to affect more people.
Tweeter implied that God apparently will tell a believer if they have COVID or if they need vaccines, not mainstream media, which is apparently lying on these matters.

This anti-vaxx tweeter tweeted a story made by The Post Millennial, to communicate that a child was denied a kidney transplant due to their vaccine status. The Post Millennial is a conservative opinion news site, that has been accused of publishing misleading news about COVID-19. The goal of this post is to build disgust towards vaccine mandates.
criticism_other: Denying health care due to vaccine status

meaning: This tweeter says that people who can't afford COVID-19 tests in the U.K. will suffer, while the rich will not. He says that cases are rising as of March 2022 and that less "well off" communities were getting "battered" by the virus.
criticism_other: Price of COVID-19 tests and their accessibility for the poor

meaning: This tweet says that articles about a specific COVID-19 booster are trending in the news today, which is pro-vaccine.
A tweet linking to a conspiracy theory website that alleges the Freemasons are a macabre organisation that invented smallpox and now COVID-19 along with the 'fake vaccine'.
The end of a thread defending vaccine and mask mandates, hammering home the point that they are safe, moral, and effective.
A tweet arguing mandates are morally wrong and people ought to have the right to choose if they want it or not.
A tweet arguing that mandates are irrational because vaccines are not entirely perfect in terms of preventing transmission and illness.

A reply to an article about natural immunity's superiority over vaccine immunity. This user says people ought to favour natural immunity, but getting sick intentionally will strain the health care system. It does not account for the fact both types of immunity fade.
Tweeter implied that anti-vaxxers who believe COVID vaccines are not safe because of the mRNA technology should opt for a COVID vaccine that is not based on that technology.
Tweeter implied that vaccines can prevent a high percentage of fatality from COVID 19 by comparing vaccination rates and COVID fatality rates of two countries.
This tweet is by a private Indian company letting its stakeholders know about the vaccine mandates at workplaces in Singapore.
Tweeter implied that governments are apparently committing heinous crimes such as massacres by enforcing vaccine mandates.

Part of an argument about the efficacy of vaccines, this tweet uses a photo of two boys with smallpox, one vaccinated the other not, to show the efficacy of the COVID vaccine. However they are different vaccines and the comparison isn't exactly fair.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx because they are angry that a vaccine was claimed to be designed in two day. This information is clearly misleading because nothing would be developed medically in two days.
