Link to a UK times article about one of the scientists behind the vaccine claiming Covid will eventually become as mild as the common cold and stop creating new variants. Published December 2021.
Tweet about an anti-vaccine protest in Stockholm Sweden against vaccine mandates and passports.

This anti-vaxx tweet shared a link to a Swiss Policy Research website, that depicts images of people on sports fields in pain. The images imply that vaccines are suffering cardiac issues from vaccination. The tweet also includes a quote that undermines the value of global vaccination campaigns.
A tweet about a map showing the distribution of vaccinations and infections, this user is criticising South Carolina for having low vaccination rates which led to high hospitalisations.

This post is against lockdowns, writing that they immiserate the working class and that forcing lockdowns in New York City, where the majority is already vaccinated, will not improve public health anyways.

This tweeter is angry at leaders who spread the narrative that the vaccinated cannot get and transmit COVID19. They write that they want to gently educate someone about this, but that is it hard to stay calm.

Tweeter is propagating a COVID conspiracy that politicians who support vaccine passports should be eliminated because they are apparently trying to control the population by injecting them with COVID vaccines.
Tweeter quoted a BMJ case report about a person developing several serious illnesses after receiving the Moderna COVID vaccine, but does not mention that part where rare side effects were mentioned.
Tweeter is implying that people who refuse to abide by the vaccine mandate are inviting trouble for themselves.
Tweeter is implying that vaccine mandates at workplaces breach an employee's right to privacy and confidentiality of their medical information, but tweeter forgets that the right is not absolute.
Tweet is part of a thread claiming the CDC and FDA cut corners on vaccine safety and rushed it to the public meaning it is dangerous and untested.

This is a news repost, yet it was deactivated from Twitter so it was likely used in an anti-vaxx context. The source is Reuters and the tweet is a simple quote from their article about how the U.S. Supreme Court blocked Biden's vaccination-or-testing mandate for large businesses.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is upset that Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, allowed a man to lie about vaccine safety. MSN reported that DeSantis "did not correct a city employee's false claim... about COVID-19 vaccines."

This misleading anti-vaxx tweet claims that people who got vaccinated may now be immune deficient. This tweet replied to an anti-vaxx doctor who promoted that triple vaxxed people are the most likely to die from COVID-19, which is not true.

This tweet is not promoting or criticizing anything, rather the person said that they are vaxxed and got the virus. I flagged this as "unsure" about the vaccine because while they are vaccinated, they could be undermining vaccine effectiveness by stating that the virus is possible to contract while vaccinated.

This anti-vaxxer replied to a pro-vaccine tweet from a Canadian government official. They say that the Quebec government set up a compensation system for people injured by the vaccine for a reason, and that it's not fair that those who died from the vaccine can't apply, which is true. What is confusing about this tweet is they mention anti-biotics which generally are not recommended while taking the vaccine - so it's not clear what the tweeter's point is other than instilling vaccine hesitation into readers.

This tweeter says that professional athlete Kyle Warner was injured by the vaccine, and that he lost his career as a result. 

Factcheck.org reported that "We asked Warner for evidence showing that his diagnosis was related to the vaccine and he provided us with a letter his cardiologist wrote to another doctor clearing him for an unrelated procedure. The letter, dated Sept. 22, said that Warner 'had myocarditis after a COVID-19 vaccination.' It went on, “a follow up cardiac MRI and stress test were normal.” 

Therefore, this post is misleading.

This anti-vaxx tweeter posted a video of Croatian MEP, Kolakusic, criticizing Macron for vaccine mandates. A video is included in the tweet of Kolakusic saying that vaccines kill people. 

Reuters reported that Kolakusic's "claim that tens of thousands of Europeans have died as a result of COVID-19 vaccines is based on a misreading of data." Therefore, this post is misleading.
This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccines are not effective. He says that the vaccine doesn't protect people from the virus, or from unvaccinated people.
This anti-vaxxer says that people were forced to get vaccines that they didn't "want or need." This is misleading because vaccines reduce the risk of serious illness.

This anti-vaxxer posted an opinion piece and quote from the Irish Times, which promotes testing for COVID-19 over simply mandating vaccines. Although this tweet relays this news post without passing personal comment, the tweet is clearly anti-vaxx because it implies that vaccines are not effective.
This tweeter seems to be making fun of people who are silly enough to go to jail for making fake vaccine cards out of a refusal to get vaccinated.

A tweet promoting the idea that Black folks need to be vigilantes, it promotes the idea people ought to resist vaccine mandates and fight against the media and government. It also links to a video of a group from Detroit making a speech about fighting crime with violence.

This tweeter claims that COVID-19 cases have gone up since mandatory vaccines were instated. This is an attempt to discredit vaccine effectiveness. There is no source information on the graph this tweeter posted to prove this, so it's not clear as to whether or not this information is accurate.

This tweeter tells readers that vaccines were invented to prevent hospitalizations, long COVID and deaths. She says vaccines weren't just to stop people from wearing masks, which implies she thinks that masks should still be worn.

I flagged this post as "unsure" about the vaccine because the tweeter seems to promote vaccines while showing a lack of approval for China's Zero COVID (implies mandate) policy. This tweeter seems to think that cases in Hong Kong would have gone down if there was no Zero COVID-19 policy in place.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that deaths resulting from the vaccination of people who didn't want to get vaccinated should be considered murder. This promotes conspiracy theories on a level because the tweet implies that a lot of people are being forced to get the vaccine, and are subsequently dying from it.
This pro-vaccine tweet says that vaccines are required to enter AAD annual meetings in Boston.

This tweet claims that more people died in Taiwan from the vaccine than they did from the COVID-19 virus. This information was fact-checked by Polygraph.info, and they reported that "The implication that vaccines might kill more people than COVID-19 is false. The report leaves out important context, is mathematically naïve and ignores abundant scientific evidence that vaccines are safe and effective."

This post is flagged as unsure about the vaccine because the tweeter is commenting on mandates rather than on vaccines. The tweeter is concerned that people would be treated as criminals as a result of not getting vaccinated, yet he says he understands that it's a necessary measure to curb the spread of COVID-19.

This tweeter is angry that front-lines workers were fired for not taking the vaccine, while they supported the public through the pandemic before vaccines were available. The tweeter says they support vaccination, but their message contains contradictory elements, therefore this tweet is flagged as "unsure" about the vaccine.
A tweet about how extreme conservative use anti vaccine protests as a guise for their true aims. Protests about vaccine mandates often include people with broader motivates.
This tweet is not for or against vaccines, rather it promotes alternative remedies. It says that glycyrrhizin is effective against SARS-CoV-2. This was confirmed in the national library of medicine.

This tweeter is not promoting or criticizing anything, other than terminology used around public health interventions. He says the NHS didn't make the Test and Trace program, which is misleading because the gov.uk website says that it is NHS.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that vaccinated people have a 1 in 5000 chance of contracting the virus, while unvaccinated people have a 50/50 chance. This is misleading. Health Manitoba reported that new cases of COVID-19 among unvaccinated people are 12 times higher than in the fully vaccinated people. This tweeter also bring class into the vaccine issue, stating that the rich are vaccinated while the poor are not.

This tweet is a quote from Dr. Robert Malone, who spread COVID-19 disinformation. He was banned from twitter. His quote in this tweet pushes natural immunity and claims that certain vaccines could hinder the U.S. population's "robust protection" against COVID-19. The quote was found in the EPOCH times - a right-wing news source -- which this tweeter posted here.

This anti-vaxxer replied to a person in a tweet who promoted vaccination. They asked why people should get vaccinated while natural immunity is effective. This is misleading because natural immunity is dangerous due to it's lack of ability to control.
A tweet about a doctor who has gone on the news to tell Canadians to take the first vaccine available to them.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says they're vaxxed for life on their twitter account. This tweet celebrates News 4 in San Antonio Texas for promoting vaccination.
A tweet about a college's vaccine policy, requiring all students to get booster shots.
This tweet promotes science and vaccines. It promotes examining how a stronger vaccine eco system can help meet challenges and needs.
This tweeter promotes Modi, the president of India, and a high vaccination rate in Goa.

This anti-vaxxer claims that tons of people have died as a result of vaccination. He claims that there is a 14 day rule for reporting deaths to VAERS, but nothing about that time frame was mentioned on the VAERS website.
This pro-vaccine tweeter comments on vaccine equity. The tweeter shared a link to a video panel discussion about equitable vaccine access and says that POTUS had no plans to scale up vaccine access.

This anti-vaxx tweeter mentions mask and vaccine mandates in relation to countries boycotting the Olympics (based on the thread this tweet is contained within). It's not clear exactly what this tweeter is trying to say, because it's so vague, but they're Twitter wall promotes natural immunity.

This anti-vaxxer takes issue with Kieran Moore who they say said that vaccines don't prevent transmission but that large venues can still operate because vaccine passports work. This tweeter is trying to say that vaccine passports are not useful because vaccines don't prevent transmission.
This tweet from a suspended account shares a link to the Joe Rogan podcast episode with Robert Malone, who is known for spreading misinformation about the mRNA vaccine.
This post criticizes the liberal government in Australia for prioritizing vaccines in liberal states for political reasons, and for mismanaging disaster funding in the country.
A tweet about how it can sometimes be problematic to engage with certain ideas, far right ideas, in public discourse, especially things like ivermectin and vaccine denial.
This anti-vaxx tweeter asks some other tweeters how they can admit that vaccines won't actually save them. This implies that the tweeter doesn't believe in vaccine effectiveness.

A tweet about the Covaxin vaccine, this user says they had a great experience with Covaxin. It criticises the American government, WHO, and other governments for not approving Covaxin because this tweet argues Covaxin could have saved lives.

This anti-vaxxer is replying to a pro-vaccine person who supported the mandatory vaccination of athletes. This tweeter replied by questioning how well the vaccine works, when people are concerned about other people's vaccine statuses even though they themselves are vaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweet says that an education secretary in the U.K. vowed to tackle anti-vaxx harassment at schools.

This pro-science tweeter says that vaccines are a good protocol for protecting children from Long COVID, but that HEPA air filters can help even more. Air filters can reduce air born infections and pollution within a room.
This tweet relays information from a Washington Post article about the upcoming availability of vaccines for children. Therefore, this tweet is pro-vaccine.

This anti-vaxx, anti-lockdown Tweeter claims that COVID-19 is an ordinary illness. He also says that his mom is in an ICU and that everyone there is vaccinated. This is an attempt at undermining vaccine effectiveness. He also says lockdowns created problems but he didn't give specifics on that.
This post criticizes a group of anti-vaxxers for saying they are only anti mandate, yet they do not wear masks or social distance. The post shares pictures of a large event with unmasked people.

In response to a picture of Donald Trump with a sign that says he made three COVID19 vaccines, this post writes that it was actually Dolly Parton who made the vaccine, because she donated one million dollars towards the Moderna shot.
This satirical tweet writes that according to QAnon, a fictional virus hits Wakanda in Black Panther 2, killing all except the one who refuses to take an evil vaccine.
This post announces that pilots for Southwest and American Airlines, engineers for Amtrak, and air traffic controllers are staging sickout to protest vaccine mandates.

This anti-vaxxer tweeted a video from Dr. Nick Zyrowski, who seems more like a sales person than a doctor. The video intends to promote alternative remedies rather than science. And, it claims that there are unintended consequences to the mRNA vaccine.

This tweeter says that the WHO advises against travel bans in light of Omicron. This is verified information from the BBC. The tweeter also appears to be anti-vaxx because they say that "measures we took before the vaccine" are more important than ever, such as distancing and masking.
This pro-vaccine tweeter posted a video to celebrate high vaccination rates in India. The tweeter also celebrates Modi for leading the vaccination effort.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx. He said that a band (name not provided) is not authentic because they demanded vaccine passports at their shows. The tweeter calls such mandates "propaganda."

This post criticizes January 6th Capitol rioters for complaining about vaccine mandates in jail. By denying unvaccinated inmates visitors and other services, writes the post, the jail seems to be protecting them from COVID19.

This post criticizes Tucker Carlson for thinking it’s boring that eight hundred thousand Americans have died from COVID19, when he and other Fox News anchors are responsible for deaths by lying about masks and vaccines.
This post argues that it is unnecessary to get vaccinated against COVID19 because natural immunity is better than vaccine-induced immunity. It shares a journal article from Science as alleged proof.

In reply to a tweet calling for people to be considerate of those who continue to take COVID19 safety precautions, this post says that the vaccinated do not deserve respect because they have been disrespectful themselves, tasered children, and enforced vaccine passports.

In response to a tweet that the New Zealand government will be scaring citizens into getting vaccinated against COVID19, this post writes that this seems to already have happened, given the long lines outside of vaccination centres.
This post announces that debt renegotiation and vaccine equity are the focus of the 2021 Africa Economic Conference.

This tweet about a World Health Organization press conference writes that those over the age of 45 with co-morbidities are most at risk for the Omicron variant, and that there is currently no evidence of reduced vaccine efficacy amid Omicron.

This tweeter is making fun of Kyrie Irving for his anti-vaxx beliefs. A video was included in this post, to joke about "smart-dumb" people. And the text of the tweet makes fun of Irving's ideas that vaccines install a microchip in people.
This tweet is pro-vaccine. It provides information about how India's government is expanding their vaccination program of kids. It also says that boosters for people over 60 will be provided.
support_other: Vaccination of kids, boosters for seniors

meaning: This post is against the COVID19 vaccine. It argues that vaccines leave people vulnerable to contracting and transmitting diseases, getting sick and dying from those diseases, cause myocarditis in kids, and are therefore not safe nor effective.
This tweeter writes that a High School in New York was closed due to a positive COVID19 case, and that no vaccinated students were being quarantined or tested.

This post shares an article from Becker News about the Czech Prime Minister ending vaccine mandates in Czechia to avoid deepening the rifts in society. The mainstream narrative, it writes, is crumbling.
This post announces that Italy is considering implementing COVID19 vaccine passports to access public places, and that a negative test result would not be accepted in lieu of a passport.
This post announces a walk-in clinic for COVID19 vaccinations and boosters in Derbyshire, England for anyone over the age of sixteen.
This post writes that according to interim estimates, this season’s influenza vaccine has not been effective, with only sixteen percent effectiveness. It shares an article from Healio.
This post announces that a nasal vaccine for Alzheimer’s disease is set to begin phase 1 clinical trials.
This post writes that those who defend vaccines are Nazis. It shares an article from the right-wing Western Journal website.

This post shares an NPR article about COVID disparities that persist for Black Americans, including lower vaccination rates. It criticizes anti-vaxx rhetoric and writes that there are lessons to be learned for the future.

This post argues that since Israel was slammed with the delta variant, despite having one of the highest vaccination rates in the world, it shows that vaccines are not effective in stopping the pandemic. It criticizes the vaccinated for blaming the unvaccinated.
This post shares a news article from The Hill about Donald Trump pushing back on Candace Owens’ claim that people are dying from the COVID19 vaccine.
This post writes that a small group of rich and powerful people, including the WHO, WEF, and UN, are producing and distributing the COVID19 vaccine with the objective of depopulation.
This post announces that Nigeria is expected to receive millions of Pfizer COVID19 vaccine doses. It also celebrates current vaccination rates in Nigeria.
This tweeter criticizes vaccine effectiveness and those who advocate for vaccines, writing that their mother got both doses and now has COVID19.
This post shares a CNN News article about fourth COVID19 vaccine doses being necessary, according to the CEO of Pfizer. It implies that this is proof the vaccine is ineffective and unreasonable.

This post criticizes vaccine passports, writing that if they were effective, there wouldn’t be spikes of infections in France, Germany, and Ireland, necessitating the closure of bars and nightclubs again. It criticizes punishing hospitality businesses.

This tweeter is an interesting mix of pro-vaccine yet freedom of choice. He says that he's vaxxed yet that he doesn't need unvaccinated people to get vaxxed to protect him - he claims that would be anti-science, meaning he believes his vaccine will protect him.

This is a news repost from a political organization in Georgia about how the FDA didn't recommend booster shots in Sept.2021. No personal opinion is included in this post, therefore it's flagged as "unsure" about the vaccine.
This tweeter calls Fox News anchors cowards because they are vaccinated - while FOX has vaccine mandates as of Dec.2021 - but push narratives about "vaccine authoritarianism" on their news channel.

This tweeter asks a pro-vaccine tweeter why they would worry about getting vaccinated when a person can still pass the virus despite being vaccinated. This tweet implies that vaccines are not effective, given transmission and contraction of the virus is still possible after vaccination.

This tweeter doesn't like mRNA vaccines, therefore this post is labelled as anti-vaxx. They compared the COVID-19 vaccine to a number of other vaccines, saying the COVID-19 vaccine is not as long lasting as polio or the measles vaccines.

This tweeter promotes vaccines because he criticizes vaccine shortages in Australia. This seems to be a comment on the inequity involved with pandemic life, while he says that some people are unemployed, or relying on charity to eat meals.
criticism_other: Vaccine shortages, rich people, police response

meaning: This tweeter is likely an anti-vaxxer because they said that there are less people working in hospitals due to vaccine mandates.
This tweeter writes that they decided to see two shows at the Kennedy center, where proof of vaccination is required, while COVID19 cases are relatively low.
This post claims that no coronavirus vaccines have been put out for mass vaccination because they have all has serious problems during development.
This tweeter announces that they have not caught COVID19, and that they have received three doses of the vaccine, and wear their mask everywhere they go.

This tweeter clearly supports republicans. He says that the democrats are "demons" and are killing the American people. This tweeter gives examples of that as: vaccine mandates, "illegals" and rising food and gas prices.
This pro-vaccine tweeter replied to someone who said that the media loves BLM protests but not union protests. This tweeter claims that tweeter is racist and anti-vaxx by making that observation.
This tweeter seems to be promoting a headline or content from a whack news site. The tweet does not contain any personal opinion and is therefore flagged as "unsure."
This anti-vaxxer claims that there's a 0.00001 chance of dying from COVID-19 and that there's therefore no reason to take the vaccine, which is dangerous and misleading.
This tweet doesn't include personal opinion, rather it asks whether kids should get the COVID-19 vaccine. It includes a link to a newspaper that is not in English language.

This tweeter is not really promoting or criticizing anything, rather he says that he knows people he thought were reasonable who now refuse to get vaccinated. He also says that mandates would be hard to pull off in Germany.
This post criticizes Republicans, writing that we should blame them for school closures because if they took the vaccine and masked up, remote learning would not be necessary.

This anti-vaxx tweeter criticized another tweeter for saying they may have had brain damage before being vaccinated and that they like booster shots. The tweet implies that brain damage is a requirement for liking vaccines.
criticism_other: Vaccine boosters, people you get vaccinated

meaning: This anti-vaxxer tells readers that the vaccine doesn't stop transmission, which is true. But she neglects to say that the vaccine reduces the possibility of severe death.
This tweeter says that some elderly people died in a care home because they couldn't get the vaccine. This tweeter is angry that there was a vaccine shortage in Australia that lead to those deaths.

This post writes that in a coronavirus outbreak in a hospital in Ichilov, Tel Aviv, Israel, ten staff members tested positive for COVID19 after receiving both doses of the vaccine. It implies that the vaccine is ineffective and dangerous.

This tweet promotes a doctor, Peter McCullough, who notoriously promoted hydroxychloroquine at the beginning of the pandemic. McCullough contributed to COVID-19 misinformation, yet this tweeter is promoting an Epoch Times article that features his opinion.
This tweeter says that people shouldn't fake vaccine passports to attend shows. She says that is a rude thing to do, and that she doesn't want to see that happen when she's on tour.

This anti-vaxxer replied to a tweet regarding Howard Stern, who said that hospitals should turn anti-vaxxers away from getting treatment. This tweeter made a sarcastic comment about how that would not actually motivate people to get vaccinated.
criticism_other: Howard stern, rejecting anti-vaxxers at hospitals

meaning: This tweeter is upset that Nigerians can buy fake vaccine passports, without being vaccinated.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says he wants his booster dose because it will give him more protection as well as it will use doses that will otherwise go to waste in North Carolina. Various news reports released information that NC did waste hundreds of thousands of vaccines.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that lockdowns, masking and vaccinations did work to slow the spread of the pandemic, which is not true. This tweeter has a Pepe the Frog profile picture, which indicates they come from a hateful spectrum of the far-right.
This tweeter is posted a quote from a science.org article that says rich countries have a much higher vaccination rate than poor countries.
Tweeter is implying that people should not trust scientists, public health officials, and governments because nothing they said about the vaccine is apparently true.
Tweeter implied that the CDC director spoke against the vaccine mandate by admitting that vaccines cannot stop Omicron transmission.
Tweeter is making a baseless assumption that public health authorities wronged people who died from the side effects of COVID vaccines because they might not have died from COVID.

This tweeter supports the Trucker Convoy and the end of vaccine mandates. They posted news about about how the OOIDA trucker's union. OOIDA called for the end of vaccine mandates for truckers working between the U.S. and Canada border.

This anti-vaxx tweet says that "globalists" promote the vaccine and that former Pfizer CEO Yeadon has concerns about the vaccine. Yeadon, though, lost his career and promoted medical misinformation throughout the pandemic, so it doesn't matter if he has concerns about the vaccine.

This tweeter promotes a news article from The Defender, which reports that healthcare vaccine mandates were allowed to go forward in the U.S. The tweeter is clearly anti-vaxx because this site is filled with disinformation about vaccine injuries.
This tweeter says his friend got vaccinated, and then was able to renew his car maintenance warranty. This is pro-vaccine because he equates something positive as a result of getting vaccinated.

This tweeter clearly supports the trucker convoy. He replied to a woman who said that vaccines lower the chance of death, not transmission. This tweeter asks her if she agrees that unvaxxed and vaccinated truckers pose the same level of risks.

This anti-vaxxer shared a link, who's video is deactivated, to an anti-vaccine site. The site had a headline "Dr. Noack is convinced that the vaccine contains nanoscale graphene hydroxide razor blades that cut through the vein causing internal bleeding." This is obviously a conspiracy theory site.

This tweet doesn't promote or criticize anything, rather it's a repost of quotes from Mayor Lightfoot who announced public health information at a University. It's inherently pro-vaccine because the post promotes science.
This tweet shows a video of Calgary's mayor standing up for real and verified COVID-19 information. The tweeter is a journalist and describes the mayor as going on the attack.

This post argues that since Israel was slammed with the delta variant, despite having one of the highest vaccination rates in the world, it shows that vaccines are not effective in stopping the pandemic. It criticizes the vaccinated for blaming the unvaccinated.

This tweet is not really clear, because it's not possible to see the tweet that came before it while it's deactivated. But this tweeter calls out another person for posting bogus data as well as a chart from a "far-right" magazine (not the WHO). This makes me inclined to think they are pro-vaccine.

This anti-vaxx tweeter has World Economic Forum's The Great Reset as his profile cover page. That means he's into conspiracy theories. He's posting data here to try to claim vaccines are not effective, it's confusing and senseless and not worth trying to understand.
This post writes that COVID19 vaccines help reduce spread, serious illness, long covid, hospitalizations, and death, and help protect the community.

This tweeter implies that vaccine boosters are spreading the virus. They say the cases sky rocketed amidst the third vaccine in Gibraltar. The tweeter posted a link to a chart with information but it's not clear what the source is.
This tweet promotes flu vaccines and tells readers where they can get them.
This tweeter says that people have been getting COVID-19 after being vaccinated, which is true. But this post likely attempts to undermine vaccine effectiveness.
Tweeter presented an unverified news report about a vaccinated soccer player who apparently died, while on the field, from heart issues because of the COVID vaccine.
Tweeter shared a report from the far-right website Breitbart on the Texan Republican Governor vowing to fight against Biden's vaccine mandate.

This anti-vaxxer claims that the FDA was "forced" to "admit" that their vaccines cause rare heart problems. This is a critique on vaccine safety, the FDA and politicians or government. The tweet hints at conspiracy theories, because it claims the FDA hid information about vaccines.

This anti-vaxxer posted a link to an article about how a group of doctors signed a petition to stop the vaccination of children ages 12 - 15 years old. The tweeter says they have been demonized and smeared for having anti-vaxx beliefs.
This anti-vaxxer calls the 90% herd immunity goal a "lie" from two years ago. They say that officials stopped printing COVID-19 "rates" when they stop fascilitating the COVID-19 narrative.

This anti-vaxx tweeter posted a video to a politician who says that the "Big Pharma" companies will not be responsible for any vaccine injuries, that governments will. The tweet calls this an "international criminal conspiracy," indicating his beliefs in conspiracy theories.

This tweeter is clearly anti-vaxx because they are promoting discussion around myocarditis and pericarditis, which are two medical issues that anti-vaxxers to refer to. The myocarditisfoundation.org does say that testosterone enhances the likelihood of getting myocarditis, as this tweeter claims.
This tweet is by a news website about Twitter adding unsafe labels to disputed to certain COVID vaccine research but the news could not be verified.

This anti-vaxx tweeter posted a link to a video featuring Dr.Malone, who promoted misinformation about vaccines throughout the pandemic. The tweeter also tagged politicians and public health officials, as a form of criticism towards them but also to bring this video to their attention.
Tweeter implied that Donald Trump Jr. should not call White House tweet about the unvaccinated mean, because he himself is vaccinated and is aware of the benefit for vaccination.

This anti-vaxxer claims that a 14 year old boy, Joshua, died from the COVID-19 vaccine. But the Carribean News reported that "Guyana’s Ministry of Health confirmed that a “pre-existing condition” is what caused Joshua Henry’s death on Monday and not the Pfizer coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccine"
Tweeter implied that the U.K. government does not need to impose COVID restrictions such as lockdowns as vaccines are preventing a large portion of the population from hospitalization due to COVID.
This tweeter says that vaccines reduce the spread of COVID-19, by making dangerous variants less likely to emerge.
This tweeter says that Steve Inman, a sports commentator, marched alongside Trump's support group against vaccines. This is anti-vaxx by nature.

This post by People’s Daily in China announces that Sinopharm’s new vaccines to target the Delta and Beta variants of COVID19 are very effective according to a Chief Scientist of the China National Biotec Group.

A tweet about how the government is intentionally dividing people with a vaccine that hasn't been vetted. The tweet is in all caps to get Americans to 'Wake Up!" It implies conspiracy between pharmaceutical companies, wealthy elite, and politicians.

This post criticizes a tweet that calls for everything to open again, given that we now have good vaccines and anti-viral pills. The post argues that the immunocompromised, those too young to vaccinated, and burnt-out heath care workers need to be considered.

A tweet about how the pandemic won't get end unless people embrace vaccines and public health interventions. It also addresses how the government is just as torn as the people are when it comes to vaccines and pandemic responses.
Tweeter is criticizing the vaccine mandate and Australian province Victoria's premier for enforcing it, saying that the mandate discriminates against people who do not want to vaccinate.
Tweeter implied that WHO chief should be invited to South Africa and punished because he apparently works for vaccine manufacturers and promote unsafe vaccines.
Tweeter wants to cut ties with people on Twitter if they support the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter appears to hold pharmaceutical companies responsible for vaccines apparently not working because people require booster shots for further protection.
This tweet doesn't promote or criticize vaccines, rather it reports that Oregon's regulators were preparing to enforce Biden's COVID-19 rules. The tweet was made by Oregon's Public Broadcaster.
This post shares an article about a baby boy in India's Palghar District, who died three days after his regular infant immunizations. The cause of death is under investigation, writes the article.

This post criticizes the Supreme Court’s decision to block the Biden administration’s mandate for mandatory vaccination against COVID19 in the workplace. It shares an article from The Atlantic, which argues that the divided culture in the United States has warped the court’s judgement.
A tweet criticising the news for focusing on the Ukraine crisis instead of convincing people vaccine mandates are unnecessary and wrong.
This post by Charlie Kirk writes that 2020 came with black squares, 2021 with vaccine cards, and 2022 with Ukrainian flags.
This tweeter appears to be pro-vaccine, however he posted a Fox News video on his twitter, that shows he is growing concerned about vaccine effectiveness.
This pro-vaccine tweet promotes a global response to vaccines. A link is provided to prove that Community Health Volunteers are in Malawi, giving COVID-19 support.
This is a news related post from about an article from the Bureau of Investigative Journalism. The topic is COVAX and how it failed to vaccinate the world. No personal opinion is added to this tweet.
Tweeter is implying that the CEO of a U.K. Hospital is wrong in mandating vaccines for hospital staff because it apparently goes against Good Medical Practice standards and amounts to coercion.

This tweeter has three vaccines, however this post is anti-vaxx because she complains about side effects she claims to have received from the vaccine, such as Tinnitus, high blood pressure and a high heart rate.
This pro-vaccine tweet seems to take a pro-MODI stance, while claiming that opposition parties made "irresponsible" statements about COVID-19.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that millions of people can't access vaccines, and that that's a big problem.

This anti-vaxx tweet, which is a news repost made by Breitbart news, claims that SouthWest airlines cancelled 1800 flights due to vaccine mandates and staff shortages. Businessinsider.com reported though that there is no evidence of this being true, because the mandates were not in effect until nearly 6 weeks after this news report was released.
In response to a tweet encouraging people to get vaccinated against COVID19, this post argues that vaccines will not get us back to our lives and that vaccination is about control.
This post by André Picard from the Globe and Mail criticizes the lack of urgency in Canada’s response to the COVID Omicron variant.
criticism_other: Lack of urgency in pandemic response

meaning: This tweeter promotes public health interventions, and thanks those who supported them, in this tweet. He also says that conservatives are using their own watered down logic in a reply to a previous tweet.
This is a pro-vaccine post that promotes vaccines to Victoria, Australia.
This post by the India Ministry of Health gives a COVID19 vaccination update, including the number of vaccines administered and the number still available.
This post by Fox News commentator Tomi Lahren criticizes COVID19 vaccination, writing that children are being bribed with pizza to get vaccinated without parent consent.

This post criticizes the trucker convoy in Canada, writing that the majority of Canadians are vaccinated and trust the government to get us out of the pandemic. The truckers do not represent the majority, it says.

This post argues that the push for vaccinations in South Africa is about filling a quota, not about health. It says that herd immunity has already been achieved because three out of four South Africans have had COVID19, so there should not be a push to vaccinate amid Omicron.

In response to a thread where astrology is being attacked for being similarly harmful to flat earth believers and QAnon, this post writes that the vaxx/anti-vaxx divide is eclipsing traditional societal divides and that they’re not surprised Astrology is being dragged into it.
This tweeter says that doctors are guilty for giving vaccines. This is clearly anti-vaxx and it promotes skepticism towards medical health professionals.
This tweet, made by the Economist, reveals an article about how new vaccines may need to be developed to suppress COVID-19 transmission.
This anti-vaxxer says that the benefits of getting vaccinated are more about not loosing a job, rather than the vaccine being effective.
criticism_other: Loosing jobs over not getting vaccinated

meaning: This post is against vaccines. In response to a tweet asking why we’re not testing for COVID19 antibodies, this post writes that it is because that would prove that millions of people do not need the vaccine.
This post criticizes anti-vaxxers, writing that those who still believe vaccines cause autism or infertility are dicks.
This post writes that vaccinations are violence against children, and that this should be what we are most worried about right now.
This tweeter is asking people to speak up if vaccines made their holiday celebrations possible in 2021, which is pro-vaccine.
This tweeter said she spoke up against vaccine mandates. She wants mandates to leave first responders alone.
This post by the bioRxiv Microbiology journal shares an article about the COVID19 Delta variant being poised to acquire resistance to wild-type spike vaccines.
In response to a post about COVID19 infection and quarantining, this tweet writes that they hope for a quick recovery and short quarantine time.

This is a tweet revealing a video of Tucker Carlson on Fox News. Tucker tells the story of Brian Stelter (CNN) and how he fired his nanny for not getting vaccinated. This tweet clearly presents Stelter as an evil man, and generates anti-vaxx sentiments.
criticism_other: Firing a nanny for not getting vaccinated

meaning: This sarcastic post by a physician criticizes a group of anti-vaxxers for protesting a non-mandatory vaccine.

This post questions why vaccination mandates continue in New York despite one full year of the vaccine, availability of COVID19 treatments, and knowing that vaccines do not stop the spread of COVID19.
This post criticizes former vice-president of the Philippines, Leni Robredo, for focusing her political platform on the fight against COVID19 amid lowering infection rates and high vaccination.
This post claims that a COVID19 vaccine database was hacked and personal information was obtained.
Tweeter is implying that his elderly relatives and neighbours' deaths were caused by the COVID vaccine. But he does not say if any these people already had pre-existing health conditions.
This anti-vaxx tweeter calls schools that have vaccine mandates "jerkoff" schools. The tweeter says that his sister never had a problem, despite not being vaxxed, with her job in West Hampton Beach.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is upset that a patient was not screened for COVID-19 when they were brought into the hospital. He says that other patients died as a result of contracting the virus. The tweeter says immunocompromised and elderly people must be treated carefully. He shared another tweeter's post to support this tweet.
criticism_other: Lack of screening for COVID in hospitals

meaning: This tweeter says that Scott Morrison did not effectively answer how he made efforts to get Australians vaxxed.

This is a news post about how Omicron is somewhat "resistant" to vaccines. Medical News today and other news sources reported that "BA.4/BA.5 Omicron subvariants over 4 times more resistant to mRNA vaccines."
A tweet saying the risks of the vaccine outweigh the benefits, which is plainly untrue.
Tweeter is implying that vaccination would not eradicate coronavirus rather it would accelerate mutation of the virus, which is partially true. Vaccines could drive mutants but the process is slow.
Tweeter, a Toronto Star reporter, shared his report on Ontario's alcohol and gaming regular revoking license of businesses that do not abide by the vaccine passport rules.

A tweet linking to an article from an independent journalist about a bill to fine businesses for forcing their employees to get vaccinated and those employees suffer vaccine injuries. The proposed fine is $1M and the user seems excited about the idea.
This post shares a New York Times article about New York City setting sweeping vaccine mandates for all private employers.
This post advocates against forced vaccinations.
This pro-vaccine tweet breaks down why some people don't want to be vaccinated. They list vaccine hesitancy (complacency, confidence and convenience) as reasons why.
This woman is reposting information about vaccination rates and death rates in the U.S. She uses graphs to prove her points that are sourced as The New York Times.

This tweeter writes that the number of children in the United States that have been diagnosed with Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome is much higher than those diagnosed with the flu. They write that they will vaccinate their child against COVID19 if the vaccine gets licensed.

In response to a tweet about police officers and firefighters who were fired for not complying with the vaccine mandate feeding the homeless in Seattle, this post sarcastically remarks that the vaccine mandate finally made the police care about people.
Tweeter is arguing that Republicans are responsible for the spread of the new variant because they are promoting misinformation about the vaccines, and encouraging people not to get vaccinated.
This anti-vaxxer says they stand up against various things, including vaccine mandates. Other things on their list include: forced sterilisation, medical experiments and organ harvesting.
criticism_other: Organ harvesting, forced sterlisation, medical experiments

meaning: This tweeter mentions vaccines but is not about COVID-19. It's about International Financial Reporting Standards wearing accountants down. He says there's no vaccine to protect workers against IFRS.

In response to an anti-vaxxer, this post writes that excess deaths during the COVID19 pandemic are not correlated to vaccines at all. It celebrates the effectiveness of vaccines in reducing death rates from COVID19.
This post criticizes those who are scared of the COVID19 vaccine.
This post is part of a twitter argument about the COVID19 vaccine. It writes that scientists do not know how vaccines work because so many vaccines have been found to be unsafe down the road.

This post shares a Globe and Mail article about the former Head of Vaccine Development and Antiviral Therapies at Canada’s top infectious disease lab, who was fired, collaborating with Chinese Major General Chen Wei on Ebola research.
This post criticizes the Myanmar government Junta for using COVID19 as a weapon to willfully create a superspreader country and block aid.

This tweeter seems to be making a comment on the cost of vaccines by saying he'd stay on a COVID-19 IV drip if he had millions. It's not clear if he's anti-vaxx, but based on his wall, he could be so I flagged this post as such.
This tweeter says she's vaccinated, indicating a pro-vaccine status. But she clearly states that she will never wear a mask again.

This post shares the story of someone who, after receiving the first dose of the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine, had five heart attacks within five months. It implies that the vaccine caused this, and that it is dangerous and should be avoided.

This post writes that the streetlight localized lockdown system is a tool that might be implemented again in the future if there is a new COVID19 variant or bad outbreak in a place with low vaccination levels.
This post writes that the vaccinated are disease vectors and that everyone who is unvaccinated has already had COVID19 and is now enjoying long-lasting and effective immunity against the disease.
This post is intended to discredit a physician on twitter who recommends vaccinating children against preventable diseases including COVID19, by questioning why there is no RSV vaccine.
This post criticizes the Biden administration and mainstream media. It writes that they are keeping the real science of the pandemic hidden, and that the fully vaccinated are the ones dying.
This tweet is by a news website sharing an article about booster shot availability before it was approved last fall.
Tweeter is explaining to another user that because vaccines are not 100 percent effective, unvaccinated people can still spread the virus to the vaccinated population.

This anti-vaxxer has #MAGA all over his twitter feed. This tweet celebrates an attorney in the U.S. for standing up against an investigation into how critical race theory is being taught in schools, meaning, he's racist.
criticism_other: Removing Critical Race Theory from schools

meaning: This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccines are not effective because he says there are different "profiles" on how vaccines are working in different countries. He shared another tweet that contains HOLD graphics to prove this. HOLD appears to be an intelligence company, it's not clear how reputable they are.
This tweeter says that "elites" are pointing their fingers at the unvaccinated. They say that if vaccines were effective, then those elites wouldn't be upset about unvaccinated people.
This tweeter says that COVID-19 vaccine passports lead to "total population control," which indicates his interest in conspiracy theories.
criticism_other: Total Population Control and CBDC passports

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that 50 deaths resulted from the swine flu vaccines. But fullfact.org reported that "Full Fact could not find a confirmed number of deaths reported after a swine flu vaccine in 1976, but reports suggest that a number of the deaths could not be directly linked with the vaccine. The rollout was halted because of a number of reports of Guillain-Barré syndrome, and the fact the swine flu cases never reached pandemic levels."

This tweeter criticizes the safety of the COVID19 vaccine, writing that they would rather continue being healthy and not being able to enter public places, rather than getting sick and compromising their immune system from the vaccine.

This tweeter says that Brian Tamaki, a fundamentalist Christian, makes all anti-vaxxers look bad. This is an anti-vaxx post, because this person implies that not all vaccine-opposed people are like that.
This post criticizes those vaccinated against COVID19, writing that they are getting infected and spreading the disease, while the unvaccinated with natural immunity do not transmit the virus.
This post criticizes anti-vaxxers, writing that they are free to deny the COVID19 vaccine but also free to be denied employment, government benefits, and entry to businesses.
In response to a high profile person saying that the vaccine did not do anything, this post comments that this is a big deal and almost a break in the narrative.
Tweeter implied that a Belgian court declaring vaccine passport as illegal and imposing a penalty on the regional government for enforcing it is a piece of good news.

Tweeter appears to mock Nicki Minaj's tweet about COVID vaccine and impotency sharing the link of another Nicki who has a different take on vaccines. But context is not clear as the tweet is no longer live.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says the U.S. should make it illegal to deny health care based on vaccine status.
criticism_other: Hospitals denying care based on vaccine status
support_other: Health care regardless of vaccine status

meaning: This anti-vaxxer says that deaths and injuries happened from "experimental" vaccines. She says that psychopathic overlords coerced people into vaccination.
This pro-vaccine tweeter criticizes ABC News for saying that American remains polarized over the vaccine, despite 80% of the country being vaccinated.

This post shares an article from USA Today about the urgent need for vaccine manufacturers around the world to produce the COVID19 vaccine to get the pandemic under control. It calls for companies to waive IP rights and share knowledge.
This tweeter says that there is not a variant that isn't susceptible to vaccines. This tweeter is pro-vaccine, which is indicated by their posts on their profile.
This post shares a link to the CDC COVID19 data tracker, and lists the latest United States vaccination numbers, including the number of people that received one and two doses.

This tweeter is angry that a hospital may require vaccination "that don't work." They posted a link to a website called "Alphanews" which seems far-right in their politics. The headline was "U of M admits vax doesn’t stop transmission, will ‘probably’ mandate boosters anyway."
This post from a suspended twitter account compares the Russian troops in Ukraine to the Ottawa police preparing to advance on anti-vaxx and anti-vaccine-mandate protestors.
This post shares a Forbes article about the COVID19 vaccine passport, and speculates that it will drive the field of digital ID technology, making it about more than just the pandemic.

A tweet about how even people who have taken the vaccine can be against it, it's unsure if in this case the person was vaccinated and then changed their mind about the vaccine or if they were vaccinated because of social pressure.

A tweet linking to a Guardian article about a British politician's connection to a hedge fund with hundreds of millions invested in Moderna. The tweet argues if the politician had no shares in Moderna he would just say so, but instead he dodges questions related to his potential Moderna shares which fosters mistrust for the government.

Tweeter shared an article from Project Veritas, a news site with questionable sources, that Pfizer hid information about the use of fetal cells in vaccine development for some supposed sinister reasons.

Tweeter implied because they did not get vaccinated they have zero possibility of developing any of the rare severe side-effects of COVID vaccines and long-term effects which have not been proven yet.
The tweeter claims vaccines do not work and criticizes Ian Sams, special assistant to the president, White House Counsel’s Office.
The tweeter is responding to an anti-vaxxer by saying their logic that the whole world is promoting a deadly vaccine to implant microchips into people does not make sense.

The tweeter is making fun of Allison Williams, a sports commentator, who left ESPN due to mandatory vaccines. Williams apparently said Biden's decision is "the most jarring thing," to which the tweeter asks if her TV was broken when Trump was president.

This post by a physician and scientist is part of a thread that shares the latest information about Johnson & Johnson vaccine effectiveness. It says that a second J&J shot provides only a small antibody level increase compared to an mRNA booster.
By sharing a story about her son's vaccine hesitancy, tweeter implied that young people in their 30s are only getting vaccinated because it has become mandatory.
The tweeter claims police officers are shocked they have to get vaccinated to continue working even though they used tear gas and rubber bullets to stop anti-vax protestors.

The tweeter shares an article about an Australian politician who stepped down from his position after being criticized for encouraging people to not vaccinate children. The tweeter clearly supports his decision to step down.
The tweeter shares a Reuters article about increased heart inflammation from Moderna vaccines.
The tweeter, who's account name is "TRUMPTRUTH" shares an article which claims that in Pfizer's trials, more people who were in the vaccine group died than those in the placebo group.
This tweeter celebrates the idea of Djokovic getting deported from Australia for not being vaccinated. They say that the situation was ridiculous.

This tweeter says that democrats make excuses as to why black people are not getting vaccinated, while pushing vaccine mandates on other groups of people. The tweeter also seems critical of giving money to people to support them through the pandemic.
criticism_other: Governor Phil Murphy, financial pandemic support

meaning: Tweeter shared a study on the efficacy of two doses of COVID vaccines in patients with chronic medical conditions. Researchers recommended booster doses and other precautionary measures for these patients.
Tweeter shared his write-up about pharmaceutical companies making profits out of the COVID vaccines while a large portion of the globe remains unvaccinated due to scarcity of vaccines.
Tweeter implied that U.S. Supreme court justices who blocked the vaccine mandate introduced by the Biden administration are heroes.
Tweeter shared a Guardian article about Texas scientists who developed cheap COVID vaccines.
This tweeter says that Idaho is a beautiful state and he's worried about people ending up in the hospitals there. He asks people to get vaccinated.
Tweeter is mocking anti-vaxxers and implying that smallpox will come back because people are spreading disinformation about vaccines.
Tweeter is reminding anti-vaxxers, who insinuate COVID vaccines are ineffective because people require boosters, that other ailments also require more than one dose and boosters.
Tweeter is mocking anti-vaxxers who believe vaccines are governments tools to control people's minds but also expressing doubt that 94 percent of Nassau County in New York is vaccinated.
A tweet rattling off a list of things that are supposedly government conspiracies from Iraq to global warming to vaccines, everything is a lie propagated to control people.

Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines cause serious heart illness in people by referring to several people he knows who got vaccinated.  This was in reply to a tweet that explained why VAERS and Yellow card data should not be used to interpret that COVID vaccines cause death.

A tweet about the Brazilian government seeking to return to normalcy despite the fact that deaths are over 600,000. The tweet implies that the government is rushing into a return to normal and that deaths will continue to rise.
A tweet promoting a vaccine clinic which will give out $50 gift cards to every family that vaccinates their kids.
A tweet criticising the initial vaccine rollout for prioritising seniors over people with disabilities who were equally vulnerable but unable to get vaccinated.
A tweet from the CBC promoting a story about the failed attempt to make a vaccine in Canada for Canadians. It explains how the government failed the people in a time of crisis.
A reply to a tweet about how COVID variants are being invented to extend the pandemic, this tweet implies the pandemic is a conspiracy and hashtags conservative groups.

A tweet calling insurrectionists 'political prisoners' and argues they were only arrested to get them to comply with vaccine mandates. It implies a wealth of conservative conspiracy theories and radical Trumpian beliefs.
A tweet arguing the vaccine was inadequately tested and the world was tricked into testing a fake vaccine to respond to a fake pandemic and the whole nine conspiratorial yards.

A tweet questioning the efficacy of cloth masks, implying doubt in public health policy and in the honesty of public health officials. It isn't quite accurate because cloth masks were effective, but it has never been contested 95 masks are better.

This pro-vaccine tweeter highlights facts about the trucker convoy. Some are inaccurate though. He claims that it was mainly mini vans but large semi-trucks were definitely part of the convoy, for example.
This tweet promotes masking and vaccination of people in India. The tweeter says that volunteers organized to distribute those public health interventions.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that anti-vaxxers are not correct in claiming that the majority of hospital deaths resulting from COVID-19 are amongst vaccinated people. She says that hospital workers gave her information that the majority of deaths are indeed of unvaccinated people.
This tweet does not promote or criticize vaccines, rather it simply asks a friend if they took the vaccine.

Tweeter implied that the anti-vaccine stance of Marcus Lamb, a Christian television host who spread false information on vaccines in his shows harmed not only himself but also people who watched his shows.

A tweet about how discrimination, in this instance transphobia, can find its way into anti vaccine conspiracy theories. It implies people who are against the vaccine also hold extremely conservative, and often discriminatory, beliefs.

Tweeter implied that children do not require COVID vaccination because a lower percentage of children were infected with the virus compared to adults. But he used the wrong pregnancy analogy to drive his point.
This post sarcastically writes that because some vaccines like measles and polio are not mandated, people should keep their masks on forever.
Tweet implies it is hypocritical for the U.S government to mandate vaccinations when "infected migrants" are being let across the border.
support_other: strict immigration limits to control the spread of Covid

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter claims that the vaccine campaign failed in PEI. They say that they are embarrassed to be from PEI, given that province had vaccine mandates.

This tweeter says she'd rather die unmarried or exiled than take the vaccine or give it to her kids. She calls the pandemic and its response "BS." She promotes conspiracy theories on her wall in addition to this tweet.
This tweet celebrates people who signed up to take part in the COVID-19 phase three trials.
support_other: People who signed up for COVID-19 vaccine trials

meaning: This tweet isn't really promoting anything, rather than thanking friends. The tweeter is pro-vaccine based on other posts on her wall. This tweet mentions "vaccine" in it, but it's amongst garbled information.

This anti-vaxxer posted an Epoch Times article (far-right news source) to communicate that vaccines don't prevent transmission. They also said that "leaky" vaccines cause superviruses. Healthline, a reputable news source, reported that leaky vaccines are "less-than-perfect vaccines [that] create a “leaky” barrier."  against the virus.

This tweeter says that the vaccine doesn't work and they shared a Our World in Data graph depicting COVID-19 deaths per million people to support this. In the graph, the deaths escalated in early 2022, in Israel and the U.S. primarily. But there is not enough information on the graph to understand if those were vaxxed or unvaxxed people.

This tweeter says that there's information coming up about vaccine ineffectiveness and that people aren't listening to it. He posted a link to a tweeter who said his triple vaxxed friend tested negative after attending a super spreader event, which doesn't support this tweeter's claim.

This anti-vaxxer made a sarcastic comment about vaccination of children. She posted some kind of quote, that is not sourced, that claims people will not know how safe the vaccine is until it's administered. Then she links that to the idea of vaccinating five year olds.
Tweeter implied that there is no point in vaccination as the COVID vaccine cannot eradicate the virus.
Tweeter implied that some Spotify podcast shows are spreading disinformation on vaccines and thus encouraging people to take the risk of dying from coronavirus.

A tweet from the Congresswoman for Iowa praising a Senate measure to end vaccine mandates for health care workers, arguing we need all of the health care workers we can get so alienating anti vaccine health care workers isn't a good idea.
Tweeter is mocking New Zealand's prime minister by spelling the country's land using the Chinese president's name, implying that democracy in the Pacific nation is thwarted by vaccine mandates.

This post criticizes the decision to fire healthcare staff for not doing their professional duty and getting vaccinated against COVID19. They were doing their professional duty when they were isolating and working long shifts, argues the post.
Tweet summarizing more than 160,000 dead in the first few months of the pandemic while conservatives stoked fear about the vaccine and discouraged other public health measures.
User is a Fox News commentator claiming NYC Mayor Eric Adams' choice to keep the vaccine mandate will lead to an "exodus to free states." No evidence provided for this claim.

A tweet sarcastically criticising people who are against any interventions, masks and vaccines especially, because they are not completely effective. This tweet argues that any measure that reduces COVID transmission is worth doing.

This anti-vaxx tweeter may also be a QAnon believer because he refers to children being stolen. He says the public complains and complies and doesn't actually do anything. He also brings up a war, likely Ukraine, because anti-vaxxers sometimes claim that Russia did not invade.
This tweeter posted a funny and angry video of himself singing a song about his annoyance with anti-vaxxers.

This tweeter posted a graph that tried to support the argument that vaccinated people are getting sicker from COVID-19 than non-vaccinated people. This tweet is a defense to another tweeter who said his chart was unfounded. This tweeter asserts that he believes more vaccinated people ended up in hospitals (as of 2022).

Tweeter shared a report by WND, a news website with questionable sources, about conservative activist group Judicial Watchdog filing an FOI case against the American public health authority for information on COVID vaccine side effects.

Although this is a news tweet from the L.A. Times, about how quite a few women died of COVID-19 while pregnant, it is inherently pro-vaccine because it highlights the dangers of not getting vaccinated.
This tweet is by a U.S. TV network channel promoting a program about a Washington state Supreme Court hearing of a man, who opposes vaccination.
Tweeter shared a Global News report about a Liberal MP criticizing Trudeau's rhetoric on vaccine mandates and COVID restrictions, creating division in the society.

This post questions the safety of vaccines, arguing that COVID19 vaccine trials should have taken years to complete, and that they were rushed, testing on humans. Long term effects are also unknown, they write.
Tweet claims the Asch conformity experiments demonstrate how the vaccinated public cannnot admit they were tricked or wrong. Keyword: Herd mentality
This tweet is a repost of news about how the World Bank's president congratulated India on a successful vaccination campaign. The post is inherently pro-vaccine.

This tweeter is the editor-and-chief at the daily skeptic, which is an anti-vaxx, anti-science platform. This tweet claims that vaccines are linked to heart attacks, and it posts and image that implies that pandemic response will never stop, based on the image used to illustrate it.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx, based on his wall posts. This tweet asks if Howard Stern is criticizing Joe Rogan for promoting Ivermectin, or if the issue is about racism. This undermines Stern's focus on Rogan's anti-vaxx sentiments.
This tweeter says he's proud he didn't take the vaccine and he implies that his conspiracy theories protected him.

Tweeter seems to insinuate that there was a connection between the breach of security at a U.S. Army base where Kamala Harris was due and FDA releasing Pfizer's vaccine documents. He seems to imply that the docs had concerning information that the company supposedly hid.
This tweet contains a video that promotes vaccination. The  man in the video talks about how he convinced his friends (who may have received disinformation about vaccines) to get vaccinated.
This is a news repost from a WSJ editor about how a Kennedy promoted anti-vaxx beliefs. The tweet contains no personal opinion.

A tweet criticising an anti vaccine Tik Tok for calling unvaccinated people 'pure bloods'. Arguing it's ironic that the same people who compared health interventions to Nazi authoritarianism are using terminology with a racist history.

Tweeter is trying to explain why layman's data on hospitalized COVID patients can be misinterpreted because the percentage of vaccinated population hospitalized is lower than the percentage of unvaccinated hospitalized.

This post by the Western Australia Department of Health announces open appointments at a community vaccination clinic. It writes that COVID19 vaccines are free for anyone, regardless of immigration status and that no insurance nor identification are needed.
Tweeter implied that she feels good about not being asked for proof of vaccination.
Tweet argues that government and public health officials are still advocating for vaccine mandates because they do not want to admit they were "wrong and negligent"

Tweet claims there is a link between climate activism, masking, and "vaccine pushers," implying it is all part of a bigger conspiracy to distract the public from something else. Tucker Carlson and Joe Rogan are tagged, as well as the accounts "unheardparent", and "OpenschoolsUS"

A tweet linking to an article from Fox News about a professor who is suing the University of California for trying to make him get the vaccine, citing natural immunity as a reason to not get vaccinated even though vaccines still help.

This anti-vaxxer says that the Facebook post he posted is proof that many people died of the vaccine. The Facebook post is a request from a news channel, who wanted to interview people who lost unvaccinated loved ones to COVID-19. Many comments placed on that thread were from people who declared that more people die from the vaccine itself.
Tweeter is implying that vaccine passport rules are illogical by sharing the news about Spain's high court's ruling on the issue.

Tweet claims there is a link between climate activism, masking, and "vaccine pushers," implying it is all part of a bigger conspiracy to distract the public from something else. Tucker Carlson and Joe Rogan are tagged, as well as the accounts "unheardparent", and "OpenschoolsUS"

This anti-vaxxer promotes anti-government ideals, saying that people shouldn't trust the government when they didn't condemn Austria's vaccine mandates. This tweet promotes far-right values on her Twitter.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that the side-effects of the COVID-19 vaccine are more rare than those same side-effects of the virus itself.
This anti-vaxxer makes a comment on tax dollars going to vaccine companies. He says this is a waste of money.
This anti-vaxxer posted links about two Australian nurses who told the public that they think there are adverse effects to the COVID-19 vaccine. This post promotes vaccine hesitation.

This pro-vaccine tweeter went off an a rant about a former Australian politician, Gladys Berejiklian. She says Gladys is a misogynist who took "nasty swipes" a Victorian Australians. She also ranted about something more to do with public health but it's hard to understand, other than that she says Gladys accused a person of creating the Delta variant.

This tweet says that the reality of doing business is that vaccinated workers are less of a risk to business. The tweeter also makes a snide comment about religious people who may not get vaccinated (he calls that the blood of christ). He tells those people to not cry about their "freedumbs."

This tweet seems neutral by posting a Forbes article that says vaccine passports are rolling out in republican states. But due to the conspiracy theories on her wall, this tweeter is clearly an anti-vaxxer. This post contains no personal comment but likely is meant to raise the alarm to her fellow anti-vaxxers.

This anti-vaxxer posted a graph that contains no source information to try to prove to the public that COVID-19 cases went down after mask and vaccine mandates were lifted. It's not clear if the information in the graph is accurate, but regardless, this is misleading because there are various factors outside mandates that contribute to lower case counts.

This tweet says that the anti-vaxx industry is worth $1.1 Billion in revenue and that Big Tech is profiting of mis/disinformation. The tweeter, the Centre for Countering Digital Hate, says that such big tech platforms don't care for the health of people.
This tweeter lists off all the bad things he thinks Trump did throughout the pandemic, and promotes another tweeter who calls out such anti-science beliefs as "negligent homicide."
This tweeter supports science and says that the side-effects of COVID-19 are undeniably worse than the side-effects of the vaccine.

This pro-vaccine tweeter promotes science by stating that this non-peer reviewed article is "anti-science." He posted a link to research done that comes from an anti-vaxx perspective. This author, who is also an MD, has been published in Time and The New York Times, and he appears to be reputable.
This tweeter is anti-mandate based on their Twitter profile. They say that Nicola Sturgeon is drawing out the pandemic by way of public health policy. This is an anti-government tweet.
This is a news repost of an article from Newsweek that reported Biden's reaction to backlash over vaccine mandates. The post contains no personal opinion.
This anti-vaxxer says that people stood up around the world for one common goal: To end vaccine and mask mandates. He says they stood up for "human rights" in doing so.
Tweet criticizing a politician for covering up the harms of the vaccine because he is receiving money from pharmaceutical companies.
Tweet implies some people who believe vaccines are unnatural or dangerous are the same people using untested drugs recreationally or huffing paint thinner.

Tweet part of a thread about people who purchased concert tickets in DC being denied entry for incomplete vaccination or lack of proof. This user is saying if proof of vaccination is required, it should say so when people purchase the tickets.

A tweet commenting on a celebrity that made an anti vaccine post on Instagram, pointing out how most people have been vaccinated and accepted the science whereas a vocal minority use vaccines as a device for political division.

This tweeter says that the mainstream media is hiding the truth about the vaccine. He says that there are growing side effects to the vaccine. He posted a link to GAB, a far-right platform that is not grounded in reality, to prove his point.

This is a news repost from a tabloid in the U.K. about how Gibraltar "panicked" over COVID-19, despite the cases being low. This post doesn't promote much other than entertainment, yet it could be considered anti-science by some.
This tweet promotes COVID-19 vaccination pop up clinics.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that Toronto will host a mass vaccination clinic for children. Because the tweet includes no personal opinion, this is pro-vaccine. And anti-vaxxer would have contested this clinic.

This woman says that the Australian government, lead by Scott Morrison, has done little to help with vaccine roll out. She says that stones were rolled out of the glass windows of Morrison's house, onto the vaccine roll out, as a metaphor, for the lack of action from the government.
This pro-vaccine tweeter commented on an anti-vaxx nurse who is a religious "freedom" fighter. This tweet says that freedom should stop at the point where personal liberty harms others.

Tweet links to a headline with an update on China's travel policies. From an account focused on getting Chinese students who were studying abroad when the boarders closed back into their home country.
Tweet argues the best way to protect children is not to vaccinate them because they are low risk for severe illness and the vaccine causes complications like myocarditis.
User compares breakthrough Covid cases to becoming pregnant while on birth control. Unclear if this is pro or anti vaccine. Profile is left leaning (BLM, veganism, astrology, etc).

A tweet about how the government forces people to do a lot of thing if they want to live in public; seat belts, no smoking indoors, no shirt no service, ID for alcohol. Vaccine mandates don't infringe on liberties any more than these laws.
Tweeter implied that side effects from COVID vaccine booster shots are manageable by sharing tweeter's personal experience.
Tweeter implied that California would impose lockdowns again to manage a COVID endemic. Though he is not a legal professional, he claimed mask and vaccine mandates as illegitimate strategies.

Since the post is no longer live, it is not clear when PM Justin Trudeau backed off from enforcing the vaccine mandate for Canadian truckers. Tweeter clearly does not support the vaccine mandate and the PM.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine, based on his twitter feed. He says here that there is evidence that COVID-19 infections can provide protection as a booster dose would. He says that such infections should be considered as a dose of the vaccine on a passport. OSHU released an article that backs this scientifically.
criticism_other: Ignoring COVID-19 infection as a booster
support_other: Including breakthrough infections as a "booster" on vaccine cards

meaning: This anti-vaxxer posted a link to a tabloid-esque far-right website, The Expose, and reposted the headline in their Tweet. That headline states that a U.K. judge demanded proof from the government that vaccines are safe for kids.

This is a pro-vaccine Tweet from someone who was arguing with an anti-vaxxer throughout a huge thread. This tweet itself is hard to follow, but it basically says that it's ridiculous to believe in alt-remedies. The tweeter before her promoted Ivermectin as a remedy.

Newsmax is a conservative website and the tweeter of this post. They tweeted their own article about how some Republican senators are trying to strike down vaccine mandates in the U.S. Newsmax is not famous for their fact-checking or neutrality, so this post promotes anti-vaxx sentiments.

Link to an article from CNN Philippines about how the election campaign could potentially effect that country's Covid measures, specifically community outreach programs focused on testing and vaccination.
Tweet directly asking Newsmax to cover Biden's vaccine mandate. Profile is full of nationalist imagery (Flag, Declaration of Independence, username 1776) and criticisms of Biden/ Democrats.

A tweet in response to a thread about vaccine mandates. It's arguing that if the vaccine works then we shouldn't have to fire people because they won't get one; if the vaccine protects you then unvaccinated people don't put you at risk.

A tweet picking a quote about how natural antibodies are more effective than the vaccine, the user selected this unverified quote from Pfizer scientists to make it seem reputable but omit the fact nearly every scientist says the vaccine is necessary, safe and effective.
Tweeter implied that vaccines should be taken to protect oneself from hospitalization or death from COVID.

Tweeter is propagating the conspiracy theory that COVID vaccines are actually a digital surveillance tool by posting a video of a New Zealand doctor, who spreads COVID misinformation on YouTube channels.
Tweeter, a news website, shared a news article that CDC recommends Pfizer and Moderna vaccines over Johnson and Johnson's.
This tweeter is upset with the CDC for inconsistent messaging. The tweet is misleading though, because the goal was always higher than a 50 or 60% vaccination rate.
Tweet says Pfizer admitted their vaccine gives "limited, if any protection." Implication is that smart people will realize this and not take the vaccine.

Tweet is a headline about the NZ Supreme Court ruling against the national vaccine mandate. User is part of the Brownstone Institute, a libertarian think tank dedicated to "post-lockdown world," and author of a book titled "The Great Covid Panic."

Tweet is from a Doctor relaying how many of his colleagues got Covid from their children who were attending school without access to the vaccine. Calls for wearing high-quality masks when vaccination is not possible.

This user allegedly had family members get Omicron despite being double vaccinated. There is no reason to suggest the story is fake, and the concerns this tweet expresses about vaccine efficacy are the user's own feelings.
Tweeter implied that Pfizer releases COVID vaccines without proper trial.
Tweeter shared VAERS data without the disclaimer that these are unverified reports by individuals. The implication of the tweet presents the COVID vaccines as unsafe.
Tweeter implied that anti-vaxxers' claim that vaccine and mask mandates are ruining their life is irrational.
This tweet is by an American public health website sharing data on COVID cases, vaccines and variants.
Tweeter is mocking the American army for implementing the vaccine mandate by sharing an opinion piece with misinformation about the Pfizer's vaccine and legality and execution of the mandate.
Tweeter implied that employers should not have the right to impose vaccine mandates on their employees if they have medical reasons for requesting exemptions.
This tweet appears like a neutral question, but it's likely an anti-vaxx / anti-masker because a pro-science person wouldn't clarify if masks and vaccines actually work.

This anti-vaxxer says that people quit Southwest airlines due to vaccine mandates, but this has been debunked in various news sources. The shortage of employees happened well before the mandate was instated.
Tweeter implied that the World Economic Forum apparently created the pandemic to supposedly control people with COVID vaccines.
