meaning: This anti-vaxxer tells "sheep" to wake up because the FDA is taking a long time to release FOIs about vaccine trials. This tweet says it will take 75 years, but various news reports listed 55 years. The FDA stated the long wait time is due to the need to censor names within the trails, and sensitive information.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx, based on his previous tweets within this thread. This specific tweet intends to communicate that tons of vaccines have been given to Americans and school kids.
User blames Trump for accelerating vaccine skepticism and claims this is why his followers are still largely unvaccinated. Refers to Trump supporters as "cultists"
User is comparing taking the vaccine without knowing what is in it to eating microwaved processed foods. The implication is that being skeptical of one but not the other is hypocritical.

This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccines make more versions of COVID-19 that then require more boosters. They then equate that to the flu shot and post a link to a random tweeter who asks why we still have the flu even though a flu shot was invented many years ago. This post intends to undermine vaccine efficacy.

This tweet is pro-vaccine yet questions vaccine effectiveness at the same time. The tweeter shows a graph that indicates vaccines are less effective in the face of Omicron, than they were with the Delta variant. Various news reports confirmed that information, and the graph he posted is sourced to site that appears to be reputable.

This tweeter made a sarcastic comment about vaccine passports working well, in reply to another tweeter who said France will abandon vaccine passports. This tweeter calls Brillo, a supporter of vaccine passports, pompous and a "darling" of the left.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx even though he says he's had other vaccines. He says that mRNA vaccines are "experimental" and that they don't protect him. This is misinformation because the mRNA vaccines were in development since the 1960's.
User claims Channel Four news is downplaying the risk of myocarditis in children.
Tweet claims it is hypocritical of Trudeau to dislike Trump when much of Canada's vaccine supply came from the US. Implication of a plot, reference to "dictatorship program" from the left.
This tweeter claims that mRNA vaccines alter your DNA. The CDC reported that "COVID-19 vaccines do not change or interact with your DNA in any way."
This tweeter makes a simple statement about wanting to give someone (likely MODI) a vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says thanks to people who lined up at a vaccination clinic to receive the jab. He thanks them for keeping the plan to help people stay safe.
This tweet seems to be promoting vaccine equity by saying that vaccines are free for everyone.
This tweeter says that vaccines are the way out of the pandemic and promotes donating to an organization that gives vaccines to people.

This anti-vaxx tweeter supports natural immunity and asks if the CDC will be cancelled from some social media platform now that their view on the matter could align with Joe Rogan (who was cancelled).
This is an informational post about how vaccines will be donated to lower income countries.

This anti-vaxxer says that unvaccinated people should make their employers fire them, rather than quit on their own terms from a job that has mandates in place. They say that that employer will likely have difficulty replacing people.

This tweet is hard to understand due to slang and bad English, but the tweeter appears to be pro-vaccine. He says that vaccines were required for travel before COVID-19. He refers to the yellow card (yellow fever) as an example.

This tweet was made by a nearly far-right leaning news outlet, the Daily Wire. It reports that New Zealand's prime minister says that vaccine passports make two separate classes of people. Essentially this post promotes freedom of choice, and it inherently criticizes liberal politicians.

This anti-vaxxer implies some kind of conspiracy theory in this tweet. She asks what the chances of four big companies coming up with the same vaccine would be, this implies some kind of sinister orchestration of the pandemic.

User claims to have data from VAERS showing 51% of all vaccine deaths were related to the Covid vaccine as of Dec 2021. Replier claims to personally know more people who have died of the vaccine than Covid.

Tweet is an article from the UK government detailing why the NHS does not vaccinated widely against chickenpox. The article is nuanced and clear, but this user appears to be using it to argue vaccines are unnecessary.
This is a news post, which contains no personal opinion, about how a judge blocked a police union from placing an injunction on the vaccine mandate.

This anti-vaxxer is calling out Australia by way of posting a video of an Australian politician. He speaks about how people who oppose vaccine mandates should be labelled as anti-vaxxers. The tweeter in turn calls this a form of fascism.

This pro-vaccine tweeter posts a link from the Daily Beast about how a military officer refuses to get vaccinated in the name of freedom. The tweeter is clearly critical of that person's decision because they put the word "freedom" in parenthesis.
This tweet posted a link that is no longer active which displays Alex Jones' response to Trump being vaccinated. This tweet takes a jab at Trump for supporting vaccination and operation "warp speed."

This tweeter is upset that Boris Johnson supports vaccination. The tweet rants and doesn't really make sense, due to bad writing, but it's clear she associates Johnson's support of vaccines with being complacent, like a "woof"-ing dog.

This tweeter, who goes by "doctor", yet is only listed as a MA-level psychotherapist on here site, asks a conspiracy related question about why the end game is of Big Pharma. She says that there was short-term economic gain resulting from vaccination... but asks what that end game is.
This tweet celebrates Australian politician, Brett Sutton, for taking a pro-vaccine stance, and proactive stance on vaccination.

This tweeter says that vaccine passports force people to get vaccinated and that they create a type of compliance system. This tweeter believes that a global form of control is established through vaccination.

This tweeter is not passing judgement on vaccine effectiveness, rather they ask what doctor's motives are when they say a vaccine does or doesn't work. The tweet is misleading in a way because it uses Fauci as an example as someone who could be lying about vaccine effectiveness, but this is counterbalanced by saying other doctors lie when they say vaccines don't work.
criticism_other: People's motives for promoting or criticizing vaccination

meaning: This tweeter says that 90 minutes of light exercise after vaccination can enhance antibody response. This appears to be confirmed in various news sources.

This tweet was made by someone who lists himself as a journalist. He posted a video featuring a doctor who tells an anti-vaxxer that not using a mask or vaccine is equivalent to having unprotected sex with someone who has an STD. Although the tweeter doesn't inject personal opinion into this post, he is clearly pro-science.

This post is informational but could be considered unsure about the vaccine. The tweeter says that people with two vaccines have tested positive for COVID-19, yet they don't provide personal opinion on their thoughts about vaccination.
This anti-vaxxer accuses a doctor of being compromised by Big Pharma and the rights to vaccine patents. He also says something negative about Fauci, although it's not quite clear what.
This tweet seems to say that we're living in a time where a certain conspiracy theory is coming true. And that conspiracy theory involves vaccine mandates.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says they like trucks when they help good causes, but not when they create problems in a pandemic around "non-existent" vaccine mandates.
This tweeter promotes the vaccination rates and COVID-19 stats from an area of India. This promotes public health interventions.

This pro-vaccine tweeter studies anti-vaxx type groups. In this post, he says that Dr. Sherri Tenpenny is an anti-vaxxer, and he points out that certain events are lead by Christians and Qanon members.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine. He calls out another tweeter here by saying that person spreads misinformation.

This pro-vaccine tweeter supports the vaccination of all classes of society. She posted a link to a Fortune Magazine article which she pulled a quote from, which says vaccines need to be made cheaper and easier to access.
This tweet informs readers on how to get a digital QR code online.

This tweeter seems to be saying that vaccine mandates have economic impacts that economists still can't really account for. Therefore this tweet seems to be criticizing mandates, but not necessarily vaccines.

This tweeter feels that certain people don't want the "truth" about vaccines to get out to the world. They posted a link to another tweet that claims the vaccine has many bad side effects. It's not clear where that information was sourced from, so it's likely embellished. The tweeter also takes a jab at "Big Pharma" by posting #PfizerGate in the tweet, which hints at conspiracy theory related sentiments.

This tweet is anti-vaxx. It contains #vaccineinjuries as a hashtag and it posts some sentence that doesn't really make sense. But the images included contain a text that say something bad was detected inside vaccines. There is no accurate way to trace where this person got this information.

This tweet includes a video and a quote from that video within the post. It shows Fauci talking about how he doesn't envision a vaccine mandate at the national level. This is clearly an anti-vaxxer post, due to the nature of what quote was highlighted.

This tweet was made by an eye doctor. He claims that COVAXIN, a non-mRNA vaccine, is better than mRNA vaccines. I was not able to find any fact online to verify that, therefore this post is misleading.
This tweeter says that vaccine passports should contain three vaccine doses, not just two. He posts a vaccine effectiveness report from the UK Health Security Agency to back up this comment.
criticism_other: Vaccine passports containing only two doses
support_other: Placing three doses on the vaccine passport

meaning: This anti-vaxxer is worried that a third vaccine will be required for vaccine passports. They call vaccines "experimental" and worry that adverse vaccine reactions are not placed on the "yellow card." This post is in response to a pro-vaccine tweet, which they posted within this tweet.

This tweet claims that scientists from Pfizer say that natural immunity (antibodies) are better at fighting COVID-19 than vaccines. But the only link I could find online to verify this statement is a hoaky homemade "undercover" reporting video. Natural immunity comes at a cost, because people can die from contracting the virus without being vaccinated.

This tweet has been deactivated but it seems to reply to an anti-vaxxer. The tweeter makes fun of that anti-vaxxer for being "armed with the Internet and a high school certificate." This implies that the anti-vaxxer is uneducated and therefore people shouldn't value that person's opinion.
This tweeter says that natural immunity is better than immunity through vaccination. They say that vaccines "rent" immunity.
This tweeter says that various "side effects" associated with vaccines are not such, rather that they are "vaccine injuries." This is an anti-vaxx post.
This pro-vaccine tweeter asks if vaccine supplies will be delivered.
This tweeter says that he wants children to be able to get vaccinated without the consent of their parents. This is a pro-vaccine post, and it supports the vaccination of children.
criticism_other: Parents who don't vaccinate their kids

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the vaxxed can also do [something]. It's not clear what, because the previous post was removed. But this likely refers to transmission of the virus. This tweeter has tons of far-right content on his wall, so he is surely anti-vaxx.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the public has been put in a "really shitty position" in regards to vaccine mandates. He also says that his friends have contacted him to say they've had adverse vaccine reactions, yet he provides no details on what those reactions or circumstances were.
This tweeter was made by the Democratic Party. It lists off various things that republicans are against. And it asks republicans to share what they're for.
This pro-vaccine tweeter said she and her family got the third shot without any side effects. She asks why people are still questioning it and encourages them to get it, and to be safe.

This anti-vaxxer posted a link to another tweet about Israel. That tweet says that Israel has high vaccination rates yet their COVID-19 rates are also high. This tweet intends to "prove" that vaccines are not effective.

This anti-vaxxer claims that some children were injected with the wrong vaccine. They provide a link that has been removed by Twitter to "prove" this. This post is misleading and provides no information to back up its claim.
This pro-vaccine tweeter tells someone who posted a notice about vaccines posing risks to kids at physical exercise class that the virus is more dangerous than vaccines.
This tweet says that Pfizer's vaccine is 91% effective in children ages 5 to 11. It was posted by MSN, a reputable newsource.
This pro-vaccine tweeter reports that their friend just got COVID-19. They encourage people to get vaxxed.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that Walmarts were prioritized over small businesses during the pandemic. They also hint at the government not doing enough of what they should have. They say they have been "hiding in the box hoping the storm passes."

This tweeter posted a review by the UK Health Security Agency. The report states that "Six of the 8 studies assessing the effectiveness of vaccination before COVID-19 infection
suggested that vaccinated cases (1 or 2 doses) were less likely to develop symptoms of long COVID following infection, in the short term (4 weeks after infection), medium term (12 to 20 weeks after infection) and long term (6 months after infection)." 

This tweeter is clearly pro-vaccine, given this information.

It's not clear what this tweeter is talking about, yet it's clear he is not vaccinated. He says that if being vaccinated against COVID-19 is a requirement, that he must remove his name [from some kind of list]. This means he's not vaccinated.

This anti-vaxx tweeter is mad at airlines and at Trudeau for requiring vaccine passports to fly. The tweeter says that vaccines don't prevent transmission, so those mandates are irrelevant in a flight context.
criticism_other: Claims that the vaccine prevents transmission, Trudeau, Airlines

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter says that businesses who support vaccine mandates should be held liable for any vaccine injuries that result from vaccination.

This tweet is a re-post and translation of a German text about vaccine adverse effects. This tweeter has published in reputable news outlets. The post suggests that there may be more adverse effects as a result of vaccination than we first realized, yet he also wrote follow-up posts explaining that more research on this must be done.

This anti-vaxx tweet posts a link to a Brownstone Institute article, which is published by a libertarian think tank. The tweet calls vaccine mandates "unscientific," which is misleading. It also calls those mandates costly and "divisive."

This anti-vaxxer posted a link and said "send this to your vaccine-hesitant friends." The link talks about medical experimentation regarding lice, which intends to spur consipiracy theories about medical testing and the COVID-19 vaccine.
This tweeter writes about how they're feeling after getting vaccinated. While this post doesn't promote or criticize anything, rather reports experience about vaccination, this post is pro-vaccine.
This tweeter says that vaccine mandates don't work because they don't stop transmission. They say that in France, night clubs had to close despite having vaccine mandates, due to a rise in cases.
This anti-vaxxer says that the meaning of COVID-19 terms change when we need them to. This seems to be a complaint on consistency of messaging.
criticism_other: Terminology and meaning around pandemic definitions, consistent messaging

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweet claims that Dr. Joel Wallskog, was injured by the vaccine. The link included in this tweet to prove this claim was deactivated by twitter. I was not able to find a reputable news report online to verify this news, so this is flagged as misleading.
This is an anti-vaxx tweet because it encourages people to be aware of their booster shot limit. It asks the public how many boosters they're willing to take.
This tweet is unsure about vaccination while it says their family member got vaccinated, but that vaccines also come with risks.
This tweeter is sad about having to wait to get better from COVID19 and then the vaccine booster before being able to do a workout again.
This post criticizes COVID19 vaccine mandates, calling for people to remind politicians that nobody will be forced to take the vaccine.
This post shares an article by FOX News about Arizona suing the Biden administration over COVID19 vaccine mandates.

This post by Buffalo’s Spectrum News 1 shares an article about Joe Rogan’s misinformation on Spotify. It writes that Spotify will now be adding content advisories before podcasts discussing the virus.

This tweeter posted some anti-vaxx information about DeSantis having a better message than Trump. DeSantis is notoriously anti-vaxx within the American political scene. And Trump has promoted vaccines at some point, therefore this is an anti-vaxx post.
This pro-vaccine tweeter replied to another tweeter who said that Pfizer vaccines only stay 35% stable. This tweeter says that is not true and refers to some other information to prove his point.

This pro-vaccine tweeter replied to an anti-vaxxer who complained about freedoms being infringed upon throughout a long thread. This specific tweet was written to remind him that mandates were similar in the U.S. and Australia - as this tweeter likely felt he was comparing democrats to Australian officials.
This tweet promotes public health interventions in India. It features a photo of people wearing masks at a Covid-19 vaccination at a woman's day event.
This pro-vaccine tweeter posted a link to a PBS article about the Trucker Convoy. The article clearly makes fun of the convoy because the headline reveals that they've urinated in public places.

This tweet seems to be criticizing government for not communicating efficientlyl to the public about possibly having to stay at home. It's not clear if this tweeter is promoting public health measures, so this tweet is flagged as unsure.
This anti-vaxxer makes an anti-government joke about people who run to get vaccinated when the government tells them to.
This post sarcastically asks whether getting the COVID19 vaccine prevents catching something they call Draco.

This post by a Reverend in New Hampshire writes that Clergy in the State were eligible early on for the COVID19 vaccine because they were considered moderate-risk health workers. It replies to a tweet that has since been deleted.
This post by the New York Times shares an article about COVID19 vaccine mandates for private businesses coming into effect amid the Omicron wave.

This tweet says that before the measles vaccine in 1963 millions of people died each year. This number of deaths is misleading as various other sources say 5,000 - 48,000 were hospitalized or died. Regardless, this is a pro-vaccine post.
This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines are harmful and she posted a link for others to read about vaccine injuries. But that link has been removed or deleted.
This anti-vaxxer is skeptical of the Nigerian government. He is worried because that country "pushes" the vaccine while simultaneously engaging in human rights abuses and civil war.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that getting vaxxed is the way to freedom. He asks anti-vaxxers to justify their anti-government beliefs, step by step.
This tweeter says that she's pro vaccination. Her tweet complains about some comments online, her complaints are around the dates when people talk about getting vaccinated.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that vaccine mandates should be struck down by the courts in Bhushan.
This is a news report from NPR that says masking helped reduce the spread of COVID-19 in states where mask mandates were present.
This post criticizes anti-vaxxers, questioning whether they would refuse typhoid and cholera vaccinations if drinking water quality dropped in the United Kingdom.

This post by WUSA9 shares an article about Councilmember Brianne Nadeau withdrawing a bill to reinstate COVID19 vaccine mandates for businesses because she does not believe she can get the required votes to pass the bill.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that anti-vaxxers have various forms of biases, designed to support their views. He basically says they use "cherry-picked" evidence to support their views.
This tweeter asks why people can't just get the vaccine and third boosters so we can return to normal. This is a pro-vaccine post.

This tweeter says that there is a huge divide amongst white people within the pandemic. And he says that those who are willing to endure the hardship of "teaching" those who refuse to mask and vaxx don't have much overlap. This is pro-vaccine because he says those who follow public health mandates will do the teaching, not vice versa.
This tweeter says one of the last things Trudeau will say, on his deathbed, is "be sure to get vaxxed." This is anti-vaxx because it makes fun of the situation at hand.
This anti-vaxxer calls a pro-vaccine tweeter an idiot. This tweeter says that vaccines don't prevent transmission.
This tweeter is vaccinated and upset that her COVID-19 test has taken over two days to come back, with no results. She's complaining about the tardiness in the system.
criticism_other: Tardiness of receiving public test results

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweet asks readers to mark the date when they would need their vaccine booster in their calendars, 84 days after the first dose.
This anti-vaxxer saws that vaccine mandates should be outlawed in Texas.
This anti-vaxxer says that the meaning of COVID-19 terms change when we need them to. This seems to be a complaint on consistency of messaging.
criticism_other: Terminology and meaning around pandemic definitions, consistent messaging

meaning: This tweeter made a snide comment about vaccine effectiveness in response to an article that reports a man went to the hospital despite being vaccinated for COVID-19.

This anti-vaxxer says that Biden is weakening the military by instating a vaccine mandate, while some members are leaving that profession. They posted a link to a hoakey looking blog, which doesn't provide much information on this matter.

This post shares an article by Stars and Stripes, announcing that as of November 22, all Defense Department civilian employees must be fully vaccinated against COVID19 in the United States. The post encourages people to get vaccinated.
This post by Senator Marsha Blackburn criticizes vaccine mandates, writing that they have no place in the United States.

This post shares an article about HIV diagnoses being higher in heterosexual people than in gay and bisexual men for the first time in a decade. It criticizes vaccine inequity, writing that we are closer than ever to having an HIV vaccine only because straight people are now more affected.

This post replies to a tweet by Conservative Member of Parliament in the United Kingdom, David Davis, which criticizes vaccine effectiveness. The post argues that COVID19 vaccines were never meant to get rid of all lockdowns and end the pandemic.

In response to a tweet about Australia aiming to attract more travellers again by making it easier for tourists to enter the country, this post criticizes Australia, calling it an authoritarian COVID19 vaccine police state.

This tweet is not necessarily anti-vaxx, rather it says that the persons friends, vaxxed and unvaxxed have been transmitting and/or contracting the virus. Therefore, I flagged this post as unsure about the vaccine because it's not overly skepitcal of vaccination, rather more of an observation.

This anti-vaxxer replied to a woman who said police should show a vaxx card before a suspect is forced to roll down their window when stopped on the highway. This tweeter in-turn tells that pro-vaccine tweeter to stay at home because they don't believe in mandates.

This tweeter criticizes India's president, Modi for glorifying his role in the pandemic. She says that he is causing harm, not good. This is an anti-politician post, but is inherently pro-vaccine due to commenting on him taking credit for vaccines.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says the government would have had to do lots of work to ensure Novak, the anti-vaxx tennis player, is viewed as a public health risk. This post is also misleading because the tweeter claims that Novak has antibodies (from natural immunity) and that Omicron spreads more through vaccinated people.

This tweeter is unsure about the vaccine because he promotes that people don't get three vaccines if they have been exposed to the virus. This is not necessarily anti-vaxx, but it does support natural immunity in replacement to boosters. The tweeter posted a Washington Post article to prove this sentiment.
criticism_other: Boosters when exposed to the virus already

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter says that people were less likely to die of Delta when vaccinated. But he also asks if scientists are recording "vaccine injuries" and "deaths" which promotes conspiracy theories and vaccine fear.

This anti-vaxx tweeter shared a video of a conspiracy theory- style video, which bashes other conspiracy theorists. The tweeter says that video will give readers more of an understanding as to why "mainstream media" is not reporting the truth about the pandemic.

This religious anti-vaxxer says that the government is at fault for mandating vaccines. She says that that party should forget their votes next time around. She posted an image of text about how the people will remove "god haters" from government in 2024.

This tweet seems to be more anti-government than anything. It doesn't pass judgement on vaccine mandates directly, so I flagged it as unsure about the vaccine. The tweeter criticizes Ford for asking people to volunteer at vaccination sites, given there is a staffing shortage at hospitals.

This tweet is anti-vaxx because they say that people could be provided with a free harmonica if they don't consent to having their children vaccinated at a school. The Tweeter describes this as a "game changer," meaning they celebrate the idea of giving an incentive to not have kids vaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that if vaccines aren't considered safe by anti-vaxxers, then why would they protest other public health measures too, like lockdowns?

This pro-vaccine tweeter refers to the Trucker Convoy as "extremists." He says that extremists moved north from the U.S. to Canada. He wonders why such demonstrations are going on while mandates were about to be dropped anyway.

This pro-vaccine tweeter makes a joke about people who fall Trump and the lame name he created: "Operation Warp Speed." He says that "brainwashed trumpers" boycotted their own health by not getting vaccinated.
This tweet doesn't promote or criticize anything, rather it asks how a vaccine passport works.

This is a news post from ABC about vaccines. It's informational yet inherently pro-vaccine because it states that vaccine makers feel they are capable of rolling out new variant-specific vaccines if needed.
This anti-vaxxer said he won't give informed consent (to take the vaccine) until the FDA releases data on Pfizer's vaccine trials.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says they observed vaccinated people discussing how sick they felt for two weeks after getting the vaccine. They describe this sensation as living in the Twilight Zone.

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines are "under performing" because transmission is still possible amongst fully vaccinated people. The tweeter discounts the fact that vaccines prevent serious illness or death.

This anti-vaxxer says that a politician is coercing people into getting vaccinated. They say that people who don't keep up with their vaccine status fall into the publicly "unacceptable" category by today's standards.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that vaccine mandates are discriminatory and that they increase the power of the state. This tweeter says such actions remove power from the people. He also takes a jab at "socialists."
This anti-vaxxer says that Boris Johnson is putting all of his eggs into the vaccine basket. This is inherently anti-vaxx because the tweeter undermines trust in vaccine efficacy.

This tweeter is complaining about someone, it's not clear who, who's promoting vaccination. The tweeter says that that person has access to data and that he should know natural immunity is better than vaccines. This is an anti-vaxx post.

This tweeter is not really criticizing vaccines, rather this tweet is part of a discussion about flu vaccines. She says that people guess as to which flu strain will be dominant, when deciding how to develop the flue vaccine each year.

This pro-vaccine tweeter seems to be questioning the data that an anti-vaxxer presented. The tweet is rather technical but intends to clarify why the head of the Health Security Agency, Jenny Harries, may have linked the risks of flu season into COVID-19.
The tweeter spreads misinformation by claiming pharmaceutical companies are using the COVID-19 vaccine to kill people.

This pro-vaccine tweeter celebrates the Singapore Government for inventing their own system to trace vaccine passports. The tweeter says this is good because it excludes untrustworthy third parties from having sensitive information.
This is a news tweet by a branch of NPR about how some corrections officers were suspended for refusing the vaccine.

This anti-vaxxer posted an article to a website called TheBlaze.com, which is a right-wing media organization. The tweeter claims that the U.S. government PAID media organizations to promote vaccines. AFP fact check this and reported that "The claim is misleading; in fact, the educational program referred to was publicly announced and described in detail on a dedicated website, and the payments made were for advertising."

This anti-vaxxer claims that the WHO advised people under 18 shouldn't be vaccinated. If this claim was true, it was relevant to a time when vaccines had only been tested for adults. The tweeter is clearly against the vaccination of children.

This anti-vaxxer says that a politician is coercing people into getting vaccinated. They say that people who don't keep up with their vaccine status fall into the publicly "unacceptable" category by today's standards.

This anti-vaxxer tells viewers that the vaccine doesn't prevent transmission, which is true. But the motive here is to undermine public trust in vaccination. The tweeter says that anyone with an immune deficiency could die from anything, to undermine the severity of COVID-19.

This tweeter is not criticizing vaccines, rather they criticize the division over vaccines and masks that the pandemic made. The tweeter says that China made this situation, and they have won the war without firing any shots.
The tweeter believes people should not have vaccine exemptions based on their religious beliefs.
The tweeter shares an article about how Ghana received 1.2 million COVID-19 vaccines from the U.S.
The tweeter expresses they are happy their children can still attend school after exposure to COVID-19 since they are vaccinated.
The tweeter shares an article about how Moderna is almost done a trial that may FDA approve vaccines for children.
The tweeter claims Vermont had higher COVID-19 infections in November 2021 because of "leaky vaccines" and "seasonality."
This anti-vaxxer says that it's not fair that border patrol agents are being fired for not being vaccinated, while "illegal" immigrants are able to get through the border without a vaccine passport.
criticism_other: Immigrants not having to prove vaccine status

meaning: This anti-mandate person seems concerned that the NHS app could lead to long-term mandates. The tweeter is clearly opposed to vaccine mandates in the work place and in travel environments.

It's not clear who this tweeter refers to, because the original tweet was deleted. But they seem to be criticizing an anti-vaxxer who spreads disinformation from an anti-vaxx doctor. The tweeter is commenting on a discussion about myocarditis and reaffirms that the cases are very low, given the millions of people that have been vaccinated.

This anti-vaxxer says that a politician is coercing people into getting vaccinated. They say that people who don't keep up with their vaccine status fall into the publicly "unacceptable" category by today's standards.
This tweeter says that Fox News is spreading lies about how the vaccine is causing deaths. She says the vaccine is life-saving, therefore this is a pro-vaccine tweet.
This pro-vaccine tweeter shares news about attending a lecture or conference to promote research she did on cost-effectiveness of HPV vaccinations.
This tweeter is not anti-vaxx yet pro-choice about vaccination so I flagged this post as "unsure about the vaccine." The tweeter criticizes Aaaron Rodgers for lying about his vaccine status.
This tweeter promotes a discussion involving Dr. Robert Malone, a scientist involved with vaccine development who spread misinformation about the vaccine. Therefore, this tweet is anti-vaxx.
This anti-vaxxer says that satan is laughing and spreading his wings amongst vaccine mandates.

This anti-vaxxer says that death can be a good side effect of the vaccine. They posted a tabloid looking image of a man getting vaccinated while looking afraid. This post is nonsensical and intends to spread vaccine fear.

This tweeter seems to be making fun of anti-vaxxers with this tweet. He makes a sarcastic comment about someone being in the hospital for a stroke, yet he's not vaccinated. This is not anti-vaxx because the same tweeter said higher up in the tweet that he knows lots of vaccinated people in the work place who had no issues with the vaccine.
The tweeter criticizes Joe Rogan and others who are supposedly profiting off their platforms that push the narrative that COVID-19 is fake and vaccines are ineffective.
The tweeter, who is from India, is making fun of the U.S. for having anti-vaxxers and toilet paper shortages, as well as their missteps with Afghanistan.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine because they share positive news about a possible new mRNA vaccine for HIV.
This pro-vaccine tweeter shares news about attending a lecture or conference to promote research she did on cost-effectiveness of HPV vaccinations.
This tweeter is simply relaying information about medical set ups in their hometown. No comment is passed on their vaccine beliefs.
This anti-vaxxer, anti-masker says that people can lock themselves in their basements if they are afraid of the virus.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says he's happy that a republican who was against pandemic mandates resigned after his wife died of COVID-19. This tweeter says he's happy that person resigned and asks if others are too.
The tweeter discusses how anti-vaxxers and vaccine boosters are both issues, claiming that both groups do not have immunity against COVID-19.
The tweeter expresses frustration for being "discriminated" against for not being vaccinated.
The tweeter spreads misinformation by saying it is typical for those who are fully vaccinated to still contract COVID-19.
The tweeter discusses how Josh Allen, a football player for the Buffalo Bills, will miss a game against the Patriots because he has had COVID-19 for 10 days and is not vaccinated.
The tweeter claims messaging around COVID-19 vaccines are general and don't promote specific vaccines (i.e., Pfizer, Moderna) because then they would have to discuss specific side effects.
The tweeter claims vaccines are ineffective and immunity between vaccinated and non-vaccinated populations are not that different based on a research article from The Lancet.
The tweeter claims that vaccinations should be a personal choice and not a requirement.
The tweeter questions how COVID-19 vaccines are safe when they cause myocarditis and blood clots.
The tweeter shares an article, that seems uncredible, discussing a lawsuit against Pfizer, Ventavia and ICON for allegedly withholding information about the efficacy of their vaccines.
The tweeter responds to someone who said not wearing masks is unethical by saying that vaccine trials are what should be considered unethical.
The tweeter shares an article about India's COVID-19 vaccination drive.
The tweeter shares that even though some people who are vaccinated may contract COVID-19, the vaccine is still effective.
The tweeter claims that anti-vaxxers are not the problem, but rather the government and public health institutions that have lied, mis-managed and broke public trust.
The tweeter spreads misinformation by claiming COVID-19 vaccines were tested during the first three-month rollout not during trials, which is why so many people are dying.
The tweeter claims that flyers will need four vaccines to fly with Qantas Airways Limited, but the website to support such a claim does not work.
The tweeter asks whether MAGAs will refuse mRNA vaccines that may prevent cancer because the process was rushed or they question what is in them.
The tweeter spreads misinformation by saying vaccines and masks are ineffective. They also claim they have been criticized by both supporters and critics of Donald Trump.

The tweeter says they quit their job after vaccinations became mandatory. They apparently told their boss that they "sicken them" as their boss also did not want to be vaccinated but did so to not be fired.
The tweeter who calls COVID-19 vaccines "trial vaccines," says they contracted COVID-19 without being vaccinated and only had mild symptoms.
The tweeter shares an article that is clearly misinformation about the ingredients in each COVID-19 vaccine and related agenda and purpose.
The tweet shares an article about anti-vaccine, mask and future lockdown protests continue in Brisbane, Australia.
The tweeter is asking someone who said they have had COVID-19 antibodies for 19 months whether their antibodies were from the vaccine or because they previously contracted COVID-19.

This post argues that people, especially young people, should follow the precautionary principle with the COVID19 vaccine, exercising caution with possible side effects because we have zero knowledge of long-term effects.
The tweeter spreads misinformation by claiming the government is re-writing human rights acts to enforce mandatory vaccinations and force people to become state property.
The tweeter discusses their frustration with Novavax rollout in Australia and how general practitioners have been lied to about vaccines for children.
The tweeter claims that medical privacy being patients and practitioners no longer exists as different levels of government can access personal information from vaccination profiles.
The tweeter spreads misinformation by claiming that COVID-19 vaccines are experimental and were not approved when they were first rolled out.
The tweeter is asking for clarification about vaccination requirements when traveling to Canada from the U.S.
The Victorian Department of Health promotes that those aged 12 to 59 book an appointment for a Moderna vaccine.
The tweeter says that selfishness in the U.S. should be accredited for poverty and poor healthcare. They say the vaccine rollout is an example.
The tweeter explains they had intense side effects from Pfizer and less from Moderna. They share that though the side effects are unpleasant, COVID-19 symptoms would be worse.
The tweet shares article discussing how New Zealand riot police were dispersed to break up anti-vaccine mandate protests on March 2, 2022.
Tweeter implied that anti-vaxxers also follow science by listing three scientists who opposed facts such as climate change and the effectiveness of COVID vaccines.
This tweeter asks if vaccines will be available soon for babies and kids under five. This is pro-vaccine because no negative comments are included with this post.
This anti-vaxxer suggests that police are stopping cars and asking for papers, meaning vaccine passports. This upsets the tweeter, therefore they are anti-vaxx.

Replying to a tweet that criticized the U.S. government for stripping the army personnel's freedom of choice by enforcing the vaccine mandate, tweeter pointed out that the military is all about following orders.

This post appears to be sarcastic. It makes fun of conspiracy theorists for thinking that the world’s elites are conspiring to reduce the human population by first releasing COVID19 and then making dangerous vaccines, with everything culminating on December 20.

A Scottish politician seems to be indirectly criticizing media outlets for not covering that the former Head of Vaccine Task Force said the UK Health Secretary should resign over his Valneva statement.
The tweeter shares a website where individuals can report nurses who spread misinformation about COVID-19 vaccines.
The Attorney General of Arizona believes border patrol agents should not have to be vaccinated or possibly fired for being an anti-vaxxer as it will present security risks the U.S. border.
Tweeter is implying that anti-vaxxers are apparently Trump and conspiracy theorist QAnon Shaman's supporters.
This tweeter asks if a vaccine could be developed with effectiveness against all variants. This is pro-vaccine because the tweeter clearly supports vaccination tactics.
This is an informational tweet about COVID-19 from a news source. It's inherently pro-vaccine although it contains no personal opinion.
Tweeter is stating that India has a lot of unused vaccines lying idle in the capital.
Tweeter is implying that children should be vaccinated against COVID 19 and not doing so will be medical negligence.
This tweet is a news re-post about how Victoria state in Australia eased it's COVID-19 restrictions. The tweet contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter says that the two nurses in Long Island who forged COVID-19 vaccination cards should go to prison.
support_other: Imprisoning people who forge vaccine cards

meaning: Tweeter is sharing his experience of seeing COVID 19 patients in the ER and their severity based on the vaccines and doses they have taken, and stated that the unvaccinated have the most severe symptoms.
Tweeter is laughing at Joe Rogan for spreading disinformation about the COVID vaccine.

This post argues that unlike the vaccines against Tuberculosis, Tetanus, Diphtheria, Whooping Cough, Smallpox, Chickenpox, Polio, and Flu, the mRNA vaccine against COVID19 does not work because it is different and not a true vaccine.

This post argues that the COVID19 vaccine is a eugenics experiment and that taking it is a gamble because side effects could be deadly. It also criticizes a politician for comparing the stigma against the unvaccinated to the stigma against HIV/AIDS patients in the 1980s.

This tweet is part of a long thread between an anti-mandate protester and a pro-vaccine tweeter. This tweet is pro-vaccine and basically tells the anti-vaxxer to go flip burgers at Mcdonald's if they don't want to get vaccinated because there were no vaccine mandates there.
The tweeter discusses how well India is doing with their COVID-19 vaccine rollout.
Tweeter is implying that anti-vaxxers are apparently Trump and conspiracy theorist QAnon Shaman's supporters.
Tweeter appears to criticize mainstream media for supporting COVID related restrictions by sharing a quote, without attribution, that implies journalists were wrong about the pandemic.

This anti-vaxxer says that by wearing masks in the classroom, teachers inhibit student's ability to learn proper speech. They also disagree with lockdowns, and say that they induced a major mental health crisis.
This tweeter tells a group of tweeters to be adult and get the COVID-19 vaccine.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine and public health measures. But she is pro-Brexit and anti-EU. She is angry that the UK's measures are being compared to other European nations.
By sharing data on vaccination and COVID death rates of a certain locality in the U.K. tweeter is implying that vaccines cannot prevent COVID fatalities.
Reacting to a tweet by Justin Trudeau announcing that he tested positive for COVID, tweeter is implying that the PM is apparently admitting that vaccines for not work.
Tweeter is mocking anti-vaxxers by posting a preposterous COVID vaccine side effect story and urging people to do their own research.

Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines do not work by sharing news about New Zealand's coronavirus response minister getting infected with the virus despite being fully vaccinated, but does not mention that the vaccines mainly prevent the severity of the disease.
This anti-vaxxer calls Biden a tyrant. They also say that there have been tons of deaths, many of which the media is not reporting about, from the vaccine. The link in this post is deactivated.
This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccines have killed more military personnel than the virus itself.
Tweeter is responding to a question about patients with anaphylaxis and whether COVID vaccines could pose any harm to them. She advises people with concerns to talk to an expert.
This tweeter is a doctor who believes vaccine passports should not be mandated to include a third dose. He says it's sufficient to have a two-vaxx passport.
criticism_other: Adding a booster requirement to the vaccine passport

meaning: This tweeter says that vaccines can cause an autoimmune issue. He invents a term for this: VAIDS. This is clearly anti-vaxx.
This anti-vaxxer is angry that politicians have mandated vaccines in certain areas of America, while "illegal" immigrants are not subject to mandates.
criticism_other: Immigrants not having to be vaccinated

meaning: Tweeter is implying that nurses who oppose vaccination apparently performed poorly or cheated the system to get their nursing degrees. That's why they do not know about the benefits of vaccination.

This tweeter says that people should not be forced to take vaccines. He asks why only "one MP" is standing up against vaccine mandates. The tweet is misleading because it claims that vaccines are not effective, yet they help prevent death and serious illness.

This tweet is flagged as "unsure" about the vaccine because while the tweeter says they got vaccinated, they also say that their arm really hurts, which spreads skeptism towards vaccines. So the tweet somehow promotes vaccination while also questioning vaccine efficacy.
Tweeter implied that people should not blame China for the coronavirus because no one blamed the U.S. for spreading the Spanish flu, which too, was pandemic.

This tweeter is upset that a board member of Pfizer is also a CEO of Reuters, the news company. He posted a link to that information and then writes in his tweet that Reuters fact checks can't be trusted in regards to clinical trials.
This tweet says that getting boosted is the best way to protect one's self from Omicron.
Tweeter implied that the COVID vaccination campaign is apparently false propaganda, which frightens people to get vaccinated.

Replying to another user whose child has been vaccinated, tweeter implied that the child would have been fine without the vaccine, rather the vaccine will supposedly have long-term harmful side-effects
Tweeter is implying that people who trust vaccines apparently are wrong because tweeter believes that vaccines are ineffective and harmful.

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccine passports and vaccines were designed to force people into being controlled. They use the hashtag "#BigPharma" which indicates their skepticism for formal medicine. The link contained in this tweet is no longer online.
This tweeter isn't clear about what they are promoting, other than that vaccines help the people who take them, while they don't really prevent transmission of the virus.

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines aren't effective and that they won't protect against death, while simultaneously saying that this is the "pandemic that never was." The link contained in this tweet is no longer active.
Tweeter implied that governments and public health officials should have taken alternative ways to stop COVID 19 transmission rather than making vaccination mandatory.

This post by someone who is not vaccinated argues that the COVID19 vaccine should not be mandatory. It criticizes the government and medical professionals for coercing people into getting vaccinated, and writes that many scientists have reservations about it.

This tweeter thanks someone for directing them to a Dr. Sophia for their vaccine certificate. The tweeter writes that they never want to get vaccinated because their cousin died from side effects. The tweet appears to imply a fake vaccine certificate.

This pro-vaccine tweeter posted about two Vancouver-based far-right activists. This post is truthful, I have met and reported on those activists. The tweeter says they are homophobic, anti-public health restriction and bigoted.

This is a news post from the Daily Beast but it takes a pro-vaccine stance by saying this news is a "doozy." The Daily Beast reported that "Dr. Joseph Ladapo, an anti-mask, vaccine-skeptical, Harvard-trained researcher, is set to replace Dr. Scott Rivkees..."
This tweet was made by STUFF, a New Zealand based news site. It reports that Omicron is on the rise and that the state warning colours may change in NZ as a result.
This anti-vaxxer says that there is no pandemic and that it's all a vax "scam" and "power grab."
Tweeter implied that vaccines are apparently experiments by governments and thus are not safe and that another experiment will be conducted in 10 years with antidotes for vaccines.
In reply to a tweet about Starbucks no longer requiring their employees to be vaccinated against COVID19, this post questions how those who reluctantly took the vaccine to save their jobs feel now.

This post argues for a more relaxed approach around the COVID19 vaccine and towards the unvaccinated, writing that COVID19 is a trial vaccine that does not work so we should not be so serious about it.
This post by CTV Ottawa announces that ninety-eight percent of the staff at a hospital in Ottawa’s west end is fully vaccinated against COVID19 and complying with new policies.
This anti-vaxx post claims that vaccines killed people and that "officials" intentionally killed patients. A video to Rumble, a far-right "news" site is posted within this misleading tweet.

This anti-vaxxer claims that a German man would not have killed his wife and kids if he was not "forced" into making fake vaccine passports. Reuters reported that "A man who killed his wife and three young children before taking his own life had faked a vaccination certificate and feared his children would be taken away from him when the forgery was discovered, a German prosecutor said on Tuesday."
This post shares an article from Lorphicweb about the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine having 1291 side effects according to official documents that were released despite Pfizer’s attempt to suppress them.

This is an anti-vaxx tweet. The tweeter says the content in the image is strategically placed: A sticker near a vaccination clinic that says vaccinations are a "lock" not a key. This means the tweeter agrees that vaccine mandates are bad.
This post shares a gif of a woman screaming in agony in the street, writing that she has Trump's vaccine in her body.
The tweeter shares that the U.S. donated two million COVID-19 vaccines to Mozambique.
The tweeter shares an opinion article from the Los Angeles Times, which discusses how it might be necessary to mock anti-vaxxers who have died from COVID-19.
The tweeter discusses the progress and successes of vaccine rollouts in India.
The tweet shares an article about how a vaccination centre in Australia is catering to meet the needs of children who have autism.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that Australia's ACT province is at 80% vaccination rate for kids over 12. The tweeter is a reporter, and this is informational, yet this is a pro-vaccine tweet.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the U.K. government damaged the natural immune systems by way of vaccination. They posted a link to an academic paper to prove this, yet it's too long for any reasonable reader to find back up for the tweeter's claim.

This tweet posts a picture of a man who died from blood clots after being vaccinated. No other news sources reported this death, so it's not clear if this information is accurate. The tweeter tries to generate fear for vaccines by saying they are dangerous and by providing an example of that.

This post criticizes another tweeter for not thinking rationally about vaccine effectiveness. Cases of the Delta COVID19 variant would have been much higher had it not been for the vaccine, they write.
This post by NTD News shares an article about at least four States have called in the National Guard to deal with healthcare staff issues amid COVID19 vaccine mandates for healthcare workers.
This anti-vaxx tweet implies that vaccines change a person's DNA by saying that the Pfizer vaccine becomes DNA in the liver cells. This is misleading, because vaccines do not alter DNA.

This pro-vaccine tweeter criticizes Russian bots. He says they must be busy given the war in Ukraine. Then he reminds readers that the end goal of vaccination is to prevent severe illness, hospitalization or death.
The tweeter criticizes people who support COVID-19 vaccines and oppose travel bans. The tweeter claims people have become hypocrites after Biden was voted in.
The tweeter shares a poll from the British Health Alliance which claims 75 per cent of voters do not trust the COVID-19 vaccine. He is also encouraging others to vote.
The tweeter claims people who no longer oppose COVID-19 vaccines after Trump was voted out of power have proven that vaccines are just about politics and hypocrisy.
This anti-vaxxer calls a pro-vaccine person a "nazi fuck." They ask the pro-vaxx tweeter why they are afraid of the unvaccinated if vaccinations work.

This tweeter supports the use of Ivermectin and monoclonal antibodies for treating COVID-19. They say that public health mandates are not the solution. Ivermectin has been proven to NOT be effective against COVID-19.
Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines are not vaccines but just shots because they do not provide long-term immunity. But the definition of vaccines that tweeter posted has no mention of long-term.

This tweeter shares a Wall Street Journal opinion post from Marty Markary, a surgeon who some label as anti-vaxx. Markary is not fully considered anti-vaxx by the medical community, based on news reports, but this tweet is. The tweet promotes natural immunity over vaccines, and says that it was a mistake to take lockdowns and public health measures so seriously.

This tweeter says that vaccine doses are still available at one location, yet that only Moderna is available. This is inherently pro-vaccine because no negative comments are made about vaccines in general.
This anti-vaxxer calls vaccines and gene therapy "experimental." He also is against boosters and says that by the time someone has their first vaccine, they are asked to take a booster.
The tweeter seems to be discussing political figures or public health officials from China who were getting vaccinated. The source of information, however, does not seem credible.
The tweeter discusses lawsuits about mandatory vaccines. They seem to be indirectly criticizing pharmaceutical companies by mentioning they have unjust immunity.
This post shares a news article about Fauci saying that the United States should consider vaccine mandates for air travel amid the Omicron wave.
This post by United States President Joe Biden writes that vaccines are the best way to fight COVID19. It encourages people to get vaccinated and boosted.
This post argues that the mRNA vaccines are better than AstraZeneca, because they give better protection and have fewer possible side effects.

This tweet says that there will be no further investigation as to whether vaccine injuries were being hidden from the public in the U.K. The metropolitan police investigated and found nothing to indicate that information was being hidden.
This is a pro-vaccine tweet. The writer provides information on how a woman was involved with developing mRNA vaccines forty years before the pandemic started.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that someone could be considered a "moron" if they're more concerned about a vaccine's long term effects than they are about dying.
This pro-vaccine tweeter mocks Djokovic for getting kicked out of an Australian tournament for lying about his vaccine status. The tweeter also mentions another athlete in the mix, Aaron Rodgers.
Tweeter implied that the Biden administration has done a better job in containing the pandemic despite anti-vaccine, masks and mandate rhetoric.
Tweeter appears to imply that he is tired of people talking about vaccines although it is not clear if he is for or against COVID vaccines.

Tweeter is stating a fact about using expired OHIP cards to book vaccine appointments in reply to another user who about clogging the booking system by bogus appointments, as suggested by a former PPC member.
Tweeter implied that Australia's Victoria province's government's policy for opening schools before all children have been fully vaccinated is questionable.
The tweeter shares they did not comment on the vaccine but rather abortion. It can be presumed they are referring to one of their previous tweets.

This post criticizes Fauci, Biden, and the COVID19 vaccine, writing that it is dangerous to get four shots, that Fauci is experimenting on everyone’s bodies, and that production of monoclonal antibodies and antivirals needs to be ramped up.
The tweeter spreads misinformation by saying vaccines will kill people.

This tweeter writes that the chances of ever catching COVID19 are less than three percent, that more than half of their country has never had it, and that survival rates from COVID19 are high. There is no reason to risk getting vaccinated since vaccines could be dangerous, they write.

This post argues that we should stop COVID19 vaccinations because there are many vaccine injuries emerging, the new variant is mild, vaccines do not stop transmission, and children have good immune systems.

This pro-vaccine tweeter is shocked that an event advertised that masking and vaccine passports are not required. The event says that special needs children are welcome as well. The tweeter calls the event organizers freaks and doesn't suggest that people drop their kids off there alone.
This anti-vaxx tweeter tells another tweeter that the report they posted is steeped in propaganda. This tweeter is blatantly anti-vaxx, as per their Twitter wall.
This tweeter writes that two factions of the CDC recommend booster shots. This is pro-vaccine because it promotes vaccination.

This tweeter said in a previous tweet that she got quite ill after taking a booster. In this tweet, she reveals her skepticism towards vaccination, politicians and pharmaceutical companies. She also says she feels she was used as a "guinea pig."
This anti-vaxxer says they're amazed at how many heart problems have been discovered since the vaccine rolled out. This instills fear in vaccines.
This tweet is by the health ministry of a region in New Zealand telling people what type of protection vaccines provide against COVID 19 and the benefits of a booster shot.
Tweeter implied that their views on vaccines do not match with their friends and family's but it is not clear whether tweeter is against or in favour of vaccines.
The tweeter is asking if anyone knows if Dr. Peter Hotez, an American paediatrician, has approved or licensed vaccines for any disease that are currently in use and have long-term data.

This post shares an article by BBC News about high rates of COVID19 infections in children in the United Kingdom. It questions whether the high rates are related to vaccination delays plus lack of protective equipment in schools, or something else.

An independent journalist comments on how Anthony Fauci said it might be good to receive a fourth vaccine. He makes a comment about the science changing since Fauci last spoke about boosters.
The tweeter shares an untrustworthy article about injuries from COVID-19 vaccines, which were uncovered by a German insurance company.
The National Health Service in England shares a video of a 14-year-old girl who promotes vaccinations through her own experience of getting vaccinated to protect herself and her friends.
This pro-vaccine tweet shares some information about unvaccinated elderly people being at risky of dying. The tweet includes a hashtag #getvaccinated .

This pro-vaccine tweeter says that Vaxart will help distribute vaccines to countries in need. They also posted a link to a CNBC article about the WHO, who labelled the distribution of boosters to poor nations a scandal.

This is a sarcastic tweet from an anti-vaxxer. He says that L.A. "nailed it again" with their strict mandates. Because the tweeter posted a news article that indicates COVID-19 rates are on the rise in L.A., his comment is facetious.
This tweeter says that vaccines work. They posted a graph that show hospitalizations going down.
This is a news post about an evangelical health director who said he's dismayed that so many of his fellow evangelists had not been vaccinated.
Tweeter is implying that COVID vaccines apparently cause blood clotting and fail to provide protection against Omicron.
Tweeter is stating that there's a lot of debate around vaccines.

This anti-vaxxer asks if the "whole idea" behind a vaccine is to prevent transmission. This post is designed to discredit vaccines because transmission is still possible, while neglecting to mention that vaccines prevent serious illness or death.

This is a pro-vaccine joke about someone who lashed out against COVID-19 public health interventions. The tweeter says that the guy will have to get waxxed as a result of lashing out against vaccines, which maybe doesn't make sense. But regardless, this is a pro-vaccine tweet.

This tweet is complicated because the tweeter says they got vaccinated. But they also say that they refuse to change their lifestyle and live in a state of "paranoia" regarding restrictions. So this is a pro-vaccine post but it does promote freedom of choice to some extent.
criticism_other: Living in paranoia throughout the pandemic

meaning: This tweet is part of a thread where the same tweeter criticizes Biden for instating mandates to protect crack users. The tweeter is anti-vaxx based on his wall, although what he's saying here, relating COVID-19 health measures to crack use, is unclear.
Tweeter implied that the U.K. government's decision last year to consider people vaccinated in several countries in Asia, Africa, and Russia as unvaccinated is racist and wrong.
Tweeter shared a Fox news report that many police officers in Seattle will be fired once the vaccine mandate is enforced.

Tweeter is asking whether employees of the retail company John Lewis need to disclose their vaccination status to obtain the sick pay leave and if U.K. MPs used a privacy clause in the country's constitution to keep their vaccination status private.
Tweeter appears to imply that he is tired of people talking about vaccines although it is not clear if he is for or against COVID vaccines.
Tweeter is propagating a conspiracy theory that American public health agencies are conspiring with vaccine manufacturers to keep Ivermectin from people and instead promote vaccines.
Tweeter seem to imply that public servants quitting or getting fired over vaccine mandates will badly impact the public services and the unvaccinated workers will be a risk to people.

Tweeter seems to imply that they have a lot of information about severe side-effects of COVID vaccines which the media apparently will not publish. Tweeter appears to imply that the media is hiding the truth about COVID vaccines' harmful impacts.

This anti-vaxx posted an article about four Alberta-based doctors who tried to sue over vaccine mandates, stating that mandates are a form of assault. The tweeter asks the public to retweet this information.
This is a pro-vaccine news re-post of a CNN article. It's about unvaccinated people who are asking for the vaccine when it's too late, after being hospitalized.
This is a health report from Medivizor titled "Comparing response to SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine doses for patients with RA and healthy controls."

This anti-vaxx tweet claims that a man was denied a heart transplant for being unvaccinated. But no proof is provided as to whether this is true or not. The link provided in this tweet has been deleted.

This anti-vaxxer says other anti-vaxxers who received vaccines throughout childhood, but not during COVID-19 are silly for saying it will make their blood unpure. But this tweeter says that anyone who has taken any vaccines has unpure blood.

This post shares a link to Pfizer documents on the Public Health and Medical Professionals for Transparency Documents website. It argues that according to Pfizer documents, COVID19 vaccines are not safe. It also questions what misinformation is, really.
This post writes that making bubbles of athletes in the NHL was important for preventing positive cases of COVID19, especially while the vaccines were not yet available.
This tweeter questions why people live in fear of the COVID19 vaccine.

The tweeter spreads misinformation by claiming vaccinations and COVID-19 is part of the "Great Reset," explaining that if the pandemic was legitimate, the U.S. would have closed their borders and started distributing "therapeutics" sooner.
The tweeter claims pharmaceutical companies would have killed South African president, Jacob Zuma for not getting vaccinated.

This tweeter claims that indigenous people should be grateful that white man colonized the land because they brought vaccines and healthcare for all. This tweet is pro-vaccine yet misleading because it celebrates the "good" colonizers did for people they oppressed.

This tweeter says that there should be penalties for transit workers who refuse to get vaccinated, because the amount the government spends on getting them tested as a substitute is costing too much money.
Tweeter, a registered nurse, expressed her frustration about COVID vaccine disinformation on social media as she shared her experience of seeing young people, healthy people die of COVID 19.
This tweet from a WHO Africa branch says that testing and surveillance of vaccine uptake must continue in Africa for COVID-19 to be controlled in that region.
This anti-vaxx tweeter calls out the CDC for taking too many years to release the vaccine trial information.

This anti-vaxx tweet asks if vaccines are really that effective and if they will prevent deaths in light of a fourth wave. The tweeter seems anti-government and believes politicians will create a fear of the fourth wave.

This anti-vaccine, anti-lockdown post says that it was not okay to question things that officials told the public regarding public health measures. This hints at conspiracy theories of the pandemic being used to control people. The tweeter claims that doctors lost their jobs for saying things that could be considered controversial.

This tweeter posts a graph that is not credibly sourced and says that there's a higher rate of vaccinated people in hospitals than there are unvaccinated people. The tweeter also says that this is an utter failure of "experts," meaning they could be anti-government or anti-science.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that the "true vaccine" is antibodies (natural immunity).
In response to a ski resort refusing to let an unmasked person enter the ski lift, this post argues that this should be illegal, and that there is no need to wear a mask outside and with distance.
This post writes that taking the COVID19 vaccine will cause people to die.
This post replies to a tweet by New York State Assemblymember Mike Reilly, asking him to get rid of vaccine mandates.

This is an informational tweet about how people braced for the freedom convoy in Brussels, yet no one showed for that event. There is no personal opinion contained in this tweet, and the link provided contains is broken.
Tweeter is implying that vaccines are not effective and thus provide no protection against COVID 19.

This tweeter claims that there are far more cases of Omicron in the vaccinated population than in the unvaccinated. It's not clear if the graph is reputable though, it's sourced to www.rki.com who's standards are not clear given the site is in German.

This tweet is hard to understand, it contains technical knowledge that wouldn't make sense to any readers, so it's not clear if the information is accurate. But it regards testing and cycle thresholds.
This is a pro-vaccine news post about how a health ministry recommends opening borders once COVID-19 booster rates improve.
This tweet is anti-vaxx because it asks if a vaccine status was considered in a certain situation, which indicates that the person is concerned with personal "freedoms."

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines could have a risk to children and that mandates should not be made. They believe that vaccines are about protecting the individual, not others, which is misleading because a certain percentage of the population must be vaccinated to reach herd immunity.
This post shares an article by Rifnote that criticizes Biden for vilifying police and medical professionals for not complying with COVID19 vaccine mandates.

In response to a tweet that suspects the winter will be a lockdown for the unvaccinated, this post argues that the unvaccinated are actually on track to reach herd immunity for COVID19 faster than the vaccinated.
The tweeter shares an article which discusses that Democrats have cut $5 million for global COVID-19 aid.

This is a news post from The Hill about how "A group of Air Force officers is suing the service in an Ohio federal court after being denied religious exemptions to the COVID-19 vaccine mandate." No personal opinion is included.
This tweeter says it's not ludicrous that Justin Trudeau could end up in jail given "many people have died because of vaccines." Obviously this post is misleading.
In reply to another user who taunted anti-vaccine protestors for using microphones in their rally, tweeter implied that the protest is not against the vaccine itself rather it is against the mandate.
Tweeter implied that scientists did not invent the vaccine out of thin air and the vaccines do work. Tweeter blames anti-vaxxers for spreading the virus and misinformation about the vaccine.

This anti-vaxxer claims that mRNA vaccines create a toxic spike protein in the human body. They say that the pharma companies are controlling the narrative on this. This is not true, Reuters reported that "scientists told Reuters the tiny level of spike protein measured in the bloodstream of vaccinated people does not cause toxicity; rather, they show the vaccine is getting to work."

This is a re-post of a news article. It's not clear if this tweet is anti- or pro-vaxx but it says the story is vindictive while the author says anti-vaxxer's rights should be curbed while they present risks for extending lockdowns.
This is a promotion for a movie and it states that double vaccination is required to enter the theatre.

This pro-vaccine tweeter mocks a guy for walking away from a job due to vaccine mandates. The tweeter says that many people have received the vaccine with no issues, and that their employers were silly for wasting time on such "silly" anti-vaxx employees in the first place.

This post criticizes anti-vaxxers, writing that they misunderstand and ignore vaccine information. It is scary that people are already foregoing vaccinations for their kids for other illnesses, too, writes the post.
This post criticizes Joe Biden, writing that despite the fact that he said the vaccinated could not get COVID19, it happens all the time. The post calls democrats dumb.

This anti-vaxxer reveals contempt for a pro-vaccine person who used their vacant office to eat lunch. The anti-vaxxer says they stopped leaving their office at that time so that the pro-vaxx person couldn't do that anymore. This reveals vengeance towards those who believe in social distancing measures.
criticism_other: People who are vaccinated and abide by social distancing rules
support_other: Causing problems for people who follow COVID-19 restriction rules

meaning: This anti-vaxxer says that her aunt died two weeks after getting the COVID-19 vaccine, which she says the home she was in made her get. There is no evidence provided that the vaccine killed her aunt, yet this post generates fear for vaccines.

This tweeter said the the VAERS report only came under scrutiny since the pandemic started, implying that media and media professionals are hiding vaccine side effects. VAERS is not peer reviewed, so people can upload misleading information that gets listed on the site, with the purpose of spreading disinformation.
Tweeter implied that the tennis player Novak Djokovic, who refuses to share his vaccination status,  should be allowed to play now that mask and proof of vaccination rules have been relaxed globally.

This anti-vaxxer says that people who get vaccinated don't understand anything about the vaccine, and how it's only "1%" effective, which is misleading. The tweeter also asks why those pro-vaxxers can't name a doctor they follow.

This anti-vaxx tweet says that ministers are urging people ages 12 to 15 to get vaccinated. And then the tweeter includes a quote to a video featuring people who say that natural immunity should be considered.

This anti-vaxxer posts a chart from the UK Health Security Agency that reveals COVID-19 cases within certain vaccination groups and age groups. Although the information could be correct, it's not clear what the details are on deaths and reactions, the chart only reveal infections. So those who are unvaccinated could die at a much higher rate.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says that vaccines are being pushed on people by Holohan and that they have a reason to be afraid of vaccines. This tweet is in reply to a news post about a woman who receive compensation for an adverse reaction to the Swine Flu vaccine.
This anti-vaxxer claims that vaccine mandates are a form of social control.
This is a pro-vaccine tweet that posts an article that encourages effective messaging to get people to take the vaccine.
This anti-vaxx tweeter reveals being upset about vaccine mandates being required for a person to get euthanized in Germany.
criticism_other: Being denied medical services due to vaxx status

meaning: It's not clear what this tweet means, and because this tweeter's profile is another language it's hard to know their stance. But it seems this tweet is a comment on Djokovic, but the tweeter calls him DjoCOVID.

This tweet is about oil production and the pandemic. The tweeter responded to a New York Times article about oil shortages and said that oil production should have been pushed for harder to avoid shortages and higher prices.
criticism_other: Lack of oil production during COVID
support_other: Pushing for oil production as demand increases

meaning: This anti-vaxxer says that people protested vaccine passports in Guadaloupe and that politicians, in turn, ran away. The link included in this tweet doesn't lead to the original post to prove this information.

This tweet comments on how vaccinated people are afraid of unvaccinated people because they're worried about transmission. But the tweeter says it's important for the public to understand transmission despite being vaccinated so that irrational fears towards the unvaccinated are eased. This is, in a way, pro-Science yet also anti-vaxx.

This tweeter says that Sinovac is better than Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, and that China will experience herd immunity for using it in their nation. This tweet is designed to discredit mRNA vaccines.
This tweet is somewhat anti-vaxx but more anti-mandate. The tweeter says that mandates are divisive, which has proven true.
This tweeter does not support the vaccination of children. They say that children don't need to be vaxxed, which is misleading.

This tweeter says that children should not be vaccinated. He uses the hashtag #noway in relation to that thought. He says that public health officials want the public to blindly trust they on this matter, which reveals anti-government sentiments.
Tweeter shared a link to a case report about a woman apparently contracting a rare disease after Pfizer's COVID vaccine second dose. But the link does not work.
Tweeter appears to be dismayed that a large corporate entity continued to support an anti-vaccine  American footballer who spread vaccine misinformation.

It's not clear if this post is promoting or criticizing anything, but the tweeter does say that the only reason why people are talking about vaccine status's in sports is because Kyrie is not allowed to play.
This pro vaccine tweet contains information about a vaccine phone line, and the hours in which calling is possible.

This anti-vaxxer says Biden got triple vaxxed 666 days after Covid began. They equate this to some kind of demonic conspiracy theory. Reuters reported that Biden did not get vaccinated with his third dose 666 days after COVID-19 began.

Replying to  tweet about a patient apparently dying from vaccination, tweeter is asking a lawyer if the Indian government's door-to-door vaccination drive can be stopped by showing medical exemption certificates.
Tweeter shared a piece of breaking news about an Indian state making vaccination mandatory for all citizens.
This tweeter says that professional athlete, Rodgers, drinks scotch and that that is more effective against COVID-19 than the vaccine.
This anti-vaxx tweeter says that government made a divide between families and therefore poses a threat to society. The tweeter says that such a threat needs to be removed from office.
support_other: Removing politicians from office for vaccine mandates, liberty

meaning: Tweeter is debunking the conspiracy theory that COVID vaccines have been developed to kill millions of people by stating that such a strategy if any, would have been carried out better with a virus not its vaccine.
Tweeter is asking the BBC to report on the discrimination Brits are facing in Korea as their vaccination is not being recognized by the Korean government.

This tweet is not about vaccines, it mentions them, but it's about mutations of the virus. The tweet is not well written and hard to understand but seems to imply that more infections strains of COVID-19 are emerging.
