Tweeter implied that people should get fully vaccinated and practice the other COVID safety measures to protect immuno-compromised individuals from the coronavirus.

This anti-vaxxer claims that there's a TikTok video that was banned while it revealed vaccine injuries and a message from someone at the CDC. The tweet contains a link that had a security warning when I tried to open it.
This is a pro-vaccine tweet. It shows images of a vaccination day celebration.
Tweeter implied that the U.K. government has not done enough to ensure the protection of clinically extremely vulnerable groups against COVID 19 by offering them priority in getting booster doses.

This is a news re-post yet it is inherently pro-vaccine. It reports how a Florida health official was suspended for sending a pro-vaccine email. DeSantis made a law banning vaccine mandates and this email was caught up in that debacle.
This is an informational post about how the U.S. is investing in global COVID-19 vaccine response.

This is an anti-vaxx tweet. It looks pro-vaccine at first, but because it says that vaccines don't cause cancer, and a skull is placed next to that line, it's actually saying that vaccines do create cancer. There is a link included in the tweet, but it was removed by twitter.

By sharing a false percentage of unvaccinated people in the U.K. tweeter implied that anti-vaxxers are not a minority and their numbers are rising because fully vaccinated people are apparently refusing booster shots.
This tweeter makes fun of Bolsonaro, who failed to provide a vaccine passport and was thus forced to eat pizza on the street in New York.
This is a news post yet it's inherently pro-vaccine. It reports that scientists say vaccines are holding up well.

This tweeter says they won't get invited to Rod Stewart's house for Christmas in reply to a news article that reported he only wanted triple vaxxed people at his house. This tweeter also makes a comment about elitism, whether or not he associates that with vaccinated people is unclear.

This pro-vaccine tweeter talks about the far-right. She says, earlier on in the tweet, that far-right activists were protesting public health mandates. This tweeter says that majority of people actually support those measures. She says that weeding out the far-right is on unions' to-do lists.
Tweeter implied that they prefer to continue to practice the mask and distancing measures to keep themselves protected against COVID even after being fully vaccinated, along with booster shots.
Tweeter shared a link to Joe Morgan's show where he interviews a biomedical scientist and podcaster who talks about COVID vaccine misinformation.
This tweeter says that minister Ron Schuler of Manitoba should be removed from office for not disclosing his vaccine status. She says that such actions have lethal consequences.

This pro-vaccine tweeter makes fun of anti-vaxxers who got sick after attending a rally. They speak of COVID-19 conspiracy theories while this tweeter says they likely got sick from eating at food stalls with unhygienic cookers, while simultaneously not being vaccinated.
Tweeter shared a video showing a non-profit development organization's effort to distribute COVID vaccines in remote communities.
By sharing an opinion piece criticizing the B.C. government for lifting mask mandates and proof of vaccination requirement tweeter implied that the decision was wrong.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine. He says that a certain country (South Korea?) has lost it's hold on flattening the curve. He also says he'd rather see heightened vaccine rates, rather than heightened masking.
This tweet is a news post from NYPost, yet that is a media outlet with questionable standards. This article says that the vaccine mandate wiped out half of NYC restaurants clientele.

Tweeter is replying to another user, who criticized COVID vaccine's safety by sharing a study on vaccine-induced blood clots. He pointed out that the rare side-effect was not from the mRNA based COVID vaccines.
Tweeter implied that Biden administration's vaccine mandate is wrong by sharing a video of an American grocery store owner who filed a case against the mandate.
Tweeter implied that the U.K. government's decision to open up the economy despite having high COVID cases is wrong as vaccines alone cannot prevent transmission.
Tweeter implied that the vaccine mandate is not effective as fully vaccinated people can also get the virus in locations that require proof of vaccination.

This tweet is part of a thread by a journalist reporting on some type of COVID-19 related press conference. She is simply reciting what a politician or public figure said about masks possibly going back to being optional. No personal opinion is contained in this post.

Although this tweet is true -- stating that natural immunity could provide stronger immunity to certain strains of COVID-19, if a person is not vaccinated for that strain -- it's clearly anti-vaxx. The tweeter has a motive for posting that information, which is to undermine vaccines.
Tweeter implied that Australia's New South Wales government should have taken other measures in fall along with vaccination to prevent rising COVID cases, as vaccines alone cannot stop transmission.
This tweeter posted a link to a bogus right-wing site and said that hospitals are filling up due to vaccines. This implies that vaccine injuries were the reason hospitals filled up.
This is a post from the far-right news outlet, Epoch Times. It says that 68,000 negative comments flooded the federal register once Biden announced vaccine mandates.
Tweeter shared a video showing a non-profit development organization's effort to distribute vaccines in remote communities.

This tweeter says that there is a new movement of "vaccine libertarians" who think vaccination is enough and that social distancing no longer has to be followed. He said people should be responsible on a societal level, not just an individual level.
criticism_other: People who think vaccination is enough

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweeter encourages readers to report people who fake vaccine passports. She provides a hotline to call if someone knows someone who did that.
Tweeter implied that the COVID vaccines, used by Ghana's government, are apparently rejected foreign products and that is why Ghanaians are refusing to get vaccinated.
This is a tweet by an Indian wastewater technology company providing data on coronavirus including prevalence, vaccination, fatalities in India.

Tweeter implied that anyone who questions the vaccine hesitancy in the  U.S. military must be a follower of mainstream media because the media is apparently brainwashing people to believe that vaccines are effective.
This is a tweet by UN Rwanda sharing information about the number of people fully vaccinated in the country.

This tweet is part of a thread by a journalist reporting on some type of COVID-19 related press conference. She is simply reciting what a politician or public figure said about masks possibly going back to being optional. No personal opinion is contained in this post.
This tweeter says they got vaccinated and that they feel sorry for their friend's brother who chose not to get vaccinated. He is now dying of COVID-19.
This tweeter promotes vaccines and asks Doug Ducey when he'll get their state up to the national average vaccination rate.

This tweet is pro-vaccine and anti-patent. The tweet says that the Northern Independence Party's account was blocked for pushing to remove vaccine patents and they ask for them to be unblocked on twitter.
support_other: Allowing other countries to produce the vaccine

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweeter says he finds it strange that some people are okay with getting one vaccine, but not the following boosters.
This tweet promotes flu vaccines and says they have benefits for society.
This tweeter says that due to slow vaccine roll outs in Europe, the infection rate is quite high. She also says opening up is a problem.
This anti-vaxxer says they thought that more people would push back against vaccines when they were approved for children. They also say that vaccination of the elderly and vulnerable is "crazy."
criticism_other: Vaccination of kids and the elderly

meaning: This tweeter says they didn't vote for a Republican in Floriday and that they don't need more anti-vaxxers in that state. This is pro-vaccine.

This tweeter says that vaccines are not a "silver bullet" but that things would be much worse without them. The tweeter says governments are now faced with the ethical dilemma of having to decide if they should re-open and let the virus "rip" through communities, or if they should put more restrictions in place.
This tweet is a job posting for a pro-vaccine related job.
This anti-vaxx tweet promotes a link for anti-vaxxers to help complain against "Biden's" vaccine mandates.
This anti-vaxx tweeter is critical of Fauci and asks if he received his COVID-19 shots. News reported that Fauci received his second shot in Feb. 2021.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that people who take risks with not getting vaccinated are ableist because they put the immunocompromised at risk.
This tweet is pro-vaccine. It asks how the government could possibly be encouraging vaccination while simultaneously lifting vaccine mandates.
This is an announcement made by the FDA about Pfizer. It says that Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine will include an additional booster vaccination.

This tweeter seems to be supporting vaccines with this post. Judging on their Twitter profile, which is fairly progressive, they likely are fighting with an anti-vaxxer in this tweet. It's hard to tell because the tweet it replies to is deleted.

This tweeter said that anti-mandate protesters "disparaged" a group of people, filmed it, posted it on social media and then took it down. This is a pro-vaccine post because an anti-vaxxer wouldn't use the word "disparage."

This tweeter says that acquiring vaccines is not a race, in relation to Australia having to get vaccines from the U.K. I flagged this as unsure about the vaccine, because this person didn't make a statement on whether vaccines are good or bad.
This pro-vaccine tweet tells readers that giving one's family the protection of being vaccinated is a great Christmas present. The tweet provides information on how to book a vaccination.

This tweeter engaged in a thread about Ukraine. One person complained that Ukrainians were huddled up in bomb shelters while the vaccination rate is low in that country. This tweeter says he is pro-vaccine but that Ukrainians have big issues to worry about, such as bombs flying over their heads.
criticism_other: People complaining about Ukrainians huddling in bomb shelters while vaxx rate is low

meaning: This anti-vaxxer posts a news headline which seems to come from Newsweek about how unvaccinated kids are less likely to die from COVID-19 than triple vaxxed adults. This intends to discredit vaccination and intends to deter vaccination of children.
This vaccinated tweeter says he's excited to see his grandma for the first time since the pandemic started. She was isolated in a care facility where no guests were allowed.
This anti-vaxx tweeter is critical of Fauci and asks if he received his COVID-19 shots. News reported that Fauci received his second shot in Feb. 2021.
This tweeter shared a link to a CDC article to encourage the vaccination of children and teens. He writes that COVID-19 is among the top ten causes of death for children ages 5 to 11.

This tweeter asks an anti-masker what their take on vaccines is, after having a battle. The discussion was prodded on by a photo of a wrestler using a mask at a tournament. The anti-masker said it was ridiculous to do that.

This pro-science tweeter tells another tweeter that COVID-19 vaccines are not gene therapy. The original tweet that this tweet replied to was deleted, so it's not totally clear what was discussed earlier.

This is a news post about Martin Kemp starring in a pro-vaccine Christmas commercial. The tweet asks the public what they think about this, therefore this post is unsure about the vaccine, rather than promoting a stance.
This anti-vaxx tweet claims that a large group of people gathered in Delhi to convey concerns about the "trial vaccine." This promotes conspiracy theories and vaccine fear.

This tweeter says that acquiring vaccines is not a race, in relation to Australia having to get vaccines from the U.K. I flagged this as unsure about the vaccine, because this person didn't make a statement on whether vaccines are good or bad.

This pro-vaccine post says that there is a shortage of vaccination, children's and maternal services. This means the tweeter sees this as a problem and wants to see more supply of medical services in their community.

This tweeter replied to another post and says that lymph nodes could swell after receiving the vaccine. It's not clear if this person is defending vaccination though, so I listed this tweet as "unsure about the vaccine." The tweeter does promote himself as a member of the far right.

This tweeter says "it doesn't have to be this way" in response to a news article -- which may or may not be true because it was deleted from Twitter -- about how unvaccinated people are filling hospitals in Minnesota.
This tweet seems like an informational news post but it seems critical of testing people for COVID-19 because it says "forced" testing is happening to travelers in Surat.

This anti-vaxxer says that a public figure from South Africa, Former Chief Justice Mogoeng Mogoeng, was the first to speak out against vaccines. He says that he wishes he had taken Mogoeng more seriously back then.

This tweeter made a sarcastic comment about republicans, asking if they don't follow public health protocols because of democrats. This tweeter's wall is progressive, so this clearly is a sarcastic comment.

This tweet is a bogus take on Omicron and mutations. The text of the post contained within this link is ludicrous and emotionally loaded and clearly not credible. The tweet proclaims that vaccination will push the spike protein into some direction, it's hard to understand.
This tweet encourages people to vaccinate children over five years old. The tweet says that vaccination is "safe and effective."
This tweeter says it was great to talk with MP Kody Blois about vaccine update, health-access and mental health. He posted a picture of them together. This is pro-science.
This tweeter shared a link about Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine being safe and effective for school children. This is a pro-vaccine post.
This tweeter says vaccines will end the pandemic. They also say that natural immunity doesn't work because people are dying of the virus when they contract COVID-19.
This pro-vaccine tweet tells readers that giving one's family the protection of being vaccinated is a great Christmas present. The tweet provides information on how to book a vaccination.
This tweet seems to imply that Trump had Bill Gates on commission in 2017 before vaccines came out. This implies some kind of conspiracy theory about Gates and vaccination.
This tweeter says that there should be more sanitation and quality of life where he lives, rather than support for vaccines. This is anti-vaxx.
criticism_other: Low sanitation levels and low quality of life
support_other: More sanitation and better quality of life

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweeter says it's good news that a judge ruled in favour of vaccination when two parents fought over whether or not their child should get vaccinated.
This tweeter is critical of vaccine mandates. He says they may remove people's trust in vaccination due to division happening in society over vaccination.

This tweeter posted a link to a medical story about how the mRNA vaccine created a hematologic disorder in two patients. The text in this tweet is a regurgitation of the title of the article plus some additional information. This post could be misleading because the research does not appear to be peer reviewed.
This tweeter asks why people would take a vaccine when they can use the "usual medication." It's not clear what this means, but this post is anti-vaxx and senseless.

This tweeter calls COVID-19 a scam by way of her hastag and lists all the public health precautions involved in the pandemic. She also says that more people died from picking olives than by COVID-19, which is not true.
criticism_other: Masking, economic devastation made by COVID-19

meaning: This tweeter doesn't really comment on vaccination, other than it's effictivness against transmission is waning. But he asks if it's dangerous to delay opening up too quickly.
This tweeter doesn't believe that COVID-19 can kill. They say they would get the vaccine if COVID-19 could kill.
This tweet is by a health centre in the U.S.A sharing information about COVID-19 testing and vaccine appointment booking availability.

Tweeter criticized anti-vaxxers who believe in my body my choice only in the case of vaccines and implied that people who do not want to comply with the vaccine mandate at their workplace should just quit.
This tweet tells readers that Bomaid will cover its members' COVID-19 vaccination administration fee, which is pro-vaccine.
This tweeter says they just got their third vaccine and hopes that they won't get a fever because they have work to do.
This tweet tells readers where they can get their second COVID-19 vaccine in Pokhara.
This tweeter criticizes Ronny Jackson for not mandating vaccines even though he got vaccinated. The tweeter feels that Jackson only cares about himself and not others.
This is a pro-vaccine tweet. The author wrote an article for The Atlantic about how testing is not interchangeable with vaccination.
This tweeter says that natural immunity is better than vaccines, while laughing at pro-vaccine tweeters.

Tweeter criticized a post on the anti-vaccine protest in Ottawa early this year that equated the protestors to WWII veterans. He implied that WWII soldiers fought for the safety of their community while the protestors did the opposite.
Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines apparently do not work and vaccinated people are more at risk from the virus.
This tweeter says that the government is withholding data, in response to an article that says anti-vaxxers are manipulating vaccine data for their cause. This tweet is anti-vaxx and anti-government.
This is an academic post made by a University that assesses whether vaccine mandates are actually a breach of human writes. An academic is mentioned and his picture is posted with this tweet.
This tweeter says that there are no trained staff available at hospitals due to vaccine mandates. This is misleading because many hospital staff are vaccinated.

This tweeter is angry that an online troll is harassing her. Her baby died and the troll says it's due to the vaccine. This tweeter says that's not true, and that the "dumb" anti-vaxxer saw some online meme. This tweeter calls that anti-vaxxer despicable for harassing a "grieving mom."

This anti-vaxx tweeter shared an article from CBC about how young kids are being experimented on for vaccine efficacy. The tweeter says that they're not cool with any kids being "experimented on." They say that a foot must come down on this.
Tweeter is criticizing Africa's ruling party for requiring proof of vaccination to attend indoor gatherings including places of worship, without understanding the reason behind such a requirement.
This tweet tells readers how to update their vaccine certificate, which is pro-vaccine.

This tweeter is critical of the funding behind vaccines and shows an image of people on dog leashes, held by a politician. The tweeter criticizes vaccines for their shot term effectiveness and lack of ability to truly prevent transmission.
This tweet is simple but says that there are politics involved with being vaccinated. Yet they don't quite say something that is blatantly anti-vaxx.
Tweeter shared a post of vaccine awareness campaign in India among sanitation workers.
Tweeter implied that Florida's governor Ron DeSantis opposes vaccine mandates, not the COVID vaccine itself and that democrats are spreading false information about DeSantis.
Tweeter implied that vaccines cause blood clots and block the natural functioning of the body. Tweeter used it as an analogy for blocking someone on social media.
Tweeter implied that President Joe Biden is a autocrat like Putin because he enforced the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter implied that vaccine mandates are pointless since fully vaccinated people can apparently spread the virus.
This tweeter promotes boosters, saying she's about to get it.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that COVID-19 is more dangerous than the vaccine. It's in response to a person who made a tweet about how abortions and vaccines should be voluntary.

This tweeter is pro-vaccine. She tells business owners to hang in their with mandates and that the trolls will stop complaining about restrictions as they get outnumbered by vaxxed people. This tweeter makes it clear that she feels safer going to businesses with mandates, and that other people do too.
This tweeter says that medical exemptions from vaccination are hardly in existence and that people who try to get them should give up. The tweet uses the hashtag #getvaccinated
criticism_other: People who try to get medical exemptions from vaccines

meaning: Tweeter implied that the harmful effect of the COVID vaccines will apparently start to show two years from now. She attributed her opinion to peer-reviewed doctors without mentioning any names.

In reply to another user who expressed anger at the Canadian government for enforcing the vaccine mandates for truckers, tweeter implied that the truckers could just get vaccinated and keep their job.
This pro-vaccine tweeter comments on anti-vaxxers who make theories about vaccine side effects. She place an emoticon that looks not happy next to this text.
This tweeter says that vaccines create mental health problems while posting a link to a Life Site News article to prove this. However that site is a far-right religious site which is not credible.
Tweeter implied that apparently no vaccine mandate was enforced by the Biden administration for companies with 100 or more employees.
Tweeter implied that the ratio of unvaccinated people to vaccinated ones hospitalized with COVID is low because the former have natural immunity which is apparently better than vaccines.
Tweeter is praising India for its capacity to manufacture COVID vaccines.
Tweeter is propagating disinformation about how the mRNA vaccines work in the body insinuating that the vaccine causes the virus to become more potent.

This tweeter posted an article in Front Page Magazine, which is a far-right publication. The article has a quote "People have reasonable questions about the safety of the vaccine, but instead of getting answers, they’re told to shut up," which indicates the anti-vaxx stance of this tweet.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says it's more likely to transmit COVID-19 if unvaxxed, and that transmission is milder amongst vaccinated people. This is still being researched yet is likely true. They also write that the majority of people who died from COVID-19 are unvaxxed.

This tweet promotes conspiracy theories, saying that a conflict distracted people from COVID-19. This person implies that there's a cycle of fake scenarios perpetuated by the news and that COVID-19 was one of those fake things.

This is a news post about the Trucker Convoy and how they want to end vaccine mandates. It doesn't contain any personal opinion although it hints at contempt towards the truckers because this person describes them as "horn blaring," which implies they are annoying.

This anti-vaxxer claims that only 62% of eligible people are vaxxed, which is not true -- many countries have higher vaccination rates overall. They also say that soon only 30% of people will be vaxxed, which makes no sense, other than it promotes vaccine hesitation.

This tweeter is likely anti-vaxx because hey wrote that a court blocked Mayor de Blasio's COVID-19 vaccine mandate without passing judgement. This means the tweeter likely accepts the move to block the mandates.
Mentioning a Pfizer scientist who supposedly spoke against COVID vaccine, tweeter implied that pharmaceuticals know that natural immunity is better than vaccines but promoting the latter for profit.

Tweeter implied that the American Citi group is wrong to enforce vaccine mandate on its employees. Tweeter promoted the use of Ivermectin to treat COVID and propagated the conspiracy theory that vaccines cause myocarditis in athletes.

This tweeter does not disclose opinion rather he says "bring it" in reference to a legal case. He posted an article that reports "The nation's medical regulator has demanded rogue crossbencher Craig Kelly stop distributing 'seriously misleading' information about COVID-19 vaccines." This tweeter is a lawyer and seems more interested in the legal case that will follow, rather than issues around the vaccine.
This anti-vaxx tweeter criticizes Bill Gates and pushes forward conspiracy theories that he is profiting off vaccines. She urges readers to "follow the money" regarding vaccines and Bill Gates.
This tweeter says that vaccines reduce our immune systems and that eventually we will become so weak from vaccines that we will need a shot to stay alive.

This pro-vaccine tweeter says vaccines have been mandated in American schools before COVID-19. They say that anti-vaxxers against mandates are pushing political propaganda. I fact checked this claim and mumps vaccines are mandated in all states except Iowa.

This tweeter promotes fear around vaccines. It says that over a million injuries (implying vaccine) injuries have been reported. The tweeter also claims that the average age of death from COVID-19 in the U.K. is 78+, which implies that people younger than that shouldn't get vaccinated.

This tweeter, who is a writer for the right-wing Telegraph paper, asks why Djokovic was considered a public health threat in Australia by not being vaccinated. She writes that vaccinated people can also transmit and contract the virus.
Tweeter is propagating the misinformation that COVID vaccines are apparently not safe and effective, they cause deaths, and they are targeted at young people.
This tweeter says that the messaging has not been consistent regarding COVID-19 vaccinations over the past six month. He asks if people would buy a used car from someone who's so inconsistent.

This pro-vaccine tweet thanks the U.S. for donating vaccines to Taiwan. An image of two hands shaking, one depicting Taiwan and the other depicting the U.S., are shown to say the two nations are "real friends."
This tweeter promotes vaccine equity. They criticize Canada for hoarding vaccines. They equate this to "genocide."
This anti-vaxx tweeter is upset that the Canadian government was enforcing the Trucker Convoy while America allowed "illegal" immigrants to "flood" the border without vaccine passports.
criticism_other: "Illegal immgrants" not having to be vaccinated to cross into America

meaning: This tweet is a reply to Taylor Swift and asks her to comment on the casting of Miles Teller in a music video. She says that he's anti-vaxx, yet news reported he is vaccinated. And she worries that he will overshadow Taylor's song and video.
This tweeter asks if she can travel from Uganda to Europe without a vaccine passport. This implies that she is not vaccinated and therefore an anti-vaxxer.

This tweeter says that Biden is pushing vaccines due to his frustration over his "failure" in Afghanistan, which is misleading. He writes another line that is hard to understand but implies that Biden is following the Taliban's dictatorship.

This tweeter, based on their wall, is a Republic. This tweet implies something about a conspiracy theory about The Great Reset and seems to be a comment on politicians. They wrote that "this is not about vaccines" in reference to another tweet about the Great Reset.
This anti-vaxxer says "they" put a tracker in the vaccine. This promotes conspiracy theories as well as distrust for government officials and scientists.
This tweeter says that people shouldn't tell each other what to do because people have a choice to decide if they get a booster or not.
Tweeter implied that the Australian Prime Minister did not do a good job of ordering the COVID vaccines in time to fight the Delta variant.

This anti-vaxxer says COVID-19 has become a "propaganda tool" and that someone needs to "justify" our COVID-19 "obsession." The tweeter implies that COVID-19 is not severe and that no one can remember why we are so afraid of it.

This tweeter said that if we want to "sneak" vaccines to Trump followers, that we'd have to sneak them into their bodies by way of deep fried foods, not by salad dressings. This tweet is a reply to a tweet that says vaccines may be in the salad dressing.
This anti-vaxxer says that the risk of death from vaccination is five to seven times higher from the vaccine than it is from COVID-19 itself.
This tweet promotes COVAX as a way to end the pandemic by providing vaccines around the world. A video is posted with the tweet that says we need to fight the pandemic everywhere in order to stop it.

This tweeter got the vaccine, so he is pro-vaccine. He posted an image of what he looks like after getting the vaccine though, which promotes some skepticism. It's an image of a guy looking confused behind a blurry filter.

Tweeter shared a FOX report on the vaccine mandate causing staff shortages and implied that many people, unwilling to vaccinate, will lose their job when the vaccine mandate comes into effect in the Washington States.

Tweeter reacted to a piece of news about mysterious COVID cases in a region in Australia with low vaccination rate. Tweeter implied that media termed the cases mysterious because of the the region's vaccination rate.

Sharing a link to an article from the Defender that made false claims about CDC director, tweeter propagated the disinformation that even public health officials admitted that COVID vaccines are not effective.
This tweeter says that vaccines are a bioweapon by way of a hashtag. And they also use the hashtag #nuremberg to connote that vaccination is like nazi Germany.
This tweet is badly written yet asks "how can Omicron be nothing when there are still people dying of COVID?" This implies that the tweeter believes in the severity of COVID-19.
This anti-vaccine tweeter says that every health care worker who was fired due to vaccine mandates should be re-hired, and now.

This tweeter is asking a question and is not supporting or criticizing anything. They say that they can't understand the Portuguese tweet that they re-posted, and ask if that tweet means that vaccine mandates will or will not be obeyed.
This tweet asks readers if their MMR and MenACWY vaccines are up to date. This is inherently pro-vaccine.
This anti-vaxxer says that vaccines are not working at The View after two anchors tested positive for COVID-19.

This tweeter says that patents are essentially being hoarded and that certain countries in the world are lacking resources to get the vaccine. This appears to be a pro-vaccine tweet while it implies that vaccine equity should be a priority.
support_other: Allowing patents to be spread to other countries

meaning: This anti-vaxx tweeter says that they see evidence of vaccine injuries, government corruption, media coercion and other things, but that the pandemic is not evident.
This post writes that more than four million children aged five to eleven have been vaccinated so far in the United States with the Pfizer mRNA vaccine for COVID19.
This tweeter announces that they have puppies which will be available after their second set of vaccinations.

In response to a post about someone getting blood clots due to the COVID19 vaccine, this post criticizes vaccine mandates, writing that side effects will happen when people are forced to be vaccinated and threatened with job loss.
This post makes fun of anti-vaxxers, writing that restaurant employees should scare off anti-vaxxers by labelling spray bottles as COVID19 vaccine spray.
This person says "we need mask and vaccine mandates now!" They also mention a person as "he" but it's not clear what this refers because the previous tweet was deleted.
This is a post from Moderna about developments in their vaccine, which is clearly pro-vaccine.

This tweeter says that vaccine passports are easy to forge in California. This is likely pro-vaccine because people who want to forge passports to help their own cause may not raise attention to this possibility out of fear of getting caught.
This tweeter says that is someone doesn't want the vaccine, that they shouldn't be forced to get it.
This tweeter says that there should be no more delays in getting COVID-19 vaccines to babies.

This tweeter replied to another tweeter who said that it's not possible that anti-vaxxers are spreading the virus when everyone is vaccinated in that area. This is inherently pro-vaccine because the tweet attempts to discredit vaccines.
This tweeter is posting information about stocks related to COVID-19. It doesn't pass personal judgement on the vaccines themselves.
This tweeter is upset that vaccine mandates are required for travelers.

In response to an ABC News article about the Kentucky National Guard and strike teams having to be deployed to hospitals across the State, this tweet criticizes Trump for not encouraging people to get the COVID19 vaccine and letting them know he took it, too.

This post criticizes the Prime Minister of Australia, Anthony Albanese, for claiming to want to manufacture COVID19 tests and masks in Australia. He did not back AstraZeneca vaccines being made in Australia, which is a superior vaccine, they argue.
This post criticizes the United States for having more COVID19 vaccines than they need, yet not distributing them abroad. It demands action from President Joe Biden to free the vaccine.

This post criticizes politicians and those in favour of COVID19 vaccinations, calling them vaccine bigots. It also criticizes journalists, implying that they spread incorrect information on behalf of politicians.
This post shares an article by The Guardian about 5G, QAnon, and how conspiracy theorists steered Canada’s anti-vaccine trucker protests.
This is a news post about vaccine cards in British Columbia. The post contains no personal opinion and it reports that mandates will get stricter.

Tweeter tweeted an article from the right-wing Breitbart that criticized republicans who supported the Biden administration's supposedly crazy global vaccination vision that would target unvaccinated Americans.
This is a news repost about tennis player, Djokovic, and how he may skip the Australian open due to vaccine mandates.

This woman is an editor-in-chief for CroakeyNews and shares a new edition of The Health Wrap with readers. The tweet is clearly pro-public health intervention while the paper talks about Zika and global vaccination gaps.

This tweeter is arguing with Ted Cruz, who said he supports Putin. This tweeter say that he doesn't support Putin and that Cruz is a bad liar. He's also fighting with Cruz about vaccine mandate details.
This tweet is a comment on another tweeter's image of a truck that has a confusing message on the back of it. This tweeter asks if that message is pro- or anti-vaccine.

This tweeter is against public health restrictions. He asks why lockdowns are increasing (which isn't true) even though the vaccines have been made available. This questions vaccine efficacy as well as lockdowns.
This anti-vaxxer says that myocarditis was never a side effect of COVID-19 until the vaccine emerged. This is anti-vaxx and promotes distrust of vaccines.

In response to a post criticizing Canada for starting to fine the unvaccinated and to take away voting rights, this post criticizes Quebec for being to blame, as well as LeGault. It also celebrates Alberta for having a law against mandatory vaccination.

This post criticizes Donald Trump for not encouraging people to get the COVID19 vaccine, and not having a plan for education or distribution, but instead simply bragging about the fact that it was developed on his watch.

This post criticizes COVID19 vaccine safety, writing that there is a survival rate of over ninety-nine percent from the disease, and that the mRNA and DNA vaccines turn your cells into spike protein with malignant effects, and could cause death.

This post implies that those vaccinated against COVID19 are the ones spreading it, especially because they do not need to show negative tests to get into events. It calls the vaccinated brainwashed and beta.
This tweeter criticizes Starbucks for dropping their vaccine mandates for employees after the Supreme Court ruled that businesses don't have to require it.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx and says that mandates are a distraction from Afghanistan. This is not only criticism on vaccine mandates, it also implies that the U.S. is doing bad work in Afghanistan by withdrawing.

Tweeter implied that the New York City mayor had enforced the vaccine mandate for political gain and now lifting it for the same reason.  Tweeter also implied that the mandate apparently hurt people and they must sue the politicians for it.
Tweeter implied that they need to go for a vacation after getting fully vaccinated to take a break from COVID restrictions.

This tweeter says that some countries in Europe are not vaccinating certain age groups. And the tweeter suggests that those countries are "wise." This is misleading though because the tweeter posted a video to a link about Sweden as an example of this, yet Sweden is heavily criticized for their lax handling of the pandemic.

This anti-vaxxer (based on his wall) shares a study and says it confirms that even vaccinated people can still transmit the virus, which is true. The study does not clearly state that it was peer-reviewed though.
This tweeter is angry that vaccine mandates are being placed in schools while "illegals" are allowed to cross the border into America without a vaccine passport.

This is a news tweet from an Axios reporter about how two Denver police officers and one Denver sheriff were fired for not being vaccinated. This is an information tweet and contains no personal information.

This tweeter seems concerned with inflation based on the other content on their post. This post is about people lining up for a food bank in the U.K. The tweeter implies that affordability is a rising issue.

This post shares an article by the far-right fake news website WorldNetDaily, which writes that Peter McCullough thinks the COVID19 vaccines are too risky, especially given that most people have a 99 percent survival rate.

This post criticizes the Dans Lockout Fail anti-vaxxer campaign to enter venues without COVID19 vaccine certificates. It writes that the campaign may have started in Belarus and Russia and is targeting small businesses in Melbourne.
This post shares an article by ABC News about protestors’ plans to target a COVID19 vaccination clinic at the Australian Institute of Sport in Canberra.

This post criticizes messaging around COVID19 vaccines and restrictions. It writes that promising a return to normality when most people are vaccinated, and then reintroducing restrictions causes confusion and vaccine hesitancy.

This post shares a video by DW News about Spain having one of the highest vaccination rates in the world without government mandates or incentives. It celebrates this fact, and shares what is behind this success story.

This is a news post from an editor at the Wall Street Journal about how some health care workers would rather lose their job than get the vaccine. The tweeter reports that about one third of the eligible U.S. population remains unvaxxed.

This tweeter says that there are staff shortages while unvaccinated people are forced to stay at home due to mandates. The tweeter is anti-vaxx because he says this is akin to a war raging while capable soldiers sit around not being deployed.

This tweeter seems to criticize crypto currency, blockchain and vaccine mandates all at once by referring to this new style of banking as technocracy. The tweeter is opposed to storing vaccination data on blockchain based records.
criticism_other: Technocracy, recording public health on blockchain

meaning: This tweeter encourages men to get vaccinated and says that they're holding recovery up if they're not.

This tweeter tells the premier that they need to do something about COVID-19 infections that are spreading. They posted a Simpson's meme to make fun of the lack of government action during the pandemic.

This tweeter says they're nervous about getting the booster shot, but that they got two vaccines already, in addition to contracting COVID-19. This tweet therefore promotes freedom of choice and vaccines. Yet it's unsure about vaccines because the tweeter demonstrates fear of boosters.

Tweeter shared a FOX news article on a CDC study comparing the hospitalization rate among unvaccinated people with prior COVID infection and vaccinated people with no prior infection to imply that vaccines are effective.
This tweeter says that people should listen to health professionals, not guys who get punched for a living. He posted an anti-vaxx tweet from boxer Conor McGregor to refer to what he's talking about.
This tweeter makes an anti-vaxx joke. She says that Canadians may be sent to jail for not getting vaccinated, where people can't be forced to get the vaccine.
This tweeter says that people risk their lives when taking the "poison" vaccine.
This is a tweet about a man who died of COVID-19 after refusing the vaccine. The tweet was made by a page dedicated to people who died of COVID-19.
This tweeter is critical of bars asking to see vaccine passports in order to drink beers.
Tweeter is insinuating that the FDA is trying to hide crucial information about the COVID vaccines by asking for 55 years from the court to release the data in response to a FOIA request.

Tweeter debunked disinformation propagated about an Argentine footballer, that he had to retire because of heart issues caused by the COVID vaccines. Tweeter posted news clips from 2017 which showed the footballer had prior heart problems.
Tweeter implied that President Biden apparently wants to vaccinate Americans and not immigrants because he wants to kill Americans through the vaccine and stay in power.
This tweet is by a Jamaican news website reporting about a royal visit to a vaccination centre in the country.

Tweeter implied that CDC directors apparently spread misinformation about the effectiveness of COVID vaccines since vaccines and masks could not stop transmission. Tweeter appears to trust Joe Rogan's vaccine narrative.

This tweeter says that their friend had a heart attack after getting the booster, which implies that the vaccine did it. The tweeter also says they know other people in this situation yet they fail to provide proof of that.
This tweeter is pro-vaccine based on his profile. This tweet doesn't really promote or criticize anything, rather it asks what a link really is, which was promoted by a tweeter before him.

Tweeter shared a link, which did not open, about a child apparently dying after receiving a COVID vaccine. Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines are apparently not safe, so vaccination of children must stop.
Tweeter shared a video explaining the timing for a booster shot for people who contracted COVID 19.

Tweeter implied that government and health authorities should not blame unvaccinated people for spreading the virus because they are reacting out of fear of the unknown. Tweeter also blamed the Chinese government for spreading the virus.
This anti-vaxx tweet features a news clip from FOX NEWS about vaccine mandates and the slew of Americans quitting their jobs as a result. The tweeter refers to mandates as "authoritarian measures."

This tweet is a reply to another tweet that has been removed. This tweeter says that the vaccine was made from the original form of the virus and asks the anti-vaxxer if they expect magic. The anti-vaxxer likely criticized vaccine efficacy. This tweet is slightly misleading today while vaccines are being modified to accommodate new variants.
This tweeter says that police officers were authorized in Melbourne to check for vaccine passports when people travel interstate. The tweeter says that's good.
criticism_other: People who travel without vaccinations, police enforcing vaccine mandates

meaning: This tweeter says that Australia is one of the most vaccinated countries on Earth and that it was a ridiculous proposal for a politician to offer to pay people to get vaxxed.
This is a news post about booster vaccines and their necessity in the future. It's posted on the Toronto Star and contains no personal information.
Tweeter implied that a study, posted by another user on Ivermectin being effective in treating COVID 19, cannot be relied on as the drug was tested on less than 500 people.
Tweeter implied that the COVID vaccines are apparently not approved by the FDA, so the U.S. military is wrong in enforcing the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter implied that her COVID infection would have been worse if she was not fully vaccinated.
This is a news post from a journalist about how Missouri may allow unemployment benefits for people who give up their jobs for not getting vaccinated.

This anti-vaxxer posted some graphic images that say deaths amongst male children were 83% higher than since the pre-Covid years. The text has no source on it. And the tweeter says this would be called "murder" before the pandemic happened.
This tweeter says that vaccines are much safer than "natural immunity" and that very few vaccine deaths have been recorded.
This tweeter says their baby died shortly after they got vaccinated, there is no proof to support this claim in this post.

Sharing a tweet by a school board in the U.S. changing their quarantine requirement for students, tweeter anticipates that the requirement might be loosened as COVID vaccination for children becomes available.
Tweeter implied that right-wing political supporters did not get vaccinated out of their own choice not because of what Trump said.
Tweeter implied that New Jersey's democrat government will lose to a republican candidate in November because of the restrictions and mandates they enforced during the pandemic.

Reacting to a tweet that showed children needed immunization cards even before COVID vaccines, tweeter implied that those vaccines have been in use for a long time and unlike COVID people do not get or transmit the diseases once they are vaccinated.
Tweeter is reiterating the strict vaccine mandate in California where unvaccinated state employees have to get tested to work and school children are required to get vaccinated.
Tweeter implied that the Malaysian health minister is like the pied piper. He led people to believe in the COVID vaccine.
This is a news tweet from an Arizona outlet about how the U.S. will allow citizens to enter the U.S. if they have been vaccinated. The post contains no personal opinion.

This tweet seems to be a joke about the world today. The tweeter posted an image of a map with towns named after identity politics or the pandemic. He says he's making his way to "vaccine valley." This doesn't really promote vaccination necessarily, rather it just uses the pandemic to make a silly map.
This tweet claims that a man's mother was injured by vaccines. It provides no proof to support this claim.
This tweet is a reply to an anti-vaxxer. This tweeter says that anti-vaxxers are dense and explains that vaccines prevent death. They posted a graph which isn't sourced to prove this.
This is a news post from CityNewsEdmonton about how MLA Thomas Dang hacked into Alberta's system to show flaws in the vaccine passport records.

This tweeter defends his anti-vaxx mom and says he wishes that the courts would stand up for people like her. This is misleading because the tweeter says that anti-vaxx sentiments are not as easy as one may think. But that's not true: Anti-vaxxers are anti-vaxxers.
This tweeter asks someone to hire back the people they fired over vaccine mandates.
criticism_other: People losing jobs due to mandates

meaning: Tweeter falsely accused the mainstream media outlet MSNBC of spreading misinformation on COVID vaccines because they broadcasted news and expert opinions that COVID vaccines provide protection against the coronavirus.
This tweet is by a city in the Philippines informing people about vaccination clinic and their hours.

Tweeter reacted to tweet that criticized anti-vaxxers by refuting anti-vaxxers are not afraid of being proved wrong about the vaccine, rather they are afraid of being forced to make a choice they don't want to.

This tweeter says his hair cutter got the COVID-19 vaccine and that she still contracted COVID-19 and ended up in the hospital. He says he's heard other stories like this too but provides no hard proof of it. This tweet is in reply to a guy who says unvaccinated people are clogging up the medical system.

This tweeter posted a pro-vaccine tweet and said that vaccines are not the best approach to the pandemic. In a following tweet, she says that pharmaceuticals are not the best and that the U.S. needs to learn that. This is anti-vaxx and likely promotes natural immunity.

This anti-vaxxer posted a fake news article (The Gateway Pundit) and said that animal studies showed adverse vaccine effects. The tweeter claims they got thousands of pages from the FDA that display adverse vaccine effects.

This pro-vaccine tweeter makes fun of Corbyn by posting four responses other tweeters had to his anti-pharmaceutical remarks by way of screen grabs. Corbyn pushed for a more global response which this tweeter may have confused though.

This tweeter says that people were fainting after taking the vaccine in India. The tweeter implies that this is an adverse effect. But The India Times reported this is likely due to anxiety related to vaccination.
This tweeter is anti-vaxx. They say that people on the internet warning of vaccine adverse effects would be doctors.
Tweeter implied that since COVID vaccines cannot stop transmission, then there should not be any vaccine mandate which leads to the termination of unvaccinated employees.
Tweeter implied that people who support vaccine mandates need to deal with the fact that COVID restrictions are loosening.
Tweeter implied that Trump supporters oppose the vaccine and call it harmful because it has not been named as the Trump vaccine.
Tweeter implied that vaccines and vaccine mandates work by sharing a New Yorker article on the issue.

Tweeter implied that  he does not have enough information to believe that the COVID vaccine for children is safe enough. Tweeter also implied that people have been given false information about vaccines.

Tweeter implied that government did not need to impose COVID restrictions and enforce vaccine mandate to fight the Omicron variant because many places in the world apparently have attained herd immunity. But she does not mention names of any such place.
Tweeter implied that people have no right to ask about another person's vaccination status because that would be an intrusion into the person's privacy.
This tweet promotes a link to information about vaccines. The link says that vaccines prevent serious illness and death.
This tweeter says that vaccine mandates are a form of religious conversion. He says that Hindus have no idea about this, which hints at conspiracy theories.
This tweeter says they won't take a vaccine to travel. They say they will just avoid travel if a vaccine is required.
This tweeter says that people can use the word "vax" instead of "vacc." The tweeter doesn't disclose any opinion on vaccines themselves, rather on the spelling of vaccines.
support_other: Using the word vax instead of vacc

meaning: This anti-vaxxer says that "vaccines aren't good" for him and that the media is missing nuanced discussions about anti-vaxxers. The tweet that this tweet replied to was deleted.

This tweeter says that pharmaceutical companies are marking their vaccines up well beyond their production cost. This is true, according to various news reports. The tweeter says this should be considered a "crime against humanity."

This tweeter is skeptical of vaccines made in China. They posted a Reuters article about how Chinese vaccines were donated to Africa. The tweeter asks if those vaccines are actually effective, which is anti-vaxx.

This tweeter asks why people should get vaccinated given the information they post in a graph, which is misleading: The graph shows that the only difference between the vaxxed and unvaxxed is that people can die if they've been vaccinated, which isnt' true.

This tweeter says that people can look up their vaccine batch and see if other people had issues too, meaning safety issues or adverse effects. The link this tweeter posted is no longer active, so it was likely disinformation removed by Twitter.
Tweeter implied that there's no use in vaccinating students in India as COVID vaccines cannot guarantee protection against infection.
Sharing the screenshot of a so-called CDC report, tweeter implied that CDC is apparently trying to hide the bad side-effects of the COVID vaccine from the public.
Tweeter implied that the Malaysian health minister is like the pied piper. He led people to believe in the COVID vaccine.
This tweeter says that colleges are bragging about their high vaccination rates. The tweeter calls this "coercion" and says that shouldn't be grounds for "bragging."
criticism_other: Colleges bragging about high vaccination rates

meaning: This is a re-post of a Reuters news article. It's about the trucker convoy and how Musk supported it. This post contains no personal opinion.

This anti-vaxx tweeter argues with a pro-vaccine tweeter. This person claims to work in the medical field but provides no proof of that. They say that they're suspicious of the FDA for not wanting to release vaccine trial results for decades. This tweeter claims he follows "real science" yet he's skeptical of vaccines.

This tweeter thinks that boosters are a form of profit for the pharmaceutical companies. The tweeter believes that since the death rate is low amongst infected patients that vaccination by way of boosters is not necessary.

This tweeter asks if the government should rethink it's public health interventions, such as mask and vaccine mandates, because he posted a link to a New York Times article that reports Pfizer's pill could prevent severe hospitalizations amongst people who contracted COVID-19.
This is an informational post about how NYC will oppose vaccine mandates upon private employers. It contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter says that they caught the virus even though they were full vaxxed. The tweet doesn't really promote anything, rather it's a recount of his experience getting COVID-19.
Tweeter implied that vaccination services in conflict zones like the Tigray regions are hampered like other essential medical services.
Listing a number of cities where vaccine mandate rallies were held, Tweeter implied that the media apparently does not report on protests against vaccine passports.
This tweet is by an extreme right-wing media company whose founder opposes vaccine mandates. The tweet promotes the founder taking sides with a radio host who refused to abide by the mandate.

Tweeter, a media outlet, tweeted that researchers did not find any new cases of blood clots induced by vaccines between August and September 2021 but no details were given, nor did the link provided open to the said report.
Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines are apparently not safe and posted a link that is not safe to open.

This tweeter says that a nurse spoke about vaccine truth. They provided a link that has been deactivated by Twitter, meaning this is a false claim. The tweeter likely claims that the nurse believes vaccines are unsafe.

This tweeter disapproves of doctors who would not treat a child due to that child being unvaccinated. The tweeter claims that this would have never happened before the pandemic. This tweeter discounts the severity of COVID-19.
criticism_other: Vaccination of children, doctors who don't treat unvaccinated children

meaning: This tweet is a news post about three separate topics: Vaccine mandates, Mindy hitting Florida and Derek Jeter getting into the Hall of Fame. The tweet contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter promotes vaccination by advertising when the booking slots will become available.

This tweeter says that conservatives demonize science and vaccines, while Liberals don't. She posts two images to prove this: one is a poll about vaccines that isn't very clear. The other is a news clipping about Erin O'Toole showing mixed supports for vaccines.

This tweet was made by an anti-vaxxer because it contains a link to a bogus news page called "Circle of Mamas." That page contains links to stories about vaccine injuries. This tweeter also questions statistics and definitions within this tweet.
This tweeter says the Sindh Govt has failed to provide vaccines for Karachi. This is a pro-vaccine post, while this tweet suggest failure in the lack of providing vaccines.
This tweet is a headline from a fake news website called the Gateway Pundit. It claims that the CDC hid information about vaccines from the public over fear of spreading vaccine hesitation.

This tweeter tells readers to not take a new study seriously. In a previous tweet, he says anti-vaxxers will jump all over it. It's not clear if this tweeter is a doctor, but he tries to clarify some medical information from the study within this tweet.

This tweeter isn't really promoting anything but he's criticizing Modi's government (India) of taking commision from pharmaceutical companies for allowing foreign vaccines into India. This is misleading because it undermines the need to get India vaccinated.
This tweeter makes fun of an anti-vaxxer who complains that they're blood was contaminated by the vaccine. This tweeter jokes and says their blood was already contaminated by incestual relationships.
This tweeter says that COVID-19 vaccines are not actually vaccines because they don't prevent transmission. This is misleading because COVID-19 vaccines prevent death.
This anti-vaxx tweeter asks if it's legal that some institutions still require vaccine passports after Feb.28 for people over five years old.

This tweeter is angry at people who don't follow public health protocols. She asks them what it will take for them to understand the pandemic's risks: A death of a loved one? She posted a link to an article about medical workers who are battling PTSD as a result of working through the pandemic.
criticism_other: Anti-maskers and people who don't social distance

meaning: This anti-vaxxer says that vaccine mandates are a violation of the Nurembourg code, human rights and political rights, among other things. The link contained in this tweet was removed by Twitter.
Tweeter implied that India succeeded in vaccinating a large portion of its population because of the country's Prime Minister and Health Minister.
Tweeter implied that Louisiana's health system is wrong in making employees pay a penalty every month for their unvaccinated spouses.
Tweeter is asking a question and referred to a Tanzanian singer's song on vaccines. The context of the tweet is not clear as the link shared has been removed from Twitter.
Tweeter implied that even if he gets infected with COVID-19 he will not get vaccinated.
Tweeter implied that many people in Groningen, Netherlands do not support the vaccine mandate and COVID restrictions.
Tweeter implied that the social media company has campaigns targeting Irish anti-vaxxers and COVID1-9 skeptics. The link shared could not be opened.
Tweeter seems to propagate a conspiracy theory about someone's charity promoting vaccines in exchange of huge returns from pharmaceutical companies.

Tweeter implied that Britain's GB News is biased because they apparently do not report on harmful side-effects of vaccines. Tweeter also reiterated the misinformation that Pfizer tried to hide its COVID vaccine data for 75 years.

Expressing her anger at a veteran English journalist who asked elderly people, unwilling to vaccinate, not to seek NHS services, tweeter implied that the vaccine mandate can make people say cruel things.

This tweeter asks why vaccinated people are still afraid of contracting the virus. She also shares another anti-vaxxer's tweet, which hints at anti-government beliefs because it criticizes people who listen to the government's advice.

This post is suspicious of Big Pharma and public health. It writes that COVID19 hospitalizations are inflated, the CDC has admitted most COVID19 deaths are of people with comorbidities, and Big Pharma executives have said vaccines do not stop the spread of COVID19.

This tweeter says that no one is talking about myocarditis post-vaccine, which indicates his distrust in vaccine effectiveness. He also claims that young people are dying every week from cardiac arrest, which is a conspiracy theory.
This tweeter may or may not be anti-vaxx, but what is certain is that they're upset schools are being closed. They say that kids can't learn over Zoom school.

This tweeter claims that mRNA vaccines are untested even though they've been in development for decades. He suggest using antibody therapy instead. He posted a link to a Washington Post article about natural immunity.
This tweet is by a vaccine manufacturer based in India quoting one of its managing directors about the importance of vaccine developments to fight infectious diseases.

Tweeter implied that vaccination in Slovenia is still very low and more people need to vaccinate to reach herd immunity but falsely claimed that 85% of the population needs to get vaccinated to achieve that goal.

Tweeter implied that they called out people who spread misinformation about vaccines for personal gains. Tweeter also criticized vaccine skeptics among healthcare professionals who get their information from social media.
Tweeter is giving information about where people over 30 can go to get vaccinated in Newfoundland.
This is a news tweet about an Indian politician accusing Akhilesh of misleading people into thinking that vaccines are bad.

Although this is a news post, it's inherently pro-vaccine because of the language that's used. It talks about one athlete who "slams" another athlete for promoting freedom of choice regarding vaccination.
This is a news article about how an expert fears the stigmatization of anti-vaxx parents. The post was made by the BBC and contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter asks why Nigeria was added to a travel ban list. He believes it's because Americans think that Nigerians didn't take vaccination seriously.
This anti-vaxx tweeter communicates some conspiracy theory about how Fauci silences doctors who had alternative remedies for COVID-19 back in 2019.
Tweeter echoed the disinformation propagated by independent MPP Randy Hillier, who was told to publicly apologize, for spreading lies and misinformation about vaccines, masks and COVID restrictions.
Tweeter implied that they are upset that their daughter's vaccine appointment was cancelled because of the so-called Freedom Convoy in Ottawa earlier this year.
This tweet is by an Australian news network reporting on the logistical challenges businesses initially faced when they tried to enforce the vaccine mandate.
Expressing her anger at a veteran English journalist who asked elderly people, unwilling to vaccinate, not to seek NHS services, tweeter implied that the vaccine mandate can turn very nasty.
This tweet is a children's vaccine campaign by the NHS  providing information on how kids between 12-15 can book appointments for COVID vaccines online.

This tweeter asks if children should be subjected to the "side effects" of vaccines while they believe that the risk of death from COVID-19 is lower in children than it is in adults. Vox reported that "...less than 2 percent of children known to be infected by the coronavirus are hospitalized, and less than 0.03 percent of those infected die. It’s difficult to draw direct comparisons to American adults now that two-thirds in the US are vaccinated, while most kids aren’t. But before widespread vaccination, about 10 percent of people infected with Covid-19 were hospitalized, and around 1 percent died."
This tweeter says that vaccines and boosters are "experimental" and can be deadly. They also posted a link to a web page that provides information about a conspiracy theory called The Great Reset.
This tweet says that vaccination before and during pregnancy is safe and effective. The tweet was made by the CDC and includes a video of a doctor speaking on this matter.
This tweeter asks what the protocol is for lining up at a vaccine clinic, given that the weather was predicted to be -30 Celsius.
This post promotes a Gateway Pundit article, which is a fake news site. It says that a German official reported that vaccine side effects are much higher than reported.

This post is part of a conversation where the tweeter writes that they got Parsonage-Turner syndrome caused by the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine. As a result, they write, their doctor advised them to get no further vaccines.
This is an information post about an exhibition of a gold smith's work. The post says that vaccines and masks are required for entry to the show.

Tweeter shared a malicious link which appears to list apparently peer-reviewed studies that proved that the COVID vaccines are unsafe especially for young people. The link was not opened because of the perceived risk.
Tweeter is asking the Australian Prime minister if he is removing the vaccine mandate in reply to a tweet by the leader that no one in his country will be left behind or held back.
Tweeter implied that vaccines are not 100 percent effective in protecting people from COVID infection, other measures such as masks, social distancing, and using air filters also have to be followed.
Tweeter shared his positive experience of getting a booster jab.

Tweeter implied that scientists and health professionals who spread vaccine disinformation, have themselves benefitted from the vaccine but are harming minorities and religious communities with their anti-vax propaganda.

This tweet appears to be a simple re-post of an article about Disney freezing vaccine mandates in the work place. But this tweet comes from an anti-vaxx perspective while it shares an article from a patriot website, which is alt-right and biased towards anti-science beliefs.

This anti-vaxxer says that they wish they would have spoken up against vaccination long before now. There is an anti-government tone in this tweet because the tweeter mentions criticism towards trusting the government.
This tweet is by Fox News. It reports that asking someone about their vaccine status could soon be made illegal, along with a $14,000.00 fine and up to one year in jail.
criticism_other: Asking someone for their vaccine status

meaning: This is an anti-vaxx tweet that shares information about how Sweden suspended the Moderna vaccine for use in people 30-years-old and under.

This tweeter says that Big Pharma will get sued if they approve the COMIRNATY vaccine (spelling error is contained in this tweet.) The tweeter implies that vaccines are not safe because they say that big pharma can't be sued if vaccines for children are approved.

This post by an NBA writer quotes New York City Mayor Eric Adams on his views about Kyrie Irving’s unvaccinated status. The mayor said that he cannot make an exception for Irving, given the vaccine mandates in the city, as much as he wants to see him play.

This tweet doesn't really promote or criticize vaccines, therefore this tweet is flagged as unsure about the vaccine. The post does say though that doctors recommend waiting for three months to get vaccinated or boosted after contracting the virus.
This tweeter says that cruise lines are getting more in touch with reality by ending vaccine mandates.

This anti-vaxxer says that Pfizer vaccines were reported to only have a temporary effectiveness of 95%, and that that wanes over time, which is true. They mention that placebos were used in Pfizer's vaccine trials, which is true.
This anti-vaxxer says that vaccine mandates have gone world wide. She posts a graph containing screen shots of news clippings from around the world to prove this.

This tweet was made by Marc Emergy, a controversial figure in Canada's marijuana scene. He says that countries that didn't get vaccinated and that didn't practice social distancing have less cases of COVID-19 than vaccinated  countries, or countries that exercised lockdowns. This simply isn't true.
This tweeter says that black lives are the most likely to be destroyed by vaccine mandates, because they are a highly unvaccinated demographic.

This pro-vaccine tweeter makes fun of a guy who's doing his own research about the vaccine. The tweeter says that guy married his high school sweet heart. And he says if that guy couldn't do more research on finding a life partner, then why should he be able to research a vaccine?
This is an anti-vaxx tweet that shares information about how Sweden suspended the Moderna vaccine for use in people 30-years-old and under.

This tweet by the New York Post shares an article about Fauci saying that the Food and Drug Administration Panel have concluded that the Johnson & Johnson shot should have been two doses, not one. In general, the article seems to favour other vaccine brands over the J&J shot.
This post is in favour of abolishing the police and of ending vaccine mandates. It argues that without police, there would be no lockdowns or vaccine mandates.
This tweeter says that COVID-19 mutations will happen in vaccinated too because vaccine efficacy is low. This is misleading because higher vaccination rates can limit mutations from happening.
This anti-vaxxer asks people to explain the purpose of vaccine passports to her.
This tweeter is happy that masks are worn in Hawaii. She also praises their social distancing and vaccination checks. She says that Florida could do the same thing, but that they never will.

This anti-vaxx tweeter promotes conspiracy theories about vaccines killing professional athletes. They ask if vaccines are killing people and then they provide a link to a bogus web article about how vaccines are killing people.
This tweet says that the U.K.'s vaccine roll-out was not as good as France, Spain and Portugal's vaccine roll-outs.
This anti-vaxxer is angry at a professor for taking a strict pro-vaccine view. He doesn't like that anti-vaxx ideas are banned on Twitter as well.
In response to a tweet by an anti-vaxxer, this post by a NASA Astrobiologist questions the anti-vaxxer’s logic underlying their claims that the COVID19 vaccine is unsafe.

This tweeter asks if children depicted in the video they shared qualified for vaccination. The kids were denied entry to a ball game and the tweeter says that may not be fair if they did not qualify for vaccines to begin with. This post passes no judgement on whether vaccines are good or bad.
support_other: Clarifying details about who can get vaccinated

meaning: This tweeter says that Australia treated Djokovic like a "terrorist." He says he was "interrogated" at the border for not being vaccinated and then deported. The tweeter tells readers to boycott the Australia Open.
This anti-vaxxer says that Biden is waging "medical slavery" against Americans by keeping vaccine mandates active.
This tweeter says they think vaccinated people are spreading the virus faster than anyone else, which may or not be true. Regardless, this tweeter is anti-vaxx.
This tweet is about Nicki Minaj and a conflict with Twitter regarding her anti-vaxx tweets. The tweet also reports that the White House did not invite Minaj for a visit.
This tweet is inherently pro-vaccine because it says that India recommends that the Sputnik vaccine goes through a phase three trial. It contains a link that won't open to support this tweet.
This tweeter says that no child should have vaccine side effects because they believe that no healthy children should be given the vaccine.

This tweet seems purely informational while it simply states that vaccines are required for Canadians to travel. But it comes from an anti-vaxx perspective because the tweeter included a link that has been removed, likely because it's false and misleading.

This tweeter says that his brother is dying even though he's vaccinated. And he asks how the vaccine helps. He's not clear about whether his brother is dying of COVID-19, but that is implied in this tweet.
This is a news tweet from a prominent Canadian journalist, Chantal Hebert, about Erin O'Toole and Jason Kenney.

This post by a Christian Pastor is in favour of freedom of choice and against amending the Health Act. They do not want the COVID19 vaccine, it writes, implying that the COVID19 vaccine and worshipping God are mutually exclusive.
This post by a New Zealand doctor criticizes the unvaccinated amid the COVID19 Omicron wave, writing that the unvaccinated are overwhelming hospitals. This could have been prevented, they write.

This is a post from a pro-vaccine activist page that says Marcus Lamb die of COVID-19 after refusing to get vaccinated. This information was also confirmed in the Washington Post, and is true. This tweeter intends to raise awareness about the risks of not getting vaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that there are less than nine vaccine-related deaths. They say that vaccines are therefore very safe.

This tweeter says that they don't necessarily distrust vaccines. They say that they distrust the officials that "demand" that the public take them. This is inherently anti-government and unsure about the vaccine.

This tweeter says that they don't want people to die of COVID-19 as a form of revenge for not believing in the virus. But they are irritated by people who still reject the vaccine while lying on their death bed.

This anti-vaxx tweeter criticizes Jason Donovan for praising Australia's high vaccination rates. The tweeter says Donovan should be aware of all the broken hearts in the world, which refers to myocarditis caused by vaccines - which is misleading.
This is an informational tweet from India's government about the number of vaccines that have been delivered. It provides numbers on the recovery rates of people with COVID-19 as well.

This post makes fun of those vaccinated against COVID19, writing that even with two, three, or four shots, the vaccinated still have to wear masks. It includes an image that writes mask mandates are against our rights and a step towards perpetual enslavement.
This tweeter says that QR codes are not needed for the flu. He says that with COVID-19 there's not choice, when there was with other viruses. This tweet undermines the severity of COVID-19.
This is a informational tweet about how Pfizer authorized the vaccination of kids 5 through 11 years old. The tweet contains no personal opinion.

This tweeter says that people are afraid of vaccine mandates and distrustful of government because of the interpretation of Kyle Rittenhouse's shooting. Rittenhouse killed three people in what he claims was self defense but it is commonly seen as a race based crime. This tweeter is racist by saying that the shooting was self defense and says that the government's response to it was grounds to breed mistrust.
This is a news post about how the White House offered to call Nicki Minaj to answer her questions about the vaccine. This tweet contains no personal opinion.

Although this tweet appears to tell people to get vaccinated, this tweet isn't pro-vaccine. I flagged it as unsure because the tweeter claims that Fauci has "shooters." He linked to a story about a shooting involving a customer who refused to wear a mask. That link was on Russia Today, a fake news site, so it likely was false information.
This tweeter says that vaccine mandates equate to coercion. And she says that any politician who stands for them is a tyrant.

This tweeter tags a bunch of other Twitter users and questions why someone would disown their own son over a vaccine. Although details on the division between this family are not given, it's clear that this is an anti-vaxxer calling out a pro-vaccine person for asking their child to get vaccinated.
This tweeter says that India did manage to design it's own vaccine. He tells another tweeter to shove "Western Tech" up his "ass." This is a comment on vaccine patent hoarding.
criticism_other: Vaccine patent horading and Western superiority
support_other: Vaccine equity - other countries developing vaccines outside "The West"

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweeter shows a picture of two children and another of a dog at the vaccination clinic where she works. She says these kids showed up to support vaccination.
This tweeter says that the vaccine killed millions of people, but that is not true.

In response to anti-vaxxer tweets, this post argues that the COVID19 vaccine reduces likelihood of being hospitalized, reduces the chances of transmitting COVID19 because symptoms are less severe, and that chances of dying from the vaccine are extremely low.
This post writes that if men became impotent after taking the COVID19 vaccine, they likely would not broadcast this side effect.
This tweeter tells an anti-vaxxer to educate himself on how vaccines work. That anti-vaxxer had asked why people are still contracting the virus, despite being vaccinated.
support_other: Educating one's self on how vaccines work

meaning: This tweeter appears to be anti-vaxx because they say the U.K. has to instate vaccine mandates, otherwise they will risk becoming an outcast of the international community. The tweeter doesn't provide any reasoning as to why mandates could be good or bad for public health though.

This tweeter replied to an anti-vaxxer. They explain that the flu didn't kill anywhere as near as many people as COVID-19 did. This tweeter says it's crazy that people said no to a vaccine that lessens the symptoms and death rate of people who contracted COVID-19.

This anti-vaxxer says that the vaccine was designed to spread the virus. He is also skeptical of government, which he says has no liability. He believes government made Covid-19 to intentionally spread the virus, which is a conspiracy theory. The tweeter also posted some data that has no source, which tries to make it look like more people are dying since the vaccine was released, yet there is no information to supplement those numbers or to clarify if they are real.
This tweet is by the right-wing media, Outkick, reporting that Hawaii ended all its COVID restrictions, including proof of vaccination, for travellers.

This tweeter says that "leftists" are abusing people with vaccine mandates. He defines these mandates as "interference" with democracy. He posts a link to the conservative news site, The Washington Examiner, to show readers that vaccine mandates will indeed likely be reinstated.

This anti-vaxx tweeter posted a video link to a clip about "The Great Replacement" which is a racist take on how immigration is lowering the number of white people in North America. The tweeter says that vaccines are making white people infertile and that Muslim immigrants are not being checked for COVID-19.
