This tweeter is anti-vaxx and anti-government. He says the government has been bought and that they are using vaccine passports to manipulate people into fear. This tweeter is also against the vaccination of children.

This tweeter says that a California governor got paralyzed by the booster shot. But this is fake news. Verify this reported that "Video claiming to show Calif. Gov. Gavin Newsom suffering side effects from COVID-19 booster shot is fake."
This post criticizes a nurse who complained about having to get the COVID19 vaccine to keep her job. It argues that the nurse has no right to endanger her patients by being unvaccinated.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that natural immunity doesn't work because the first person who died of Omicron had COVID-19 before, and previously contracting the virus didn't save them from Omicron.

This tweeter has a saved text that they show to people when they get asked if they've been vaxxed. The text says things that link into conspiracy theories and false ideas about "spike proteins." The word "scamdemic" is also written in the text and the tweeter says that it's falling apart.

This anti-vaxxer says that pro-vaccine people not only praise vaccines, but that they lecture anti-vaxxers about Ukraine. Many anti-vaxxers take a pro-Russian stance, likely because Russia fuels a lot of the medical disinformation that is found within the pandemic.

This anti-vaxxer says that nurses don't acknowledge that vaccines can alter a person's DNA which is misleading. This tweeter also says that a company called Tyson Foods demands workers to be vaccinated.
This anti-vaxx tweet was made by a far-right, pro-trump news site called One America News. It claims that vaccine mandates were paused in Tucson after a warning from AG Brnovich.

This tweeter says they're not against vaccines, rather they're against vaccine passports. The tweeter says that vaccine mandates are dangerous in the hands of government officials. The tweeter also feels government has eroded too many rights of the people.

This tweeter says they've lost all faith in U.S. doctors because they've been slow at developing a vaccine for children under five. The tweeter says she's going to hurry her kid to Germany to get them, where they "actually give a shit about kids."
criticism_other: Tardiness of vaccines being released for kids under 5

meaning: This tweet is informational and does not contain personal opinion. It says that 100,000 doses of Pfizer vaccines are at risk of being wasted due to citizens not taking them.

This anti-vaxxer says that side effects to vaccines are real. He also says that people who "crush" any discussion about this creates more conspiracy theories. This tweeter also accuses the pro-vaccine person they're replying to of being paid to complain (protest) anti-vaxxers.

This tweeter is a writer for Rolling Stone. She wrote an article about how people unsuccessfully planned a walk out on schools, due to vaccine mandates. But they did it on a weekend, when no one was at the school, so it flopped. Although this is a news post, it's inherently pro-vaccine while it makes fun of anti-vaxxers.
This is a COVID-19 vaccine awareness-raising campaign tweet by the American state of Utah.

Tweeter is questioning the anti-vax rhetoric in U.S. based on the Americans, both Democrats and Republicans, she met during her international trips. She claimed all of them were vaccinated and abided by the vaccine rules.
Tweeter implied that proof of vaccination requirement at the Super Bowl will not help the attendees because vaccines cannot stop transmission.
Tweeter implied that she got a booster COVID-19 vaccine shot as well as a Shingle vaccine shot.

Although this tweet seems like a joke about Starbucks' bad coffee, it's more about vaccine mandates and how Starbucks suspended them. The tweeter tells readers that there's much better coffee elsewhere, which supports a pro-vaccine stance.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is amazing that Letitia Wright would loose out on a multi-million dollar acting contract just for her anti-vaxx views. The tweeter calls vaccines "life saving."

This tweeter says that it will be confusing for seafarers to get re-vaccinated after they were told the J&J vaccine does not meet their vaccine mandates. This tweet is pro-vaccine though because the tweeter doesn't criticize vaccination, rather he just says that it will be hard for those seamen to get a different vaccine.
criticism_other: Sefarers being subjected to vaccine mandates around the J&J vaccine only

meaning: This tweeter wonders why a petition to stop the vaccination of children ages 5 to 11 has hardly any signatures on it. The tweeter provided a link to that petition.
support_other: Petitioning the vaccination of 5 to 11 year olds

meaning: This tweeter replied to a journalist. He expressed that the journalist didn't complain about how vaccine mandates violate the charter of rights and freedoms, while that same journalist reported on an issue about religious freedoms being violated.

This tweeter says that there are various people monitoring one account and that those people are in the anti-vaxx rabbithole. It's not clear who or what this tweeter refers to, no other details are given, but this is a pro-vaccine post.

This tweet offers information on bilingual meetings to talk about COVID-19. This is an outreach post so that people from different backgrounds can have equitable access to COVID-19 related information.
Tweeter is raising awareness about throat cancer and informing everyone that a vaccine to prevent the cancer has been approved by the FDA.
Tweeter shared an article on the U.S. National Institute of Health running clinical trials for mRNA vaccines for HIV.
Replying to a tweet by another user who equated the right to remain unvaccinated with the right to stay obese, tweeter implied that the pride of obese people is apparently also leading to fatalities.

Tweeter implied that all COVID restrictions should be lifted since the vaccination drive has already taken place and because COVID will never be over unless apparently, every single person in the world gets infected.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that it would be easy to sneak vaccines into people by making the vaccine oral and by placing that in ranch salad dressing and Duke's Mayonnaise.
support_other: Oral vaccines and sneaking vaccines to people

meaning: This is a tweet from J&J about how new data came out on the vaccine. Although the tweet is scientific, it's inherently pro-vaccine because it was released by J&J.
Tweeter implied that governments of a couple of countries where vaccine mandates or COVID restrictions continue are  apparently being paid by  Pfizer to keep the restrictions in place.

Tweeter is criticizing Victoria, Australia's Premier Dan Andrews for enforcing PCR testing requirements to attend various public places. He implied that a class action lawsuit will be brought against his government for mismanagement during the pandemic.
Engaging in a debate with an anti-vaxxer, tweeter is praising the people who took part in the COVID vaccine trials before vaccines were approved for use.
This tweet is a response to an anti-vaxxer who asks what vaccines do. The tweet is pro-vaccine and explains that vaccines reduce transmission, hospitalizations, death tolls and ICU admissions.

This tweeter says that car wrecks have a higher chance of death than COVID-19. They ask why someone would freak out about COVID-19 when they don't freak out about the possibility of car wrecks. This tweet is inherently anti-vaxx and undermines the severity of COVID-19.
criticism_other: Freaking out about COVID-19, severity of COVID-19

meaning: Tweeter shared a Forbes article that reported about a COVID vaccine, being developed by the U.S. Army, which could give protection against different variants of COVID-19.

This anti-vaxx tweet spreads false rumours that a German health insurance company found 400,00 cases of vaccine injuries. Factcheck.org reported that "Some have wrongly claimed Germany found the COVID-19 vaccine caused 'serious side effects' in a large number of people."

This tweeter says that Australians are forcing vaccines upon people, which is not true. They also posted a link to a guy on video who claims that the military was pulling people out of their homes to vaccinate them, which is fake information.
This anti-vaxxer says that NYC police are getting shot in the line of duty, but that the biggest problem around policing today is that they are cracking down on vaccine card violations.
criticism_other: Police "cracking down" on vaccine card violations

meaning: This tweeter is telling readers what vaccine mandates are. In a previous tweet, the tweeter told Californians to wake up before it's "too late," meaning that they disapprove of mandates.

This tweeter is asking questions about lockdowns and vaccine statuses during the fourth wave of COVID-19. He seems unsure about the vaccine. The post is misleading because he claims that lockdowns had 0% effectiveness.
Tweeter, a Canadian news website, reported on how YouTube apparently bans all content that casts doubt on any vaccines including those for COVID-19.
Tweeter implied that a good initiative has been taken to vaccinate truck drivers entering Australia's Queensland.

This tweeter asks why vaccine manufacturers are not made liable for anything that goes wrong with their vaccines. CNBC reported that "The federal government has granted companies like Pfizer and Moderna immunity from liability if something unintentionally goes wrong with their vaccines."
criticism_other: Lack of liability on pharmaceutical companies
support_other: Asking questions about the liability of Big Pharma

meaning: This tweeter shares information about mask and vaccine mandates in Italy. A link in Italian language is provided along with this tweet to confirm this information. The tweet contains no personal opinion.
This anti-vaxxer says that when Sesame Street charachters promoted vaccines, that that was a form of propaganda.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is shocked that vaccines are running low at Hausarzt. They say that vaccines are also running out at mobile buses by 10 a.m. This is a criticism on the supply shortage.
This is a tweet from a radio station about how the Australian Digital Health Agency is warning the public that scammers are generating fake vaccine certificates.
Tweeter, a NY Post, reporter shared her scoop about two top-ranking New York police officers faking COVID-19 vaccination certificates after the vaccine mandate came into effect.
Tweeter is criticizing former British health Secretary Sajid Javid for announcing and then scrapping the NHS vaccine mandate.
This tweeter replied to Biden to say that insulin, like vaccines, should be made free. This is pro-public health care and pro-medicine.
This is a news post about how workers in Boston organized against vaccine mandates. The post contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter asks people to get boosted because it will provide protection against the virus. The tweet says that COVID-19 is spreading quickly across the U.K.
This tweeter is upset that their line of work is still subject to vaccine mandates, while their husband can go to work as a construction worker without showing a vaccine passport.

This tweeter says that they are unvaccinated and have been feeling healthy throughout the pandemic for the past two years. They say that if companies told the public that vaccines are "experimental" that it wouldn't be good for vaccine sales.

This tweet from BIDEN tells people that Pfizer and Moderna are very effective in reducing severe illness caused by Omicron. He says that people will face a very severe winter if they fail to get vaccinated.
Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines are not effective, so vaccine mandates do not make sense. Tweeter is laughing at a British politician who tested positive even though he got the booster dose.

This tweeter says that if the People's Party of Canada didn't exist, that no one would speak out against lockdowns, mass immigration and vaccine passports. This is an anti-vaxx post which celebrates far-right politics.
support_other: People's Party of Canada, Maxime Bernier

meaning: This tweet is about how to make the TB vaccine more effective. A link to an article on Medical Xpress is included here. This post is inherently pro-vaccine because it's promoting vaccine effectiveness.

This tweeter is against vaccine passports and public health restrictions. He asks a pro-vaccine tweeter to have "empathy" towards mental health and people's freedoms. This tweeter claims that vaccine passports have not scientifically proven to work.
This anti-vaxx tweeter tells another tweeter that vaccines have a "ton of nasty side effects," which is misleading.

This tweeter supports vaccines, he says so in a previous post. In this tweet, he replies to another tweeter who got the Whooping Cough. This tweet says that a certain strain of that cough wasn't protected by vaccines at that time.

This anti-vaxxer replied to a tweet depicting a girl shaking in a bed. Other anti-vaxxers said that she had a vaccine injury, but no proof of this claim is provided. This tweeter says that lawyers and politicians made it impossible for that girl to sue for the injury.

This tweeter is excited about people protesting vaccine mandates in Washington D.C. in January 2022. They posted a link to some footage, although you have to click an additional link off the link on this page.

This tweet from BIDEN tells people that Pfizer and Moderna are very effective in reducing severe illness caused by Omicron. He says that people will face a very severe winter if they fail to get vaccinated.

This is a news tweet about vaccine mandates in Manila. The tweet says vaccine cards will be required to enter indoor establishments and that cinemas were operating at 100 percent capacity. The tweet contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter says that people who call out police for enforcing vaccine mandates, yet don't care that police enforce using "no knock warrants," don't really care about people.
criticism_other: People who criticize police for enforcing vaccine mandates only
support_other: calling out police for enforcing by using "no knock" warrants.

meaning: This tweeter says they are not anti-vaxx, but they are anti-vaxx because they wrote that vaccines can do more harm than good. The tweeter claims to have "long term data" to prove this.

This tweeter claims that a pro-vaccine comedian, Heather McDonald, fell at a comedy club during her performance because she was vaccinated. But Poynter reported that "While the cause of her collapse is unknown, a publicist told local journalists in Arizona it may have been the result of dehydration... Fox News shamelessly promoted the notion that there is a connection between the performer’s collapse and her having been vaccinated."

This tweeter says that the pancoronavirus vaccine is a good idea. That's a vaccine that works for all strains of COVID-19. He posted an article from a science magazine which reports that that vaccine is a "Dream Vaccine." He also posted another image that promotes needing "just one shot."

This tweeter says that mandates matter yet they say that there are more deaths with a vaccine out, which is confusing. The tweeter seems unsure about the vaccine yet promotes mandates. The tweeter also criticizes someone called Bullock for his vaccine policies.
This is a pro-vaccine post. It promotes looking after employees and it gives information about their vaccine program within the tweet.

This tweeter appears to be against COVID-19 or mRNA vaccines. It's hard to tell because the tweet he replied to was deactivated. But this tweeter says that polio vaccines stopped people from getting polio. And he implies that they were better than COVID-19 vaccines, which don't stop someone from actually contracting COVID-19.

This tweeter says that if Trump had mandated vaccines, it would have been called fascism by the public. The tweeter also says that Biden and Kamala ridiculed vaccines before the election which isn't true.
This tweeter says that it's great is someone supports "forced" vaccinations. It's hard to read the tone of this tweet, but I flagged it as pro-vaccine by default.
This anti-vaxx tweeter posts a fake news article with a headline stating the pandemic is a scam. The tweeter then asks if someone can prove the effectiveness of the vaccine against the fake virus.
This tweet shows where people can get vaccinated if they're over 18 years of age.
This tweeter is unsure about the vaccine boosters. They ask readers if they would be willing to get "another COVID-19 vaccination."

This pro-vaccine tweet shows two thumbs up emoticons regarding 1 billion doses of vaccines being made. Yet the tweeter calls those doses the "China virus vaccine." So this tweet could be perceived is racist towards China.

This is a news tweet by a CNN White House correspondent, yet it is pro-vaccine. It shows Biden at the podium in an image and quotes him saying that people can get their booster shot if six months after their first shot has passed.

This tweeter is upset that lockdowns in Ireland were re-imposed despite that country having a high vaccination rate. It's not clear if this tweeter is for or against vaccination, yet he refers to lockdowns as a tool for keeping people obedient.
This is a news post about Trump's support for the Trucker Convoy. The post was made by CTV and contains no personal opinion.
This tweeter supports the Trucker Convoy. They are against vaccine mandates. And they say the convoy was on the "right side of history."

This tweeter says that the teacher who made students in America chant against Biden is no more at fault that teachers who preach in support of Biden and the vaccine. I was not able to find a news source stating that teachers have been caught promoting Biden to students. This tweeter also says thinks that sex education is bad.
criticism_other: Biden, Teachers promoting vaccination, sex education

meaning: This tweet doesn't promote or criticize anything, rather it replies to a tweet who complains about vaccine mandates within the army. This tweeter says those vaccine mandates don't really matter, when a soldier is basically property of the state once drafted, anyway.
This tweeter says that long-term negative effects don't happen from vaccines but they do from the virus. He also says some medication can have long-term effects, but not a three-dose vaccine.
This is a news post from the CBC about how vaccine mandates were likely approaching.

This tweeter criticizes Joe Rogan for promoting COVID-19 disinformation. They posted a link of Rogan speaking to prove this. The tweeter said they previously liked Rogan for being unbiased and curious about both sides of the argument.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx based on other tweets on their wall. And they are against the democratic party as well. This tweet basically says that democrats are for vaccines when it suits their cause, as they are for filibusters when it suits as well.
This tweeter said she's triple vaxxed, got the virus and wasn't hit as hard as someone who hasn't been vaxxed. She also says the kids will be better if they get rest and eat well.

This tweeter says that freedom of choice should be given to people. The tweeter posted an image of a nurse holding up signs showing her anger towards being fired for not getting vaccinated. The tweeter says that the vaccine is hurting people, which is misleading. The tweeter also seems critical of democrats who support the choice of abortion, but not the choice to get vaccinated or not.
criticism_other: Firing medical staff who don't want to be vaccinated

meaning: This tweeter is an anti-vaxxer, based on their other twitter posts. They say that the vaccine mandates, made by the Biden administration, are a power move. The tweeter says Biden wouldn't limit medications as well, if they cared about saving lives (in reference to another tweet about health care costing money.)

This is a tweet about an news article from a science magazine that tries to lighten science for a general audience. No personal opinion is contained in this tweet, and the tweet is hard to understand, other than that Japan's Delta rates were nearly driven to "extinction."

This tweeter asks if Putin made his troops get vaccinated, which hints at support for Russia. The anti-vaxx scene is rampant with pro-Russian propaganda. This tweeter posts a lot about crypto currency on their wall as well, which is also commonly supported amongst trucker convoy activists.
This tweeter says they wish people would get vaccinated but that it's their responsibility. He also complains about the death toll count for the day, which another tweeter posted.
This tweeter reports that a rabbit character got the 2nd vaccine dose. The rabbit reported that they are doing well and that they need to rest and take care of their body.

Tweeter implied that the vaccine mandate adopted by governments to encourage immunization against COVID-19 apparently violates the Nuremberg Code, which requires informed consent from participants of medical experiments.
Tweeter shared a new report about an American basketball player who refused to get vaccinated, even when he was not allowed to participate in games in New York.
Tweeter shared a National Geography article that showcased an interview of a professor of philosophy on vaccine injury and hesitancy and the complexity surrounding it.

Tweeter implied that COVID-19 is apparently common cold, which is not fatal, so people do not need to vaccinate. Tweeter also implied that COVID-19 is apparently media's creation and warned everyone not to trust Nano tech.
Tweeter implied that Australian premiers are encouraging people to vaccinate apparently for to look good for their own benefit and they should not implement the vaccine mandates.

Tweeter shared a scientific paper on the side-effects of COVID vaccines to imply that they are not safe. However, he does not highlight the part where the limitation of the study notes that the side-effect are self-reporter and were not verified.
Tweeter is debunking the narrative about vaccine mandates being coercive by noting that getting vaccinated or not is still an individual choice that comes with consequences.
Tweeter shared a news article about two police officers submitting fake COVID vaccine certificates to keep their jobs.

Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines cause harmful side effects as well as death and gave an example of a boy who died of a heart attack apparently five days after getting the second dose of a nameless COVID vaccine.
Tweeter implied that Canadians who oppose vaccine mandates are not necessarily against the COVID vaccines, they just hate the prime minister for enforcing the vaccine mandate.
Tweeter is explaining the benefits of having a vaccine passport to another user who questions how vaccine mandates help if vaccines cannot stop transmission.

This post appears to defend an in-person gathering in Spain, writing that everyone there was fully vaccinated or about to get their COVID19 booster shot, and that despite allegations that Spaniards kiss and hug all the time, this has stopped amid the COVID19 pandemic.

In response to a post about hospitals filling up with unvaccinated patients, this post argues for freedom in the United States when it comes to the COVID19 pandemic. People should be able to choose how they manage their own health, whether the get vaccinated, whether to mask, etc, it writes.

This post criticizes the government, claiming that it has censored and suppressed doctors, lab scientists, virologists, pathologists, peer-reviewed studies, side effects, natural immunity, and alternative treatment options for COVID19, all to support their own vaccination campaigns.

This tweeter argues that testing for unvaccinated workers needs to be at the employer’s expense because they are the ones mandating it. They write that they’re happy Montana has made it illegal to take vaccination status into account in employment matters.
This post shares an article by the far-right website Epoch Times, about how Facebook has been called out for a vaccine marketing alliance.

This post jokingly suggests how great it would be if Omicron turned out to be a natural vaccine against COVID19, and those who held out getting vaccinated were rewarded with only a mild cold, natural immunity, and no vaccinations.
This post criticizes Justin Trudeau for criticizing the unvaccinated by linking their opinion about vaccines to bad character traits with no evidence. It also criticizes those who dislike Joe Rogan.
This post criticizes Joe Biden and vaccine mandates, replying to a post about Biden saying he can cure cancer. The cure for cancer, writes the post, is to not take the COVID19 vaccine.

This post shares an article from The Political Globe celebrating a federal judge’s ruling against the Biden administration’s vaccination and masking mandates for Head Start programs in schools in Texas.

This is a news tweet from an entertainment journalist about actress Evangeline Lilly. This tweet reports that she attended an anti-vaxx protest. The tweeter also mentions that the actress protested quarantine measures previously.

This tweeter says that lies about the vaccines are surfacing, and that "entire industries" have been destroyed. The tweeter worries about inflation and division between people. They also criticize government for having no accountability. No hard proof to any of these claims is provided.
Tweeter implied that Dr. Anthony Fauci lied about the efficacy of COVID vaccines, apparently forced people to get vaccinated and that supposedly led to vaccine induced deaths.
Tweeter implied that COVID apps and vaccine passports include personal information and that governments need legislation on data sharing and protection of these sensitive medical data.

This post writes that there is no long-term data on the effect of spike protein from the COVID19 vaccine. It says that decisions to remove people from the heart transplant list based on their vaccination status are political, not scientific. The account holder has spread vaccine misinformation in other posts, as well.

This post is part of a thread celebrating COVID19 vaccine effectiveness, explaining that post-vaccination infections are normal and do not mean vaccines are ineffective. The post says that the vaccine act as a prevention, not a cure.

This post shares an article by Rolling Stone about Neil Young demanding that his music be removed from Spotify, as protest against Joe Rogan. It quotes Young, saying that Spotify can have Rogan or Young but not both.

This post shares an article about how overwhelmed hospitals in Idaho are. It writes that many patients do not trust their doctors or nurses, fighting against vaccination and medical care, including life-saving ventilators.

This post calls for an end to the Tigray Siege in Ethiopia, writing that due to lack of fuel and money, many children will not be able to be vaccinated against Measles, which will have a severe impact on their futures.

In response to a post about anti-vaxxers calling themselves pure bloods while calling others Nazis, this tweeter essentially agrees, saying that his blood is free from the COVID19 vaccine and that getting Americans fired for being unvaccinated is dictatorship.

This post criticizes Pfizer, writing that Pfizer only cares about making money, and that they created a vaccine that does not work, which is proven by the fact that vaccinated people still get and transmit COVID19. It calls the vaccine poison, and says we should not vaccinate children.
This post shares a commentary article from the New Hampshire Bulletin in favour of keeping registries to help increase vaccination records and reduce vaccine-preventable disease and suffering.

This post shares an article by The Guardian about the richest countries hoarding vaccines. It shares a quote that asks what the world can do when massive financial interests are placed before people’s survival.

This tweeter seems to support science by rudely criticizing her roommate for thinking that the vaccine kicks in immediately after it's administered. She calls her roommate dumb for not understanding how vaccines actually work.
criticism_other: People who think the vaccine is activated immediately

meaning: Tweeter implied that he is still wearing a mask and is fully vaccinated along with a booster to protect himself from COVID19.

Tweeter implied that the COVID 19 vaccines are the only vaccines in the history of mankind that is not effective in long-term protection or stopping transmission of the virus, so there should not be any vaccine mandate for COVID vaccines.

This post criticizes anti-health-measure conspiracy theories, calling them irrational and violent. It shares a link to a news article by the Daily Kos about the dangers of far-right anti-vaccine and anti-mask violence.
This post asks whether anyone else felt sexually aroused after their first shot of the COVID19 vaccine.
This post shares a tweet by a Group Leader at the Max Planck Institute for Infection Biology, celebrating the group’s experiments on neutralization of Omicron by the Pfizer vaccine.
This post argues that neither the coronavirus nor the vaccines against it are new. It says that there was a lot of funding which meant the vaccine was able to be tested and manufactured more quickly.
This post criticizes the Democratic Party in the United States, writing that their vision of America is lockdowns, mandates, and vaccine passports.
This post criticizes the anti-vaxx movement, comparing anti-vaxxers to followers of the Hindu religion who, it writes, believe in fake news.
This post is against the COVID19 vaccine, claiming that it does not prevent infection or transmission, and is likely to cause myocarditis, blood clots, and/or neurological disorders.

This tweeter says that vaccine passports shouldn't be used because we need to learn to live with COVID-19. The tweeter is concerned that if gyms and businesses close again, the economy will be crippled. The tweeter doesn't declare if they are pro- or anti-vaccine, so I flagged this tweet as "unsure" about the vaccine.
This tweeter says that vaccine mandates "took at least 6.5 years" in the past, which doesn't make sense. But the tweet implies that vaccine development moved too quickly during COVID-19.
criticism_other: The warp speed production of COVID-19 vaccines

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweet tells readers that vaccination and masking will help protect children from COVID-19. A link is provided in this tweet, featuring interviews with five pediatricians on this subject.
support_other: Protecting children by way of public health measures

meaning: This person is pro-vaccine yet they say they are tired of everything regarding COVID-19, especially Joe Rogan. This is just a vent from a frustrated person living through a pandemic.
criticism_other: Everything about COVID-19 and Joe Rogan

meaning: Replying to a piece of news about an Illinois man dying from rabies because he refused the vaccine, tweeter implied that they would definitely take the series of shots needed instead of facing inevitable, painful death.
Tweeter, a Swedish minister, posted about vaccine donation to Rwanda.
This post by the Mayor of Chicago, Lori E. Lightfoot, encourages people to use at-home COVID19 tests, writing that these are a simple and effective way to do your part and stay on top of your health.

In response to a post by Scott Morrison congratulating citizens of Victoria, Australia for reaching 90% vaccination rate, this tweet writes that this was achieved despite Morrison’s botched vaccine rollouts and constant lies.

In response to a tweet asking people whether they think Boris Johnson should step down, this post writes that they are unsure, because whoever replaces him would likely impost lockdown and vaccine passes again, which they are against.

This post criticizes mandates for vaccination and COVID19 testing, writing that these would mean a permanent change to freedom of movement. The virus is never going away, it argues, therefore such healthcare mandates make no sense.

In response to a tweet calling Australia dogmatic and restrictive during the COVID19 pandemic, and saying Canada’s trucker convoy spun out of Australia’s, this post argues that Canberra’s convoy actually only had about five trucks and that Australia has over 90% vaccination rate.

This post criticizes Pfizer and the safety of the COVID19 vaccine, writing that if Pfizer does not release vaccine data until 2076, they will wait until then to get the vaccine so they know it is safe.

This tweeter is asking questions about the vaccination status of some hospital workers. They also ask why their vaccines would work while other's wouldn't. It's too hard to read the tone of this message, while the tweet is deactivated, so it's not clear if this is anti- or pro-vaccine, so I labelled this post as "unsure."
support_other: Asking questions about vaccines, using one's brain

meaning: This anti-vaxx post contains a link that doesn't work. And it says that the EU parliament opposes vaccine mandates, which isn't true. Mandates existed in many locations in Europe.
This tweeter believes that Fauci created COVID-19, and that he also created a vaccine dependency.
This is a news repost from Reuters about a pro basketball player who decided to get vaccinated. The post contains no personal opinion, yet it's inherently pro-vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter tells an anti-vaxxer that vaccines reduced the symptoms of COVID-19 to a cold within a person who may have otherwise been hospitalized.

This tweeter questions COVID-19 vaccines (mRNA or not) and asks what other vaccines don't stop the transmission of the virus. The tweeter essentially says that COVID-19 vaccines are ineffective because they don't prevent transmission.

This tweeter says that vaccine mandates are messing up the supply chain. He says that truckers and warehouse workers are quitting (due to mandates) and that society needs them. This tweet clearly supports the Trucker Convoy.
This anti-vaxxer says they get annoyed by seeing vaccine "ads" by Washington State (likely the University). He says he doesn't consent to it.
This tweeter tells people to get vaccinated and that there are tons of vaccines available. The tweeter mentions SINOVAC, China's vaccine, and that it's available.
It is not clear what tweeter meant by this post.
Replying to another user who urged people not to get vaccinated because vaccines cannot stop infections, tweeter explained that vaccines provides protection from he severity of COVID 19 infection.
This is a news post from the New York Times. The headline talks about how vaccines are an American tradition, and so is the backlash.

This post criticizes Joe Biden for saying in December 2020 that COVID19 vaccines should not be mandatory, and then announcing that they will be mandatory in 2021. It includes a link to a Fox News article about this.

This post criticizes a vaccine mandate announcement made by Premier of Victoria Dan Andrews, which required 12-year-olds to be double vaccinated to play community sports. There was not enough notice with this mandate, and too much flip-flopping, argues the post.

This tweeter says that public health policy will encourage unvaccinated people to congregate amongst themselves given they are told to not attend group events if they're not vaxxed. The tweeter also makes a comment on vaccine efficacy, by saying that people who are vaxxed have protection from "very excellent vaccines." Yet this feels sarcastic in tone.
criticism_other: Creating a divide between vaxxed and unvaccinated people

meaning: This tweeter says that Pfizer will be brought to justice, which implies that vaccines are unsafe. The tweeter also says that China will experience tougher sanctions than Russia during the war in Ukraine.

This tweeter claims that the UN will be brought in to patrol the New World Order, which is a conspiracy theory. The tweeter also says that 10K marines will skip vaccination. The Washington Post reported that UP TO 10K would skip vaccination.
This post shares a news article criticizing the Moderna COVID19 vaccine for not being legitimate, safe, or effective.

This tweet replied to Fox News' Tucker Carlson, who posted a joke about COVID-19. This tweeter found it offensive and asked if those who died from COVID-19 would laugh at his joke. The tweeter then reminds readers that Carlson is vaccinated, and posted a link to a Guardian article to prove that.
This tweeter is just asking another tweeter if they want the 2.2 billion children of the world to be vaccinated.
Replying to another user who compared other vaccines with the ones for COVID 19, tweeter implied that different vaccines work differently and not all have 100 percent efficacy.
Tweeter shared a news article about U.K.'s former health secretary back tracking on the idea of a vaccine passport but not that of a vaccine mandate for healthcare workers.
Tweeter implied that vaccinated people who do not want to wear mask to protect unvaccinated ones from getting severe COVID infection are being morally selfish.
This tweet says that vaccines haven't stopped transmission of COVID-19. That is true to some extent, yet this tweet is used to undermine trust in vaccines, while they do reduce severe illness.
This tweet promotes how to get a vaccine or booster. A photo of a pamphlet with more details is provided within the tweet.
This tweeter says they're pro-vaccine as well as pro-freedom of choice. They are against lock downs because they think it harms the people who are locked down.

This post is part of a thread about the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine. It includes a link to an article about the possibility that some people have received a harmless saline injection instead of the vaccine, by accident. The post writes that removing the requirement to dilute the Pfizer vaccine would speed up vaccination processes and reduce human error.

This tweeter chose not to get vaccinated because they have blood clots. They are not anti-vax, they write, but have concerns. The post also says nobody should be criticized for doing what they think is best for their health.
This tweeter shows a graph of data, which is unsourced but likely comes from ICNARC because it looks reputable. The data shows that those admitted to critical care were primarily unvaccinated people.
Replying to another user, tweeter implied that unvaccinated people with underlying health issues have a higher chance of dying from COVID 19.

Tweeter implied that the GP interviewed on BBC was wrong about the effectiveness of COVID vaccines and cited a CDC report. which tweeter claimed, shows natural immunity from prior infection is better than vaccines. But the report does not state that explicitly.

This tweeter is critical of Trump and his followers. They say Trump did everything to kill his followers, which is not true. None the less, the tweet is pro-vaccine while it says that anti-vaxxers think the vaccine is about control, when in fact, it is not.
This pro-vaccine tweeter replied to an anti-vaxxer. She tells her that the vaccine was tested for decades. This tweet intends to defend mRNA vaccines.
This tweeter posted an image of birds flying on a map. She says that birds can surpass bureaucracy of travel visas and vaccine passports, which sounds anti-vaccine.
This post replies to a tweet from a suspended account that has been removed from twitter. It writes that there exists, indeed, a vaccine against the bubonic plague.

This tweeter is vaccinated yet they support freedom of choice because they don't care about other people's vaccine statuses. The tweeter says that they are bored of vaccine statuses as a topic of conversation.
This post criticizes the trucker convoy, writing that they are polluting the air with their diesel trucks and causing mental stress through noise pollution with their honking.

This tweeter seems to be anti-vaccine, although they could just be neutral and reporting some information they found about myocarditis. The graph they show appears to be from the CDC, yet the logo is different from what I googled online - so, this could be a fabricated graph. The tweeter says that the myocarditis found from vaccination looks similar to "classical" myocarditis.
This post celebrates the vaccination rates in India, citing the high number of vaccine doses administered, and the low number of current active cases of COVID19.
This tweeter posted an article about how the National Guard revolted against vaccines. She also wrote that the Pentagon needs to deal with this, indicating a pro-vaccine stance.

This tweeter replied to an anti-vaxxer. They say that vaccines aren't forced upon people and that they're well tested and prevent transmission. This fact about transmission is being disputed and researched by medical professionals, yet the intention of this tweet is pro-vaccine.
Tweeter shared a news article about U.K.'s former health secretary back tracking on the idea of a vaccine passport but not that of a vaccine mandate for healthcare workers.
This tweet is by the business magazine Forbes reporting about a survey which showed a large number of flyers supports a vaccine mandate.
This tweet is pro-vaccine while it says there's scientific evidence (an article is posted to prove it) that COVID-19 vaccines do not produce blood clots that have been observed by embalmers.

This is a conspiracy-theory based post against democrats and vaccines. The tweeter says that democrats are pushing for the murder of babies and that democrats want people to die from vaccine mandates. This tweeter is likely a Qanon supporter.
This tweet reports the daily case counts of COVID-19 in India. There is a number listed for the amount of vaccines administered, therefore this post supports vaccination.
This tweeter provides information on how to enter places that have vaccine mandates. No personal opinion is provided, yet this tweet is inherently pro-public health interventions.

This post announces information about COVID19 vaccination mandates. It gives the date vaccine and testing mandates were announced, the deadline to declare vaccination status and to upload proof, and the later date when mild enforcement could start.
This post shares a link to a job board with jobs that do not require COVID19 vaccination with another twitter user. The post also calls for no vaccine mandates.
This post shares an article from The Star saying that an omicron-specific vaccine will likely not be available in time for the wave.
This post shares an article by the unreliable website Becker News, about Military members from all five branches filing a class action lawsuit against the pentagon for vaccine mandates.

This post shares a graph of the cases and deaths in Italy amid the Omicron wave. It writes that the wave appears to have peaked, with deaths rising, but that more people are now vaccinated or have natural immunity.

This anti-vaxx tweeter says they're not happy with an ABC reporter who spread misinformation about vaccines being able to prevent transmission of the virus. The tweeter claims that natural immunity is better than vaccination, which has been proven to be false.

This tweeter claims that people are going door to door in the U.S. to find out people's vaccine statuses. This is misleading. She claims other people are going door-to-door to collect blood as well, to test COVID-19 anti-bodies. This post promotes conspiracy theories regarding government overreach.

This tweeter is pro-public health measures, yet they think that vaccines alone are not enough to stop the pandemic. They say that Bristol's council is failing and that vaccine rates are low there. The tweeter implies that more social distancing is needed.
criticism_other: Bristol council, lack of social distancing, lack of vaccination rates in Bristol

meaning: This post by The Guardian Australia shares a news article about a Koala chlamydia vaccine trial done by Australian researchers to improve the species’ survival.

This post shares a CTV News article about a summer COVID19 surge in the United States. It writes that this does not matter because everyone who wants to be vaccinated already is, and that COVID19 is nothing more than a flu now.

This tweeter told an anti-vaxxer to sit down, and to look up Polio Pioneers. The tweeter claims that the polio vaccine was rolled out on a completely experimental basis, but that's not entirely true. Regardless, the tweeter tried to convince the anti-vaxxer to support COVID-19 vaccines.

This tweeter has posts on his wall which support the Trucker Convoy. This tweet claims that swine flue vaccines were subject to VAERS reports, and recalled in 2009. Wikikpedia says though, that "On 15 December 2009, one of the five manufacturers supplying the H1N1 vaccine to the United States recalled thousands of doses because they were not as potent as expected."
This tweeter promotes the idea of vaccine mandates regarding the voting process. He's clearly pro-vaccine and wants anti-vaxxers to have less say in the electoral process.

This tweeter is reporting on a speech by Maxime Bernier, from a far-right perspective. Although the tweet really just quotes Bernier, the tweeter represents the True North Journal and is therefore against mandates.
This tweeter is upset with vaccinated people who forget to social distance or wear masks. He encourages people to remain vigilant and to not behave like an "asshole."
criticism_other: People who don't social distance despite being vaccinated

meaning: Tweeter implied that they do not understand the rationale behind the anti-vaccination campaign as vaccines save lives.
Tweeter implied the U.S. President spread misinformation by saying in public that COVID vaccines stop transmission.
Tweeter implied that the Alberta premier should continue the cash incentive to vaccinate because the COVID case number in the province was still high.

This post criticizes public health messaging around COVID19 vaccinations. It writes that first we were told to get two shots to be free, then three, and now four. It also questions vaccine effectiveness, writing that we now need to take pills to recover from COVID19 even when vaccinated.

This tweet is a headline from a Business Insider article. That is a fact checked publication, yet this tweeter likely promoted the article for anti-vaxx causes. The article is about how law makers invested in vaccine stocks.
criticism_other: law makers investing in vaccine stocks

meaning: This tweeter posts some type of "disease" that may or may not be true, which they claim is a result of vaccination. It's hard to understand what the disease is. But this tweeter has anti-vaxx stuff posted on their wall.

This tweeter is anti-vaxx and they posted a link to a far-right style news post which contains some true information that is presented in a biased way. The article features information about how the FDA wants to keep vaccine trial FOIs private for 55 years. And their headline is written in this tweet.
Tweeter implied that anti-vaxxers who claim the COVID vaccines are harmful to children should feel ashamed as vaccines in general has protected children from deadly diseases.
Tweeter implied that legal charges should be brought against people who spread disinformation and conspiracy theories on social media platforms.
Tweeter implied that COVID vaccines may have long-term effects but people have to take the risk of getting vaccinated as the risk of remaining unvaccinated is greater.
This post argues with an anti-vaxxer, writing that even though the vaccinated can still spread COVID19, it is the unvaccinated that are dying more and spreading the disease more frequently.
This is a news re-post from Axios. A link to the article is provided here. No personal opinion is included in this tweet.

This anti-vaxx tweeter questions the existence of the pandemic by asking why media and the public are talking about Ukraine and not COVID-19 anymore. This tweeter implies that the pandemic was never real.
This tweeter tells readers to "step up and ride down against this vaccine." That means, he wants people to say no to vaccination.
A tweeter asked this tweeter if COVID-19 protocols were in place at a certain event. This tweeter says yes, "of course" there were, and that he didn't see anyone without a mask outside the venue.

This anti-vaxxer asks what's inside of vaccines. She says that they're being forced upon people in America regardless of the constitution. She's suspicious of what the motive behind vaccination is and hints at conspiracy theories.

This tweet makes a simple statement and doesn't really promote or criticize anything directly - that pandemics surface all the "muck." They posted a link to a reputable article about what needs to be learned from pandemics.
It's not clear what this tweeter is talking about because the tweet they replied to has been deleted. But this tweeter is anti-vaxx based on their far-right, pro-masculinity posts.

Tweeter insinuated that the COVID-19 vaccine is fake because scientists apparently could not isolate the virus to develop a vaccine for it. Tweeter did not provide any scientific basis of their claim.
Tweeter shared their frustration about Joe Rogan's role in propagating vaccine disinformation.
Tweeter shared information about the availability of COVID vaccines in the U.S. for children 5 to 11 years old.

Tweeter insinuated that anti-vaxxers and people, who oppose COVID restrictions, intentionally associate long-term health problems that result from  COVID 19 with vaccines, masks and restrictions to spread misinformation.
This tweet is by a COVID vaccine bot providing updates about vaccination in Ireland.

This post shares a new article praising New York City police officers for arresting an alleged shooter. It appears to celebrate their work and that they are probably vaccinated too, writing that real heroes get vaccinated.

This post writes that the growing cases of COVID19 in China are at a tipping point where Chinese authorities may not be able to continue to enforce measure to contain the spread. It links to a New York Times article.
This is a news post about Bono's fight against COVID-19. The article reports that Jeep, Ram and Fiat joined Bono and a quote from the article is contained within the tweet.
This tweeter uses a bunch of hashtags to promote vaccination, such as #VaccinesSaveLives. The video they posted is a happy song that doesn't contain vaccine related content.

This tweeter tells an anti-vaxxer that there are strict guidelines in place for animals living within zoos. The other tweeter said she doesn't vaccinate her animals, while this tweeter says that vaccination of pets is normal.
This anti-vaxxer says that the threat of "long-Covid" shouldn't be a reason to force vaccines. The tweeter believes that all people should be free to weigh the risks of vaccination.
This tweeter makes a racist comment about China and says that Biden won't pull back vaccine mandates, leading to issues with post arriving on time.
This post shares a news article by the Washington Times about white evangelicals lagging in COVID19 vaccine uptake, according to a new survey.
This tweeter says that masks harm communication and that vaccines are for parents. This tweeter is clearly against public health protocols.
This tweeter may or may not be pro-vaccine. But what is clear is that she believes in letting people live their own lives. She says people can chose to wear a mask or take the vaccine.

Sharing a link that claims U.S. funding for vaccine development in the Ukraine tweeter insinuated some underhand deals are going on without the knowledge of the American public. The link did not open.

Tweeter implied that a WSJ article on anti-vaccine campaign on Facebook  conflated overall anti-vaccine attitudes with people opposing just the COVID vaccine and also people who oppose COVID restrictions.

Replying to a user who complained about the vaccine mandate, tweeter pointed out that people need all sorts of documents to enter another country. If that can be accepted then a vaccine passport should be too.

In response to a tweet by a healthcare worker writing that vaccines work, this post questions where the solid data and evidence is for this, apart from being bribed by institutions and administrations.
This anti-vaxxer criticizes vaccines because they don't prevent transmission or contraction of the virus. The tweeter also undermines the severity of COVID-19 by saying it's only a common cold.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says she's happy her mom finally got vaccinated. She also mentions that her family back east thinks COVID-19 is "overhyped."

This anti-vaxxer says that vaccinated people have "buyer's remorse" because they're on their third booster and long-term effectiveness of the vaccine is questionable. This tweeter says that vaccinated people "complied."
This is a news re-post from Sky News, about how Pfizer is testing the amount of required boosters on children. No personal opinion is contained in this post.
This is a news re-post about how the vaccination of children with the Moderna vaccine is delayed. No personal opinion is included in this tweet.

This tweeter is in favour of a targeted campaign to encourage the unvaccinated to get their COVID19 shots. They also suggest showing changes to the unvaccinated figures rather than daily vaccination numbers.

This post by the Sputnik Vaccine account links to a Harvard study on animals showing that antibody response induced by mRNA vaccines is not sufficient to neutralize the Omicron variant or other mutations of coronavirus, and that a mix and match approach with Sputnik for example, is needed.
This tweeter writes that they have not had COVID19 yet, by being careful, washing their hands, avoiding large crowds, and getting vaccinated.
This tweeter says that more precautions need to be taken to mitigate the risks of COVID-19, such as better ventilation systems, contact tracing, rapid testing, sterilization and better masks.
support_other: Ventilation, contact tracing, rapid testing, sterilisation

meaning: This tweeter criticizes Howard Stern for standing up against anti-vaxxers. The tweeter asks why Stern is worried about anti-vaxxers when he's already vaccinated. The tweeter implies that vaccines don't work if vaccinated people are worried about unvaccinated people. He also asks why anyone should take the vaccine if it doesn't prevent transmission.

This tweeter seems to say that POC are not vaccinating as a form of rejection of the vaccine. He posted a link to PBS about how vaccination rates in POC communities are much lower than caucasian communities.
This pro-vaccine tweeter says that Trump is a "grifting con man" and that he can't even spell the word vaccine.

This woman encourages people to get vaccinated. She posted an image of a brain that was effected by COVID-19, and she wrote that people who contracted COVID-19 have measurable changes to their brains.

This post quotes Jim Goodwin saying that he does not think Scottish football players should be forced into getting vaccinated against COVID19. It calls for the sport to stand together against vaccine passports.
This tweeter writes that they have received the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine and that they feel fine, aside from a pre-existing condition of chronic depression.
This post shares an article about Pfizer withdrawing their COVID19 vaccine application in India after regulators demanded Pfizer complete a local safety and immunogenicity study.
This post simply writes that the COVID19 vaccine does not work.
This tweeter says "Fuck Penn State" for their vaccine mandates. The tweeter also uses the hashtag #CovidNazis.

This tweeter is upset at the Biden administration for enforcing vaccine mandates at the U.S. - Canada border, while "illegal" immigrants are allowed into America without vaccination. The tweeter shared a Breitbart news article, which is a far-right publication, to support this tweet.
This tweeter is anti-government based on his profile. This tweet implies that the government is tracking everyone who has received the vaccine.

This tweeter posted an article from The Telegraph about how a woman died of a brain hemorrhage after getting the AZ vaccine. The tweeter then challenges the idea of vaccinating kids. He also says that people will be hurt by the Pfizer vaccine and asks where the news report on that is.
This tweeter says that the pandemic can be mitigated through vaccination and that people should be doing the "heavy lifting" that's required.
This post suggests that we should change the definition of being vaccinated to promising not to get ill.
This tweet writes that the Yankees and Mets are debating what to do amid the New York City COVID19 vaccination mandate. The tweet suggests the solution is to get vaccinated.
This post quotes Kristalina Georgieva, Head of the International Monetary Fund, saying that vaccine policy is economic policy and that without it we cannot turn the fate of the world economy around.
This tweeter says that vaccine mandates are a joke. He also says that transmission can happen between vaccinated and unvaccinated people, which is true. This tweeter believes in freedom of choice.

This tweeter says that Martha Fulford was caught financing the Trucker Convoy. They display a screen shot of the records of who donated and her email is included. The Globe and Mail reported that she has been seen attending those protests and "Martha Fulford, an infectious disease physician who works at McMaster Children’s Hospital in Hamilton, is facing criticism for some of her statements about the risks of COVID-19."
This tweeter says she was only sick for a day when she contracted COVID-19, due to being vaccinated. She said her friend who wasn't vaccinated (there's a typo so it's unclear) was sick for a month.

This post by The Financial Times shares an article about Moderna’s COVID19 booster shot increasing antibody levels 37-fold against the Omicron variant, even further than a booster shot of the Pfizer vaccine.
This pro-vaccine tweeter asks how Larry David (actor) feels about his co-star's husband, who refers to vaccine mandates as "the holocaust."
criticism_other: Comparing vaccine mandates to the holocaust

meaning: This tweeter encourages readers to stop supporting businesses that ask for vaccine passports. He says the government needs to take responsibility for vaccine deaths and injuries.
support_other: Hurting businesses that ask for vaccine passports, vaccine fear

meaning: This tweeter claims that the CDC "admits" that natural immunity is better than vaccines. This is false information.
This post celebrates the COVID19 vaccine, citing a specific laboratory’s achievements in making a vaccine, led by Walter Reed, over two years of work.

This tweeter says he doesn't trust Joe Biden and that the vaccinated made a big mistake in taking the jab. He says that the government "screwed the pooch bad" which implies that corruption is present between the Biden administration and pharmaceutical companies.

This is a post from a guys who says he uses needles (likely heroin). He says that pharmacy students think they're "the shit" because they administer vaccines (using needles). But he says he uses them too.
This tweeter says that not only vaccines can be used to mitigate the pandemic. They say that mask mandates should also be in effect.
This anti-vaxxer posted quite a few tweets within this thread. He is clearly anti-vaxx, and posts various scientific and confusing terms yet he doesn't appear to be a medical professional.
In response to a deleted tweet, this post asks whether federal vaccine mandates are now cancelled. The tweeter appears to be against COVID19 vaccine mandates.
This pro-vaccine tweeter is telling someone to not be afraid of vaccines. She also makes a comment on their QAnon beliefs, mentioning that the tweeter shouldn't be afraid of "cabals."

This tweeter says there are "odds" (conflict) over the vaccine. And they ask how many have taken it in secret. They posted a Giff of a woman thinking and showing skepticism. This tweet is in reply to a tweet about republicans hating vaccines.
criticism_other: People who take the vaccine secretly

meaning: This tweeter says they are pro-vaccine but anti-mandate for the COVID-19 vaccine only. The tweeter says they may support mandates in the future for this vaccine, but not now. They used the hashtag #nuance in this tweet.
This tweeter says that natural immunity (NI) is the way out of the pandemic. He claims that people have known this before COVID-19 came about. This is clearly an anti-vaxx post.

This post by CNY Central shares a news article about soap opera star Steve Burton being fired from the show General Hospital because he refused to get vaccinated against COVID19. The article includes a video of Burton explaining that he was denied religious exemption.

This tweeter posted a video of Stanley Plotkin, the inventor of various vaccines. In the video, Plotkin is asked about certain methods of vaccine testing. The video makes vaccine testing appear to be completely unethical. It's not clear if any of this content is fake, yet there was misinformation about Plotkin online in the past, which has been fact checked by various news outlets, regarding the use of fetal cells in vaccines.
criticism_other: Ethics behind vaccine production, Stanley Plotkin

meaning: This pro-vaccine tweeter says she's happy she got vaccinated with Pfizer's vaccine. She asks why anti-vaxxers care so much about the rest of the population being vaccinated.

This post argues that part of the reason hospitals are overwhelmed during the COVID19 pandemic is because competent staff are being fired over their refusal to get vaccinated. The post also calls the COVID19 vaccine a failure.
This post writes that the risk of getting myocarditis from the COVID19 vaccine outweighs the risk of getting myocarditis from COVID19. It questions why people still do not know this.

This tweeter is against the vaccination of children. They refer to Dr. Byram Bridle, who has been in the news for making unsupported claims that the vaccine is dangerous by way of a news link. One news outlet reported that "there is no evidence to back [Bridle's] claim that what is known as the vaccines’ spike protein produces a toxin that could cause heart problems and neurological damage."

In response to a tweet that says the COVID19 vaccine works, this post questions what is works for. It argues that it does not stop transmission, that people have to take too many doses, and that we should have the freedom to choose.

This post argues that because cases in Australia went from nearly zero to sixty thousand per day, despite the fact that Australia is among the most vaccinated countries in the world, it proves that vaccines do not work like the were intended and that health measures need to be loosened.
